en: Teachings on the ceremony of taking [the vows of the bodhisattva discipline]

comment_en: Kashmir

term: ཀ་ ཏ་ མོ་ར་ ཀ་ ཏི་ ཤ
comment_en: One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.

One of the great śrāvakas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī, probably the same one that is listed among the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Son of She Who Gathers and grandson of Padmagarbha, he was a highly realized monk of Buddha Śākyamuni’s order. Also rendered here as “Kātyāyanaputra.”
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of an elder and senior disciple of Buddha Śākyamuni.
See “Kātyāyana.”
(also Kātyāyana). Disciple of the Buddha noted for his skill in analysis of the Buddha’s discourses and, traditionally, the founder of the Abhidharma.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
One of the ten principal pupils of the Buddha. He was renowned for his ability to understand the Buddha’s teachings. Also rendered as “Kātyāyana.”
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni. Also rendered here as “Kakuda, a descendant of Kātyāyana.”
One of the six outsider teachers.

(also Mahākātyāyana). Disciple of the Buddha noted for his skill in analysis of the Buddha’s discourses and, traditionally, the founder of the Abhidharma. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-936.
One of the ten principal pupils of the Buddha. He was foremost in explaining the Dharma.
See “Mahākātyāyana.”
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
This seems to be the ancient name of Arakan, or what is now the Rakhine State in Myanmar.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A pond on Equal Peaks.

comment_en: A lake on Equal Peaks.
A king of the Kushan empire in the second century ce.

A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.

A principal teacher of the monastic saṅgha during the Buddha’s lifetime. Described as pale skinned and with a prominent nose.

A river in the south of Jambudvīpa.
A river in Jambudvīpa.
One of the two kṣetras.

An Indian scholar who was involved in a number of translations during the eleventh century in Tibet.

Indian Buddhist master (713–763) who came to Tibet in the late 8th century. Said to have been assassinated after a debate with the representatives of Chinese Buddhism. A later legend has him return to India and come back in another body in the eleventh century as the master Padampa Sangye.

A woman who, because she had previously been the Buddha’s mother for five hundred lifetimes, saw him as her son and ran to embrace him. Then, hearing the Dharma from him, she became ordained and manifested arhatship, and the Buddha declared her foremost among nuns who interpret the sūtras.
A woman who was the Buddha’s mother in a former life.
A member of the Śākya clan.

en: Situated by the End of Karaṇa
comment_en: An area in Kuru.
Nerium indicum.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
Kārttikeya (alt. Skanda) is the son of Śiva and Pārvatī. Like Gaṇapati, Kārttikeya is said to lead the gaṇas in battle against demonic beings and is considered a god of war.
A deadly poison that originated when the gods and asuras churned the oceans to create the nectar of immortality.
An island in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
“Black Form.” This seems to be an epithet of Mūrdhaṭaka, one of the wrathful emanations of Mañjuśrī.
Name of a country; inhabitant of this country.

A grove or forest within the Veṇuvana near Rājagṛha, where Buddha Śākyamuni spent several monsoon retreats and delivered many Great Vehicle teachings. In other texts it is known as the Kalandakanivāsa or °nivāpa, the dwelling place or feeding ground of kalandaka—crows or other birds according to Tibetan renderings, but some Sanskrit and Pali sources suggest flying squirrels.

A place where the Buddha often resided, within the Bamboo Park (Veṇuvana) outside Rajagṛha that had been donated to him. The name is said to have arisen when, one day, King Bimbisāra fell asleep after a romantic liaison in the Bamboo Park. While the king rested, his consort wandered off. A snake (the reincarnation of the park’s previous owner, who still resented the king’s acquisition of the park) approached with malign intentions. Through the king’s tremendous merit, a gathering of kalandaka—crows or other birds according to Tibetan renderings, but some Sanskrit and Pali sources suggest flying squirrels—miraculously appeared and began squawking. Their clamor alerted the king’s consort to the danger, who rushed back and hacked the snake to pieces, thereby saving the king’s life. King Bimbisāra then named the spot Kalandakanivāpa (“Kalandakas’ Feeding Ground”), sometimes (though not in the Vinayavastu) given as Kalandakanivāpa (“Kalandakas’ Abode”) in their honor. The story is told in the Saṅghabhedavastu (Toh 1, ch.17, Degé Kangyur vol.4, folio 77.b et seq.).
A place where the Buddha often resided, within the Bamboo Grove (Veṇuvana) outside Rājagṛha that had been donated to him by King Bimbisāra of Magadha.
Convolvulus repens, Ipomoea aquatica.
A country.
One of the two chandohas.
An ancient country on the Coromandel Coast.
A town in South India.
A buddha.

term: ཀ་ ཤི་ ཀ་ ནས་ བྱུང་བ་ -འི་ གོས
comment_en: Cotton from Vārāṇasī, the capital of the ancient kingdom of Kashi, renowned as the best.

“Beauty of Kāśi.” Princess of Vārāṇasī, child of Brahmadatta (present), who was extraordinarily beautiful and desired by six royal suitors. When her father announced she would choose her own spouse, she “chose” the Buddha, went forth, and manifested arhatship.
Ancient name for Vārāṇasī, the holy city on the banks of the Ganges in modern day Uttar Pradesh, India.
A country or a city named the same.
Another name for Vārāṇasī.
Country whose capital was Vārāṇasī, in the Buddha’s time it had been absorbed into Kośala. Its monarch was Brahmadatta (past).
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the two auxiliary chandohas.
The name of an important ancient Indian city identified as modern Kannauj in Uttar Pradesh, India.
A barbaric people in Jambudvīpa.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa, corresponding to the northern Afghanistan
A nāga king.
A class of malevolent spirits.
A country corresponding to modern Karnataka State in India.
“One with the Face of Karkoṭa.” One of the eight nāga queens.

Successive incarnations as the heads of the Karma Kagyu tradition, beginning with Dusum Khyenpa (dus gsum mkhyen pa, 1110–1193).
Lit. “weighing a karṣa,” a coin or weight of different values (Monier-Williams 276.3); a type of ancient Indian currency.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A disciple of the Buddha.
An image of the Buddha.

Counted among the most famous of the Indian Buddhist Mahāsiddhas and renowned for his association with packs of dogs (kukkura), he is a central figure in a number of tantric lineages, specifically of the Guhya­samāja Tantra and Mahā­māyā Tantra. He was active sometime between the 8th and 10th centuries.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A grove in Promotion
The son of Vaiśravaṇa (one of the four great kings).
Also known as Vaiśravaṇa. One among the Four Great Kings, guardian of the north.
A Hindu god of wealth, appearing in the Buddhist pantheon as Vaiśravaṇa.
An alternate name for the yakṣa Jambhala.

en: Forest of the Assembly of Kubera
comment_en: A forest in Supreme Strength.

term: ཀུ་ མ་ དཱའི་ དུས་སྟོན་ སྣ་ཚོགས་ ཅན
comment_en: A certain bird that lived on Gandhamādana Mountain, who died with thoughts of joy toward the Buddha and therefore took rebirth as a god.
The name of an Indian preceptor and teacher who lived during the early Sarma (gsar ma) period (c. 11th century) and worked on the Tibetan translation of the Mañjuśrīmūlatantra.
Named as one of the editor-translators of this sūtra.

Nymphaea pubescens. This night-blossoming water lily, which can be red, pink, or white, is not actually a lotus. It does not have the lotus’s distinctive pericarp. Nevertheless, it is commonly called the “night lotus.” It is also known as “hairy water lily,” because of the hairs on the stem and the underside of the leaves.

Nymphaea pubescens. This night-blossoming water lily, which can be red, pink, or white, is not actually a lotus. It does not have the lotus’s distinctive pericarp. Nevertheless, it is commonly called the “night lotus.” It is also known as “hairy water lily,” because of the hairs on the stem and the underside of the leaves.

The water plant Nymphae esculenta.
This water lily, Nymphaea pubescens, can be pink or white and is sometimes incorrectly called a lotus. It flowers at night, and therefore is also called “night lotus.”

Nymphaea pubescens. This night-blossoming water lily, which can be red, pink, or white, is not actually a lotus, since it does not have the lotus’s distinctive pericarp. One of the eight principal bodhisattvas, he figures strongly in the Gaṇḍavyūha (the final chapter of the Avataṃsaka­sūtra) and in the Lotus Sūtra. His prominence in these sūtras is the reason why emphasis is placed on Avalokiteśvara’s superiority over him. (Not to be confused with the buddha in the Nyingma tradition.)

The Samanta­bhadra­caryā­praṇidhāna appears in the final part of the Gaṇḍa­vyūha­sūtra, which itself forms part of the Buddhāvataṃsaka­sūtra. It is well-known in Tibet, where it has been the subject of numerous commentaries. It continues to be recited daily in some monastic traditions in Tibet and China. The work also goes under the Sanskrit titles Bhadracari(-ī), and Bhadra­caryā­praṇidhāna. See Skilling and Saerji 2013, 198 n. 30.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.

An umbrella term for the class of wandering religious ascetics of diverse religious persuasions that were common at the time of the Buddha.
A general term for homeless religious mendicants who, literally, “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term refers to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics including Jains and others.
Evidently a general term for homeless religious mendicants who, literally, “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term refers to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics including Jains and others.

“Wandering mendicant,” parivrājaka (Sanskrit, wanderer; Pāli, paribbājaka). Refers to a class of Indian religious mendicants holding a variety of beliefs who wandered in India from ancient times, including during the time of the Buddha. These peripatetic ascetics, who included women in their number, engaged with one another in debate on a range of topics. Some of their metaphysical views are presented in the early Buddhist discourses of the Pāli Canon.
A non-Buddhist religious mendicant, lit. who “roams around.”
A non-Buddhist religious practitioner who has no fixed residence.
A lake near Sudharma.

A specific order of mendicants, or a general term for homeless religious mendicants who, literally, “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term can refer to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics including Jains and others.
A general term for homeless religious mendicants who literally “roam around”; in Buddhist usage the term refers to non-Buddhist peripatetic ascetics, including Jains and others.

Trachelospermum jasminoides. It has its name because of its starlike white blossoms. In India it is used in speech as an example of whiteness, i.e., “as white as star jasmine.” Also called downy jasmine, Chinese jasmine, Chinese ivy, and trader’s compass.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.

One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
A great bodhisattva.
Personal attendant and cousin of the Buddha. One of the ten close śrāvaka disciples.
Disciple and attendant of Buddha Śākyamuni.

Buddha Sākyamuni’s cousin, who was his attendant for the last twenty years of his life. He was the subject of criticism and opposition from the monastic community after the Buddha’s passing, but eventually succeeded to the position of the patriarch of Buddhism in India after the passing of the first patriarch, Mahākāśyapa.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
Śrāvaka arhat, the Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant, who is said to have memorized the sūtras.

Buddha Śākyamuni’s cousin, who was his attendant for the last twenty years of his life. He was the subject of criticism and opposition from the monastic community after the Buddha’s passing, but eventually succeeded to the position of the patriarch of Buddhism in India after the passing of the first patriarch, Mahākaśyapa.

(1) A disciple of the Buddha. (2) A disciple of a former Buddha. (3) A disciple of a future Buddha. (4) A king in the past.

A monk of the Buddha’s order, brother of Devadatta, who for twenty-five years served as the Buddha’s personal attendant. Second in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.

A monk of the Buddha’s order, brother of Devadatta, who for twenty-five years served as the Buddha’s personal attendant. Second in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.
The Buddha Śākyamuni’s cousin, who was his attendant for the last twenty years of his life.

The Buddha Śākyamuni's attendant who is celebrated for having recited all the Buddha's teachings by memory at the first council of the Buddhist saṅgha, thus preserving the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.

The Buddha Śākyamuni’s attendant who is celebrated for having recited all the Buddha’s teachings by memory at the first council of the Buddhist saṅgha, thus preserving the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.
The buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight great śrāvakas.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant, who is said to have memorized the sūtras.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
The Buddha's cousin and longtime attendant.
Close disciple and attendant of the Buddha.
The cousin and close attendant monk of the Buddha.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
A mountain in Dwelling on Forest Riverbanks.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
A park in House of Refined Gold.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell. Appears to be identical with Joyless Thought.
A fifteenth century Sakya scholar, nephew of Ngorchen Kunga Zangpo.
A fifteenth century Sakya scholar, nephew of Ngorchen Kunga Zangpo.
The Buddha’s nephew and attendant who recited the Buddha’s sūtra discourses from memory after the Buddha passed.
The Buddha’s cousin and attendant who recited the Buddha’s sūtra discourses from memory after the Buddha passed.
A lotus pool in Lateral.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A forest at Sudharma.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A nāga king.

A great bodhisattva.

comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A king and sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.

term: ཀུན་ དུ་ རྒྱུ་ གནག་ ལྷས་ ཀྱི་ བུ
comment_en: One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.

comment_en: One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. Also rendered here as “Parivrājaka Gośālīputra.”

term: ཀུན་ དུ་ རྒྱུ་ གནག་ ལྷས་ ཀྱི་ བུ
comment_en: See “Maskarin Gośālīputra.”
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A yakṣa king.
A buddha.
A forest in Special Joy.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: ཀུན་ ནས་ ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ དབྱིངས་ ནམ་མཁའ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ ཅོད་པན
en: Crown That Fully Illuminates the Space of the Realm of Phenomena
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
The process of karma and affliction leading to suffering.
A term referring to all the primary and secondary afflictive emotions that completely disturb the mind.
The process of karma, afflictions of the mind, and suffering.
Saṃsāra, in being nothing but afflicted; its opposite is “purification” (vyavadāna).
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The buddhafield of Vimalakīrtirāja.
Name of buddhafield of Buddha King of Many Arrangements.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.
A buddha realm.
A lotus pond in Delighting in Flower Garlands.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Alternative name for Thoroughly Joyous Form.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A buddha realm.
A king.
A bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A grove in Dwelling on Mixed Riverbanks.
An area in Kuru.
Bauhinia variegata, Phaneria variegata. In other sūtras kovidāra is translated as sa brtol.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

term: ཀུན་ ནས་ འོད་ཟེར་ ཡོན་ཏན་ རྟག་ ཏུ་ མང་བ་ བརྒྱ་ མཚོ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
en: Fully Illuminated Oceanic King of Many Hundreds of Virtues
comment_en: A buddha who lives in the east in a buddha realm called Elevated by Abiding in Aspiration.
The twelfth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
The name of a celestial realm.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The buddha realm of the buddha King of Splendor.

term: ཀུན་ ནས་ ཡོངས་སུ་ རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A royal capital in a world in the eastern direction in a past kalpa.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A world realm in the distant past.
The buddha realm in which Prince Ratnākara will attain awakening.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: ཀུན་ ནས་ རྒྱུན་ ཤེས་ ཀྱི་ བུ
comment_en: One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
A park in South India.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

term: ཀུན་ ནས་ རྫིང་ ཀུན་ དུ་ བསྐོར་བ
comment_en: A pool in Shaded by Garlands.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

The third stage in the development and expression of afflictions (Skt. kleśa, Tib. nyon mongs), preceded by “latent tendency” (Skt. anuśaya, Tib. bag la nyal ba) and “belief” (Skt. dṛṣṭi, Tib. lta ba smra ba).
A buddha realm.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A town in the south of India.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
(1) Name of tathāgata in the western buddhafield Illuminated. (2) A bodhisattva in the southeastern buddhafield Sorrowless.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

term: ཀུན་ ནས་ སྣང་ ཞིང་ སྒྲིབ་པ་ མེད་པ་ -ར་ ལྟ་བ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
The bodhisattva Supreme Scent-Perfused Preacher when he becomes a buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the grahas.
An epithet of Viṣṇu. Sometimes also used as an epithet of Brahmā.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Alternative name of the lake Expansive.
A lake in the realm of the asuras.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
A forest in Promotion.
A forest in Distinguished in Many Colorful Ways.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A righteous nāga king.
A class of asuras that live on the third level, Excellent Abode.
A sage.

en: Noble truth of the origin of suffering
comment_en: Second of the four noble truths.

en: Knowledge of the origin of suffering
comment_en: Sixth of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
A buddha realm.
A sage, former incarnation of the Buddha Dīpaṃkara.

term: ཀུན་ རྒྱལ་ འབེའི་ ར་ ཏིའི་ བུ
comment_en: A proponent of the doctrine of scepticism (vikṣepavāda).

This denotes the empirical aspect of reality as conventionally experienced through our perceptions, which, in contrast to ultimate reality or emptiness, is considered true only within the relative framework of our own experiences.

Another name for Kauṇḍinya. One of the five monks present for the first teaching of the four noble truths; on account of his realization he became known as Venerable “All-Knowing Kauṇḍinya” or “Kauṇḍinya who understood” ( Ājñāta­kauṇḍinya ).
See “Kauṇḍinya.”
“Kauṇḍinya Who Understood.” Name of the first monk that Śākyamuni Buddha recognized as having understood his teachings.
A pleasure grove in Shaded by Garlands.

The highest of the three paradises that correspond to the second dhyāna in the form realm. In other contexts, the Tibetan ’od gsal ba usually refers to Ābhāsvara, and the Tibetan gya nom snang ba would refer to Sudṛśa.

A great fourteenth century Jonangpa scholar, practitioner, and translator (1283–1363), who had earlier studied at Sakya, with Butön at Zhalu, and with Tharpa Lotsāwa at Sangphu, before becoming the first major disciple of Dolpopa.
A forest in Dwelling in Forests.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
A mountain range surrounding the hell of Embers Within.
Inhalation (one of the four stages during a single breath).
Name of a yakṣa.
A sea monster; a crocodile of the Ganges (Monier-Williams).
A yakṣa king.
A land to the west of Jambudvīpa.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Pandanus odoratissimus.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A class of vidyādharas.
A land in the south of Jambudvīpa.
A ṛṣi.
A clairvoyant sage who lived with five hundred devotees in the forests of the Adumā region and spent time on the banks of Lake Mandākinī. His nephew was the sage Śaila.
A bodhisattva of the past.
A monk who joined Devadatta’s plot against the Buddha.
A Buddhist monk who sided with Devadatta and defended him when the latter’s schemes to usurp the Buddha were exposed.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.
Devadatta’s companion.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
An asura in one of the variants of the maṇḍala of Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa.
A lake on Equal Peaks.

The court priest in the Buddha’s father’s kingdom, who predicted the Buddha’s awakening. He became one of the Buddha’s five companions in asceticism. They renounced him when he abandoned asceticism but after his awakening they became his pupils. Kauṇḍinya was the first to convert to being his pupil and was the first of his pupils to become an arhat. Also called “Kauṇḍinyagotra” and “Ājñāta­kauṇḍinya.”
See also Ajñātakauṇḍinya.
A country corresponding to modern Gujarat.
A land in Godānīya.
(1) The king of the country of Kuru. (2) A king in the past.
One of the four pīṭhas.
One of the two auxiliary kṣetras.
Home to a group of troublesome monks who quarreled with monks from Vaiśālī.
An ancient city, capital of Vatsa, located down the Ganges River from Rājagṛha.
An epithet of Indra.
Epithet of Śakra.
A rishi, usually said to be identical with Viśvamati, but his son and descendants also carried this name.
An epiphet of the god Śakra.
An epithet of Śakra.
Alternative name of Śakra, lord of the gods.
An epithet of Śakra.
Another name of Śakra.
An epithet of Indra/Śakra.
Another name for Indra. Kauśika, Śakra, and Indra all refer to the same god, centrally prominent in the Vedas, who in Buddhist cosmogony is regarded as the king of gods in the realm of desire.
An epithet of Śakra.
(1) A river in the east of Jambudvīpa. (2) A river in the ephemeral hell known as Red.
An epithet of Śakra.
An epithet of Śakra.
Another name of Śakra; see definition for “Śakra.”
Epithet of Indra.
A river on Excellence of Exquisite Intelligence.
An ancient Indian kingdom located somewhere in present day Uttar Pradesh.
An ancient Indian kingdom, in present day Uttar Pradesh. Śrāvastī was its capital.
An ancient kingdom, northwest of Magadha, abutting Kāśi, whose capital was Śrāvastī. During the Buddha’s time it was ruled by Prasenajit.
A country in ancient India.
An ancient kingdom, northwest of Magadha, abutting Kāśi, whose capital was Śrāvastī. During the Buddha’s time it was ruled by Prasenajit. It presently corresponds to an area within Uttar Pradesh.
An ancient Indian kingdom located in present day Uttar Pradesh.
One of the power places.
A famous Tibetan scholar practitioner of the nineteenth century.
The court priest in the Buddha’s father’s kingdom, he predicted the Buddha’s enlightenment, and was the first of the Buddha’s pupils to become an arhat.
One of the five former spiritual friends with whom Gautama had practiced meditation before his awakening.

Appears to mean “a person from Kañci.” Unidentified. Possibly a description of Pūrna, who is next in the list of the Buddha’s disciples. Alternatively this may be Kaccāna, also known as Kaccāyana, but principally as Katyayāna, one of the Buddha’s ten principal pupils.
Alternate name for “Kauṇḍinya.” Literally “of the Kauṇḍinya family.”

The court priest in the Buddha’s father’s kingdom, who predicted the Buddha’s enlightenment. He became one of the Buddha’s five companions in asceticism. They renounced him when he abandoned asceticism but after his enlightenment they became his pupils. Kauṇḍinya was the first to convert to being his pupil and was the first of his pupils to become an arhat. Also called “Kauṇḍinyagotra” and “Ājñāta­kauṇḍinya.”
One of the tathāgatas.

One of the five excellent companions, with whom Siddhārtha Gautama practiced asceticism near the Nairañjanā River and who later heard the Buddha first teach the Four Noble Truths at the Deer Park in Sarnath. Kauṇḍinya immediately realized its import and entered the stream, shortly thereafter becoming an arhat.
The father of Maudgalyāyana.

An arhat and disciple the Buddha Śākyamuni. He is counted among the five wandering mendicants (parivrājaka) who initially ridiculed the Buddha’s austerities but later, after the Buddha’s awakening, became one of his first disciples and received his first discourse at Deer Park.
(1) A buddha in the past. (2) A disciple of the Buddha. (3) The name of a brahmin family.
See “Ājñāta­kauṇḍinya.”
Close disciple of the Buddha.
One of the first five disciples of the Buddha.

The hundred sons of King Dhṛtarāśtra, who were the enemies of their cousins, the Pāṇḍava brothers. Their family name means they are the descendants of the ancient King Kur (as were the Pāṇḍava brothers). Their battle is the central theme of the Mahābhārata, India’s greatest epic.
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.
One of the hells.
One of the eight cold hells.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell. Literally, “Cries of Woe” or “Lamenting.”
Fourth of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
One of the eight cold hells. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
One of the cold hells
One of the kings of Nepal, possibly Vṛṣadeva of the seventh century.
A wrathful deity of the heruka type.
A king who is the father of the Buddha in a former life.
Monarch who covered Buddha Kāśyapa’s reliquary stūpa and the surrounding area with four kinds of jewels to the distance of one mile.
A village or town. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-3125.
Indian commentator (fl. second century).
This term, meaning “elephant” in this context‌, is a metaphor, suggesting that those present in the assembly were leaders of considerable stature rather than followers.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Melody of Lions.
A class of celestial beings.
A buddha in a southeastern realm.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.

The Sanskrit term suparṇī in nāga­suparṇī­graha, translated by the Tibetan term ’dab bzang, literally means “fine-winged” or “beautiful-leaved.” While this can be an epithet for the mythical garuḍa bird, here it seems to simply describe a general characteristic of the nāga.
One of the ancient dynasties in Madhyadeśa.
One of the garuḍa kings.
The name of a king who reigned over the peaceful, flourishing city Ayodhyā before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A species of euphorbia used in burnt offerings to get rid of nāga influences.

Second- or third-century Indian master whose writings formed the basis for the Madhyamaka tradition. In following centuries there were other masters and authors of the same name, and in Tibet all their works became attributed to one person.
Second- or third-century Indian master whose writings formed the basis for the Madhyamaka tradition.
Saint, scholar, and mystic of Buddhist India from about four hundred years after the Buddha; discoverer of the Mahāyāna sūtras and author of the fundamental Madhyamaka treatise.
A Indian author who presumably lived in the ninth century or later. He composed two practices of Tārā preserved in the Degé Tengyur.
The second- or third-century master whose teaching forms the basis of the Madhyamaka tradition.
A semi-divine being similar to a large snake.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of semidivine beings that inhabit bodies of water and act as guardians of treasure.
Type of being in Buddhist cosmogony.
A class of serpentine water spirits and repositors of subaquatic and subterranean treasure.
In India, this was the cobra deity, which in Tibet was equated with water spirits and in China with dragons, neither country having cobras.
Semi-divine aquatic beings, often appearing in half-serpent, half-human form.
In India, this was the cobra deity, which in Tibet was equated with water spirits and in China with dragons, neither country having cobras.
A class of nonhuman beings who live in aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
In India, this was the cobra deity, which in Tibet was equated with water spirits and in China with dragons, neither country having cobras.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of nonhuman beings with bodies that are half snake and half human.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.

A class of nonhuman beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. Nāgas are associated with snakes and serpents, and often assume a snakelike appearance.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.

A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments where they are known to guard wealth and esoteric teachings. Nāgas are associated with serpents and often assume a snakelike appearance. In Buddhist art and in written accounts, nāgas are regularly portrayed as being half human and half snake, and, as mentioned in this sūtra, said to have the ability to change into human form. Some nāgas are Dharma protectors, but they can also bring retribution if they are disturbed. Nāgas likewise fight one another, wage war, and destroy the lands of others by causing lighting, hail, and flooding.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.

A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and are said to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents, and are subordinate to Virūpākṣa, the Great King of the West.
A semidivine class of beings who live in aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings that live in subterranean aquatic environments and that are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
Nāgas are associated with springs, streams, rivers, and water in general, and among their many magical powers are the ability to produce rain.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean acquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
One of the lords of the ocean, appearing as a great, many headed, sea dragon.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
Nāgas are serpent-like animals who live (invisibly) in the human realm and have an ambivalent status, on occasion positive but also frequently harmful.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are said to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of nonhuman beings who live in subterranean acquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of semidivine beings who live in aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings that live in subterranean aquatic environments and that are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
Class of beings believed to have a snake body. There are both powerful and powerless types of nāgas.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
Snake-like mystical creature with supernatural powers belonging to the animal realm.
A serpentine class of beings associated with intelligence and wealth.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean and aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.

A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments where they are known to guard wealth and esoteric teachings. Nāgas are associated with serpents and often assume a snakelike appearance. In Buddhist art and in written accounts, nāgas are regularly portrayed as being half human and half snake, and, as mentioned in this sūtra, said to have the ability to change into human form. Some nāgas are Dharma protectors, but they can also bring retribution if they are disturbed. Nāgas likewise fight one another, wage war, and destroy the lands of others by causing lighting, hail, and flooding.

Nāgas belong half to the animal realm and half to the god realm (Rangjung Yeshe Dictionary). They are believed to abide in subterranean realms, having control over rain, ponds, rivers, and soil productivity. Some are Dharma protectors, but they can bring retribution if they are disturbed. Often in Buddhist arts and in written accounts, they are portrayed as being half human and half snake (Rigzin 9).

A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments where they are known to guard wealth and esoteric teachings. Nāgas are associated with serpents and often assume a snakelike appearance. In Buddhist art and in written accounts, nāgas are regularly portrayed as being half human and half snake, and are said to have the ability to change into human form. Some nāgas are Dharma protectors, but they can also bring retribution if they are disturbed.
A nonhuman class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of semi-divine beings with bodies that are half human, half snake.
A class of nonhuman beings, half-human and half-snake.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
Serpentine beings typically associated with waterways, springs, and the rains.
A class of terrestrial beings.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of semidivine beings that are half serpent, half human.
The name of the Bengali dynasty that ruled from the second to the early fourth centuries ce.
Class of semi-divine serpent-like beings.
A nonhuman class of beings who live in subterranean and/or aquatic environments and are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of nonhuman beings who live in aquatic environments and who are said to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class of nonhuman beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A class on nonhuman beings, half-snake and half-human.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A semidivine class of beings who live in subterranean aquatic environments and who are known to hoard wealth and esoteric teachings. They are associated with snakes and serpents.
A mountain in Living on the Peak.
A river on Great Slope.

en: Crown Ornament of the Nāga Lord
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Honey.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A son of King Sarvārthasiddha.

Among the many magical powers of the nāgas are the ability to produce rain. Presumably this ability is what is meant here by “nāga-power,” although this appears to be the only mention of the term in the Kangyur in connection with clouds and rain.
Name of a king of a race of supernatural serpents who protect the doctrine.
One of the seven golden mountains that surround Mount Sumeru.
An ascetic statesman.
A virtuous nāga king.
Place in northwestern India.
A country.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva who seeks a prophecy from Śākyamuni.
The name of a māra in another world in the distant past.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

term: ཁ་ན་མ་ཐོ་བ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ གནས་ ན་ འདུག་ མ

comment_en: Synonymous with Himavat. This “mountain” is actually the entire Himalayan range.
The Himalayan mountain range
An alternative name for the Himalayas.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
One of the two auxiliary chandohas.

The sūtra contains the only known reference to a nāga king and kinnara king who both have this name in Sanskrit. The nāga’s name was translated into Tibetan as “hundred mouths” (kha brgya pa), and the kinnara as “hundred faces” (bzhin brgya pa). Other deities with the name Śatamukha appear in Indian literature.
One of the rāśis.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
Name of a mountain in present day Bihar, possibly at Barabar. The mention of it in this sūtra, as its setting, is the only mention at all in the Kangyur.
A buddha in the realm of Enduring.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.

A tribe of people from the northwest of India and central Asia who were significant in ancient India and are described in the Mahābhārata as having taken part in the Kurukṣetra war on the side of the Kurus against the Paṇḍavas. The Purāṇic literature generally describes them in a negative light, as barbarians. They are often mentioned in Buddhist literature and presently maintain Khasa culture in Himachal Pradesh.
A country north of India.
The hamlet from which Maitreya comes.

Distinctive Indian assembly hall or temple with one ground-floor room and a high ornamental roof, sometimes a barrel shape with apses but more usually a tapering roof, tower, or spire, containing at least one additional upper room within the structure. Kūṭāgāra literally means “upper chamber” and is short for kūṭāgāraśala, “hall with an upper chamber or chambers.” The Mahābodhi temple in Bodhgaya is an example of a kūṭāgāra.

An important early monastery outside of Vaiśālī. The name Kūṭāgāraśālā means “hall with an upper chamber.” It refers to a temple with one ground-floor room and at least one additional upper room within the structure.

Distinctive Indian assembly hall or temple with one ground-floor room and a high ornamental roof, either a barrel shape with apses or, more usually, a tapering roof as a tower dome or spire, containing at least one additional upper room within the structure. Kūṭāgāra literally means “upper chamber” and is short for kūṭāgāraśala (“hall with an upper chamber or chambers”). The Mahābodhi Temple in Bodhgaya is an example of a kūṭāgāra.
A seaside town in South India.
A hall near Vaiśālī where the Buddha frequently stayed.
A park in Tamer of Madness.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
A realm in which Musulundha resides.
A pleasure grove in Shaded by Garlands.
A mansion in Sudharma.
The palace or meeting-hall of the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. Also estate.
Refers to Encircled by a Thousand Houses in Ornament of the Mind.
The modern-day Rāptīnadī. L. Chandra gives Ajiravatī for the Tib. khyams ldan.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.
A forest that is burned to the ground by Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna in the conclusion to the first book (ādiparvan) of the Mahā­bhārata.
A mountain off Videha.
A yakṣa usually paired with Kharakarṇa.
A bodhisattva.
A region in South India.
An island beyond Videha.

term: ཁམས་པ་ ལོ་ ཙཱ་ ཝ་བ་ རི་ ཆོས་གྲགས
comment_en: Ca. eleventh century; a Tibetan translator who translated ninety-three sādhanas that are grouped together under his name in the Tibetan canon.
A bodhisattva.

Eighteen collections of similar dharmas, under which all compounded and uncompounded dharmas may be included: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind, plus their objects: visible forms, sounds, smells, flavors, touchables, and dharmas, plus the consciousnesses corresponding to each of the first six.

The eighteen constituents are: eye, visual object, visual consciousness; ear, sound, auditive consciousness; nose, smell, olfactory consciousness; tongue, taste, gustative consciousness; body, touch, tactile consciousness; mind, mental objects, mental consciousness. When it refers to six elements, they are: earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.
See “eighteen sensory elements.”
The six sensory objects, six sensory faculties, and six consciousnesses.

Often translated “element,” commonly in the context of the eighteen elements of sensory experience (the six sense faculties, their six respective objects, and the six sensory consciousnesses), although the term has a wide range of other meanings. Along with skandha and āyatana, one of the three major categories in the taxonomy of phenomena in the sūtra literature.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness). It can also refer to the six elements of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness. Out of these six, the first four elements are also called “great elements.”
Sphere; primary element (such as earth, water, etc.; see “six elements”); sensory “elements” that comprise six types of sense objects, six types of sense faculties, and six sense consciousnesses.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and tactile sensation, mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added). Also refers to the “four elements.”

In the context of epistemology, it is one way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental phenomena, and mind consciousness). These also refer to the elements of the physical world, which cab enumerated as four, five, or six elements may be enumerated. The four elements are earth, water, fire, and air. A fifth, space, is often added. The six elements are earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added).

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and smell, tongue and taste, body and physical objects, and mind and mental phenomena, to which the six consciousnesses are added). Also refers here to the four elements of earth, water, fire, and wind.
See “eighteen elements.”

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and smell, tongue and taste, body and physical objects, and mind and mental phenomena, to which the six consciousnesses are added). Also refers here to the four elements of earth, water, fire, and wind.

Depending on the context, may translate either: (a) Skt. mahābhūta, Tib. ’byung ba chen po, the four “main” or “great” outer elements of earth, water, fire, air, and (when there is a fifth) space; or: (b) Skt. dhātu, Tib. khams, the “eighteen elements” introduce, in the context of the aggregates, elements, and sense-media, the same six pairs as the twelve sense-media, as elements of experience, adding a third member to each set: the element of consciousness (vijñāna), or sense. Hence the first pair gives the triad eye-element (caksur­dhātu), form-element (rūpadhātu), and eye-consciousness-element, or eye-sense-element (caksur­vijñāna­dhātu)—and so on with the other five, noting the last, mind-element (manodhātu), phenomena-element (dharma­dhātu), and mental-sense-element (mano­vijñāna­dhātu).

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness).

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness).

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness). It can also refer to the six elements of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements: eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added).

In the context of Buddhist philosophy, one way to describe experience and the world is in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, smell, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental phenomena, and mind consciousness).

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, odor, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness).

In different contexts four, five, or six elements may be enumerated. The four elements are earth, water, fire, and air. A fifth, space, is often added. The six elements are earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness. According to traditional Indian medicine, many diseases arise when the elements of the body become unbalanced.

A word that can refer, in different formulations, to the fundamental constituents of material and/or mental phenomena, or to the realms of existence, it also has the general meaning of the nature of something.

In the context of Buddhist philosophy, one way to describe experience and the world is in terms of eighteen elements (eye, form, and eye consciousness; ear, sound, and ear consciousness; nose, smell, and nose consciousness; tongue, taste, and tongue consciousness; body, touch, and body consciousness; mind, mental phenomena, and mind consciousness). The elements also refer to the elements of the physical world, which are the four main elements: earth, water, fire, and wind. Sometimes two extra elements are added to this list: space and consciousness.

The list of dhātus in the sense of “elements” comprises the four great elements (see “great elements”) of earth, water, heat, and wind, plus space and consciousness, and is a list specifically designed to describe the assemblage of conditions that makes it possible for a new moment of consciousness to arise after the last moment of consciousness at death, i.e., it is meant to explain the process of rebirth.
The three realms are the desire realm (kāmadhātu; ’dod khams), form realm (rūpadhātu; gzugs khams), and formless realm (ārūpyadhātu; gzugs med khams).
Also rendered here as “element” and “constituent element.”
Also rendered here as “temperament” and “constituent element.”
Also rendered here as “temperament” and “element.”

Often translated “element,” commonly in the context of the eighteen elements of sensory experience (the six sense faculties, their six respective objects, and the six sensory consciousnesses), although the term has a wide range of other meanings. Along with the aggregates (Skt. skandha) and the sense bases (Skt. āyatana), one of the three major categories in the taxonomy of phenomena in the sūtra literature.
The six sensory objects, six sensory faculties, and six consciousnesses.
The six sensory objects, six sensory faculties, and six consciousnesses.
There are eighteen such psycho-physical elements—the twelve sense fields plus the six types of sensory perception.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and physical objects, and mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added). It can also refer to the four elements of earth, water, fire, and wind, or the six elements when space and consciousness are included with those four.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added).

Commonly designates the eighteen elements of sensory experience (the six sense faculties, their six respective objects, and the six sensory consciousnesses), although the term has a wide range of other meanings. Along with skandha and āyatana, it is one of the three major categories in the taxonomy of phenomena in the sūtra literature.

In different contexts four, five, or six elements may be enumerated. The four elements are earth, water, fire, and air. A fifth, space, is often added. The six elements are: earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

One way of describing experience and the world in terms of eighteen elements (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, and mind and mental objects, to which the six consciousnesses are added).
Phoenix sylvestre Roxb.
One of four parks that surround the city of Radiant.

term: ཁུ་བྱུག་ གིས་ གང་བ་ -འི་ སྒྲ་དབྱངས་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
en: Endowed with the Songs of Cuckoo Birds
comment_en: A mountain to the north of Jambudvīpa.

term: ཁུ་བྱུག་ དང་ ནེ་ཙོ་ དང་ རི་སྐེགས་ དང་ ཀུ་ ན་ ལ་ དང་ ཀ་ལ་པིང་ཀ་ སྐད་ འབྱིན་པ་ ལྟ་བུ་ -ར་ ཡིད་ དུ་ འོང་བ་ -འི་ ང་རོ་ -འི་ གདངས་ ངེས་པར་ སྒྲོགས་པ
en: Voice as Delightful as the Songs of Cuckoos, Parrots, Grouse, Pheasants, and Kalaviṅka Birds
comment_en: One of the bodhisattva great beings.

The first buddha of our eon; the fifth buddha of the “seven generations of buddhas” (sangs rgyas rab bdun); there are variants of the Sanskrit (Kakutsunda, Kukucchanda) and the Tibetan log pa da sel seems to refer to the same buddha.

Also known as Benares, the oldest city of northeast India in the Gangetic plain. It was once the capital of its own small kingdom and was known by various names. It was an important religious center, as well as a major city in India, even during the time of the Buddha. The name may derive from being where the Varuna and Assi rivers flow into the Ganges.

In Buddhist cosmology this mountain range forms an outer ring at the edge of the flat disk that is the world. These mountains prevent the ocean from overflowing. In other contexts this name can refer to the entire disk of the world, the paradises above it, or, as in the Kṣiti­garbha Sūtra, to a mountain that contains the hells, also known as the Vaḍaba submarine mountain of fire.
Means “Periphery.” Name of mountain range that surrounds the world according to Buddhist cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, this is commonly described as the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk that is the world, with Mount Sumeru in the center.
Name of a mountain range in Buddhist cosmology.
A mountain in this sūtra and many others; but, in systematized Buddhist cosmology, the name of the ring of mountains that surrounds the world.
God personifying the ring of mountains surrounding the ocean that encompasses the four continents; the horizontal edge of the world in traditional Buddhist cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, a ring of iron mountains said to exist at the periphery of a world system.

“Circular mass.” In this sūtra it is the name of the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk that is the world, with Sumeru in the center. However, it is also used to mean the entire disk and the paradises above it. There is also a system where it is the eighth mountain range encircling Sumeru within the ocean.

“Circular Mass.” There are at least four interpretations of what this name refers to. In the Kṣiti­garbha Sūtra it is a mountain that contains the hells. It is also equivalent to the Vaḍaba submarine mountain of fire, which is also said to be the entrance to the hells. The term cakravāla is also used to mean “the entire disk of a world,” including Meru and the paradises above it. More commonly, as in this sūtra, it is the name of the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk of a world, with Sumeru in the center. Yet it is has the nature of heat, like the Mountain Vaḍaba, in that the heat of the ring of mountains evaporates the ocean so that it does not overflow. Also called Cakravāḍa.
Means “Periphery.” Name of mountain range that surrounds the world according to Buddhist cosmology.
An ocean beyond Videha.
This appears to refer to the great circles of mountains that enclose a thousand worlds, each with its own Cakravāla.
Means “Great Periphery.” Name of mountain range that surrounds the world according to Buddhist cosmology.
Name of a mountain range in Buddhist cosmology.
A mountain, or sometimes a range of mountains.
Name of a god who personifies a mountain of this name. See Cakravāḍa.
“Great Cakravāla,” an epithet for the ring of mountains forming the periphery of a world system in Buddhist cosmology.
A mountain in the hell called Wailer.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The third of the four types of joy.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A king in the distant past.
One of the kinnara kings.

One of the central gods in the Hindu pantheon today. He had not yet risen to an important status during the Buddha’s lifetime and only developed his own significant following in the early years of the common era. Vaishnavism developed the theory of ten emanations, or avatars, the ninth being the Buddha. His emanation as a dwarf plays an important role in this sūtra. The Sanskrit etymology of the name is uncertain, but it was already in use in the Vedas, where he is a minor deity, and has been glossed as “one who enters (everywhere).”
A god.
The preserver of the universe. He is part of the Hindu triad of gods, with Brahmā the creator and Śiva the destroyer.
One of the eight great gods in the Indian pantheon.
One of the principal deities in the Hindu pantheon.
A householder and magistrate of King Diśāṃpati of Pāṁśula. Father of Guardian of the Flame Govinda.
Short form of “Guardian of the Flame Govinda.” Not to be confused with his father the householder Govinda.
One of the primary gods of Hinduism, associated with the preservation and continuance of the universe, held by many as a supreme being.
One of the principal three Hindu gods.
A brahmin statesman.
Belonging or relating to the god Viṣṇu; a devotee or follower of Viṣṇu; see “Viṣṇu.”
The god Viṣṇu; also the names of various kings.
One of the Hindu gods.
In the schema of the eight guardians of the directions, Viṣṇu guards the nadir.
A brahmin.
See “Guardian of the Flame Govinda.”
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK; a king identified as the Vākāṭaka emperor Pravarasena Viṣṇuvṛddha.
A king.
One of the great mātṛs.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
An outcaste tribe.
One of the two melāpakas.
A garden frequented by Devadatta and his followers.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A nāga king.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha King of Splendor with Many Glorious Appearances resides.
This possibly is another name of Govinda (according to Jayaswal 1934, p. 30), of Maṅgala.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha.
One of the kings of Nepal.
A buddha.

term: ཁྱུ་མཆོག་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ མེ་ཏོག་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ སྟོན་པ་ -འི་ གོ་ཆ
en: Infinite Leader with the Armor of Revealing the Flower of Buddhahood
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.

A mythical bird normally depicted with a sharp, owl-like beak, often holding a snake, and with large and powerful wings. In Buddhism, the symbolism of the garuḍa is generally‌ associated with pristine cognition (it is said that the garuḍa can fly as soon as it is hatched) and with the consuming of afflicted mental states (the holding of a snake in its beak).
One of the races of supernatural beings said to come to listen to the Buddha’s teachings; it is a bird with humanoid features, gigantic in size.
A supernatural being that is a gigantic bird with humanoid features.

A mythical bird normally depicted with a sharp, owl-like beak, often holding a snake, and with large and powerful wings. In Buddhism, the symbolism of the garuḍa is generally‌ associated with pristine cognition (it is said that the garuḍa can fly as soon as it is hatched) and with the consuming of afflicted mental states (the holding of a snake in its beak).

Lower class of divine beings described as eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A class of semi-divine bird-like beings.
A park in Moving in the Stream.
Refers to Spacious Palanquin Houses.
A village.
Alternative name for Consuming Blood and Marrow, which is one of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.

Considered to be the third great Dharma king of Tibet, he was the grandson of Trisong Detsen and reigned from 815 to 838 or 841. His reign saw the expansion of Tibet’s political dominion to its greatest extent, and a significant continuation of the “early period” of imperially sponsored text translation, the end of which is traditionally marked by the end of his reign.

Considered to be the third great Dharma king of Tibet, he was the grandson of Trisong Detsen and reigned from 815 to 838 or 841. His reign saw the expansion of Tibet’s political dominion to its greatest extent, and a significant continuation of the “early period” of imperially sponsored text translation, the end of which is traditionally marked by the end of his reign.
King of Tibet (704–754 ce).
King of Tibet. Reigned circa 742/55–798/804 ce.
King of Tibet (r. 742–98 ce) under whose auspices the first Buddhist monastery was established and a decades-long program of the translation of Buddhist texts commenced.
King of Tibet who reigned circa 742/55–798/804 ce.

Considered to be the second great Dharma king of Tibet, he is thought to have been born in 742, and to have reigned from 754 until his death in 797 or 799. It was during his reign that the “early period” of imperially sponsored text translation gathered momentum, as the Buddhist teachings gained widespread acceptance in Tibet.

Considered to be the second great Dharma king of Tibet, he is thought to have been born in 742, and to have reigned from 754 until his death in 797 or 799. It was during his reign that the “early period” of imperially sponsored text translation gathered momentum, as the Buddhist teachings gained widespread acceptance in Tibet.
This refers to the habit of copulation, called a dharma perhaps as it is a property/feature that belongs to those who copulate, or in the sense of something that is one’s course of behavior.
A mendicant who is converted by the Buddha. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2054.
A measure of length from the elbow to the tip of the middle finger.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Alpha Pegasi in the occidental tradition.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Gamma Pegasi in the occidental tradition.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Unerring Power.”
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A village.
A mahoraga lord.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
Along with Tārā, a female deity visualized in the sādhana of Lavaṇāmbha.
According to Tibetan historical sources, the Nepalese princess who married the Tibetan king Songtsen Gampo. She is believed to have arrived in Tibet in either 632 or 634.
One of the deified female bodhisattvas; one of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A nāga who visits Saṅkāśa Mountain.
“Great wrath.” This seems to be a synonym of vidyārāja.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; an epithet of Yamāntaka; an epithet of Yamāri; the name of a boar-faced emanation of Mañjuśrī.
One of the epithets of Bhūtaḍāmara.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A householder.
An epithet of a wrathful form of Vajrapāṇi.
“Wrath,” an epithet of some wrathful male deities, such as Vajrapāṇi.
A wrathful deity, usually on the sambhogakāya level; appears to be synonymous with krodharāja or mahākrodha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
An epithet of Yamāntaka; also the namesake mantra. The name is also written in this translation as “Lord of Great Wrath.”
See “Great Lord of Wrath.”
Epithet of Yamāntaka; also the namesake mantra.

“Lord of wrath.” In the MMK this term seems to refer in some cases to a whole class of divine beings, which can perhaps be regarded as the wrathful vidyārājas. “Lord of Wrath” elsewhere is an epithet of Yamāntaka.
See “krodharāja.”
A village.
Unidentified.

Site of a stūpa where the Buddha instructed the thousand monks from Uruvilvā by displaying three miracles, thereby freeing them from the wilds of saṃsāra and establishing them in the utterly final state of perfection and the unsurpassably blissful state of nirvāṇa.
A mountain.

A sacred hill immediately to the south of the city of Gayā. Its name means “Gayā head,” and may derive from pre-Buddhist legends of a buried, reclining giant—in one version, a demon king called Gayāsura who was immoblised by Viṣṇu, and in another a saintly prince called Gaya; this hill marks the position of his head, with other features of the landscape in the region associated with other parts of his body.
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.

The brother of Nadīkāśyapa and Uru­vilvā­kāśyapa. A practitioner of fire offering at Uruvilvā (Bodhgaya), he and his two hundred pupils were converted to becoming bhikṣus of the Buddha. He and his brothers and their pupils were the third group to become followers of the Buddha after his enlightenment.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.

A sacred hill immediately to the south of the city of Gayā. Its name means “Gayā Head,” and may derive from pre-Buddhist legends of a buried, reclining giant—in one version, a demon king called Gayāsura who was immobilized by Viṣṇu, and in another a saintly prince called Gaya; this hill marks the position of his head, with other features of the landscape in the region associated with other parts of his body.
A city near Sarnath, where the Buddha gave his first sermon; this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. The name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Kāśī.”
A city in Godānīya.
The sacred river of North India.
The river Ganges.

en: The banks of the Gaggarā lotus pond
comment_en: The Gaggarā lotus pond was excavated by Queen Gaggarā of Campā, the capital of Aṅga, and the groves of flowering trees along its banks became a popular location for wandering teachers and ascetics to take up residence. The Pāli dictionary of proper names notes that the Buddha took up residence on the banks of the Gaggarā pond several times, and a number of discourses in the Pāli nikāya tradition were taught in this location. Pāli: gaggarāpokkharanī; Chinese: 伽伽靈池.
A rich man who was Upālin in a former life.
The sacred river of North India.
The sacred river of North India.
The sacred river of North India.
The sacred river of North India.
The most important holy river in India, more commonly known in English as the Ganges.
The sacred river of North India.
The most important holy river of India.
The sacred river of North India.
The sacred river of North India.
A river in Jambudvīpa.
The sacred river of North India.
The sacred river of North India.
The river Ganges.
The river Ganges
Name of a river.
A river goddess.
The sacred river of North India.
The sacred river of North India.
The major river in North India and, according to Buddhist cosmology, one of the four sacred rivers that flow through the southernmost continent of Jambudvīpa.
The sacred river of North India.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: གང་ གཱའི་ མུ་སྟེགས་ ཀྱི་ སྒོ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ བཀྲ་ བཤིས་ ཀྱི་ དཔལ

comment_en: A forest in Dwelling on Summits.
One of the eight principal nāga kings. More commonly translated in other sūtras as rgya mtsho.
Name of a yakṣa general; brother of Maṇibhadra in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
A buddha in the past.
One of the first to join the Buddha’s renunciate order. He followed his friend Yaśas into the Buddhist order.
A pupil of the Buddha who was preeminent in teaching.
One of the four great hearers.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha from Sūrpāraka (gang po). (2) A disciple of the Buddha from Kuṇḍopadhāna (gang po). (3) A haṃsa (gang ba). (4) A buddha in the past (rdzogs ldan).

Śrāvaka disciple of the Buddha noted for his ability as a preacher of the Hinayāna teaching, especially skillful in the conversion and training of young monks; also known as Pūrṇa­maitrāyaṇī­putra. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-934.
Same as Pūrṇa Maitrāyaṇīputra.

At least five different disciples of the Buddha in the canonical texts have this name, but the Pūrṇa in this text is likely to be the eminent disciple of the Buddha from Kapilavastu, nephew of Ājñātakauṇḍinya who ordained him, and described as the foremost disciple in explaining the doctrine.
A wealthy householder in Rājagṛha whom the Buddha prophesied would become the future Buddha Pūrṇa.
Name of a yakṣa general.
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, famous for his ability to teach.

A monk and disciple of the Buddha. At least six different disciples in the canonical texts have this name (see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-047-001.html#UT22084-047-001-2361), but the Pūrṇa in this text is likely to be the same Pūrṇa as in The Deeds of Pūrṇa (see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-047-001.html#UT22084-047-001-2356).
A brahmin devotee of Buddhism.
God of wealth.
A yakṣa.
Name of a yakṣa general.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the distinguished brahmins of Mathurā.
Synonymous with Himagiri. This “mountain” is actually the entire Himalayan range.
The Himalayan mountain range.
Mountains in the north of Jambudvīpa.
Monarch of the city of Campā before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A mountain.
A mountain.
“Snowy mountain,” the name of a mountain range and the god who personifies it.
Name of a yakṣa general in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
Lit. “impossible to be cut.”
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A buddha realm.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A mountain in Jambudvīpa.
See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1140.
One of the six outsider teachers.
A group of ascetics common in the Buddha’s time, widely believed to refer to the early Jain community.
One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
Also known as the Mahāvīra, the founder of the Jaina sect.
See “Nirgrantha Kinsman of the Kāśyapas.”

The son of a poor brahmin farmer who lived outside of Rājagṛha, he mistook Nirgrantha Jñātiputra for Buddha Śākyamuni and became Nirgrantha Jñātiputra’s student. He then took refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha shortly before his death. Also called “Nirgrantha Kāśyapa,” or simply “Kāśyapa,” his given name.
A type of non-Buddhist religious practitioner.
Another name for the Jain religious tradition.

The Tibetan means “naked one,” and the Sanskrit “without possessions” or “without ties.” In Buddhist usage, a non-Buddhist religious mendicant who eschews clothing and possessions, often referring to Jains.
In Buddhist usage, non-Buddhist religious mendicants, often referring to Jains, who eschew clothing and possessions.
Followers of the Jain religion.

The Sanskrit term means “without possessions” or “without ties” and the Tibetan means “naked one(s).” In Buddhist usage, it refers to non-Buddhist religious mendicants, especially Jains, who eschew clothing and possessions.
A type of non-Buddhist religious mendicant who eschews clothing and possessions. Often considered another name for the early Jain tradition.
In Buddhist usage, a non-Buddhist religious mendicant, usually referring to Jains, who eschews clothing and possessions.
One of the seven sages.
This seems to be the name of an island, but is rather dubious.
A goldsmith, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 49.

The translator of Nyen, Darma Drak. He accompanied Ra Lotsawa (rwa lo tsā ba, 1016–1128?) to India where he stayed twelve years. Darma Drak is credited with translating Prajñākaramati’s commentary on the Bodhicaryāvatāra, as well as texts on Kālacakra and Tārā, and other works.

term: གཉིད་ མཐའ་ -ར་ ཕྱིན་ དང་ འཇིག་རྟེན་ ཐུབ་པ
comment_en: One of the tathāgatas. The Tib. erroneously inserts dang into the translation of this sage’s name.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Finest Gold of Immeasurable Propriety.

en: Possessor of the Free Sphere of Nonduality
comment_en: A buddha.
The third of the four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa. In this age humans are endowed with two quarters, or half of the good qualities that they had during the age of perfection.
The city of the asura king Kaṇṭhamāla.
One of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni. According to some, one and the same with Mahāvira, the last Tīrthaṅkara of the Jains.
See “Jñātiputra, the Nirgrantha.”
Carrying out virtuous actions as an antidote to past negative deeds.
A king during the time of the Tathāgata Vipaśyin.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
(1) A city. (2) A river.

A city of the (past) ninety-first eon and the birthplace of Buddha Vipaśyin. In The Hundred Deeds, two women offered Vipaśyin food there and made prayers, resulting in their rebirths as Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother Mahā­māyā and his aunt Māyā.
Name of a past king, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the twelve branches of Buddhist scriptures.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Region of Joyous Radiance.

en: Glory of the Incense of Non-ignorance
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Ornamented by Pure Conduct.
Consort of White Acala.
A deity personifying the true nature of the faculty of sight.
A mountain range surrounding the hell of Embers Within.
A mountain.
The chief deity of the CMT.
A king based in Ujjain; a contemporary of the Buddha.
King of Ujjayinī, in Śiṃśapā Forest, where Buddha Śākyamuni sometimes dwelt. Also called just “Pradyota.”
A yakṣiṇī. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2556.

comment: person-(not in the Skt. source of the MMK)
comment_en: One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
‟Fierce Kātyāyanī,” one of the eight kātyāyanī spirits.
Another name for the channel carrying semen, used when it carries menstrual blood.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
Another name for Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa’s consort.

en: King of the Well-Settled Treasury of Peace
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Victorious.
A householder in Kauśāmbī who provided a garden for the Buddha and his monks to reside.

A garden in Kauśāmbī that the householder Ghoṣila donated to the Buddhist saṅgha. This Tibetan rendering of Ghoṣilārāma only appears in The Hundred Deeds, and the precise correlation between the Tib. las rig and the standard Sanskrit for this location remains unclear.
A village or town. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2037.
The first wife of a certain householder of great means who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
A buddha realm.
A buddha realm.

term: གདུགས་ ཀྱི་ ཕྲེང་བ་ མེ་ཏོག་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ
comment_en: A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A buddha realm.
A buddha of the northwest.
A buddha.
A mango grove.
One of the kings of the piśācas.
The sixth of the hot hells. In later Tibetan translations it is “hot” (tsha ba).
A river.
One of the great piśācīs.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Highly Renowned.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A leading nāga.
The capital city of one of the subterranean paradises inhabited by nāgas.
‟One with the Terrible Face,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A son of King Sarvārthasiddha.
A thus-gone one of the past.
An evil spirit that causes seizures and insanity.
A type of evil spirit known to exert a harmful influence on the human body and mind. Grahas are closely associated with the planets and other astronomical bodies.

A class of nonhuman beings able to enter and possess the human body; a class of beings, such as Rāhu, that cause solar and lunar eclipses; a planet (this category includes the sun and the moon but excludes the earth); a planet or planetary influence personified.
One of the lower order of spirits with grotesquely misshapen bodies who endlessly suffer from hunger and thirst; also spirits of deceased persons.
The name of a past sage who was one of the Buddha’s previous incarnations.
