One of the lower social classes that are outside, and beneath, the four castes.

An outcaste woman; one of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra; the mystic heat below the navel, personified as a goddess; one of the five ḍākinīs visualized on the prongs of the vajra scepter.
One of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni. Teacher and head of the Ājīvika sect.
A country.
A brahmin.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
Tibetan translator (fl. late eighth–early ninth centuries).
Lightning; also lightning personified.
A form-realm paradise that is never destroyed during the cycles of the destruction and creation of the universe.
The generic name of the five pure realms inhabited by the higher orders of the gods.
The name given to the five highest levels of existence within the form realm.
The name given to the five highest levels of existence within the form realm.
Name for the five highest levels of existence within the form realm.

The five Pure Abodes are the highest heavens of the form realm and result from mastery of the fourth meditative absorption. They comprise the heavens of the Insentient Beings, Unlofty Heaven, Sorrowless Heaven, Heaven of Sublime Vision, Heaven of Great Vision, and Highest Heaven. The Pure Abodes are never destroyed during the cycles of the destruction and creation of the universe. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the fourth meditative absorption.
The name given to the five highest levels of existence within the form realm.
The generic name of the five pure realms inhabited by the higher orders of gods.
The highest division of the realm of form, comprising its five highest heavens; also used as the name of the gods living there. The name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Śuddhāvāsa.”
See “Realm of the Pure Abode.”
The “Pure Abode” heaven; a name for the five highest levels of existence within the form realm.

The gods who live in Śuddhāvāsa heavens, the five “pure abodes” that form the highest realms that constitute the realm of subtle form (rūpadhātu) and which comprise the fourth of the meditative concentrations (dhyāna).
Five realms above the four form realms into which only noble beings are born.

These realms and abodes denote the hierarchy of the gods who, in the manner of human beings and antigods, partake of the higher realms (svarga, mtho ris) of rebirth, but nonetheless remain trapped within cyclic existence. The gods altogether comprise (i) six god realms within the world system of desire, commencing with Catur­mahā­rāja­kāyika and Trayas­triṃśa, and concluding with Yāma, Tuṣita, Nirmāṇa­rata, and Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin; (ii) the twelve Brahmā realms, extending from Brahmakāyika through Brahmapurohita, Mahā­brahmā, Parī­ttābha, A­pramāṇābha, Ābhāsvara, Parītta­śubha, A­pramāṇa­śubha, Śubha­kṛtsna, An­abhraka, and Puṇya­prasava to Bṛhat­phala, which are attained corresponding to lesser, middling, and higher degrees of the four meditative concentrations; and (iii) the five Pure Abodes at the pinnacle of the world system of form, extending from Avṛha, through Atapa, Su­dṛśa, and Sudarśana to Akaniṣṭha. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1427 and note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1582. This hierarchy is conveniently illustrated in the form of a chart. See, for example, Dudjom Rinpoche (1991): 14–15.
The abodes inhabited by anāgāmins (“non-returners”) who are on the path to arhathood.
Realms associated the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.
Pure abode, said of a heaven, or five heavens, in which dwell the gods so called. The pure abodes among the form realms, where only non-returners are reborn.
A goddess.
The hundred-and-ninth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Parārtha­savihāra­śirī.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
An ancient city corresponding to the modern Thaneswar in Haryana, India.
Text by Sahajavajra (Toh 2227).
A country mentioned in the story of the physician Ātreya and the story of King Māndhātṛ.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
In getting ordained, a monk pledges to make do with a restricted set of supports that conduce to the holu life. These fall into four categories: clothing, shelter, food, and medicine.
Third level of the asuras.
One of the eighteen nikāya schools.
A lost verse text possibly included in the Kṣudraka­piṭaka of the Mūla­sarvāstivādins.

A monk who has been ordained for at least ten years yet still cannot recite thePrātimokṣasūtraor its supplements and is thus not entitled to grant entry into the order, grant ordination, accept charge of novices, give refuge, or live independently.
A lost verse text possibly included in the Kṣudraka­piṭaka of the Mūla­sarvāstivādins.
A senior monk.
A monk of seniority within the assembly of the śrāvakas.
A monk who possesses the qualities of stability and skill.

Literally “one who is stable” and is usually translated as “elder”; a senior teacher in the early Buddhist communities. Also became the name of the Buddhist tradition within which the Theravada developed.

The term is used to designate a senior monk. The sixteen great arhats, or sixteen noble elders (āryasthavira), were the successors of the Buddha’s teaching after he passed. They promised to preserve the teaching until the coming of the future Buddha Maitreya. They are on the path of seeing of the arhat path. Each arhat lived in a specific place: (1) Aṅgaja on Mt. Kailash; (2) Ajita in the Crystal Wood of Sages; (3) Vanavāsin on Mt. Saptaparṇa; (4) Mahākālika in Tāmradvīpa; (5) Vajrīputra in Siṃhaladvīpa; (6) Śrībhadra on Yamunādvīpa; (7) Kanakavatsa in Kashmir; (8) Kanakabharadvāja in the Western continent of Godānīya; (9) Bakula in the northern continent of Uttarakuru; (10) Rāhula in Priyaṅgudvīpa; (11) Cūḍapanthaka on Mt. Gṛdhrakūṭa; (12) Piṇḍolabharadvāja in the eastern continent of Pūrvavideha; (13) Mahāpanthaka in Trayatriṃśa; (14) Nāgasena on Mt. Meru; (15) Gopaka on Mt. Bhihula; (16) Abhedya in the Himālayas.

Literally “one who is stable” and usually translated as “elder,” a senior teacher in the early Buddhist communities. Also became the name of the Buddhist tradition within which the Theravada developed.
A disciple of the Buddha.

Literally “one who is stable” and usually translated as “elder,” a senior monastic teacher in the early Buddhist communities. Also became the name of the Buddhist tradition within which the Theravāda developed.
A senior student of the Buddha.
A title used when addressing the most venerable bhikṣus.

Literally “one who is stable” and usually translated as “elder,” a senior teacher in the early Buddhist communities. It also became the name of the Buddhist tradition within which the Theravāda developed.
A title used when addressing the most venerable bhikṣus.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: གནས་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲ་དབྱངས་ ལ་ ལྷག་པར་ མོས་པ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ གནས་པ
en: One Who Dwells in Devotion to the Non-Abiding Melody
comment_en: A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the sixty-seventh meditative stability.
A buddha.
“Unlocated Display.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse Anālayaviyūha.
A forest in Sunrise in Kosala. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1910

en: Expert about Cessation of What is Possible
comment_en: A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the seven great rishis of ancient India, said to have composed part of the Rigveda.
A disciple of the Buddha.
Name of the thirty-second meditative stability.
A learned brahmin and author of “Māṭhara’s Treatise.” He was also the grandfather of Upatiṣya, that is Śāriputra.
A river.

One of the Four Mahārājas, he is the guardian deity for the east and lord of the gandharvas. Also the name of the king of the geese that was a previous life of the Buddha as described in the Jātakas. In other sūtras, more commonly translated as yul ’khor srung.
A type of power place where yogins and yoginīs congregate.
Ca. eleventh century. An early Tibetan master of the Nyingma tradition.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An ocean mentioned here as the source of coconuts.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
A buddha realm.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A town in Videha.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A yakṣa king associated with wealth and often identified with Kubera/Vaiśravaṇa.
Second of the five obscurations. Also translated here as “malice.”
An acid river in the hell Forest of Continuous Flames
A class of beings said to dwell in the north, under the jurisdiction of the great king Vaiśravaṇa.

term: གནོད་སྦྱིན་ གྱི་ སྡེ་དཔོན་ ཆེན་པོ་ བཅུ་གཉིས་ ཀྱིས་ དམ་བཅའ་ -ས་པ
en: The Vows of the Twelve Great Yakṣa Generals
comment_en: An alternate title for The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Seven Thus-Gone Ones

term: གནོད་སྦྱིན་ གྱི་ སྡེ་དཔོན་ ཆེན་པོ་ བཅུ་གཉིས་ ཀྱིས་ དམ་བཅའ་ -ས་པ
en: The Vows of the Twelve Great Yakṣa Generals
comment_en: An alternate title for The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Thus-Gone Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.
A lake in Godānīya.
A lake in Godānīya.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks. (2) A river on Saṅkāśa.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
One of eight children, a daughter, of King Siṃhahanu of Kapilavastu.
These are composed of the five highest paradises in the form realm: Akaniṣṭha, Sudarśana, Sudṛśa, Atapa, and Avṛha.
The five highest of the paradises that constitute the realm of form, which are above the paradises of the realm of desire in which our world is situated. Also translated as gtsang ris.
The five highest of the paradises that consitute the realm of form, which is above the paradises of the realm of desire in which our world is situated.
Traditionally “one who is learned in the Vedas.” The Tibetan means “one who keeps pure and clean.”
The name of the one-syllable mantra of Mañjuśrī—bhrūṁ—and also of the form of Mañjuśrī that it invokes.
One of the six buddhas who preceded Śākyamuni in this Fortunate Eon.
The second of the seven buddhas of the past.
A garuḍa.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.

term: གཙུག་ཏོར་ གྱི་ མཛོད་ ཆོས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ གྱི་ སྤྲིན
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of the goddesses (possibly a male deity) in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-088-038.html#UT22084-088-038-762.
One of the mantra deities.
A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the tathāgatas. The second of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. Identified in other texts as the penultimate buddha to appear in the eon that preceded the present one.
A name common to thirty buddhas in the past. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5316.
The second of the “seven previous buddhas.”
The second of the seven tathāgatas/buddhas. Identified in other texts as the penultimate buddha to appear in the eon that preceded the present one.
A previous buddha.

In early Buddhism the second of seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas—Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhuk—appeared in a kalpa earlier than our Bhadra kalpa, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha. Also translated elsewhere as gtsug ldan; the Mahāvyutpatti also translates as gtsug tor can.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas
Second of the seven buddhas of the past.

In early Buddhism, the second of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas—Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhu—are in an earlier eon than the Bhadraka eon, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha.

In early Buddhism, the second of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas—Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhu—are in an earlier eon than the Bhadraka eon, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
A class of fully awakened nonhuman beings, especially the chief eight among them.

One of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In its simplest form it is a pointed shape to the head (like a turban), or more elaborately a dome-shaped protuberance, or even an invisible protuberance of infinite height.

One of the thirty-two signs of a great being, in its simplest form it is a pointed shape to the head (like a turban), or more elaborately a dome-shaped protuberance, or even an invisible protuberance of infinite height.
One of the physical marks of a buddha that takes the form of the elevated shape of the crown of his head or an extension rising upwards from it.
A protuberance on the top of the Buddha’s head. One of the thirty-two marks of a great person.

One of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In its simplest form it is a pointed shape to the head (like a turban). More elaborately it is a dome-shaped protuberance, or even an invisible protuberance of infinite height.
One of the physical marks of a buddha that takes the form of a protuberance on the crown of his head.
A protuberance on the head of a buddha; this term may also refer to beings who have this protuberance, known as uṣṇiṣa kings or uṣṇīṣa-tathāgatas.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings; another name of Uṣṇīṣarāja.

One of the thirty-two signs of a great being. In its simplest form it is that the head has a heightened or pointed shape (like a turban). More elaborately it refers to a dome-shaped extension of the top of the head, or even to an invisible extension of immense height.

A feature of the head often depicted as a topknot or a protrusion on the crown, sometimes understood as describing the lofty shape of the head; the Sanskrit term signifies that the head is “like a turban.” One of the thirty-two marks of a great being.
A bodhisattva.

A gandharva who was very prominent in early Buddhism and is featured on early stupa reliefs playing a lute and singing. He would come to Buddha Śākyamuni, who was not portrayed as omniscient, to inform him of what was occuring in the paradises. He also accompanies Indra on a visit to the Buddha and plays music to bring the Buddha out of his meditation. He performs the same role in the Mahāyāna sūtra The White Lotus of Compassion. He was portrayed as living on a five-peaked mountain, and appears to be the basis for Mañjuśrī, first known as Mañjughoṣa (Beautiful Voice) with Pañcaśikha still being one of Mañjuśrī’s alternate names. In this sūtra he is clearly distinct from Bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.
A deity in Brahmā’s paradise. Also the name of a past buddha. Also the name of a Mahābrahmā in the upward direction at the time of Buddha Mahābhijñā­jñānābhi­bhū.
“Crown Ornament Holder.”
A buddha.
One of the śakras.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A certain young gandharva allied with the god Śakra.
A gandharva king who is employed by Śakra to serve the Buddha. He is sometimes said to be a form of Mañjuśrī or historically to have been his original identity.
One of the gandharva kings.
A certain young gandharva allied with the god Śakra.
A gandharva who is employed by Śakra to serve the Buddha.
A series of verses that were supposed to prevent dangers.
A temple in Khotan.
A temple in Khotan.
The second of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The Tibetan translation could also be read as “one with a crown protuberance.”
Name of a village chief in a story Buddha tells.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Highest Summit.”
A buddha in the past.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Exceedingly Widely Renowned Glory resides.

term: གཞན་ གྱི་ དབང་ གི་ ངོ་བོ་ ཉིད

comment_en: One of the great mātṛs.
A future buddha.
“Not Able to Be Harmed by Others”; a previous buddha.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
‟Never Conquered by Another,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
One of the mantra deities.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.

term: གཞན་ གྱིས་ མི་ ཐུབ་ རྒྱལ་མཚན་ སྟོབས
comment_en: The ninety-ninth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha in the past.
A bodhisattva and the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 31.
(1) One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell. (2) One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
The principal deity in the paradise of the same name, which is the highest in the desire realm. Also called Vaśavartin.
Gods of the sixth and highest-level god realm within the desire realm.

The deities of this, the sixth level of the gods of the desire-realm, appropriate and enjoy the magical creations of others; hence their name, literally, “who assume control of the emanations of others.” Their abode contains all the wonders created elsewhere and is referred to as a standard of splendor.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The sixth and highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Delighting in Others’ Emanations
comment_en: One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
“Controlling Others’ Emanations,” the sixth heaven of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, highest of the six heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others, then dispose of them themselves.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The highest of the heavens located in the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations

comment_en: A god realm.
Sixth god realm of desire, meaning “mastery over transformations.”
The highest paradise in the desire realm.
The highest of the six levels of gods of the Desire Realm.
One of the gods’ realms.
A class of gods who inhabit the highest of the six heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others, then dispose of them themselves.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The sixth and highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The highest of the six heavens of the desire realm, its inhabitants enjoy objects created by others.

en: Heaven of the Masters of Others’ Creations
comment_en: The sixth and highest of the heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others and dispose of them themselves. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-195.
The highest level of the desire realm.

en: Heaven of the Masters of Others’ Creations
comment_en: One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, highest of the six heavens of the desire realm. The inhabitants enjoy objects created by others, then dispose of them themselves.
The highest paradise in the desire realm, named “power over the emanations of others” because its inhabitants have that power.
“Ruling Others’ Emanations.” The highest paradise in the desire realm, so named because the inhabitants have power over the emanations of others. Also called Vaśavartin.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations
comment_en: The highest heaven in the desire realm.

en: Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations

comment_en: Paranirmitavasavatti, the highest of the group of four heavens immediately above the peak of Mount Meru.
In the context of sentient beings being “immeasurable.” One of the ten topics to be expounded to the bodhisattva who has perfected application.
A river in the northern continent of Kuru.

Vimāna, translated here as “airborne palace,” can mean a divine chariot or palace, or a combination of the two, as in this translation. These flying palaces of the deities are well known in Indian mythology. Burnouf translates as “chariots”; Kern has “aerial cars.”
These palaces served as both vehicles and residences for deities.
A location in Supreme Strength.
A forest in Total Pleasure.

The largest and most detailed of the six extant vinaya recensions. Substantial fragments have survived in Sanskrit, and much of it was translated into Chinese by Yijing in the eighth century, but the Tibetan translation in the Kangyur is the fullest version. It is also the only vinaya corpus to have been translated into Tibetan.
Name of a prince in a story the Buddha tells; a former incarnation of the buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.

term: གཞི་ མེ་ཏོག་ གི་ སྙིང་པོ་ -འི་ རྒྱན་ གྱིས་ བརྒྱན་པ
comment_en: An ocean of universes that includes our Sahā universe of a thousand million worlds and the even greater assembly of universes called Prabhāsa­vairocana. It has elsewhere been interpreted to be an alternative name for the Sahā universe.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
An ancient king, contemporary of the Buddha.
Sagittarius (zodiac sign and constellation); also the name of an ancient king.
See “Dhanus.”
A class of godlings, probabably related to yakṣas.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
One of the great mātṛs.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Another name of Karttikeya, the god of war.
Another name for the god Skandha.
See “kumāra.”

Apart from the usual meaning and usages (such as being a title of Mañjuśrī, etc.), this also seems to be the name of a class of nonhuman beings. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “divine youth.”
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the grahas; the Gupta emperor Kumāragupta II; an ascetic statesman.
Another name for Kārttikeya/Skanda, the son of Śiva.
One of the two auxiliary pīlavas.

en: Vowed to ascetic discipline from youth
comment_en: May also refer to practitioners who deliberately act like children; see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-004.html#UT22084-057-004-1317.
One of the previous incarnations of Māra.
A great bodhisattva.

comment_en: One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
The planet Mercury; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha; a south Indian king, the son of Śaṅkara.
See “Budha.”
A demon that causes an eclipse; a spirit that causes possession; a planet.
Eclipse; a class of spirits causing possession.
Deities associated with the planets.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A nāga king.
One of the eight great nāga kings.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A king of the nāgas.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
Name of a nāga king.
A nāga king.
A ruler of the garuḍas.

term: གཟི་བརྗིད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ བཟང་པོ་ -ས་ དགའ་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ
comment_en: The forest goddess of Lumbinī and the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 42.
A prince in another world in the distant past.
A forest in Supreme Strength.

en: King of Splendor with Many Glorious Appearances
comment_en: The name of a buddha in the northwestern direction.
One of the mantra deities.
A world system.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ mother.
Name of a buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the rāśis.
One of the four garuḍa kings, present at the teaching of the sūtra.
One of the kinnara kings; one of the rāśis.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the kinnara kings.
A cakravartin king in the distant past.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A buddha.
A buddha.

Name of a sage in a story the Buddha tells.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

comment: person-(not in the Skt. source of the MMK)
comment_en: One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK. This name, which occurs only in the Tibetan translation of the MMK, may represent a case of scribal dyslexia in which the last two syllables of the extant Skt. name Sujeta have been reversed.
A buddha.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past.

comment_en: A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A buddha.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva.
Name of the forty-second meditative stability.
A world realm in the distant past.
The ninety-fifth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Tejavati.

term: གཟི་བརྗིད་ སྟུག་ ཅིང་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་ ལ་ ཉི་ཟླ་ ཟིལ་ གྱིས་ གནོན་པ
en: Fine and Stainless Splendor That Outshines the Sun and the Moon
comment_en: A buddha of the present, formerly the bodhisattva Joyful King.
May, or may not, correspond to the Giñjakāvasatha of other texts. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-012.html#UT22084-072-012-52.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
First of the five psycho-physical aggregates.

According to the Lesser Vehicle, the buddha body of form refers to the thousand buddhas of the Auspicious Eon, including Śākyamuni. In the Great Vehicle, however, the term includes both the buddha body of perfect resource which appears in a pure light form to tenth level bodhisattvas and the buddha body of emanation which manifests physically for the sake of all beings.

term: གཟུགས་ ཀྱིས་ འཚོ་བ་ སྐྱེ་བོ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀཡ་ ངོ་བོ་ -འི་ རྗེས་སུ་ འཇུག་པ
en: Sustaining through Form and Adhering to the Nature of All People
comment_en: A former life of the Buddha, who was a very good-looking person.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Manifest Mount Sumeru.
One of the grahas; also the name of a mahāsiddha.
Listed here as the aggregates of feeling, notion, assembled factors, and consciousness.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the great yakṣiṇīs.
“Beautiful one,” a class of female spirits.

The king of Magadha and a great patron of Śākyamūni Buddha. His birth coincided with the Buddha’s. His father, mistakenly attributing the brilliant light that marked the Buddha’s birth to the birth of his son by Queen Bimbī (Goldie), named him ‘Essence of Gold.’
A king of Magadha at the time of the Buddha, the father of Ajātaśatru.
The king of the country of Magadha.
The king of Magadha.
The king of Magadha.
A king of Magadha at the time of the Buddha, the father of Ajātaśatru.
A king of Magadha at the time of the Buddha, the father of Ajātaśatru.
King of Magadha who lived at the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
The queen, wife of King Mahāpadma and mother of Bimbisāra.
“Great Form.” The name of a past eon.
This bodhisattva asks Vimalakīrti the whereabouts of his family, etc., thus prompting the latter’s extraordinary verses on the family and accoutrements of all bodhisattvas (Chap. 8).
Wife of the householder Vijayarakṣa.
A yakṣa lord.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: གཟུགས་ མ་ མཆིས་པ་ -འི་ སྙོམས་པར་ འཇུག་པ་ བཞི
comment_en: These are typically listed as follows: (1) the equipoise of the sense field of infinite space, (2) the equipoise of the sense field of infinite consciousness, (3) the equipoise of the sense field of nothing at all, and (4) the equipoise of neither perception nor nonperception.

term: གཟུགས་ མངོན་པར་ འདུ་ བགྱིད་པ་ ལ་ སྤྱོད
en: Engage in the conditioning of physical forms

comment_en: “Beautiful Array.” One of the bodhisattvas in the entourage of the Buddha Śākyamuni when he taught the girl Vimalaśraddhā.
A deva or god in the formless realm.

Term for a deva belonging to the realm of form, which is the second of the three realms of existence according to Buddhist cosmology, rebirth in which is achieved through mastering meditative techniques known as the four dhyānas or meditative absorptions; this realm has seventeen subdivisions. The beings reborn here possess ethereal physical bodies and experience only three senses: sight, hearing, and touch. Attachment to material objects is in general less than in the desire realm (Skt. kāmadhātu).
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
“Power of Beauty,” the good looking one; Prince Puṇyabala’s oldest brother, who exemplifies beauty.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Victorious Melody.
See “matter.”

The first of the five aggregates, defined in Abhidharma literature as anything comprised of the four major elements (earth, air, fire, and water), either alone or in combination. Also rendered here as “material form.”
See “aggregate.”
One of the five aggregates, that which gives rise to physical qualities.
This term can also mean “comprehensible speech,” in contrast to gzung ba med pa’i tshig (agrahaṇapada) or “incomprehensible speech.” See Negi (1993-2005): 5505.
Name of a nāga king.
Name of the nineteenth meditative stability.
Name of the ninety-fifth meditative stability.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
Lit. “Intelligence of Dhāraṇī.”
A buddha in the distant past.

term: གཟུངས་ ཀྱི་ སྙིང་པོ་ ཡོན་ཏན་ གྱི་ འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ སྨོན་ལམ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ འཛིན་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
The term used to describe both the scriptures and the deities of the “five protectress goddesses” popular in the Mahāyāna-Vajrayāna tradition.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.

An exceptional power of mental retention. According to context, this term can also designate sentences or phrases for recitation that are said to hold the essence of a teaching or meaning (rendered here as dhāraṇī), and are therefore said to hold the power to bring about a range of pragmatic and spiritual effects when uttered, written, or worn.

According to context this term can also mean sentences or phrases for recitation that are said to hold the essence of a teaching or meaning. This term is also rendered in this translation as “dhāraṇī.”
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the grahas.
One of the grahas.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.

en: Primordially in the state of peace

comment_en: An iconographic aspect of Śiva who is facing south.
An ancient Indian symbol of auspiciousness and eternity.
In this text, it is a description of the ultimate and quasi-synonymous with nirvāṇa.

term: གཡུང་དྲུང་ གི་ མཐར་ཐུག་པ་ གྲུབ་པ་ དང་ བདེ་བ
comment_en: In this text, being “established . . . in the unsurpassed, supreme welfare of nirvāṇa” appears as a synonym for the attainment of arhatship.
Name of a yakṣa.
Name of women’s avadhūtī referring to menstruation.
One of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Guru of Many.

en: Skill of the Completely Victorious in Battle
comment_en: A buddha who resides in the eastern buddha realm called Entering from All Doors.
A “ruler of the world” who belongs to the class of the māras.
Forest on the third asura level, Excellent Abode.

term: གཡོ་བ་ མེད་ ཅིང་ གནས་པ་ མེད་ ལ་ དགའ་བ
en: Engaging Without Wavering and Without Settled Focus
comment_en: Name of the 107th meditative stability.
Name of the seventieth meditative stability.
Also translated here as “motionless.”
Also translated as “unwavering.”
Also translated as “immovable.”
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
The king identified with Kharagraha of the Maitraka dynasty.
Name of a yakṣa.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering; one of the four guardian goddesses who can be indicated to a fellow practitioner by her pledge sign.
The Tibetan and Sanskrit terms both carry a dual sense of “servant” or “retinue.”
Also translated here as “assembly.”
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A ṛṣi in the past.
A ṛṣi in the past.
An area in Kuru.
An alternate spelling of Bharga, a country during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni that had its capital at Mount Śiśumāri.
A famous Puranic rishi of India, who features particularly in the Vaishnavite literature.
‟Lord of Dance,” most often the dancing form of Avalokiteśvara; in the Bhūta­ḍāmara Tantra, he is a dancing form of Śiva.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element of wind.
A yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
One of the eight great bhūtinīs; also one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the grahas.
A monastery in Mathurā predicted by the Buddha to be built a hundred years after his nirvāṇa.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the two brothers in Mathurā who were predicted by the Buddha to build a monastery in the future.
A certain nāga king and the hermitage that bears his name.
The buddhafield of the Thus-Gone One Supari­kīrtita­nāma­dheyaśrī­rāja.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
The lord of death, who judges the dead and rules over the hells.
The lord of death in Indian mythology, who judges the dead and rules over the hells and the realm of the hungry ghosts.
Lord of Death.
From Vedic times, the Lord of Death is the one who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth.
Usually the Lord of Death who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth, but here refers to the Lord of the hungry ghost realm.
Ruler of the hell realms.
The ruler of the lower realms.
God of the lower realms.
The god of death and the overlord of the hell realms.
From Vedic times, the deity who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth.
Ruler of the hells.
The lord of death, who judges the dead and rules over the hells.
The lord of death who judges the dead and rules over the hells.
From Vedic times, the Lord of Death who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth.
From Vedic times, the Lord of Death who directs the departed into the next realm of rebirth.

en: Borderlands of the Lord of Death
comment_en: One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.

en: World of the Lord of Death
comment_en: This is a reference to the world of the pretas.

en: Realm of the Lord of Death
comment_en: The realm of the Lord of Deth is another name for the realm of hungry ghosts or pretas. This term is also the name of the Vedic afterlife inhabited by the ancestors (pitṛ).

en: World of the Lord of Death
comment_en: The world of Yama, the Lord of Death.

en: Realm of the Lord of Death
comment_en: In this text, another name for the hungry ghost realm; Yama is also sometimes said to preside over the hell realms.

en: Realm of the Lord of the Dead
comment_en: The preta realm, or the realm of ghosts, where Yama, the Lord of Death, is the ruler and judges the dead. Yama is also said to rule over the hells. This term is also the name of the Vedic afterlife inhabited by the ancestors (pitṛ).

en: Realm of the Lord of the Dead
comment_en: The preta realm, or the realm of ghosts, where Yama, the Lord of Death, is the ruler and judges the dead. Yama is also said to rule over the hells. This term is also the name of the Vedic afterlife inhabited by the ancestors (pitṛ).

en: World of the Lord of Death
comment_en: Epithet for the preta (hungry ghost) realm.

en: Domain of the Lord of Death
comment_en: See “world of the Lord of Death.”
A great bodhisattva.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Name of a class of gods, as well as one of the ranges of mountains around Sumeru.
One of the seven golden mountains.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Name of a yakṣa.
Attendants of Kubera, the god of wealth, and the guardians of his treasures. They live in the Himalayas at the source of the Ganges on the mountain that has been identified with Kailash.
A class of devas that, like the yakṣas, are ruled over by Kubera, but are also said to be his most trusted helpers. It is said that they protect his hidden treasures and live in mountain caves.
A class of celestial beings.
A subclass of yakṣas.
A type of semi-divine being frequently found in the entourage of Kubera, the lord of wealth.
A subclass of yakṣas, but much of the time used as an alternative name for yakṣas.
Name of a yakṣa.
A type of nonhuman being frequently found in the entourage of Vaiśravaṇa (Kubera), the lord of wealth.
Epithet of Vaiśravaṇa.
A class of devas that, like the yakṣas, are ruled over by Kubera, but are also said to be his most trusted helpers.
Another term for the yakṣa subjects of Kubera.
Semidivine beings closely related to or identical with yakṣas, who, like them, live in the realm of Kubera.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A city where the Buddha descended from the heaven of the Thirty-Three gods.
A forest in Moving Mind.
A lake on Utterly Delightful to Behold.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The king of Kośala.
Son of King Arāḍa Brahmadatta of Śrāvasti. Later, as king he gave all servants in his lands permission to join the Buddhist order if they wished.
The king of Kosala.
King of the Kośala state during the time of the Buddha.
King of the country of Kośala, he reigned in the city of Śrāvastī. Sometime enemy of King Brahmadatta (present), with whom he eventually reconciled.
A king of Kośala, contemporary of the Buddha.

King of the country of Kośala, he reigned in the city of Śrāvastī. In this sūtra, Surata humbles him and then becomes one of his teachers. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-043-008.html#UT22084-043-008-11.
A king of Kosala.
Modern Vārāṇasi.
“Power of Splendor,” Puṇyabala’s father.
A king based in Ujjain, contemporary of the Buddha.
A village or town.
“Lord of Speech,” epithet of Mañjuśrī.

term: གསུང་ གི་ ཡན་ལག་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ སྒྲ་དབྱངས་ དཔལ
གསུང་ ནི་ འཁོར་ དང་ འཐུན་པ་ -ར་ ཁྱབ་པ་ -ར་ མཛད་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ གྱི་ ཕྱི་རོལ་ དུ་ གསུང་ མི་ འགྲོ
en: Speech is pervasive, in conformity with their assembly, but it does not extend outside their assembly
comment_en: Sixty-eighth of the eighty minor marks.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha.

The “twelve branches of excellent speech” or the “twelve categories of the Buddha’s teachings” are discourses (Tib. mdo’i sde, Skt. sūtra), verse narrations (Tib. dbyangs kyis bsnyad pa’i sde, Skt. geya), prophecies (Tib. lung du bstan pa’i sde, Skt. vyākaraṇa), poetic verses (Tib. tshigs su bcad pa’i sde, Skt. gāthā), aphorisms (Tib. ched du brjod pa’i sde, Skt. udāna), ethical narrations (Tib. gleng gzhi brjod pa’i sde, Skt. nidāna), narrative discourses (Tib. rtogs pa brjod pa’i sde, Skt. avadāna), parables (Tib. de lta bu byung ba’i sde, Skt. itivṛttaka), past-life stories (Tib. skye pa’i rabs kyi sde, Skt. jātaka), extensive sayings (Tib. shin tu rgyas pa’i sde, Skt. vaipulya), marvels (Tib. rmad du byung ba’i chos kyi sde, Skt. abidhutadharma), and resolutions (Tib. gtan la bab par bstan pa’i sde, Skt. upadeśa).
Refers to the discourses of the Buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

term: གསུང་སྙན་ ཅིང་ རྣམ་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡོངས་སུ་ རྫོགས་པ
en: Speech is sweet and fully perfected
comment_en: Forty-sixth of the eighty minor marks.
Name of a class of gods in the desire realm. There is also an associated heavenly realm, the Realm of the Thirty-Three Gods, which is named after these.
A forest in Dwelling in One Direction.

en: Threefold combination [of happiness, suffering, and neutrality]

comment_en: The second of the four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa. In this age humans are endowed with three quarters of the good qualities that they had during the age of perfection.
Foremost among the Buddha’s pupils in analytic reasoning.
An area in Kuru.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
Name of an elder and senior disciple of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Foremost among the Buddha’s pupils in analytic reasoning.
Śrāvaka arhat.
A senior student of Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his analytical knowledge.
One of the disciples of the Buddha.
One of the grahas.
A nāga king.
A world system.
A buddha.
A park in Sustained by Fruition.
A park in Attached to That.
A river on Saṅkāśa.

term: གསེར་ གྱི་ དྲ་བ་ -ས་ ཀུན་ དུ་ ཁེབས་པ
comment_en: A buddha realm.

term: གསེར་ གྱི་ དྲ་བ་ -ས་ སྐུ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ བརྒྱན་པ
comment_en: One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

term: གསེར་ གྱི་ ནོར་བུ་ སྣང་བ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Firelight.
A buddha.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
A god.
A river at Radiant Streams.
A village or town.
(1) A river on Cakravāḍa. (2) A sea between Godānīya and Kuru.
Golden-complexioned nun who achieved arhatship during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni, due to the intercession of a previous incarnation of Venerable Ānanda during the time of Buddha Kāśyapa.
The world of the past buddha Mervabhyudgata­rāja.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Meteor.
A forest of the asuras.
A buddha in the distant past.

term: གསེར་ གྱི་ རྒྱན་ ལྟར་ མཚན་ རབ་ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ ལུས
en: Body That Expands Like a Golden Ornamented Victory Banner
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
King and sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
An island in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.

term: གསེར་ གྱི་ ཤིང་ ཏ་ལ་ རབ་ཏུ་ བརྒྱན་པ
comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Exalted King of Palmyra Trees.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm in the east.

Home of King Suvarṇapati who figures in a prophecy made by Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana’s teacher Sañjayin that convinces them of their teacher’s prescience, which in turn gives them conviction to seek out the Buddha as Sañjayin advised they should.
A region of Southeast Asia visited by Indians.
One of the two auxiliary melāpakas.
A buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Infinite Purity.
One of the six buddhas who preceded Śākyamuni in this Fortunate Eon.
The second buddha of the Fortunate Eon.
Name of a former buddha usually counted as the second of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kāśyapa, and Śākyamuni.
A buddha in the past.
“Golden Sage.”
The fifth of the “seven previous buddhas.”
Fifth of the seven tathāgatas/buddhas. Identified in other texts as the second buddha to appear in the present eon.
The name of a previous buddha.
Name of a buddha who preceded Śākyamuni, usually counted as the second buddha of the current fortunate eon, Śākyamuni being the fourth.
One of the eight tathāgatas.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
See “Kanakamuni.”
Fifth of the seven buddhas of the past, and second in this kalpa. Also rendered “Kanaka.”

The fifth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The second buddha in this Bhadraka eon that we are in. In the White Lotus of Compassion Sūtra, Buddha Ratnagarbha specifically prophesies that the third of Ratnagarbha’s thousand vedapāṭhaka pupils will be this buddha. He also earlier prophesies that his fifteenth brother will be a buddha who has that name.

The fifth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The second buddha in this Bhadraka eon that we are in. In the White Lotus of Compassion Sūtra, Buddha Ratnagarbha specifically prophesies that the third of Ratnagarbha’s thousand vedapāṭhaka pupils will be this buddha. He also earlier prophesies that his fifteenth brother will be a buddha who has that name.
A forest on Tamer of Deer Enemies.
A world system.
A peacock who was the Buddha in a former life.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Forest on the third asura level, Excellent Abode.

A king of Suvarṇadvīpa who figures in a prophecy made by the teacher Sañjayin that convinces Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana of his prescience. This in turn gives them conviction to seek out the Buddha as Sañjayin advised they should.

term: གསེར་ བཟང་ དྲི་མེད་ རིན་ཆེན་ སྣང་ བརྟུལ་ཞུགས་ གྲུབ་པ
comment_en: The thus-gone one residing in the buddhafield Heaped with Jewels and Full of Perfume.

term: གསེར་ བཟང་པོ་ དང་ ནམ་མཁའ་ ངེས་པར་ སྒྲོགས་པ་ བཀོད་པ་ -འི་ འོད
en: Array of Light Constantly Proclaiming Pure Gold and Space
comment_en: The name of a buddha in the above direction.

term: གསེར་ བཟང་པོ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ བསགས་པ་ -འི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ ཀྱི་ འོད་ཟེར
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly. His name means, “Brilliant Light Rays of the Collection of Fine Gold.”

term: གསེར་ བཟང་ ཞིང་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ དབྱིག་ གིས་ སྤྲས་པ་ -འི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ མཛེས་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
Name of a buddha of the past.
A nāga king.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Glorious Golden Light.”
The name of a buddha in the southwestern direction.
One of King Bimbisāra’s daughters.
Name of a king who was the previous incarnation of the bodhisattva Maitreya.

term: གསེར་མདོག་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ དག་པ
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A park in another world in the distant past. The name as given in verse. In prose it is called Suvarṇa­puṣpābha­maṇḍala.
A class of bird deities.
A class of bird deities.
A river in Enjoyment of Scents.
A mountain in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to at the zenith above the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Replete.

en: King of the Golden-Hued Lion’s Play

comment_en: In a story the Buddha tells, this was the name of our continent countless eons ago.
The realm of the Buddha Śantābha.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: གསེར་ རིན་པོ་ཆེ་ -འི་ རི་ སྤོ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྣང་བ
comment_en: A vast array of many masses of world realms in the distant past.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

en: Five Fences of Gold and Other Materials
comment_en: An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.

term: གསེར་ ལྟར་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ རྒྱན
comment_en: A world realm in the eastern direction. Also called Kanaka­vimala­prabhā.
A world realm in the eastern direction. Also called Kanaka­vimala­prabhā­vyūha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Moon.
The name of a river.
Name of a sage, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Guru of the Moon.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK. Possibly also a shortened form of the name of the tathāgata Kanakamuni.
A certain householder who was fourth among those in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.
A king, the father of King Māndhātṛ.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element of water.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell. Also known as No Death.
A buddha.
“Lord of All Animals,” an epithet of the god Śiva.

Child of householders in Śrāvasti, he was born “corpulent, full-fledged in skin, flesh, and blood.” He leapt from a boulder at the sight of the Buddha but was unharmed due to the Buddha’s blessing. Having then heard the Dharma from the Buddha, he went forth and manifested arhatship.

A type of sandalwood that is reddish in color and has medicinal properties. It is said to have the finest fragrance of all sandalwood. In the Mahāvyutpatti it is translated as sa mchog, which means “supreme earth.” Later translations translate gośirṣa literally as “ox-head,” which is said to refer to the shape or name of the mountain where it grows. Appears to be red sandalwood, though that appears separately in the list of incenses.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Where the gods receive their armor before battle.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
A nāga king.
The Buddha Śākyamuni.
The Buddha’s given name, Gautama Siddhartha.

One of the seven great rishis of ancient India. Author of some of the vedas. His Dharmasūtra specified renunciation as yellow robes, shaved head, and being called a bhikṣu. Buddha Śākyamuni was his descendant.
One of the names of the Buddha, especially during his earlier life as an ascetic.
Family name of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
(1) Family name of the Buddha Śākyamuni. (2) A nāga king.
Refers to Siddhārtha Gautama, the name of the historical Buddha.
Appellation for the Buddha, primarily used by non-Buddhists.
The family name of the historical Buddha Śākyamuni.
Siddhārtha Gautama is the most common given name used for Buddha Śākyamuni prior to his enlightnement.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
The clan name (gotra) of the Buddha.
Name of a nāga king.
“Gautama” refers to Siddhārtha Gautama, the name of the historical Buddha. “A child of Gautama” denotes one of his followers.
A nāga king.
One of the four auxiliary pīṭhas.
A river in the south of Jambudvīpa.
One of the mantra deities closely related to the uṣṇīṣa kings, or perhaps one of them.
A part of Bengal bordering Orissa, also the name of the dynasty that ruled there.
A location in Jambudvīpa renowned for soft cotton.
A wife of Śākyamuni and the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 43.
The name of Buddha’s wife as found in some texts, including the Lalitavistara; the name of Buddha’s tantric consort.
A sacred stūpa in Khotan, said to have been blessed by several past buddhas.
A river in Khotan.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A minor mountain on Lofty Peak.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.

en: Conceiving of oneself as being superior to those who are supreme
Conceiving of oneself as being greater than those who are superior

comment_en: A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.

term: གོས་ ཀ་ ཙ་ ལིན་ ད་ལྟར་ རེག་ ན་ འཇམ་པ
comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Astride Mount Sumeru. The Mahāvyutpatti has kācalindikam for kA tsa lin da’i gos, but Edgerton (175) calls this and other forms of this term a corruption of kācilindika, which he rather nebulously defines as “n. of some kind of very soft textile stuff.”
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
A Sino-Tibetan translator during the ninth century; the translator of The Armor Array.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
A great bodhisattva.
(1) A king at the time of the Buddha Ratnaśikhin (gos sbyin). (2) A god (nor lha).
The fifteenth heaven of the form realm.
One of the five pure abodes.
The third of five realms associated with the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.

One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology belonging to the form realm. The fourth-highest heaven of the Pure Abodes. Non-returners and those who have mastered the fourth meditative absorption are reborn there. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-280.
Third of the pure abodes, meaning “attractive.”
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, third of the five so-called pure realms of the form realm.
Another name for Dravya Mallaputra, a disciple of the Buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
A country.
A tribe or clan.
A kingdom of ancient India situated to the North of Magadha.
Name for a country and the people who reside there.
A river in Khotan.
Unidentified.

en: Bearer of the Armor Beyond Change and Free from Weariness
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Unobstructed Glorious King of Medicine resides.
The city of Ujjayinī, located in the province of the same name. The Sanskrit Ujjayinī is commonly translated into Tibetan as ’phags rgyal.
One of the five vital airs, centered in the throat.
Name of a buddha.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A buddha realm.
World of the tathāgata Viśālakīrti.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha Intelligence Arrayed with Immeasurable Eloquence resides.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Impervious.

A mountain in South India, presently known as Potikai, that was of great importance to both Tamil Buddhists and Śaivists (who saw it as the residence of Śiva, known as Lokeśvara). This is the first mention in a sūtra that has identified Avalokiteśvara with this mountain as his residence rather than the pure realm of Sukhāvatī. However, in this sūtra the verse appears to locate it in the ocean, while the prose appears to describe it on land. In Tibet and China, Potalaka was believed to be an island. In Tibet it is usually referred to by the shortened form Potala.

Lacking knowledge of or being ignorant [of the Dharma]. J. S. Negi (Negi 935, s.v. ngan pa) cites a few instances where Tibetan ngan pa represents the Sanskrit semantic field “lack of understanding,” e.g., Bodhi­caryāvatāra (Tib. ngan pa; Skt. ajñaḥ “not knowing,” “devoid of knowledge,” “stupid,” “foolish,” etc.); Jātakamālā (Tib. ngan pa; Skt. jaḍā matiḥ “dull,” “stupid,” “irrational”); Avadāna­kalpalatā (Tib. ngan pa; Skt. mūrkhāḥ “stupid, dull-headed; a fool”). Context suggests that this is one sense of ngan pa in Exposition of Karma when it talks about the Dharma and knowledge thereof. Also translated here as “bad deed.” See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-039.html#UT22084-072-039-88.

This refers to those teachings of the Buddha that are in terms of ultimate reality; it is opposed to those teachings given in terms of relative reality, termed “interpretable meaning,” because they require further interpretation before being relied on to indicate the ultimate. Hence definitive meaning relates to voidness, etc., and no statement concerning the relative world, even by the Buddha, can be taken as definitive. This is especially important in the context of the Mādhyamika doctrine, hence in the context of Vimalakīrti’s teachings, because he is constantly correcting the disciples and bodhisattvas who accept interpretable expressions of the Tathāgata as if they were definitive, thereby attaching themselves to them and adopting a one-sided approach.

This seems to be another name for Jambhala.

A class of asuras.

(1) An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa. (2) A river on Forest Garlands.

A place in the south of India.

A pond on Equal Peaks.
A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.
A lotus lake on Endowed with Lotuses.
A pond at the forest Joyous in Sudharma.
A pool in Special Joy.
One of the eight cold hells.

A word for a high number (ten million). Also translated as “Blistering Hell” when it designates one of the eight cold hells. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-230.

Name of one of the eight cold hells. Its inhabitants are tormented by a cold wind that causes their bodies to be covered in sores. The Skt. arbuda in other contexts may refer to a number; see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-230.
First (and lightest) of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. Its inhabitants are wracked with a cold wind that causes their bodies to be covered in sores.
One of the cold hells.
One of the eight cold hells.
One of the cold hells.

Name of one of the eight cold hells. Its inhabitants are tormented by a cold wind that causes their bodies to be covered in sores that burst open. The Skt. nirarbuda in other contexts may refer to a number; see also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-230.

A word for a high number (one hundred million). A variant of the Skt. nyarbuda. Also translated as “Bursting Blister Hell” when it designates one of the eight cold hells. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-230.
Second of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. Its inhabitants are wracked with a cold wind that causes their bodies to be covered in sores that burst open.
A river.

The river near Kuśinagara on the banks of which the Buddha passed into final nirvāṇa.
The river Gandakī (a tributary of the Gaṅgā).
A river in Dwelling in the Lofty.
A river in Dwelling in the Lofty.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.

A part of the forest known as Incomparable.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.

A river in the Hell of Intense Heat.
A buddha in the past.
The place where the Buddha showed the skeleton of the Buddha Kāśyapa to monks.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
Period of 24 minutes.

In the Vedas, Varuṇa is an important deity and in particular the deity of the sky, but in later Indian tradition only of the water and the underworld. The Tibetan does not attempt to translate his name but instead says “god of water.” The Sanskrit name has ancient pre-Sanskrit origins, and as he was originally the god of the sky is related to the root vṛ, meaning “enveloping” or “covering.” He has the same ancient origins as the ancient Greek sky deity Uranus and the Zoroastrian supreme deity Mazda.
A lotus pond in Pair of Śāla Trees.
An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa.
A future buddha.

en: Place Where the Water is Enjoyed
comment_en: A pond on Equal Peaks.
A land in the south of Jambudvīpa.
One of the great mātṛs.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva. Alternatively, the god of waters, an ancient deity of the Vedic pantheon.
The principal nāga king; also the god of the sea in the Vedas. In this sūtra Sāgara is an alternative name and not another nāga.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A god.
One of the guardian deities.
Vedic deity of the sky, water, and ocean.
The name of one of the oldest of the Vedic gods, associated with the waters.

One of the oldest deities of the Vedic pantheon and one of the first to be considered a supreme deity or “king of the gods.” Varuṇa eventually came to occupy a lesser status in the Vedic pantheon as a god of the waters.
One of the kinnara kings.
The god of waters.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha's retinue.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Varuṇa guards the northeast quarter.
A god.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva.

A forest on Encircled by White Clouds.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Delta Sagittarii in the occidental tradition.
The name of a certain householder.

comment: person-(not in the Skt. source of the MMK)

One of the kings of the nāgas.

comment: person-(not in the Skt. source of the MMK)
comment_en: The name of a nakṣatra. One of the two Āṣāḍhās.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Sometimes has the alternative Sanskrit spelling Śiśumāragiri.
Sometimes has the alternative Sanskrit spelling Śiśumāragiri.

A fabled sea monster, the front part of which is a mammal. It is said to be the largest animal in the world, with the strongest bite. Its head is said to be a combination of the features of an elephant, a crocodile, and a boar. The name is also applied to the dugong, the crocodile (in particular the Mugger crocodile, whose name is even derived from makara ), and the dolphin, particularly the Ganges dolphin, because the Ganges goddess is said to ride on a makara.
An aquatic monster.

A fabled sea monster, the front part of which is a mammal. It is said to be the largest animal in the world, with the strongest bite. Its head is said to be a combination of the features of an elephant, a crocodile, and a boar. The name is also applied to the dugong, the crocodile (in particular the Mugger crocodile, whose name is even derived from makara), and the dolphin, particularly the Ganges dolphin, because the Ganges goddess is said to ride on a makara.
See “Makara.”
Capricorn (zodiac sign and constellation).
A great bodhisattva.
The god of water.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A type of ordeal to test one’s veracity.

en: Appearance of the Sovereign of Water
comment_en: The world realm of the Tathāgata Glory of Precious Blue Lotus.

The name of the deity of water, whose weapon is a noose. In the Vedas, Varuṇa is an important deity and in particular the deity of the sky, but in later Indian tradition he is the deity of the water and the underworld. The Tibetan does not attempt to translate his name but instead has “god of water.” The Sanskrit name has ancient pre-Sanskrit origins, and, as he was originally the god of the sky, is related to the root vṛ, meaning “enveloping” or “covering.” He has the same ancient origins as the ancient Greek sky deity Uranus and the Zoroastrian supreme deity Mazda.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
An ocean between Kuru and Godānīya.
A certain yakṣa, a friend of the Buddha.
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means teachings that were not given in response to a request. See also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”
A verse text possibly included in the lost Kṣudraka­piṭaka of the Mūla­sarvāstivādins.
A formal mode of expression, usually on a religious topic.
The king identified with the Kushana emperor Huvishka, the successor of Kanishka.
One of Upananda’s two novices whose homoerotic play led the Buddha to forbid allowing two novices to live together.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
A river.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.

A bodhisattva.
A world realm in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.

“The sphere of dharmas,” “the base of dharmas,” “the ore of dharmas”—a synonym for the nature of things.

Defined as the ultimate nature of phenomena, and also as the essence of the Dharma. Literally “the element of phenomena, or the Dharma.” This term is also used to mean “the realm of phenomena,” meaning all phenomena.
A synonym for ultimate truth, the nature of phenomena.

Defined in the commentary as the ultimate nature of phenomena, or the supreme among phenomena. Also defined as the essence of the Dharma. Literally “the element of phenomena, or the Dharma.” This term is also used to mean “the realm of phenomena,” meaning all phenomena.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things.

A synonym for emptiness, the ultimate reality, or the ultimate nature of things. This term is interpreted variously due to the many different meanings of dharma as element, phenomena, reality, truth, and/or the teaching.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things.

A synonym for emptiness or the ultimate nature of things. This term is interpreted variously—given the many connotations of dharma/chos—as the sphere, element, or nature of phenomena, reality, or truth.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things.

This term is interpreted variously—given the many connotations of both dharma and dhātu—as the sphere, element, or nature, of phenomena, reality, or truth. In this text it is used with this general, Mahāyāna sense, not to be confused with its rather different meaning in the Abhidharma as one of the twelve sense sources (āyatana) and eighteen elements (dhātu) related to mental perception.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things.
The expanse of phenomena, the sphere of ultimate reality.

In combination with pratītya­samutpāda (in this text rten cing ’brel bar ’byung ba chos kyi dbyings), the term dharmadhātu can refer to a type of Buddhist relic which is said to embody the essence of the Buddhist doctrine.
The field or nature of ultimate reality.
The “sphere of phenomena,” a totality of things as they really are.
See “dharmadhātu.”

Defined in the commentary as the ultimate nature of phenomena, or as the supreme amongst phenomena. Also defined as the essence of the Dharma. Dhātu can be used to mean an essential element or a realm, and so dharmadhātu is also used to mean “the realm of phenomena,” meaning all phenomena. Also translated here as “essence of phenomena.”
See “realm of phenomena.”
Varyingly, “the sphere of phenomena,” “the base of phenomena,” “the ore of phenomena”—a synonym for the nature of things.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of phenomena.

A synonym for emptiness or the ultimate nature of things (see i.4). This term is interpreted variously—given the many connotations of dharma / chos—as the sphere, element, or nature, of phenomena, reality, or truth. In this text it is used with this general, Mahāyāna sense, not to be confused with its rather different meaning in the Abhidharma as one of the twelve sense sources (āyatana) and eighteen elements (dhātu) related to mental perception.
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things. Also translated here as “realm of phenomena.”
The “sphere of dharmas,” a synonym for the nature of things. Also translated here as “realm of Dharma.”
Things as they truly are, with nothing imputed to them through dualistic thinking. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “dharmadhātu.”

A synonym for emptiness or the ultimate nature of reality (dharmatā). This term is interpreted variously—given the many connotations of dharma/chos—as the sphere, element, or nature of phenomena, reality, or truth. In this text it is used with this general, Mahāyāna sense, not to be confused with its rather different meaning in the Abhidharma as one of the twelve sense fields (Skt. āyatana) and eighteen elements (Skt. dhātu), and comprising all objects of mental perception.
The nature of phenomena; the dimension or space (dhātu) in which phenomena (dharma) appear.
The fundamental space that is the characteristic of all phenomena.
Varyingly, “the sphere of dharmas,” “the base of dharmas,” “the realm of dharmas”—a synonym for the nature of phenomena.
The element, or nature, of ultimate reality.
A Buddhist hermitage, or monastery, located in the Magadha kingdom.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ དྲ་བ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སངས་རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ ཟླ་བ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A buddha of the distant past.

comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ ནམ་མཁའ་ སྒྲིབ་པ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ འོད
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

en: Lamp of the Sky of Dharma
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Palmyra Trees Reaching the Sky/Fully-Adorned Sky.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ པད་མོ་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར
comment_en: A body goddess.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ པདྨོ་ རབ་ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ སྤྲིན
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ པདྨོ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྣང་བ་ -ས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སངས་རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
Collections of the Buddha’s teachings.

The four are as follows: All compounded things are impermanent (anityāḥ sarva­saṃskārāḥ). All defiled things are suffering (duḥkhāh sarva­sāsravāḥ). All things are without self (anātmanāḥ sarva­dharmāḥ). Nirvāṇa is peace (śāntaṃ nirvāṇaṃ). Also called “the four insignia of the Dharma.”
A bodhisattva.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ ཕྱོགས་ སུ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ གཞོལ་བ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A kūṭāgāra that miraculously appears in a lotus, within which is the Buddha’s mother.
Ninth-century Indian author.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Dharma.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of the eight sons of Candra­sūrya­pradīpa. Also one of the translators of the Lotus Sūtra into Chinese.

The main topic of this sūtra; known also in Tibetan by the synonym bka’ rtags kyi phyag rgya bzhi (“the four seals of the [Buddha’s] teaching”), in Sanskrit caturmudrā (“the four seals”) or dṛṣṭi­nimitta­mudrā (“the seals that are the marks of the [Buddhist] view”).
“All conditioned things are impermanent; all conditioned things are suffering; all phenomena are selfless; and nirvāṇa is peace.”
Fourth of the five eyes. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1119.

One of the “five eyes,” representing superior insights of the buddhas and bodhisattvas. The five eyes consist of five different faculties of vision: the physical eye (māṃsa­cakṣu), the divine eye (dīvya­cakṣu), the wisdom eye (prajñā­cakṣu), the Dharma-eye (dharma­cakṣu), and the Buddha-eye (buddha­cakṣu).
This term refers to an advanced mode of insight into the nature of reality.
The capacity of awakened beings to comprehend the inherent truth of impermanence.
Literally “Dharma eye,” this term refers to different, advanced modes of insight into the nature of reality.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ མེ་ཏོག་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ རྒྱལ་མཚན་ གྱི་ སྤྲིན
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ ཚུལ་ ཟབ་མོ་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ ཟླ་བ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

The Skt. term, which means “way,” “method,” or “system,” could be interpreted as that which is “conducive” to the Dharma, which “leads” to the Dharma or which “guides” in accordance with the principles of the Dharma. In the Ratnaketudhāraṇī, it variously refers to individual dhāraṇīs, the sections that deal with these dhāraṇīs, or the entire text of the Ratnaketudhāraṇī.
This location couldn’t be identified.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ལོ་ བསྐོར་བ་ -འི་ གོ་ཆ་ བགོས
en: Bearer of the Armor of Turning the Dharma Wheel
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ལོ་ སྤྲུལ་པ་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.
When a buddha gives his first teaching he “sets in motion the Wheel of Dharma;” just like a monarch with exceptional merit sets in motion a magical wheel that easily subdues all his enemies.

The classification of all aspects of Buddha’s teachings into twelve types: sūtra, geya, vyākaraṇa, gāthā, udāna, nidāna, avadāna, itivṛttaka, jātaka, vaipulya, adbhutadharma, and upadeśa (see individual terms). Respectively, the sūtras, literally “threads,” does not mean entire texts as in the general meaning of sūtra but the prose passages within texts; the geyas are the verse versions of preceding prose passages; the vyākaraṇas are prophecies; the gāthās are stand-alone verses; the udānas are teachings not given in response to a request; the nidānas are the introductory sections; the avadānas are accounts of the previous lives of individuals who were alive at the time of the Buddha; the itivṛttakas are biographies of buddhas and bodhisattvas in the past; the jātakas are the Buddha’s accounts of his own previous lifetimes; the vaipulyas are teachings that expand upon a certain subject; the adbhutadharmas are descriptions of miracles; and the upadeśas are explanations of terms and categories.
When a Buddha gives his first teaching he “sets in motion the Wheel of Dharma,” just as a monarch with exceptional merit sets in motion a magical wheel that easily subdues all his enemies.
The name of the energy center (cakra) in the heart.
Deity personifying the Tathāgata’s Dharma wheel.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ལོ་ -འི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.

comment_en: A buddha in a southwestern realm.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ལོ་ -འི་ སྒྲ་ ནམ་མཁའ་ -འི་ སྤྲིན་ གྱི་ སྒྲོན་མ་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past. In verse he is called Saddharma­ghoṣāmbara­dīpa­rāja.
A bhikṣuṇī in another world in the distant past. A previous life of the night goddess Sarva­nagara­rakṣā­saṃbhava­tejaḥ­śrī.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
The universal matrix represented as a triangle or two interlocking triangles; in the tantric viśuddhi (pure correspondences) system, it corresponds to the triangular area between a woman’s legs.
The eighth Tai Situpa in the Karma Kagyü tradition (1700−1777), he oversaw the creation of the Degé Kangyur.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་ཟེར་ རབ་ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ སྐུ
en: Whose Body Is the Widely Spreading Light of the Dharma
comment_en: A buddha.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་འཕྲོ་བ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva in a southeastern realm.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་འཕྲོ་བ་ -འི་ གྲོང་ཁྱེར་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ སྤྲིན
comment_en: A world realm in the distant past. In verse it is called Dharmārci­megha­nagara.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་འཕྲོ་ རི་བོ་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
The seventeenth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Dharmārci­parvata­śirī.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The name of the thirty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.

term: ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ མཐའ་ཡས་པ་ ཆགས་པ་ མེད་ ཅིང་ རྡུལ་ དང་ བྲལ་བ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ -འི་ ཏོག
comment_en: A buddha who gave teachings to the buddha Śakyāmuni in one of his previous lives.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
The deity Aralli when he is associated with the origination of phenomena.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

comment_en: The first of countless buddhas in a past kalpa. The form of his name as given in verse. In prose he is called Sarva­dharma­sāgara­nirghoṣa­prabha­rāja.

comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.

comment_en: A bodhimaṇḍa in another world in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
Name of a tathāgata.

The name of four different buddhas in the distant past. They are mentioned, separately, at note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-3068, note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-3110, note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-3353, and note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-4740.
The buddhafield of the Thus-Gone One Dharmakīrtisāgaraghoṣa.
A bodhisattva.
Someone who follows his or her goal according to the teaching of the sūtras and so forth.
According to the Mahāyāna, one of the seven types of noble beings (āryapudgala), and also one of the twenty types of members of the sangha (viṃśatiprabhedasaṃgha).
A religious discourse.
Also translated here as “scriptural categories.”
This may refer to the entire text of the Ratnaketudhāraṇī or to a section dealing with a particular dhāraṇī.

The word paryāya regularly has the sense of “method,” “procedure,” “approach,” but here it is simply “Dharma teaching,” “Dharma discourse,” or more literally, “approach to the Dharma.” The Chinese fa men (lit. “door to the Dharma”) conveys the sense of “access/approach” and by extension, “teaching.” The Tibetan rnam grangs easily misleads people into thinking that this has something to do with “enumeration.”

The word paryāya regularly has the sense of “method,” “procedure,” “approach,” but here it is simply “Dharma teaching,” “Dharma discourse,” or more literally, “approach to the Dharma.” The Chinese fa men (lit. “door to the Dharma”) conveys the sense of “access/approach” and by extension, “teaching.” The Tibetan rnam grangs easily misleads people into thinking that this has something to do with “enumeration.”
An explication of the Dharma.

The ultimate nature or essence of the fruitional enlightened mind of the buddhas, which is non-arising, free from the limits of conceptual elaboration, empty of inherent existence, naturally radiant, beyond duality, and spacious.
One of three “bodies” manifested by the buddhas.
One of the subdivisions in the collection of dharmas that constitutes a Buddha, variously explained but usually more closely related to the aspect of ultimate truth.
Also translated “ultimate body.”
See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-062-010.html#UT22084-062-010-23.

Distinct from the rūpakāya or “form body” of a buddha. In origin it was a term for the presence of the Dharma, which would continue after the Buddha’s passing. It also came to refer to someone who was an embodiment of the Dharma, and also the eternal, imperceptible realization of a buddha, and therefore became synonymous with the true nature. In the context of the teaching of the three kāyas of a buddha, only the term dharmakāya (chos kyi sku), rather than dharmaśarīra, (chos kyi lus) was used.
A teaching or spiritual method by which the Dharma is understood.
See “Dharma-door.”
Certain teachings are called “Dharma-doors” (or “doors of the Dharma”), as they provide access to the practice of the Dharma.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Dharma­pradīpa­śiri.
A bodhisattva.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A buddha in a world in the eastern direction in a past kalpa.

ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ སྤྲིན་ གྱི་ ཆ་ -ར་ གྱིས་ རྱལ་ སྲིད་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ ཚིམ་པ
en: One Who Satisfies the Kingdom with Rain from Dharma Clouds
comment_en: A buddha.
