One of the three modes of giving recorded in Buddhist literature, this refers to spreading the Dharma through teaching, recitation, copying of texts, and so forth. The other two consist of the gift of material goods (āmiṣadāna) and the gift of fearlessness (abhayadāna).
Name of the fifty-ninth meditative stability.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī. Also the seventy-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.

The bodhimaṇḍa of the Buddha Sūrya­gātra­pravara in another world in the distant past, as given in the prose passages, where it is also called Dharma­meghodgata­prabhā. In verse it is called Sudharma­megha­prabhā.
A synonym for emptiness, and the expanse of reality (dharmadhātu).
These include the outer robe (bla gos), the lower robe (mthang gos), and the monk’s shawl (snam sbyar).
The upper robe of a Buddhist monk.
The thus-gone one residing the buddhafield Victory Banner of the Dharma.
One half of a two-headed bird, the half that was the Buddha in a former life.
One of the four kinnara kings.
A buddha in the distant past.
The 9th century Tibetan translator of this text.
Tibetan translator of this sūtra in the ninth century, also well known for his collaboration in compiling the Mahāvyutpatti (Skt.-Tib. dictionary).

A translator and editor active in the late eighth and early ninth centuries, he translated a dozen important sūtras in the Kangyur including this text and was a contributor to the Drajor Bampo Nyipa, an early ninth century edict and manual defining translation methodology.

en: Victory Banner at the Pinnacle of Dharma
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Family of Jewels. Likely the same as the thus-gone one He Who Possesses a Body Adorned with All Jewels and the thus-gone one He Who Possesses a Body Adorned, Exalted by All Jewels.

The eighty-fifth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. The syllable dpal appears to actually belong to the previous name in the list of buddhas, Smṛti­ketu­rāja­śri.

Name of hall where the gods of the thirty-three assemble to listen to the Dharma.
A Mahābrahmā in the southern direction at the time of Buddha Mahābhijñā­jñānābhi­bhū. Also one of the four kings of the kinnaras, present at the teaching of the sūtra.
The assembly hall of the devas on the summit of Mount Sumeru.

The assembly hall in the center of Sudarśana, the city in the Trāyastriṃśa (“Thirty-three”) paradise, which has a central throne for Indra/Śakra and thirty-two thrones arranged to its right and left for the other thirty-two devas that make up the epnoymous thirty-three devas of Indra’s paradise. Indra’s own palace is to the north of this assembly hall.
Śakra’s assembly hall.
The assembly hall of the devas on the summit of Mount Sumeru.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
The bodhimaṇḍa of the Buddha Sūrya­gātra­pravara in another world in the distant past, as given in verse. In prose it is called Dharma­meghodgata­prabhā.
King Vīradatta’s garden.
A buddha realm.

Daughter of King Prasenajit’s minister Dinna, betrothed to Viśākha. She achieved the state of a non-returner and displayed miracles at her wedding, receiving permission from her betrothed and his family to forgo marriage and go forth. Quite beautiful, as a novice she was threatened by lustful would-be suitors. Her predicament led to the Buddha permitting full ordination of nuns by message.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK. The Tibetan term would translate *Sarvādharmopaccheda.
The Buddha’s teachings regarding subjects such as wisdom, psychology, metaphysics, and cosmology.

Conventionally, the general name for the Buddhist teachings presented in a scientific manner, as a fully elaborated transcendental psychology. As one of the branches of the Canon, it corresponds to the discipline of wisdom (the Sūtras corresponding to meditation, and the Vinaya to morality). Ultimately the Abhidharma is “pure wisdom, with its coordinate mental functions” (Prajñāmalā sānucārā), according to Vasubandhu.
The Buddha’s teachings regarding subjects such as wisdom, psychology, metaphysics, and cosmology.
The Buddha’s teachings regarding subjects such as wisdom, psychology, metaphysics, and cosmology.
An important work written by Vasubandhu, probably in the fourth century, as a critical compendium of the Abhidharmic science.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of Non-conceptuality.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bird who shares one body with another bird, Dharma.
One of the three types of patience, which consists in accepting the teachings on emptiness.

An early term to denote the Buddha’s teaching. “Dharma” refers to the sūtras and “Vinaya” to the rules of discipline.

The name for the canon of monastic discipline recorded in the Tripiṭaka, of the vows and commitments enshrined therein, and of the practice of that discipline. Also rendered here as “monastic discipline.”

comment_en: Literally, “tolerance that understands phenomena.” This denotes receptivity to the non-arising nature of all things, identified with emptiness.

en: Seal of Entry into All Phenomena
comment_en: Name of the eleventh meditative stability.
A minister; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Guru of Dharma.

Second of the four unhindered discernments.

A yakṣa in Retuka.

Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of the Sky.
The last in a series of countless buddhas in a past kalpa. The form of his name in verse. In prose he is called Dharma­dhātu­nagarābha­jñāna­pradīpa­rāja.
The tenth bodhisattva bhūmi.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a bodhisattva great being.
A term for those who teach the Buddhist Dharma.

Among many of its meanings, this term can refer to: the teachings of the Buddha; positive actions that accord with those teachings; or a minimal element of existence, which bears certain features through which it may be cognized.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
King Vīradatta’s palace.

The term dharma (chos) conveys ten different meanings, according to Vasubandhu’s Vyākhyā­yukti. In the context‌ of the present work, it may mean “sacred doctrine” (also rendered “Dharma” in this translation), the “attributes” which buddhas and bodhisattvas acquire, “phenomena” or “things” in general, and, more specifically, “mental phenomena” which are the object of the mental faculty (manas, yid).

A term that predates Buddhism, Dharma/dharmas has a wide range of meanings and usages in Buddhist texts depending on context: As Dharma , it is the teaching of Buddha Śākyamuni and other buddhas, preached by their followers, and transmitted in the form of scripture; or, alternatively, it means ultimate reality itself, the referent of the teaching and what is realized through it. As dharmas , it is variously the different teachings given by Buddha Śākyamuni, other buddhas, and their followers; the trainings enjoined in those teachings; the positive qualities acquired through applying those trainings; mental phenomena in general; or phenomena in general or their characteristics. Often in Buddhist literature there is a play on the multiple interlinked senses of this term.
Name of a tathāgata.
Quality or phenomenon in a general sense; when spelled with a capital letter it refers to the Buddha’s teaching, one of the Three Jewels.

The term “dharma” (chos) conveys ten different meanings, according to Vasubandhu’s Vyākhyā­yukti. It may mean the Buddhist teachings, the awakened qualities which buddhas and bodhisattvas acquire, phenomena or things in general, etc. In the context of this work, it was rendered as “Dharma” when it refers to the teachings, and in other contexts, rendered according to the specific meaning, namely as phenomena and qualities. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-003.html#UT22084-060-003-8.
The second of the Three Jewels, that is, the teaching of the Buddha.

This term has multiple interrelated meanings. In this text, the primary meanings are as follows: (1) the doctrine taught by the Buddha (Dharma); (2) the ultimate reality underlying and expressed through the Buddha’s teaching (Dharma); (3) the trainings that the Buddha’s teaching stipulates (dharmas); (4) the various awakened qualities or attainments acquired through practicing and realizing the Buddha’s teaching (dharmas); (5) qualities or aspects more generally, i.e., phenomena or phenomenal attributes (dharmas); and (6) mental objects (dharmas).

Among its many meanings, this term can refer to the teachings of the Buddha (when capitalized in this translation); positive actions that accord with it; an entity, which has (dhṛ) certain features through which it may be cognized (also the relevant sense in which it is used when dharmas are listed as the objects of thought); and a property or a quality (such as when discussing the Buddhadharmas, i.e., the dharmas of the Buddha, meaning his special qualities or properties).

May refer to the teaching of the buddhas, to religious teachings generally, to phenomena generally, or to the specific characteristics of an object or objects in a generic sense, among other meanings.
A phenomenon; religion; teachings; religious duties; when capitalized (Dharma), it refers to the teachings of the Buddha.
A village in South India.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Teachings of the Buddha.
A senior minister at the court of the Chinese king Cayang.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
Name of Maitreya in a previous lifetime as a bodhisattva.

A great fourteenth century (1299–1354) Jonangpa scholar of Sanskrit and translator, student of Dolpopa, who had earlier studied at Sangphu and Sakya. He is best known for his revised translations, made with Sabzang Mati Paṇchen, of the Kālacakra­tantra and Vimala­prabhā.
The Bengali Buddhist master (980–1054) who came to Tibet, and whose pupils founded the Kadampa tradition.
A class of asuras.

term: ཉ་ གྲོ་ དྷ་ ལྟར་ ཆུ་ཞེང་ གབ་པ
comment_en: Nineteenth of the thirty-two major marks.
A buddha.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A merchant who was Dravya Mallaputra in a former life.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
Pisces (zodiac sign and constellation).
See “Mīna.”
The way or vehicle of the śrāvaka.
The vehicle comprising the teaching of the śrāvakas.
The vehicle comprising the teaching of the śrāvakas.
The way or vehicle of the śrāvaka.
The path of the śrāvakas.
A term denoting the primary disciples of a buddha.

The vehicle comprising the teaching of the śrāvakas, the disciples or "Hearers" who heard the teachings from the Buddha. According to Mahāyāna sources, one of the two constitutents (along with the Pratyekabuddhayāna) of the so-called "Lesser Vehicle" (Hīnayāna).
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Stūpa That Overwhelms with Jewel Light.
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.

Primarily referring to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self liberation. It is usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it heard by others.”
Based on the verb “to hear,” the Sanskrit term śrāvaka is used in reference to followers of the non-Mahāyāna traditions of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas who follow the Mahāyāna path.

The pious attendants heeding the words spoken by Lord Buddha, contrasted in terms of their realization with both pratyekabuddhas and bodhisattvas (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-8).

This term, based on the verb to hear, means “disciple,” and is used in that general way, as well as for those who were followers of the non-Mahāyāna tradition of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas.

Hīnayāna practitioner of the first turning of the wheel of the Dharma on the four noble truths, who realizes the suffering inherent in saṃsāra and focuses on understanding that there is no independent self. By conquering disturbing emotions, he liberates himself, attaining first the stage of stream enterer at the path of seeing, followed by the stage of once-returner who will be reborn only one more time, and then the stage of non-returner who will no longer be reborn into saṃsāra. The final goal is to become an arhat. These four stages are also known as the “four results of spiritual practice.”
A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on the monastic lifestyle.

The word, based on the verb “to hear,” means disciple, and is used in that general way, as well as for those who were followers of the non-Mahāyāna tradition of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas.
Someone who practices according to the vehicle of the hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.
A disciple of the Buddha; in the Mahāyāna sūtras this term refers to the followers of the Hīnayāna, or the Lesser Vehicle.

Those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self-liberation. The term is usually defined as “one who hears the Dharma from the Buddha and makes it heard by others.”
Someone who practices according to the vehicle of the hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.

Derived from the Sanskrit verb “to hear,” the term is used in reference to followers of the non-Great Vehicle traditions of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas who follow the Great Vehicle path.
Early disciple of the Buddha.
A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on the monastic lifestyle.
One who listens to and hears the teachings from a buddha and strives to become a worthy one.

It is usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it heard to others.” Primarily it refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self liberation and nirvāṇa.
Lit. “listener.” Disciple of the Buddha and follower of the Hinayāna teaching.

A follower of those teachings of the Buddha that focus on the monastic lifestyle and liberating oneself from suffering, in contrast to followers of the bodhisattva vehicle who seek buddhahood for the sake of all beings.

A follower of those teachings of the Buddha that focus on the monastic lifestyle and liberating oneself from suffering, in contrast to followers of the Bodhisattva Vehicle who seek buddhahood for the sake of all beings.
A person who practices according to the vehicle of the hearers; the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on the monastic lifestyle and one’s own liberation from cyclic existence.
A term for someone who follows the Vehicle of the Hearers or those who “hear” the teachings from a Buddha.
A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on the monastic lifestyle. Also translated as “listener.”
Hearer.

A follower of those teachings of the Buddha that focus on the monastic lifestyle and liberating oneself from suffering, in contrast to followers of the Bodhisattva Vehicle who seek buddhahood for the sake of all beings.
The disciples of the Buddha who followed the Lesser Vehicle (Hīnayāna). A śrāvaka is explained as someone who hears the teachings and then proclaims them to others.

A follower of those teachings of the Buddha that focus on the monastic lifestyle and liberating oneself from suffering, in contrast to followers of the bodhisattva vehicle who seek buddhahood for the sake of all beings.

The term is most simply interpreted as “those who hear” the Buddha’s teaching, i.e. his disciples, but the additional element that they then “make it heard” to others is often present in canonical glosses. In a Mahāyāna context it refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat, and not to embark on the path of a bodhisattva (with buddhahood as its ultimate goal).

Primarily referring to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of a worthy one by seeking personal liberation. The term is usually defined as a person who hears the teaching from the Buddha and makes it heard to others.
Someone who practices the teachings of the Hearers’ Vehicle to achieve liberation from saṃsāra through direct perception of the absence of a personal self.
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others) or someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others).
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha. See also “Lesser Vehicle.”

It is usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it heard to others.” Primarily it refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self liberation and nirvāṇa.

Primarily referring to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self liberation. It is usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it heard to others.”

A “hearer” or “listener,” someone who first hears the Dharma from another. This refers to the disciples of the Buddha who sought the enlightenment of an arhat, that is, their own liberation from cyclic existence.

The term is most simply interpreted as “those who hear” the Buddha’s teaching, i.e. his disciples, but the additional element that they then “make it heard” to others is often present in canonical glosses. In a Mahāyāna context it refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of a worthy one (arhat), and not to embark on the path of a bodhisattva (with buddhahood as its ultimate goal).
One who listens to the Buddha’s teaching in order to reach liberation.

A “hearer” or “listener,” someone who first hears the Dharma from another. This refers to the disciples of the Buddha who sought the enlightenment of an arhat, that is, their own liberation from cyclic existence.

This term, based on the verb “to hear,” means disciple, and it originally referred to those direct disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni who had actually heard the Buddha’s teachings. It is also used to refer to those who aspired to the state of an arhat, in contrast to the bodhisattvas. More generally, it refers to those who were followers of the non-Mahāyāna traditions of Buddhism.
Someone who practices according to the vehicle of the hearers (those who hear the teachings from others) or someone who has heard the Dharma from the Buddha.

It is usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it heard to others.” Primarily it refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self liberation and nirvāṇa.
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.
Any disciple receiving teachings from the Buddha.
Disciples who heard the Buddha’s doctrine from his own lips; followers of the Hīnayāna school in general.

A follower of those teachings of the Buddha that focus on the monastic lifestyle and liberating oneself from suffering, in contrast to followers of the bodhisattva vehicle who seek buddhahood for the sake of all beings.

The word, based on the verb to hear, means disciple, and is used in that general way as well as for those who were followers of the non-Mahāyāna tradition of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas.

The word, based on the verb “to hear,” means “disciple” in a general sense, and more specifically refers to those who were followers of the non-Mahāyāna tradition of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas.
A disciple of the Buddha; in the sūtras, this term refers to the followers of the Hīnayāna, or the Lesser Vehicle.
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.
A personal disciple of the Buddha who later disseminates the teachings themself.
One of the rāśis.

Usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it known to others.” Primarily this refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking nirvāṇa.

Primarily referring to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat by seeking self-liberation. It is usually defined as “those who hear the teaching from the Buddha and make it heard by others.”

The word, based on the verb “to hear,” means “disciple," and is used in that general way, as well as for those who were followers of the non-Mahāyāna tradition of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas.
Based on the verb “to hear,” the Sanskrit term śrāvaka is used in reference to followers of the non-Mahāyāna traditions of Buddhism, in contrast to the bodhisattvas who follow the Mahāyāna path.
A practitioner of the common vehicle who strives to attain the level of an arhat.
A ‘listener’ or direct disciple of the Buddha. Often used to denote the non-Mahāyāna monastic community.
The word, based on the verb “to hear,” means “disciple” in general, and is more specifically applied to the followers of the non-Mahāyāna traditions of Buddhism.
The disciples of the Buddha who are on the path to arhathood.
A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on the monastic lifestyle. Also translated as “listener.”
The name of the disciples of the Buddha who follow the teachings of the Lesser Vehicle.

Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (“those who hear” the Buddha's teaching, i.e., his disciples). In a Mahāyāna context it refers to those disciples of the Buddha who aspire to attain the state of an arhat.
Someone who practices according to the Vehicle of the Hearers (those who hear the teachings from others); or, someone who heard the Dharma from the Buddha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
A yakṣa in the country of Bhraṣṭolā.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Moonlight.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of the Moon.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The dynasty originating from the legendary king Ikṣvāku.
The bodhisattva Supreme Wisdom when he becomes a buddha.

term: ཉི་མ་ ལྟར་ བཞིན་ མདོག་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ
comment_en: A cakravartin king in another world in the distant past.
One of the two primary bodhisattvas who accompany the Thus-Gone One Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja in the buddhafield Vaiḍūrya­nirbhāsa.
A mountain in the sea south of Jambudvīpa.

term: ཉི་མ་ ཤར་བ་ -ར་ གྱུར་ བས་ མི་ རེག་པ
comment_en: A river on Saṅkāśa.

en: Superior Glory of the Sun Lamp
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
The name of an eon.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Moon.
A Kashmiri scholar (paṇḍita) who is well known for his commentaries on Tārā.
The god of the sun; the sun personified.

In the Vedas, the name originally meant “child of Aditi” so that in some texts it refers to a group of deities. However, in the Kāraṇḍavyūha it has the later meaning of being synonymous with Surya, the deity of the sun. It was translated into Tibetan simply as the common word for sun.
The sun personified as a god.
A bodhisattva.
A Hindu god (personification of the sun).
The ninth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
The sun; the god of the sun; the king identified as Āditya­vardhana of the Śrīkaṇṭha-Sthāṇvīśvara dynasty who ruled in Madhyadeśa in the sixth century ce.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The god of the sun; the sun personified.
The god of the sun; the sun personified.
A god.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Suriyatejā.
A certain sage who was third in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.
The name of an absorption.
A buddha.
A buddha of the southwest.
One of the great mātṛs.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; also a patronymic of Yama.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
Name of a tathāgata.
One of the ten absorptions of the bodhisattvas.
A southwestern buddha realm.

comment_en: A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
A bodhisattva.
A god; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A merchant’s daughter, a previous life of Gopā.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A ṛṣi in the past.
An epithet of the Buddha’s tribe derived from a legend concerning his ancestry (Rigzin 128). See also “Śākya.”
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

comment_en: A class of vidyādharas.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Sūrya­pradīpa­ketu­śiri.
Name of the forty-sixth meditative stability.
An absorption.
A buddha in the distant past.
The name of bodhisattva Cloud Voice when he becomes a buddha.

en: Stainless Light, the Essence of the Sun
comment_en: A buddha.
“The King of Clouds of the Light of the Essence of the Sun.” The name of the precious jewel of a cakravartin in the distant past.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A brahmin.
A buddha in the distant past.

comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.

Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Freeing.

An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual. Cloth from foreign countries to the west of Magadha, such as Aparānta (also Aparāntaka), an ancient kingdom in western India.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A bodhisattva.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Excellent Attainment.
A goddess who attempts to seduce Surata and later becomes one of his attendants.
A woman in Sunrise, sister of Beautiful. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1922.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
A forest on Heap in the Stream.
A nāga king.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
One of the disciples of the Buddha.
The name of a certain nāga. Not to be confused with “Upananda,” one of King Mahā­deva’s ministers; or with Upananda, the monk.

A member of the Śākya clan and monk of the Buddha’s order, he often appears in the vinaya texts, as here, to exemplify certain wrong behaviors. Not to be confused with Upananda, one of King Mahā­deva’s ministers; or with Upananda, the nāga.
Along with Nanda, one of King Mahā­deva’s two chief ministers in the city of Mithilā. Not to be confused with “Upananda,” the nāga; or with Upananda, the monk.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the kings of nāgas.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A nāga king.
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.

One of the eight great nāga kings. Usually paired with the nāga king Nanda. Also the name of a bhikṣu of the Buddha’s listed as being present at the sūtra’s teaching and listed along with the Buddha’s half-brother, the bhikṣu Nanda.
One of the main nāga kings, usually associated with the nāga king Nanda.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

One of eight mythological nāga kings. The story of the two nāga kings Upananda and Nanda and their taming by the Buddha and Maudgalyāyana is told in the Vinayavibhaṅga (Toh 3, D vol. 6, ’dul ba, ja, F.221a–224a).
A nāga king.
Considered the “younger brother” of Indra, the name Upendra appears as an epithet of Viṣṇu or Kṛṣṇa in Sanskrit epic and purāṇic literature.
A Hindu deity.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; the name of a yakṣa.
The younger brother of Indra.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A lay brother living in Nādikā.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the grahas.

A type of power place where yogins and yoginīs congregate.

One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the grahas.

One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
One of the four retinue goddesses of Siddhaikavīra; also of Arapacana.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

en: Eight Close Sons of the Buddha
comment_en: The eight bodhisattvas Mañjuśrī, Avalokiteśvara, Vajrapāṇi, Kṣitigarbha, Ākāśagarbha, Sarva­nivaraṇa­viṣkambhin, Maitreya, and Samantabhadra.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Name of a meditative absorption.
A buddha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A lay brother living in Nādikā.
The ninth of the twelve links of dependent origination, “grasping” more broadly refers to the exceptionally strong form of craving through which we remain attached to and fixated on cyclic existence.

A collective name for the five impure psycho-physical aggregates: (1) physical forms, (2) feelings, (3) perceptions, (4) formative predispositions, and (5) consciousness. These “acquisitive” psycho-physical aggregates (upadānaskandha, nye bar len pa’i phung po) denote the contaminated aggregates (sāsravaskandha, zag bcas kyi phung po) which emerge through the primary cause of past actions and afflicted mental states, and become the primary cause for subsequent actions and afflictions.

The five aggregates (skandha) of form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected. They are referred to as the “bases for appropriation” (upādāna) insofar as all conceptual grasping arises on the basis of these aggregates.

The five aggregates (skandha) of form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected. They are referred to as the “bases for appropriation” (upādāna) insofar as all conceptual grasping arises on the basis of these aggregates.
The five aggregates of form, feeling, notion, assembled factors, and consciousness. They are referred to as the bases for clinging insofar as all conceptual grasping arises based on these aggregates.

en: Aggregates as the bases for clinging
comment_en: The five aggregates (skandha) of matter (rūpa), sensation (vedanā), perception (saṃjñā), karmic dispositions (saṃskāra), and consciousness (vijñāna). They are referred to as the “bases for clinging” (upādāna) insofar as all conceptual grasping arises on the basis of these aggregates.
See “five aggregates for appropriation.”
Said of the aggregates individually, but more commonly in terms of all five as a collective, because they are “the basis of clinging to existence” (Edgerton).
The five skandhas seen as both caused by karma, and themselves the cause, through karma, of future existences.
A lay brother living in Nādikā.
A mountain in Living by Rājanina.
An ocean between Kuru and Godānīya.
A city in Videha.
A river on Deer Abode.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A city in Videha.
Śāriputra’s grandfather named him Upatiṣya, “Tiṣya’s Heir,” to honor Śāriputra’s father Tiṣya.
Another name of Śāriputra.
Another name of Śāriputra.
One of the given names of Venerable Śāriputra. See “Śāriputra.”
A nāga king; one of Ānanda’s past lives.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

A monk of one year whose premature taking of a ward prompted the Buddha to decree that only those who had been monks for ten years could allow going forth, grant ordination, accept charge of novices, give refuge, and live independently.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A certain monk who had gone forth under the Buddha. With his support Lotus Color found faith in the Buddha’s doctrine and also went forth.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
A monk who was predicted by the Buddha to appear in the future.
Fifth in the apostolic succession that carried on the Buddha’s teachings after his parinirvāṇa.
The name of Svāgata, a disciple of the Buddha, before he meets the Buddha.
A piece of land belonging to Virtuous Castle.
A buddha.

en: Cleansed of the Stains of Affliction
comment_en: A buddha.

term: ཉོན་མོངས་པ་ མེད་པ་ ཉོན་མོངས་པ་ དང་ བཅས་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ འདུ་བ
en: Convergence of All Mental Afflictions in Non-affliction
comment_en: Name of the 106th meditative stability.

term: ཉོན་མོངས་པ་ མེད་པ་ རྟོགས་པ་ -ར་ ཁོང་ དུ་ ཆུད་པ

comment_en: A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A type of mental imperfection. The most basic afflictions are attachment, aversion, and confusion.
The afflictions that hold one back from awakening, often listed as desire (rāga), anger (pratigha), pride (māna), ignorance (avidyā), wrong views (kudṛṣti), and indecision (vicikitsā).
A type of mental imperfection, the most basic afflictions being attachment, aversion and confusion.
A type of mental imperfection; the most basic afflictions are attachment, aversion, and confusion.
The mental states which cause unrest in the mind, distorting the view of reality.
A type of mental imperfection, the most basic afflictions being attraction, aversion, and confusion.
This is the figurative or embodied demon of emotional disturbances.
The head of a guild who was Jyotiṣka in a former life.
A self-awakened one.
Negative qualities in the mind, the basic three being ignorance, attachment, and aversion.
See “kleśa.”
Desire, hatred and anger, dullness, pride, and jealousy, as well as all their derivatives, said to number 84,000. Also translated “passions.”
Any defiled mental state that disturbs the mind.

Literally “pain,” “torment,” or “affliction.” In Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit it literally means “impurity” or “depravity.” In its technical use in Buddhism it means any negative quality in the mind that causes continued existence in saṃsāra. There are said to be 84,000 of these negative mental qualities for which the 84,000 categories of the Buddha’s teachings serve as the antidote. These mental disturbances can be subsumed into the three or five poisons of attachment, anger, and ignorance plus arrogance and jealousy. Also translated here as “disturbing emotions.”

Literally “pain,” “torment,” or “affliction.” In Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit it literally means “impurity” or “depravity.” In its technical use in Buddhism it means any negative quality in the mind that causes continued existence in saṃsāra. There are the 84,000 variations of mental disturbances for which the 84,000 categories of the Buddha’s teachings serve as the antidote. These mental disturbances can be subsumed into the three or five poisons of attachment, aversion, and ignorance plus arrogance and jealousy.

In Buddhism, affliction (Skt. kleśa) refers to any destructive mental state that causes suffering and continued existence in saṃsāra. In this regard, the three basic kleśas are ignorance, attachment, and aversion (or hatred). In terms of etymology, the primary meaning is “defilement.” This is reflected in the middle-Indic kileśa and Pali kilesa which mean “to soil, stain, defile.” The meaning “affliction” is a secondary meaning that derives from a more general (non-Buddhist) classical understanding based on the verbal root kliś (“afflict, torment, cause pain”).
Mental factors that disturb the mind and incite unwholesome deeds of body, speech, and mind.

Some readers may be familiar with the term samadhi, written without diacritics as it would appear in English dictionaries, where it is usually explained as referring to meditation or meditative states. In a more restricted sense, and when understood as a mental state, samādhi is defined as the one-pointedness of the mind (cittaikāgratā), the ability to remain on the same object over long periods of time. In Vaibhāṣika abhidharma, samādhi is a mental state that accompanies each and every moment of mind; the practice of meditation and the like is for the purpose of making samādhi more powerful (samādhiś cittasyaikagrateti | agram ālambanam ity eko 'rthaḥ | yadyogāc cittaṃ prabandhena ekatrālambane vartate | sa samādhiḥ | yadi samādhiḥ sarva­cetasi bhavati | kim arthaṃ dhyāneṣu yatnaḥ kriyate | balavatsamādhiniṣpādanārthaṃ, Abhidharma­kośa­vyākhyā 2.24, Wogihara 1989, p. 128). Some forms of abhidharma (Yogācāra, for example) do not consider samādhi as a mental factor that accompanies every moment of mind. In a slightly less technical sense, samādhi can describe a number of different meditative states, including the highest such as the “samādhi that is like a diamond” (vajropamasamādhi). If we understand the term samādhi as derived from sam + ā + dhā, the sense is something like to “place together” or “collect.” In the Tibetan rendering of this term, the ’dzin represents, we think, the root dhā and matches one of the senses of this root, “to hold” (dhāraṇa). The possible etymology of ting nge is debated and possibly a complex matter; if we accept the hypothesis that ting nge is related to gting, then the sense is probably akin to “profound” or “deep,” which may indicate taking sam + ā more or less as intensifiers. The sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa commentary on the Mahāvyutpatti explains the term samādhi as referring to the instrument through which mind and mental states “get collected,” i.e., it is by the force of samādhi that the continuum of mind and mental states becomes collected on a single point of reference without getting distracted (samādhi zhes pa samādhiyante anena zhes bya ste | ting nge ’dzin gyi mthus sems dang sems las byung ba’i rgyud dmigs pa gcig la sdud cing mi g.yo bar ting nge ’dzin ’jog pas na ting nge ’dzin zhes bya).

The concept of skillful means is central to the understanding of the Buddha’s enlightened deeds and the many scriptures which are revealed contingent to the needs, interests, and mental dispositions of specific types of individuals. According to the Great Vehicle, training in skillful means collectively denotes the first five of the six transcendent perfections when integrated with wisdom, the sixth transcendent perfection, to form a union of discriminative awareness and means.

en: Those who have entered the path of liberation
comment_en: Perhaps a gloss or paraphrase for noble persons or noble ones, i.e., those who, through having reached the path of seeing, belong to one of four types: stream enterer (Skt. srota-āpanna), once-returner (Skt. sakṛdāgāmin), non-returner (Skt. anāgāmin), or worthy one (Skt. arhat). These stages are characterized by the gradual elimination of the fetters (Skt./Pāli saṃyojana) that bind one to saṃsāra and to being an ordinary person (Skt. pṛthagjana; Pāli puthujjana).
