The same as the Bodhisattva Vehicle, whose practitioners aim at complete buddhahood.

When the Buddhist teachings are classified according to their power to lead beings to an enlightened state, a distinction is made between the teachings of the Lesser Vehicle, which emphasizes the individual’s own freedom from cyclic existence as the primary motivation and goal, and those of the Great Vehicle, which emphasizes altruism and has the liberation of all sentient beings as the principal objective. As the term “Great Vehicle” implies, the path followed by bodhisattvas is analogous to a large carriage which can transport a vast number of people to liberation, as compared to a smaller vehicle for the individual practitioner.
Literally the Sanskrit means “great way,” but in Buddhism this has developed the meaning of great vehicle, and so is translated literally into Tibetan as “great carrier.”

The “Great Vehicle” of Buddhism, called “great” because it carries all living beings to enlightenment of Buddhahood. It is distinguished from the Hinayāna, including the Śrāvāka­yāna (Śrāvaka Vehicle) and Pratyeka­buddha­yāna (Solitary Sage Vehicle), which only carries each person who rides on it to their own personal liberation.

The “Great Vehicle” of Buddhism, called “great” because it aims with altruistic intent to transport all living beings to the goal of liberation. It is distinguished from the Hinayāna (Lesser Vehicle), including the Śrāvakayāna (Śrāvaka Vehicle) and Pratyeka­buddha­yāna (Solitary Buddha Vehicle), which allegedly aims to transport only its followers to their own personal liberation.
Great Vehicle.

When the Buddhist teachings are classified according to their power to lead beings to an awakened state, a distinction is made between the teachings of the Lesser Vehicle, which emphasizes the individual’s own freedom from cyclic existence as the primary motivation and goal, and those of the Great Vehicle, which emphasizes altruism and has the liberation of all sentient beings as the principal objective. As the term “Great Vehicle” implies, the path followed by bodhisattvas is analogous to a large carriage that can transport a vast number of people to liberation, as compared to a smaller vehicle for the individual practitioner. See also “Lesser Vehicle.”
The same as the Bodhisattva Vehicle, whose practitioners aim at complete buddhahood.

One of the major three Buddhist schools, Hīnayāna (Small Vehicle), Mahāyāna (Great Vehicle), and Vajrayāna (Diamond Vehicle). The Great Vehicle is characterized by its emphasis on compassion and altruistic principles of the bodhisattva path.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Literally “the lesser way” or “lesser vehicle.” It is a collective term for the śrāvakayāna and pratyeka­buddha­yāna, which have nirvāṇa instead of buddhahood as their goal.

It is a collective term used by proponents of the Great Vehicle to refer to the Śrāvakayāna (Hearer Vehicle) and Pratyeka­buddha­yāna (Solitary-Buddha Vehicle). The name stems from their goal—i.e., nirvāṇa and personal liberation—being seen as small or lesser than the goal of the Great Vehicle—i.e., buddhahood and liberation of all sentient beings.
See “Disciple Vehicle.”

It is a collective term used by proponents of the Great Vehicle to refer to the śrāvakayāna (hearer vehicle) and pratyeka­buddha­yāna (solitary buddha vehicle). The name stems from their goal—i.e. nirvāṇa and personal liberation—being seen as small or lesser than the goal of the Great Vehicle—i.e. buddhahood and liberation of all sentient beings. See also “Great Vehicle.”
In the context of the sūtras, the three vehicles are the Śrāvaka, the Pratyeka­buddha, and the Bodhisattva Vehicles.

One of the two main lineages through which different Kangyurs can be traced, although most are of more or less mixed lineage. This lineage started with a manuscript called the Thempangma that was produced at Gyantsé (rgyal rtse) in 1431 from sources in the locality.
One of the two textual lineages of the Kangyur, starting from a manuscript so named that was produced at Gyantsé (rgyal rtse) in 1431.
The important West Tibetan monastery founded in 996 ce by King Yeshé Ö (ye shes ’od) and the translator Rinchen Zangpo (rin chen bzang po).
A bodhisattva from the world known as Illusory.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha.
One of the mantra deities.
A buddha.
A buddha.

term: ཐོགས་པ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ འོད་ཟེར་ པད་མ་ སངས་རྒྱས་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ
en: Splendor of the Unimpeded Light Rays of the Superior Lotus of Awakening
comment_en: A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
Name of a buddha.
A thus-gone one of the past.
Name of a sage, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of a buddha.
Indian commentator (fl. late fourth–early fifth centuries).
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
A wrathful emanation of Hevajra(?).

First recorded in medieval Tibetan literature as a seventh-century minister of the Tibetan King Songtsen Gampo, he is credited with the invention of the Tibetan alphabet and the composition of two much-studied grammar texts.
The seventh century scholar and minister credited with developing the Tibetan alphabet.
A location in the Heaven of Joy.
Hearing or listening to teachings, this refers to receiving oral instructions and studying scriptures.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
Translator of the Sukhāvatī­vyūha­sūtra.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.
An Indian paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
One of the Indian preceptors who assisted in translating this text.
An Indian paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian preceptor and translator who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian preceptor and translator who lived in the ninth century.
An Indian preceptor and translator who lived in the ninth century.
“Charitable,” an Indian paṇḍita who traveled to Tibet during the time of King Trisong Detsen to serve as a translator.
Eighth-century Indian teacher and translator.
An Indian paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian paṇḍiṭa resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.
An Indian preceptor from Kashmir who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth- and early ninth-centuries. He was a frequent collaborator of Yeshé Dé.
A prince living in the past at the time of the buddha Merugandha.
The ancient kingdom of the Darada people in the Gilgit region of larger Kashmir.

term: ད་ལྟར་ བྱུང་བ་ -འི་ དུས་ ལ་མ་ ཆགས་ མ་ཐོགས་པ་ -འི་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ གཟིགས་པ་ -ར་ འཇུག་ གོ
en: Engage in the perception of pristine cognition which is unobstructed and unimpeded with respect to the present
comment_en: Eighteenth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
The name of the twentieth Jain arhat of the present descending age (avasarpiṇī).
A buddha in the past.
One of the wives of Śiva.
Śiva.
Epithet of Pārvatī, consort of Śiva.
One of the wives of Śiva; in the Bhūtaḍāmara maṇḍala she is one of the eight goddesses of offerings.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: དཀའ་ ཟློག་ རྐང་ སྤྱོད་ ལྡན་ མ
comment_en: One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
Name of the first level to be acquired by bodhisattvas.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
All good beings together (as opposed to the black faction of Māra); from Māra’s point of view, this is the “black faction.” The bright fortnight of the lunar month.

en: First day of the bright fortnight

comment_en: One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Ancient Indian sage, known primarily for tales of his short temper and the curses he inflicted, hence the meaning of his name: “difficult to live with.”
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode; one of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of eight children, a daughter, of King Siṃhahanu of Kapilavastu.
One of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the great dūtīs.
A goddess; a rākṣasī in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).

The Ratnakūṭa section of the Kangyur (Toh 45–93) is a distinct collection, also found in the Chinese Tripiṭaka (Taishō 310), of forty-nine selected sūtras on a range of themes. In some titles and colophons the collection is presented as a single sūtra with its component texts as chapters.
One of the five major sūtra groups contained within the Kangyur.
A buddha in the eastern direction.
A collective term for the Buddha, his sacred doctrine (Dharma), and the Saṅgha, which are listed separately in this glossary.
The Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha—the three objects of Buddhist refuge.
The Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha.
The Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha. In the Tibetan rendering, “the three rare and excellent ones.”

The Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha are three sources or objects of refuge for Buddhists. The Tibetan translators rendered the Sanskrit ratna (“jewel”) as “the [three] rare and superior ones” (dung dkar tshig mdzod chen mo, 143).
The three objects of Buddhists’ refuge, also known as the Three Jewels: the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha.
The Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha.
The Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha.

Lit. “Jewel-Array.” Name of one of the bodhisattvas in the original assembly (rendered in Tibetan as rin chen bkod pa); also the name (with several renderings in Tibetan) of a buddha who presides in the universe called Ananta­guṇa­ratna­vyūha, yet who comes to Vimalakīrti’s house at the latter’s supplication, to participate in the esoteric teachings. He can be identified with the Tathāgata Ratnasaṃbhava, one of the five major buddhas of the Guhya­samāja­tantra.
One of the buddhas who appear in the house of Vimalakīrti on esoteric occasions; the Sanskrit name, but with a different rendering in Tibetan, also refers to a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
Forty-nine selected sūtras on a range of themes, compiled as a separate collection.
A collection of texts comprising a section of the Kangyur as well as of the Chinese Buddhist canon. See the Reading Room “About” tab notes for details.
A collection of texts comprising a section of the Kangyur as well as of the Chinese Buddhist canon.
A prince in the distant past.
A buddha.
One of the buddhas who assembled at Vimalakīrti’s house to teach the Tathāgata­guhyaka, according to the goddess.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the ten absorptions of the bodhisattvas.
The name of a future eon.

One of the buddhas who appear in the house of Vimalakīrti on esoteric occasions. According to the Prajñā­pāramitā, he is the Buddha of the universe Upaśānta, in the western direction (see Lamotte, p. 384, n. 27).

A demarcated area within a larger boundary. An official act of the saṅgha requires a “consensus” of all monks present within the monastery’s boundaries or of a quorum of monks within an “inner circle.”

In the higher tantras this is usually a diagram representing the details of the visualization of a deity and its palace and retinue. In the Kāraṇḍavyūha it is a simpler representation of a few deities, made of precious powders.

Apart from the well-known meaning of a magical diagram and several other conventional meanings, this term seems to denote any magically charged area or sphere of a specific type, such as, e.g., the maṇḍala of wind, the maṇḍala of sound, etc.

A mystic diagram, usually consisting of a square within a circle, used to define a sacred space in the context of esoteric rituals of initiation and consecration preliminary to certain advanced meditational practices.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
The energy centers along the middle channel.
Also rendered in this sūtra as “disk.”
Literally a “disk” or “circle,” in the ritual context maṇḍala is a sacred space on the ground or a raised platform, arranged according to a pattern that varies from rite to rite.
Lit. “Black One.”
Name of the thirty-seventh meditative stability.
The pure aspect (usually a particular Buddhist category) of a ritual implement or any ordinary entity.
A region in Magadha.
One of the five celestial bodhisattvas associated with Mañjuśrī.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha.
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Thoroughly Illumined Glorious Array of Excellences resides.
The island of Java, part of the Indonesian archipelago.
A mango forest.
A forest in Endowed with Increasing Bliss.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Devoid of Sorrow.

term: དགའ་བ་ དང་ མགུ་བ་ དང་ ཚིམ་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ བསྐྱེད་པ
en: Truly creating all forms of joy, contentment, and satisfaction
comment_en: Name of an absorption.
A lake near Flow of Beauty.
The world within which Ratnavara will attain enlightenment.
A buddha realm.
A city in Videha.
Name of the thirty-ninth meditative stability.
Name of an eon (kalpa).
A city in the world called Emanation.
A buddha.
A town in South India.
Fourth of the seven branches of enlightenment.
A pleasure garden in Moving Like the Moon.
A grove.
Name of the fifty-eighth meditative stability.
A buddha realm.
Third of the four immeasurable aspirations.
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
One of the factors of awakening and one of the abodes of Brahmā, the other being: loving kindness or love, equanimity, and compassion.
A city.
A southern buddha realm.
One of the four immeasurables.
A future solitary buddha.
The first bodhisattva level.
Joy in general; the first of the four joys of sexual experience.
652−710 ce. He went from Khotan to China, where he translated the Avataṃsaka Sūtra. The Tibetan should be bslab pa dga’ ba but translates only the nanda half of the name.
Also Nandapura; another name of Pāṭaliputra.
One of the apsarases.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks (dga’ ba’i chu). (2) A river on Saṅkāśa (rab tu dga’ bar gyur pa’i chu ).
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha of the zenith.
One of the four auxiliary pīṭhas.
The bull of Śiva who serves as his vehicle.
A town in South India.
A forest of Indra.
Another name for the Forest of Amusements in Moving in the Stream.
A forest on the southern face of Sumeru.
One of the four divine pleasure gardens.
“The Pleasure Grove”; the chief of the parks in Sudarśana city, where the resident gods of the city, headed by Śakra (Indra), go for their amusement.
One of the four kinds of food.
A brahmin youth.
The Nibandhana explains that “rejoicing” refers to a happy, joyful mind (saumanasya).

term: དགའ་བ་ -འི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ དཔལ་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ སྦྱངས་པ
comment_en: The daughter of a courtesan in another world in the distant past, a previous life of Gopā. In verse she is called Saṃcālitā.
The palace of a king known as Puṇyodgata.
A goddess in another world in the distant past who informs a courtesan’s daughter of the presence of a buddha.
A town in another world in the distant past.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
An absorption.
A river in the Swan Forest.
“Filled with Joy.” The name of a future eon in which Mahā­maudgalyāyana will become a buddha.
Bodhisattva of the zenith.
A river on Saṅkāśa.

term: དགའ་བ་ -ས་ རབ་ཏུ་ འཛུམ་པ་ -འི་ འོད་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
A nāga king.
The Buddha’s half-brother, who became one of his principal pupils. Also the name for the nāga king usually associated with Upananda.
Śrāvaka arhat.
The Buddha’s half-brother, who became one of his principal pupils. Also the name for the nāga king usually associated with Upananda.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha. (2) A herdsman. (3) A nāga king.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
The Buddha’s cousin and principal attendant.
The Buddha’s half-brother and disciple.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
The name of a certain nāga. Not to be confused with “Nanda,” one of King Mahā­deva’s ministers.
Along with Upananda, one of King Mahā­deva’s two chief ministers in the city of Mithilā. Not to be confused with “Nanda,” a certain nāga.
The Buddha’s cousin; see also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-076-001.html#UT22084-076-001-22.
The nāga king usually associated with Upananda.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight chief pratyeka­buddhas; one of the pratyeka­buddhas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; a nāga king; a Magadhan king, the successor of Śūrasena; a tantric scholar of the early medieval period.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The younger half-brother and disciple of the Buddha, who is the interlocutor in this discourse.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.

One of eight mythological nāga kings. The story of the two nāga kings Nanda  and Upananda and their taming by the Buddha and Maudgalyāyana is told in the Vinayavibhaṅga (Toh 3, D vol. 6, ’dul ba, ja, F.221a–224a).
Name of a nāga king.
A nāga king.

term: དགའ་བྱེད་ ཀྱི་ བཀྲ་ བཤིས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ འཛིན་པ

comment_en: A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the attendants on Śiva.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Goddess invoked to obtain power, riches, and splendor.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A member of the Śākya clan.
One of the Buddha’s great disciples.
A yakṣa child.

The third joy, interpreted as intense joy in the Kālacakra system, where it supplants the joy of cessation of the Yoginī Tantra. While both these meanings can be derived from the Sanskrit viramānanda, the Tibetan dga’ bral dga’ ba seems to reflect only the joy of cessation.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
In the Tibetan, divided into two characters, “Rati” and “Priyā.”
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
A king.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.
A country or town.
A buddha realm.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A lake near Sudharma.
A region in South India.

term: དགའ་ ཡོད་ གནས་བརྟན་ ཀ་ པི་ ན
comment_en: A disciple of the Buddha. The Tibetan instance of dga’ yod gnas brtan ka pi na, which would render the name “Nandika Kapphiṇa,” is read in the Sanskrit source as brāhmaṇa­kapphiṇas sthaviraḥ, “the elder Brāhmaṇa­kapphiṇa.” This figure seems to be identical to Brāhmaṇa­kapphiṇa.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the deities invited to partake in the oblation offering.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, counted among the six heavens of the desire realm, it is home of future Buddha Maitreya.
A divine world located in the Desire Realm; in Great Vehicle Buddhist thought, it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
Heaven of Joy, the fourth heaven in the desire realm.
A divine world located in the desire realm. In Great Vehicle Buddhist thought, it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A god realm.
Fourth god realm of desire, meaning “joyful.”
The fourth (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm.
A divine world located in the desire realm; in Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
The fourth (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm. The paradise from which Śākyamuni descended to be born into his world.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. In Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
The fourth (third highest) of the six levels of gods of the Desire Realm.
One of the gods’ realms.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. In Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
The third highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The third of the six god realms of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm, where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
A class of gods in the desire realm among whom the Bodhisattva is supposed to be born in his penultimate life, before that in which he attains full awakening.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. In Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. In Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
A deity; also the name of the fourth level of the heavens in the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm, where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

A heaven, the fourth level of the heavens of the realm of desire, and the last stopping place of a buddha before his descent and reincarnation on earth; at present the abode of the future Buddha Maitreya.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The third of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens in the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, counted among the six heavens of the desire realm, it is home of future Buddha Maitreya.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. In Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. In Buddhist thought it is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
A divine world located in the desire realm. In Buddhist thought, this is where all future buddhas dwell prior to their complete awakening.
Name of a god realm.
One of the six heavens in the desire realm.
The fourth of the six heavens of the desire realm. The heaven from which Śākyamuni descended to be born into this world and where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
The third highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, counted among the six heavens of the desire realm; home of the future buddha Maitreya.

The fourth level of the heavens of the realm of desire, and the last stopping place of a buddha before his descent and reincarnation on earth. According to Buddhist cosmology, it is presently the abode of the future Buddha Maitreya.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The fourth (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm.
The fourth (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm. The paradise from which buddhas descend to be born in this world.
A heaven in the god realms where it is understood that future buddhas reside prior to manifesting buddhahood in the world.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The lord of the desire realm who resides in the Tuṣita heaven.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
The fourth heaven among the six heavens of the desire realm.
The celestial realm where a bodhisattva is born before being reborn as a Buddha in the human realm. Second of the group of four heavens immediately above the peak of Mount Meru.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm, where all future buddhas dwell prior to their awakening.
See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-008.html#UT22084-072-008-4.
A potter.
One of two sisters who nursed Siddhārtha Gautama after his six years of austerities.
Young woman of Serika village, who, along with Nandā, is credited in this text and in the Divyāvadāna with giving honeyed porridge prepared from milk to Gautama prior to his enlightenment.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A forest on Upward Ocean.
A nāga.
Seventh god realm of form, meaning “little virtue.”
The second of the three paradises that are the third dhyāna paradises in the form realm.
The seventh heaven of the form realm.
First of three states of the third concentration level.
The first level of the third concentration.

The seventh of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the third meditative absorption. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-263.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, first of three levels of the third dhyāna realm.
The lowest of the three paradises that correspond to the third dhyāna in the form realm.
A Tibetan translator active in Tibet in the late eighth to early ninth century.

term: དགེ་བ་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ རྣམ་དག་ རིན་ཆེན་ ཟླ་འོད་ རྒྱལ་པོ
en: King Precious Moonlight of Pure Virtue
comment_en: One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A great bodhisattva.
A king in the distant past.
A supreme god, or Brahmā, of another universe, who visits our universe to converse with Aniruddha about the divine eye, and is taught instead by Vimalakīrti in Chap. 3.

The ten virtuous actions are divided into three modes of excellent physical conduct, four modes of excellent verbal conduct, and three modes of excellent mental conduct. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-2260.
Abstaining from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, lying, uttering divisive talk, speaking harsh words, gossiping, covetousness, ill will, and wrong views.
Abstaining from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, lying, uttering divisive talk, speaking harsh words, gossiping, covetousness, ill will, and wrong views.

Abstaining from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, lying, uttering divisive talk, speaking harsh words, gossiping, covetousness, ill-will, and wrong views. Also rendered here as “ten virtuous actions.”
Abstaining from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, lying, uttering divisive talk, speaking harsh words, chatter, covetousness, ill will, and wrong views.
Abstaining from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, lying, uttering divisive talk, speaking harsh words, gossiping, covetousness, ill will, and wrong views.

Abstaining from the ten nonvirtuous actions. Namely, abstaining from killing, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, lying, uttering divisive talk, speaking harsh words, gossiping, covetousness, ill will, and wrong views.
See “ten virtuous courses of action.”

The opposites of the ten nonvirtuous courses of action (as they occur in note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-039.html#UT22084-072-039-322; note that only nine actions are listed): Abstaining from killing, stealing, leading an unchaste life, lying, divisive talk, [abusive language], trivial talk, greed, hatred, and wrong views.
Usually expressed as the opposites of the ten unwholesome courses of action, i.e., not killing living beings, etc.

These are the opposite of the ten sins, i.e., refraining from engaging in activities related to the ten sins and doing the opposite. There are three physical virtues: saving lives, giving, and sexual propriety. There are four verbal virtues: truthfulness, reconciling discussions, gentle speech, and religious speech. There are three mental virtues: loving attitude, generous attitude, and right views. The whole doctrine is collectively called the “tenfold path of good action” (daśa­kuśala­karma­patha).
The opposite of the standard nonvirtuous actions (three of the body, four of the speech, and three of the mind).

(1) Not killing (prāṇātighātād virati, srog gcod spong ba), (2) not stealing (adattādānād virati, ma byin par len pa spong ba), (3) not indulging in sexual misconduct (kāmamithyācārād virati, log g.yem spong ba), (4) not lying (mṛṣāvādāt prativirati, brdzun spong ba), (5) not slandering (pāiśunyāt prativirati, khra ma spong ba), (6) not using harsh words (pāruṣyāt prativirati, tshig rtsub spong ba), (7) not indulging in idle gossip (sambhinna pralāpāt prativirati, ngag ’khyal spong ba), (8) not being covetous (abhidhyāyāḥ prativirati, brnab sems spong ba), (9) not wishing harm on others (vyāpādāt prativirati, gnod sems spong ba), (10) not holding wrong view (mithyādṛṣṭeḥ prativirati, log lta spong ba) (Rigzin 45).
A world system.
The name of an eon.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
An upāsikā in Dhanyākara (translated as dge ba yod pa). Also a daughter in Dhanyākara (translated as dge ba bzang mo).
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Peak of Pure Conduct.
The lowest of the three paradises that are the third dhyāna paradises in the form realm.

The term kuśala can function both as a qualifier or as a noun in its own right, which makes it difficult to resort to a single translation (I have resorted to “virtue” and “virtuous”). It refers to something beneficial or virtuous and is sometimes etymologized as something that keeps badness in check (kutsitaṁ śalate); when the sense of kuśala is more akin to “skillful” or even “virtuoso,” the etymology is that it is “someone who can cut the kuśa grass” (kuśān lāti), a type of grass that is very sharp and thus requires remarkable skill to cut it without being cut in turn.
A country prophesied by the Buddha. It refers to the country of Khotan.
A brahmin statesman.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Also translated here as “virtuous attributes.” For a listing of the mundane virtuous phenomena, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-407. (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-408).
Also translated here as “virtuous phenomena.”
A Tibetan translator.
An upāsikā in Dhanyākara.
A town in South India.

The city where the temple mentioned in this text is being built. Possibly to be identified with the southern city Śubhapāraṃgama in the Gaṇḍavyūha (see note note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-047-001.html#UT22084-047-001-2366).
A Mahāyāna teacher is termed “friend,” or “benefactor,” which indicates that a bodhisattva-career depends on one’s own effort and that all a teacher can do is inspire, exemplify, and point the way.
A spiritual mentor.
A general term to denote a qualified spiritual teacher.

Ma Gewai Lodrö (ma dge ba’i blo gros), a Tibetan lotsāva, was an important disciple of Rinchen Zangpo (rin chen bzang po, 958-1055) who translated several texts with Atiśa and worked with the Kaśmīri master Subhūti­śri­bhadra to translate a number of pramāṇa texts.
One of the three translators responsible for the canonical translation of the SEV.
A sage.
A buddha realm.
Name of a past king in a story the Buddha tells.

en: Blossoming and Purity of the Flowers of Virtue
comment_en: Name of the seventy-fourth meditative stability. “Purity” here could also be rendered “vibrance.”
A buddha.
A kalpa in the distant past. The name means “Good Light.”

term: དགེ་བ་ -འི་ རྩ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ འབྱུང་བ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: “The Voice That Causes the Emergence of All Roots of Merit.” The name of a ray of light.

en: Accumulation of All Precious Roots of Virtue
comment_en: The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
Wholesome actions that are conducive to happiness.
Wholesome actions that are conducive to happiness.
Wholesome actions that are conducive to happiness.
Wholesome actions that are conducive to happiness. There are three fundamental roots of virtue from which the others arise: absence of desire, absence of hatred, and absence of delusion.
A virtuous action or state of mind that will “ripen” into happiness later in this life, the next, or at some point in the unknown future.
Wholesome actions that benefit others.
Wholesome actions that are conducive to happiness.

The roots of virtue are of three types: absence of desire (ma chags pa, alobha), absence of anger (zhe sdang med pa, adveṣa), and absence of bewilderment (gti mug med pa, amoha). These three give rise to all wholesome qualities and hence they are called “roots.”

Cumulative meritorious deeds performed by an individual throughout past lives. The most common threefold list of roots of virtue include non-greed (Skt. alobha), non-hatred (Skt. adveṣa), and non-delusion (Skt. amoha).
Wholesome actions that are conducive to happiness.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the early schools of Buddhism, within which views such as the transcendence of the Buddha formed the basis for the rise of Mahāyāna.

A disciple of Śāriputra who was abducted by nāgas and taken back to their land under the sea where he helped three young nāgas memorize the Four Āgamas, thereby establishing the sūtras in the land of the nāgas.
Third of the ten recollections.

One of five types of offenses a monk can incur. Second only to a defeat in severity, there are thirteen saṅgha stigmata. Offenses against the monastic vows are classed as either atonable (Skt. sāvaśeṣa; Tib. lhag bcas) or unatonable (Skt. nirvaśeṣa; Tib. lhag med). Unatonable offenses, such as defeats, entail loss of one’s monk- or nunhood while atonable offenses can be atoned for in prescribed ways, according to the severity of the offense. When a monk incurs an offense whose remnant is restored by the saṅgha, the saṅgha imposes a probation and penance during which the monk must endure a loss of status and privilege and give regular reports on his conduct. Upon completion of this period of probation and penance, the saṅgha may then reinstate the monk with full honors and privileges. There is no consensus on the exact referent of the Sanskrit term vaśeṣa or its Tibetan translation lhag ma, though it seems to refer to the “remnant” or “remainder” of a monastic’s precepts that persist in the wake of atonable offenses. The translation “saṅgha stigmata”—literally “saṅgha remnant”—follows Kalyāṇamitra’s gloss: a group of “saṅgha” meet to impose a disciplinary act upon an offending monk who retains a remnant of his monastic precepts (Kalyāṇamitra, folio 292.a.6–7).
A temple on Mount Gośṛṅga.

Though often specifically reserved for the monastic community, this term can be applied to any of the four Buddhist communities—monks, nuns, laymen, and lay women—as well as the community of bodhisattvas.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, see also “Three Precious Jewels.”
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particulary the monastics.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particularly the monastics.
Congregation in a general sense; the Buddha’s congregation (one of the Three Jewels).

The third of the Three Jewels (Triratna) of Buddhism, the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Community. Sometimes narrowly defined as the community of mendicants, it can be understood as including lay practitioners.
Community.
The community followers of the Buddha; the third of the triad that constitute the “Three Jewels,” in which Buddhists take refuge.

Explained as a “cohesive assembly,” saṅgha refers ultimately to those who have realized the nature of reality in accordance with the Buddhist path or, in a more conventional sense, with an assembly of monastics.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particularly the monastics.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, often referring to the monastic community and sometimes to the community of realized bodhisattvas that are not visible to ordinary beings.
A congregation in a general sense; when spelled with a capital letter it refers to the Buddha’s congregation, one of the Three Jewels.
The congregation of monastics (one of the Three Jewels).
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particularly the monastics.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particularly the monastics.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particularly the monastics.
The “community” of ordained Buddhist monks and nuns.
The community of followers of the Buddha’s teachings, particularly the monastics.
Ninth god realm of form, meaning “most extensive virtue.”
The ninth heaven of the form realm.
Third of three heavens of gods on the third concentration level.
The second level of the third concentration.

The ninth of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the third meditative absorption. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-267.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, third of three levels of the third dhyāna realm.
One of the rāśis.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A land in South India.
“The renunciant Gautama,” the name by which the Buddha might have been referred to prior to his enlightenment or by those who were not his followers.
Epithet of the Buddha.
An epithet of the Buddha.
A māra.
A buddha.
The famed Madhyamika scholar.

term: དགེ་སློང་ ཚུར་ ཤོག་ གི་ བསྙེན་པ་ -ར་ རྫོགས་པ
comment_en: The informal ordination first employed by the Buddha.

A formula for ordination that consists of the words, “Come, monk.” This is one of the ways of ordaining a man as monk and is said to have been used by the Buddha until he established the rules of the standard ordination ceremony.

The Saṃdhi­nirmocana­sūtra ( Unraveling the Intent , Toh 106) is one of the most important Mahāyāna sūtras, especially for the Yogācāra school. As an authoritative source for Mahāyāna Buddhist hermeneutics, it is perhaps best known for its delineation of the three turnings of the wheel of the dharma (dharmacakrapravartana), which became a highly influential schema for classifying the teachings of the Buddha according to their various intended meanings and target audiences.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Non-grasping.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The eighty-second buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Vajrāśaya­giri­śirī.
A river.
A forest on Vast Garlands of Bliss.
A peak on Sumeru.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Lion’s Melody.
A forest in Part of the Assembly.
“Forest Dweller,” the name of the son of householders in Śrāvastī, he preferred seclusion, eventually attaining arhatship.
The name of Śākyamuni’s son. Also the name of the sons of all the buddhas that Śākyamuni had received the Samādhirāja from in previous lifetimes.
A king.
A buddha.
Name of a king, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha in the past.
“Worthy one” or “someone who has killed his foes” (i.e., mental afflictions); a Buddhist saint who has obtained liberation.
Fourth of the four fruits attainable by śrāvakas. One who has eliminated all afflicted mental states and personally ended the cycle of rebirth.
Used as both as an epithet of the Buddha and the final accomplishment of early Buddhism, or the Hīnayāna.
Final goal of the śrāvaka practitioner.
Used as both an epithet of the Buddha and the final accomplishment of early Buddhism, or the Hīnayāna.
Used both as an epithet of the Buddha and to mean the final accomplishment of early Buddhism, or the Hīnayāna.
One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path and who has attained liberation with the cessation of all afflictive emotions.
One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path and attained liberation with the cessation of all afflictive emotions.
Sometimes translated “worthy one,” a term for one who is liberated and who has extirpated the passions (kleśa, nyon mongs).

According to Buddhist tradition, one who has conquered his enemy passions (kleśa-ari-hata) and reached the supreme purity. The term can refer to buddhas as well as to those who have reached realization of the Disciple Vehicle.
A person who has achieved complete liberation from saṃsāra.
One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path and who has attained liberation with the cessation of all mental defilements.
“Worthy.” A being who has eliminated afflictive emotions and hence is liberated from suffering. The Tibetan, taking a doubtful Sanskrit etymology ari han, understands the term as “foe destroyer.”

One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who has attained liberation with the cessation of all mental afflictions. It is also used as an epithet of the Buddha. The Skt. means literally “worthy one.” The Tibetan interpretation explains the Middle Indic form arahat as ari-hata, “someone who has killed his foes (i.e., mental afflictions).” Also translated here as “worthy.”
One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who has attained liberation with the cessation of all mental afflictions.

One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path, and who has attained liberation with the cessation of all mental afflictions. The Skt. means literally “worthy one.” The Tibetan interpretation explains the Middle Indic form arahat as ari-hata, “someone who has killed his foes (i.e., mental afflictions).”
One who has achieved the fourth and final level of attainment on the śrāvaka path and who has attained liberation with the cessation of all mental afflictions.
“Worthy one” or “someone who has killed their foes” (i.e., mental afflictions). A Buddhist saint who has obtained liberation.

There are four kinds of noble persons (Skt. āryapudgala) according to the Śrāvakayāna path, characterized by a gradual abandonment of ten kinds of fetters (Skt. saṃyojana) that bind one to saṃsāra. This is the fourth and final of the four (or eight) stages of the realization of the supermundane path (and fruit), equivalent with awakening or liberation.
Literally “foe-destroyer”—the foe in this case being the afflictive emotions—one who has attained arhatship.
In Sanskrit meaning “venerable one,” in Tibetan “enemy defeater.” Used as both as an epithet of the buddhas and to refer to the final accomplishment of early Buddhism.
Used both as an epithet of the Buddha and to mean the final accomplishment of the śrāvaka path.
“Worthy one” is an epithet applied to the original (usually sixteen) disciples of the Buddha; also a term for any being who attained nirvāṇa by following the Hīnayāna vehicle.

Sometimes translated “worthy one,” a term for one who is liberated and who has extirpated the passions (Skt. kleśa, Tib. nyon mongs). The Tibetan rendering, based on a creative Sanskrit etymology ari han, understands the term as “foe (Tib. dgra) destroyer (Tib. bcom pa).”
Used both as an epithet of the Buddha and as the final accomplishment of the Śrāvakayāna.
Used both as an epithet of the Buddha and as the final accomplishment of the Śrāvakayāna.
A “worthy one,” who has destroyed the afflictions (Skt. kleśa) and all causes for future rebirth, and who thus will reach awakening at death.
A buddha.
A buddha in the past.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
Literally, “tolerance of remaining infused [by suffering].”
The first joy.
A place in Śūrasena.
A pool upon one of Airāvaṇa’s ears.
The name of the person who occupies the role of Devadatta in the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ realm.
A river on Saṅkāśa.

term: དངུལ་ གྱི་ ལྗོན་ ཞིང་ གི་ ནགས
comment_en: Part of the Forest of Joy.
A forest in White Body.
The silvery liquid metal.

term: དངུལ་ དང་ བཅས་པ་ -འི་ བྱེ་མ་ -ས་ ཡོངས་སུ་ བསྐོར་བ
comment_en: An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A forest on Tamer of Deer Enemies.
Accomplishment in general; supernatural power, especially, one of the eight magical powers.
An accomplishment that is the goal of sādhana.

Accomplishment or success in general, as well as any particular magical power or ability. In the latter sense, eight are traditionally enumerated, namely the siddhi of the magical sword, of an eye ointment that renders invisible, etc. The content of the list may vary from source to source.
See “accomplishment.”
See “accomplishment.”
An accomplishment that is the goal of sādhana practice; a supernatural power or ability.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha countless eons in the past.

term: དངོས་པོ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ ངོ་བོ་ ཉིད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

en: Emptiness of the essential nature of non-entities
comment_en: Eighteenth of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
A king.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
One of the factors of awakening. It is also included in the lists of the five spiritual faculties, the five strengths, and the seven riches.
One of the five powers and five abilities.

Here “faith” is not used so much in the sense of “religious faith,” but rather as when one says, “I have faith in you” or “I have faith in your good qualities.” It is often explained as “a good disposition of the mind” (cetasaḥ prasādaḥ) toward something and is occasionally divided into three types: faith as the conviction that something exists, faith as the conviction that something has good qualities, and faith as the conviction that something with good qualities can be obtained.
First of the five faculties.
First of the five powers.

en: Searching for the Vessel of Trust
comment_en: A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
According to the Mahāyāna, one of the seven types of noble beings (āryapudgala), and also one of the twenty types of members of the sangha (viṃśatiprabhedasaṃgha).
A river in the south of Jambudvīpa.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

term: དཔག་ ཏུ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ གསེར་མདོག་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ

comment_en: A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s assembly.
A lake near Sudharma.

A mythical tree granting all desires. The Kalpavṛkṣa is usually depicted as being located in a heaven or Indra’s paradise, but the wish-fulfilling tree mentioned in The Limits of Life is said to be located in Uttarukuru.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of a past king, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Bright Light.
(1) A queen of King Sarvārthasiddha. (dpag med spos) (2) A bodhisattva disciple of King of the Lunar Lamp. (dpag med dbyangs)
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
The seventy-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of the first meditative stability.
A special type of samādhi (meditative absorption).
One of the 35 buddhas of confession.

term: དཔའ་ བརྟན་པ་ -འི་ སྡེ་ མཚོན་ཆ་ -ས་ ཉོན་མོངས་པ་ སེལ་བ
en: Leader of Loyal Heroes Who Uses Weapons to Eliminate Afflictions
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Powerful.
The name of all the buddhas who had been followers of King Mahābala in a previous lifetime.
A king in the distant past.
Another name for Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa; he is called “sole” because, apart from his consort, he is not accompanied by the deities of the maṇḍala.
An epithet of a male deity (it may also apply to his mantra) who appears in his maṇḍala without a retinue.
Emanation of Mañjuśrī; the title deity of the SEV. He is visualized in the rituals of the 41st and 46th mantras of the SEV.
Male deity visualized with a consort, but without the maṇḍala deities.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the two brothers in Mathurā who are predicted by the Buddha to build a monastery in the future.
A certain nāga king and the hermitage that bears his name.
“Valiant, heroic, manly”; an epithet applied to male deities of wrathful aspect.
Closely associated with notions of virility, this term can denote the male deity of the maṇḍala (whose consort is the Vidyā) or the yogī who practices this mode of Tantra.
A mariner who is the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 25.
A king contemporary with the Buddha.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A bodhisattva disciple of King Who Transcends the Light of Mount Meru.
A bodhisattva who only appears in passing in the Samādhirāja, and in no other sūtra.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Devoid of Sorrow.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
“Heroic Rank”; two different individuals in this sūtra: (1) a universal monarch of the past and (2) a bodhisattva disciple of King Who Transcends the Light of Mount Meru.
A Magadhan king, the successor of Viśoka.
A bodhisattva.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A country.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
A monk.

term: དཔལ་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

en: Glorious with Surrounding Fragrance and Light
comment_en: See “Samantāvabhāsa­śrī.”
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK. His name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “Glorious with Surrounding Fragrance and Light.”

term: དཔལ་ ཀུན་ ནས་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva from a western realm.
A buddha in the eastern direction.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A king in the distant past.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha in the distant past. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-3100.
A cakravartin’s precious queen in the distant past.

term: དཔལ་ གྱི་ བེ་ འུ་ རྡོ་རྗེ་ འོད་འཕྲོ་ བས་ བརྒྱན་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
An auspicious symbol, taking the form of an endless knot, indicative of eternity.

Literally “the favorite of the glorious one,” or (as translated into Tibetan) “the calf of the glorious one.” This is an auspicious mark that in Indian Buddhism was said to be formed from a curl of hair on the breast and was depicted in a shape that resembles the fleur-de-lis. In Tibet it is usually represented as an eternal knot. It is also one of the principal attributes of Viṣṇu.
An auspicious sign found on the chest of the Buddha. In non-Buddhist traditions it is also found on the chest of certain deities, such as Viṣṇu.
A special symbol, often represented as an endless knot in the Tibetan tradition.

Literally “the favorite of the glorious one” or (as translated into Tibetan) “the calf of the glorious one.” This is an auspicious mark that in Indian Buddhism was said to be formed from a curl of hair on the breast and was depicted in a shape that resembles the fleur-de-lis. In Tibet it is usually represented as an eternal knot. It is also one of the principal attributes of Viṣṇu.
A girl, one of the two kalyāṇamitras in Chapter 53.
The twenty-fourth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Śiridevamati.

term: དཔལ་ གྱི་ མཆོག་ མི་ འམ་ ཅི་ མོ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ དང་ ལྷ་མ་ ཡིན་ མོ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ མཆོག

comment_en: A buddha in the distant past. BHS: Śirisa Mudra.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

en: Endowed with the Moon of Glory

comment_en: A buddha in a northwestern realm.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
The ancient country roughly corresponding to the Guntur district in Andhra Pradesh; also the name of various mountains.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Meruarciśiri.
Epithet of Lakṣmī, Hindu goddess of wealth and prosperity and consort of Viṣṇu.

The goddess of royal splendor, equated with Lakṣmī; in the Bhūtaḍāmara maṇḍala she is one of the eight goddesses of offerings.
A goddess; a yakṣiṇī in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).

Apart from Butön’s inclusion of Palgyi Lhünpo in his list of translators, there does not appear to be much biographical information available on this ninth-century translator. In addition to his work on the vinaya, Palgyi Lhünpo translated at least two Mahāyāna sūtras (the Buddhapiṭakaduḥśīlanigraha and the Drumakinnararājaparipṛcchā ), several chapters of dhāraṇī, and several works in verse included in the Tengyur. The colophons of his translations indicate that Paltsek revised some of his translations, including the Vinayavastu and the Bhikṣuṇī Vinayavibhaṅga , to either complete unfinished work or reflect newly adopted standards.
One of the greatest Tibetan translators. He lived in the eighth to ninth century. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-058-006.html#UT22084-058-006-827.
A member of the Tibetan translation group of the Vinayavastu of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya.

comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Pile of Śrīgarbha Jewels.

A buddha.
A type of red-colored precious gemstone.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A kind of gem, reddish in color.

en: Golden Light of the Glorious Essence
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A king in the distant past.
A king, who was a past life of the Buddha. He was a bodhisattva renowned for his unstinting generosity and spiritual resolve.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
An unidentified mountain only mentioned in this sūtra. Possibly an alternative name for one of the seven golden mountain ranges encircling Sumeru.
One of the names of Lakṣmī.

One of the four retinue goddesses of Siddhaikavīra.

Nineteenth of the eighty minor marks.

Lit. “Splendor and Wealth.” A young merchant from Vārāṇasī.
One of King Bimbisāra’s queens. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-005.html#UT22084-055-005-139.
A buddha who lives in an eastern buddha realm called Sorrowless.
(1) A buddha (dpal bzang). (2) A bodhisattva (dpal bzang po).
An upāsikā in Dhanyākara; also an eminent daughter in Dhanyākara.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one He Who Is Proclaimed King of the Pile of Śrīgarbha Jewels.

One of the greatest Tibetan translators, most commonly known as Kawa Paltsek. Kawa Paltsek lived in the eighth to ninth century. Translating numerous canonical texts, both sūtra and tantra, he became one of the most active translators of his time. He was one of the initial seven Tibetans to be ordained during the founding of the first Tibetan monastery of Samyé.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A buddha from the east.
A buddha.

Paltsek, from the village of Kawa north of Lhasa, was one of Tibet’s preeminent translators. He was one of the first seven Tibetans to be ordained by Śāntarakṣita and is counted as one of Guru Rinpoche’s twenty-five close disciples. In a famous verse by Ngok Lotsawa, Paltsek is named with Chokro Luyi Gyaltsen and Zhang Nanam Yeshé as part of a group of translators whose skills were surpassed only by Vairotsana. He translated works from a wide variety of genres, including sūtra, śāstra, vinaya, and tantra and was an author himself (for a list of his translations and writings, see Martin, 2011). Paltsek was also one of the most important editors of the early period, one of nine translators installed by Trisong Deutsen to supervise the translation of the Tripiṭaka and help catalogue translated works for the first two of three imperial catalogs (the ldan kar ma and bsam yas mchims phu ma catalogs, which were probably the initiative of Tride Songtsen; see Raine, 2010, 8).
A buddha.
One of the proofreaders of the Tibetan translation of the Vinayavastu of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya.

Paltsek, from the village of Kawa north of Lhasa, was one of Tibet’s preeminent translators. He was one of the first seven Tibetans to be ordained by Śāntarakṣita and is counted as one of Guru Rinpoche’s twenty-five close disciples. In a famous verse by Ngok Lotsawa, Paltsek is named along with Chokro Lui Gyaltsen and Zhang Nanam Yeshé as part of a group of translators whose skills were surpassed only by Vairotsana. He translated works from a wide variety of genres, including sūtra, śāstra, vinaya, and tantra, and was an author himself. Paltsek was also one of the most important editors of the early period, one of nine translators installed by Trisong Detsen to supervise the translation of the Tripiṭaka and help catalog translated works for the first two of three imperial catalogs (the ldan kar ma and bsam yas mchims phu ma catalogs).
Tibetan editor of the sūtra.
A monk; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A country northwest of Delhi.
The district around Sthāṇvīśvara.

In chapter 10 the name of a buddha in the past. In chapter 44 the name of one of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

The name, in his previous lifetime as a monk, of the buddha named Jewel Moon Performing Enlightened Actions.

A buddha.

A set of eighty bodily characteristics and insignia borne by both buddhas and universal emperors. They are considered “minor” in terms of being secondary to the thirty-two marks of a great being.

A set of eighty bodily characteristics and insignia borne by both buddhas and universal monarchs. For a comprehensive list of the eighty marks see Negi (3333). These are considered “minor” in terms of being secondary to the “thirty-two signs of great persons.” For a comprehensive list of the eighty and thirty-two marks see Berzin (2012).
These characteristics of a supreme being are eighty in number and include such details as the redness of the fingernails and the blackness of the hair.
These characteristics of a supreme being are eighty in number and include such details as the redness of the fingernails and the blackness of the hair.
A buddha realm.
A forest at Sudharma.
The twelfth bodhisattva level.

A teacher associated with Maskari Gośāliputra and the doctrine of non-action (akriyāvāda), a type of antinomianism.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A night goddess.
The month of Caitra.
The month of Vaiśakha.
A solar month in the Indic calendar, roughly from mid-March to mid-April.
A particular form of Heruka; personification and the god of spring; name of an attendant on Kāmadeva.

en: Support for miraculous ability combining meditative stability of scrutiny with the formative force of exertion
comment_en: Fourth of the four supports for miraculous abilities.
A particular type of jewel with great magical powers. The name suggests the ability to enchant or enthrall, or to produce things at will.
A rainbow.

Foretold as the name of a future monarch of Kauśāmbī, during the time of the Dharma’s disappearance from our world. In either case not to be confused with Mahendra or Mahā­sena, neither Mahendrasena, the King of Videha; Mahendrasena, the prince of Potalaka; or Mahendrasena, the king of Vārāṇasī.

Typically given as the name of the King of Videha, son of King Mahendra, and a previous incarnation of the Buddha. Not to be confused with Mahendra or Mahā­sena; or with Mahendrasena, a future monarch of Kauśāmbī; Mahendrasena, the prince of Potalaka; or Mahendrasena, the king of Vārāṇasī.
King of Vārāṇasī, a previous incarnation of the Buddha.

A previous incarnation of the Buddha, who was son of King Mahendra, the ruler of the city of Potalaka. Not to be confused with Mahendra or Mahā­sena., or with Mahendrasena, a future monarch of Kauśāmbī; Mahendrasena, the king of Videha; or Mahendrasena, the king of Vārāṇasī.
Queen and wife of King Mahendrasena of Videha

King of the city of Potalaka, father of Mahendrasena.

Identified as Mahendravarman I of Kāñci, a Pallava king of the early seventh century; this name is shared also by the Khmer king Mahendravarman.
Mahendra or Mahendrāditya is another name of the Gupta emperor Kumāragupta.

comment_en: Eighth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.

Faith, diligence, mindfulness, absorption, and insight. These are the same as the five powers at a lesser stage of development.

King of the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. Also known as Śakra.

The lord of the devas, the principal deity in the Vedas. Indra and Brahmā were the two most important deities in the Buddha’s lifetime, and were later eclipsed by the increasing importance of Śiva and Viṣṇu.
Another name for Śakra.
King of the gods of Trāyastriṃśa, usually referred to by the name “Śakra.”
(1) A god, also known as “Śakra.” (2) A brahmin. (3) A buddha in the past.

A major god in the Vedic pantheon, he dwindled in importance after Vedism was transformed into Hinduism in the early A.D. centuries. However, he was reinstated in Buddhist sūtras as the king of the gods and as a disciple of the Buddha and protector of the Dharma and its practicers.
The chief god in the realm of Thirty-Three and Hindu deity. Also known as Śakra.
Name of a god.

One of a list of five qualities cultivated on the first two stages of the path of joining (faith, diligence, mindfulness, absorption, and knowledge). These are similar to the five strengths but in a lesser stage of development.
A bodhisattva.
Another name of Śakra.
A god.

A Vedic god who eventually emerged as one of the most important in the Vedic pantheon; Indra retains his role as the “King of the Gods” in Buddhist literature, where he is often referred to by the name Śakra
The chief god in the realm of Thirty-three and Hindu deity (personification of the sun). Also called Śakra.
See “Śakra.”

The deity, also called Mahendra (“Lord of the Devas”), who dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. He is also known as Śakra (Tib. brgya byin, “Hundred Offerings”). Śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu (“one who has performed a hundred sacrifices”). The highest Vedic sacrifice was the horse-sacrifice ritual, and there is a tradition that Indra became the lord of the gods through performing them.
The god Indra; Indra is often referred to by the epithet Śakra; when used in the plural it refers to a class of gods; The name of an ancient Buddhist king; one of the Buddhist mleccha kings.
Indra is the Vedic king of the gods of the atmosphere or sky. Indra was incorporated into the Buddhist pantheon as a guardian of the Dharma and the king of the deva realm.

A Vedic god who eventually emerged as one of the most important in the Vedic pantheon; Indra retains his role as the “Lord of the Gods” in Buddhist literature, where he is often referred to by the name Śakra.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Indra guards the eastern quarter.
A buddha realm.
Name of the twenty-fifth meditative stability.
A yakṣa lord.

One of the most frequently used names for Śiva. A deity of the jungles, named Rudra in the Vedas, he rose to prominence in the Purāṇic literature at the beginning of the first millennium. Often synonymous with Maheśvara, though sometimes presented as separate deities.
One of the most frequently used names for Śiva. A deity of the jungles, named Rudra in the Vedas, he rose to prominence in the Purāṇic literature at the beginning of the first millennium.

One of the most frequently used names for Śiva. A deity of the jungles, named Rudra in the Vedas, he rose to prominence in the Purāṇic literature at the beginning of the first millennium.
Literally “lord,” this term is an epithet for the god Śiva, but functions more generally in Buddhist texts as a generalized “supreme being” to whom the creation of the universe is attributed.
One of the most frequently used names for Śiva. A deity of the jungles, named Rudra in the Vedas, he rose to prominence in the Purāṇic literature at the beginning of the first millennium.
Literally “lord,” this term is an epithet for the god Śiva, but functions more generally in Buddhist texts as a generalized “supreme being” to whom the creation of the universe is attributed.
The lord of the world; the permanent, single agent who created the universe; God as accepted by theistic brahmanical schools.

One of the principal three Hindu gods.
Major deity in the pantheon of the classical Indian religious traditions. He is sometimes portrayed as one part of the divine triad, which also includes Brahmā and Viṣṇu.

One of the most frequently used names for Śiva. A deity of the jungles, named Rudra in the Vedas, he rose to prominence in the Purāṇic literature at the beginning of the first millennium. Often synonymous with Īśvara, but sometimes presented as a separate deity.

‟Great Lord,” one of the epithets of Śiva.
A god.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha from the northeast.
‟Great Lord Mahādeva,” one of the epithets of Śiva.
A brahmin who teaches the dhāraṇī known as The Mother of Avalokiteśvara in Sukhāvatī, the realm of the Buddha Amitābha.
The names of two of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The name of a future buddha in this kalpa.

Powers attained by bodhisattvas on the path: power over life, karma, materials, devotion, aspiration, miracles, birth, Dharma, mind, and wisdom. Not to be confused with the ten strengths, which are qualities of buddhahood.

Powers attained by bodhisattvas on the path: power over life, karma, materials, devotion, aspiration, miracles, birth, Dharma, mind, and wisdom. Not to be confused with the ten strengths (bala, stobs) which are qualities of buddhahood.
The ten powers gained by bodhisattvas as they progress on the path: life, deeds, necessities, devotion, aspiration, miraculous abilities, birth, doctrine, mind, and wisdom.

Powers attained by bodhisattvas on the path. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-061-005.html#UT22084-061-005-164. Not to be confused with the ten strengths (bala, stobs) which are qualities of buddhahood.
An epithet of Śiva.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Īśāna guards the northeast quarter.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Īśāna guards the northeast quarter.

term: དབང་ བསྐུར་བ་ ཐོབ་པ་ -འི་ བྱང་ཆུབ་ སེམས་དཔའ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གཞག་པ
en: Category of the bodhisattva who has received consecration

comment_en: The principal deity in the Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin paradise. It is the highest paradise in the desire realm.
The king of gods in the Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations.
The king of gods in the Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations (Skt. Paranirmita­vaśavartin).
One of the subtle channels in the body.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
The wife of Indra; also the name of an apsaras.
One of the great mātṛs. Elsewhere her name is given as “Indrāṇī.”
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
One of the great mātṛs.
The lord of mātṛs; one of the kings of the Nāgasena dynasty, identified with Īśānavarman.
‟Ruler,” an epithet of Rudra.

term: དབང་ སྒྱུར་ མཆོད་སྦྱིན་ གྲགས་པ་ -འི་ མཆོད་སྡོང་ བློ
comment_en: The hundred-and-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
The principal deity in the Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin paradise, the highest paradise in the desire realm. The deity himself is also called Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin.
“Mastery.” The highest paradise in the desire realm, so named because the inhabitants have power over the emanations of others. Also called Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin.
A buddha.

en: Head is [large], similar to a parasol
comment_en: Forty-fifth of the eighty minor marks.
A river in Enjoyment of Scents.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A river on Triple Horns.
A town in Videha.

Derived from the Sanskrit expression madhyamapratipad, meaning the “Middle Way” between the extremes of eternalism and nihilism, Madhyamaka is one of the most influential among the schools of Indian Buddhist philosophy since it emphasizes the deconstruction of all conceptual elaboration and the realization of emptiness. Various sub-schools evolved in India and Tibet, based on distinctions between relative and ultimate truth, the logical methodologies of reduction ad absurdum and syllogistic reasoning, and views concerning the nature of buddha attributes.
An area in Kuru.
A shrine built to commemorate the Buddha’s going forth.

term: དབུ་སྐྲ་ མཐོན་ ཏིང་ ལ་འཇམ་ ཞིང་ རིང་བ
en: Hair of their heads is bluish black, soft, and long
comment_en: Seventy-second of the eighty minor marks.
“Breath.” The previous incarnation of the great king Dhṛtarāṣṭra as a nāga king who lived on Mount Meru, he eventually went for refuge and took the fundamental precepts.
“Great Breath.” The previous incarnation of the great king Virūdhaka as a nāga king who lived on Mount Meru, and who eventually went for refuge and took the fundamental precepts.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A nāga.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the goddesses from Vajrapāṇī’s retinue in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī.
A village.
The “central region,” which seems to refer to all the regions and countries between the Vindhya and Himālaya mountains.
School based on Madhyamaka, and followers of that school.
Teaching of the Middle Way.

The “Analysis of the Middle and the Extremes,” it is an important work of Vijñānavāda philosophy, said to have been received as a revelation from the future Buddha Maitreya by the great scholar and saint, Āryāsaṅga, after twelve years of meditation.

It is traditionally categorized as being of three types: (1) detachment or seclusion of the body (kāyaviveka), which refers to remaining in solitude free from desirous or disturbing objects; (2) detachment or seclusion of the mind (cittaviveka), which is mental detachment from desirous or disturbing objects; and, (3) detachment or seclusion from the “substrate” (upadhiviveka), which indicates detachment from all things that perpetuate rebirth, including the five aggregates, the kleśas, karma, etc. This last category is what is being referenced here.
Name of a teacher in a story the Buddha tells.
A lake near Sudharma.
A buddha.

term: དབྱངས་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ བསྒྲིབས་པ་ མེད་ ཅིང་ ང་རོ་ སྙན་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A prince in the distant past.
One of the māras.
The hundred-and-fourth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.

term: དབྱངས་ ཀྱི་ ཡན་ལག་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཟིལ་ གྱིས་ གནོན་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
en: Melody That Eclipses All Types of Song
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
The goddess of music and eloquence. The Sanskrit name means “she who has flow,” or “she who has a body of water.” She was originally the personification of the Punjab river of that name.
Hindu goddess of art and wisdom, consort of Brahmā.
Goddess of learning; she is visualized as part of the Perfection of Wisdom practice.
Literally, “The Melodious One.” The goddess of eloquence and learning.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one White as the Moon.
Goddess of learning; one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs who form the retinue of Vasudharā.
A river goddess.
The Indian goddess of eloquence and music. Also translated elsewhere as dbyangs can.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Flowered.
A buddha in the distant past.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Superior to All Cymbals.

en: Voice is deep [like the trumpet of an elephant or the rolling of thunder]
comment_en: Twenty-fifth of the eighty minor marks; the additional simile comes from the Sanskrit term used in this list in other sūtras.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of Māra’s daughters.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Gandharva king present at the teaching of the sūtra.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
The chief minister of Magadha.
The month of Āṣāḍha.

term: དབྱར་ སྤྲིན་ རབ་ཏུ་ དང་བ་ -འི་ ཆུ་ འབབ་པ
comment_en: A river on Saṅkāśa.
A certain sea captain during the reign of King Brahmadatta (past), father of Wealth’s Delight.

(Fourth century). The younger brother of Āryāsaṅga, he was one of the greatest scholars in Buddhist history, author of the Abhi­dharma­kośa, the most definitive work on the Abhidharma, and later of numerous important works on the Vijñānavāda philosophy.
The fourth-century pupil and brother of Asaṅga and an important author and founder of the Yogācāra tradition.

Previous incarnation of the Buddha, a sea captain during the reign of King Brahmadatta, and son of Wealth the sea captain. He saved the lives of a number of sailors by drowning himself so that they could use his floating corpse as a buoy to safely reach shore.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
A certain nāga, son of the nāga king Vasu.
An arhat monk whose past virtuous deeds ripened into countless glories both human and divine.
Epithet of Indra; when used in the plural it refers to a class of gods.
This figure is identified in the Blue Annals with Songtsen Gampo, the first Tibetan Buddhist king.

en: Certainty in the Expanse of Reality
comment_en: Name of the eighth meditative stability.
A yakṣa king
A period of 24 minutes. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-077-002.html#UT22084-077-002-162.
A staff; punishment; the duration of a single breath (from the moment of inhalation until the moment of the next inhalation).
A brahmin.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi and a mantra deity.
Name of a buddha.
Mahāvyutpatti 5192.
A buddha in the distant past, as rendered in verse. In prose he is called Dharma­cakra­nirghoṣa­gagana­pradīpa­rāja.

term: དམ་ཆོས་ ཡིད་བཞིན་ ནོར་བུ་ ཐར་པ་ རིན་པོ་ཆེ་ -འི་ རྒྱན
en: An Adornment for the Precious Path to Liberation
comment_en: A celebrated text on the graduated path by Gampopa, also known as the Dakpo Thargyen (dwags po thar rgyan).
(1) A queen of King Sarvārthasiddha. (dam pa sna tshogs kyi dbyangs; 眾妙音) (2) A son of King Sarvārthasiddha. (dam pa’i dbyangs; 妙音)
(1) A buddha in the past (dam pa). (2) A young brahmin who was the Buddha in a former life (bla ma).

term: དམ་པ་ -འི་ ཆོས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ མི་ བརྗེད་པ་ -ར་ གནས་པ
comment_en: The name of a bodhisattva. “Not-Forgetting All the Sacred Teachings”
An absorption.
The Buddhadharma or the Buddha’s teachings.
The Buddhadharma or the Buddha’s teachings.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Sustenance.
The forty-fourth buddha in a realm in the distant past, also one of countless buddhas in another past kalpa. BHS verse: Vara­lakṣaṇa­śiri.
Another name of the Rāṣṭrapāla­paripṛcchā­sūtra.
One of the mantra deities.
The form of the deity generated and visualized by the practitioner.
Name of a buddha.
King of Kauśāmbī and father of Udayana.

The name of an ancient city, the capital of Magadha was moved to Pāṭaliputra during the Mauryan expansion, and Pāṭaliputra would then serve as the capital of King Aśoka’s Maurya empire. Identified with the modern Indian city of Patna.
A river in the ephemeral hell known as Red.
(1) An ocean between Videha and Jambudvīpa. (2) An ocean off Jambudvīpa. (3) A river in Jambudvīpa. (4) An ephemeral hell to the north of Jambudvīpa.

This Buddha who sends the previous life of Śākyamuni to Buddha Padmottama. However, the Tibetan had dmar po’i mchog, “supreme red,” which would have been a translation of Raktottama, evidently a mistake for Ratnottama, which would have been translated as nor bu’i mchog or rin chen mchog.
A city on the Ganges that became the capital of Magadha after Rājagṛha.
A shrine in Pāṭali Village.
A village which eventually became Pāṭaliputra, the capital of Magadha.
One of the great piśācīs.

comment_en: A great bodhisattva.

A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A bodhisattva in a northeastern realm.

The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
A teaching on the state of realization in which a practitioner no longer perceives reified entities.
The name of a hell realm. One of the eight hot hells.
The second of the eight hot hells.
The last and most severe of the eight hot hells.
The sixth of the eight hot hells.
The first of the eight hot hells.

The great hells are also often called hot hells in secondary literature because beings there suffer from heat and being burned. They are Wailing, Loud Wailing, Black Thread, Crushing, Revival, Heat, Intense Heat, and Incessant Torture. Within in the Kangyur, one elaborate description of the eight hells is found in The Application of Mindfulness of the Sacred Dharma (Toh 287), 2.294–2.1280.
One of the rāśis.

term: དར་དཀར་ ལྟ་བུ་ -འི་ རལ་པ་ ཅན་ ཡང་ ལག་ མ་སྨད་པ

One of the great piśācīs.
(1) A king in the future. (2) A ṛṣi.

One of the kings of the nāgas.

A pond on Equal Peaks.
An ocean between Kuru and Godānīya.
A Hindu goddess.
Another name for the channel carrying semen.
A rākṣasī in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
“The great conch shell.” One of the four great treasures and the being who presides over it.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the rāśis.
One of the grahas.
A certain gandharva king, father of Princess Suprabhā.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
‟Lord of the Cremation Ground,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
One of the grahas.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A brahmin devotee of Buddhism.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
In the list of buddhas from whom Śākyamuni received the Samādhirāja, this name appears twice, perhaps in error. Translated the first time in Tibetan as dul rab, and the second time as shin tu dul.
A town in Videha.
A forest in Dwelling on Forest Riverbanks.

comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
