The celestial musicians who reside in the two heavens at the very top of Mount Meru, or beings in the bardo who feed on odors.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes known as “celestial musicians.”
Semidivine class of being, under the control of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, the Great King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as heavenly musicians.
A class of generally benevolent semi-divine beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.
A semidivine class of beings that are generally identified as ethereal celestial musicians.
Lower class of divine being, under the control of the Guardian King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”

Lit. “smell eater.” Gandharvas are a class of spirits and minor gods (deva) in both Hindu and Buddhist cosmologies. They are supposedly messengers, singers and skilled musicians and dancers. Often closely associated with various nature-spirits (yakṣa), they are on occasion depicted as disturbing to monks practicing meditation.

In Indian religious mythology, a class of nonhuman beings who often appear as semidivine celestial musicians. The same term is used in certain Buddhist texts in a quite different sense: to denote a disembodied sentient being or anguished spirit in the intermediate state between two lives, seeking the conditions for a new birth as a human or other kind of embodied being.
A class of spirits, sometimes described as celestial musicians. In other contexts the term can also refer to beings in the bardo-state.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as “heavenly musicians.”
Lit. “scent-eater.” A heavenly musician.
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.

The term generally refers to a class of non-human beings sometimes known as “celestial musicians.” In Abhidharma cosmology, the term is also used to refer to the mental body assumed by any sentient being in the realm of desire (kāma­dhātu) during the intermediate state between death and rebirth. Gandharvas are said to live on fragrances in the desire realm, hence the Tibetan translation dri za, meaning “scent eater.”

Here and very frequently in the canonical texts, a type of non-human, semi-divine celestial being or spirit. The term is also used to refer to the consciousness of a being between death and the next rebirth.
The name of a kind of preta (ghost). These spirits are said to live on odours, hence their name “smell-eater.” Known for their music.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as “celestial musicians.”
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.

Gandharvas (literally “odor eaters”) are generally regarded as a class of menacing divine offspring, but in Abhidharma the term is often used differently—as a synonym for the mental body assumed by any sentient being of the world system of desire (kāma­dhātu) during the intermediate state between death and rebirth.
Class of ethereal beings, living on scents.
Gandharvas, lit. “smell-eaters.” A class of deities known for being skilled musicians. Also the name of spirits in the bardo state.
Semidivine celestial musicians.
Lower class of divine beings said to dwell in the east, under the jurisdiction of the Great King Dhṛtarāṣṭra. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
Lower class of divine being, under the control of the Guardian King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
A lower class of divine being, under the control of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, the Great King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
A class of sentient being who lives on scents; literally “smell eater.” Also a type of celestial musician living on the rim of Mt. Sumeru.
Gandharvas, literally “smell eaters,” are a class of spirits, sometimes described as celestial musicians. In other contexts the term can also refer to beings in the bardo state.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as heavenly musicians.
A class of celestial beings.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes known as “celestial musicians.”
Gandharvas, literally “smell-eaters,” are a class of spirits, sometimes described as celestial musicians. In other contexts the term can also refer to beings in the bardo-state.

Class of beings under the control of the King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.” This term can also refer to beings who have died and not yet taken rebirth.
A class of celestial spirits and minor gods (deva) in both Hindu and Buddhist cosmologies who are said to live on scents. They are messengers, singers, and skilled musicians and dancers.

Here and very frequently in the canonical texts, a type of non-human, semi-divine celestial being or spirit. In a very few texts (but not this one), e.g. The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant , the term is also used to refer to the consciousness of a being between death and the next rebirth.

A class of nonhuman beings, literally “smell-eaters,” who are sometimes seen as anguished spirits but more often appear, as in many passages in this text, as semi-divine celestial musicians. The same term is used in other passages in a quite different sense: to denote a disembodied sentient being in the intermediate state between two lives, seeking the conditions for a new birth as a human or other kind of embodied being.
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as heavenly musicians.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as heavenly musicians.
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.
A class of nonhuman beings who are particularly renowned as celestial musicians.
A class of spirit beings that dwell in the heavens.
A class of spirit beings that dwell in the heavens.
A class of celestial beings.
Lower class of divine beings under the control of the Guardian King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
A class of semidivine beings associated with music and singing.
One of the rāśis.
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as heavenly musicians.
A race of deities who are renowned to be great musicians and gain their nutrition through smells.
A race of deities who are renowned to be great musicians and gain their nutrition through smells.
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.
A type of nonhuman being often rendered as “celestial musicians” who fly through space and serve as muscians for the gods.
A class of nonhuman beings known for their musical skills.
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as heavenly musicians.

Usually, a particular category of semi-divine celestial being, one of the four kinds on the four sides of Mount Meru; but in the context of the process of rebirth (e.g. in 1.86 in this sūtra), gandharva refers to the consciousness of the being between death and the next rebirth.
Lower class of divine being, under the control of the Guardian King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
A class of semidivine beings sometimes referred to as “celestial musicians.”
Lower class of divine beings, under the control of the Guardian King of the East. Capable of flight, they are often described as “celestial musicians.”
See “gandharva.”
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A buddha in the distant past.
A forest in Total Pleasure.
A buddha realm.
An area in Kuru.
A forest on the lower level of Living on the Peak.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The name of a world realm.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A buddha.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
The name of a worldly deity who is identified variously as an attendant of Skanda, an attendant of Śiva, a piśāca attendant of Kubera, and a rākṣasa.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods.

A certain band of monks of the Buddha’s order who appear throughout the vinaya literature as examples of those who break the monastic rules. In Pāli their names are given as Assaji, Punabbasu, Panduka, Lohitaka, Mettiya, and Bhummaja. The Hundred Deeds contains one story in which they trick the nun Sthūlanandā into thinking that they can help her attain magical powers.
Six ill-behaved monks whose conduct often causes the Buddha’s establishment of new rules: Nanda, Upananda, Punarvasu, Chanda, Aśvaka, and Udāyin.
The first of the four stages of penetrative insight.
One of the fourfold classification of ways in which beings are born.
Third of the four modes of birth.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
Tibetan translator who worked on a large number of translations during the imperial period.

Butön includes the Kashmiri preceptor Dharmākara in his list of ninety-three paṇḍitas invited to Tibet to assist in the translation of the Buddhist scriptures. Tāranātha dates Dharmākara to the rule of *Vanapāla, son of Dharmapāla. With Paltsek, he translated two of Kalyāṇamitra’s works on Vinaya, the Vinayapraśnakārikā (’dul ba dri ba’i tshig le’ur byas pa, Toh 4134, Degé Tengyur, vol. SU, folios 70.b.3–74.b.5) and the Vinayapraśnaṭīkā (’dul ba dri ba rgya cher ’grel pa, Toh 4135, Degé Tengyur, vol. SU, folios 74.b.5–132.a.2).
One of the translators of the Tibetan Vinayavastu of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya.
Named as one of the editor-translators of this sūtra.
An Indian scholar from the eighth century named as one of the translators of this sūtra.
The Indian scholar who assisted with the translation of the text into Tibetan. His dates are unknown but he lived sometime during the late 10th century to the middle of the 11th century.
A mountain in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
Sansevieria roxburghiana.
One of the charnel grounds.
A mountain in Godānīya.

Nandi is the bull attendant of Śiva and the guardian of Śiva’s realm in Kailāsa. He is commonly depicted at Śaiva temples as a bull positioned outside of the main gate of the temple gazing in upon Śiva’s liṅga with utter devotion.
Jasminum arborescens. A species of jasmine that is a shrub and does not twine or climb. Its other common name is navamallika.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.

Indian scholar and practitioner (956 - 1041), a major figure in the transmission of tantric Buddhism to Tibet; earlier in his life he was an important paṇḍita of Nālandā, but left to become a yogi and siddha, the student of Tilopā, and later the teacher of Kukkuripa, Marpa, and others.
A town in ancient India where this sūtra is taught.
Śāriputra’s birthplace in Magadha. King Bimbisāra granted Śāriputra’s grandfather Māṭhara and father Tiṣya rights to this village as a victor’s spoils after debates held in his presence.
A village in Magadha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The name of an island.
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
In Rājagṛha, the son of King Bimbisāra’s elephant trainer Elephant Heart. He is tricked into giving back his precepts, then becomes ordained once again.
Citra Mounted on an Elephant’s name in a former life.
(1) An area in Kuru (nag po gsus pa). 2. One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment. (lto gnag), also called Raven’s Belly.

Not to be confused with the protectors in the later higher tantras in this sūtra, or with Śiva who also has this name (though then it has the alternative meaning of “Great Time”), in the Kāraṇḍavyūha these are dangerous spirits. Elsewhere they are also said to be servants of Śiva, which may be the meaning here as they are grouped with the mātṛ goddesses.
A Buddhist protector deity; also the name of one of the attendants on Śiva.
‟Great Death.” Most often considered a wrathful form of Avalokiteśvara, in the Bhūta­ḍāmara Tantra he is one of the wrathful forms of Śiva.

Mahākāla (“the great black one”) is both a name for one of the god Śiva’s wrathful manifestations and an important Buddhist protector deity. The Mahābhārata and Harivaṁśa list Mahākāla as one of Śiva’s attendants.
One of the deities invited to partake in the oblation offering.
A river to the south of Jambudvīpa.
An 11th or 12th century Buddhist commentator. Wrote Recollection: a commentary on the Mahāmāyā Tantra.
The nāga king who lauded Siddhārtha after he gave up his austerities and prepared to sit under the bodhi tree.
The son of Anāthapiṇḍada (Pali: Anāthapindika), the merchant who donated to the Buddha the land for the Jetavana Monastery.

The Kāla Mountains of Bhāratvarṣa (i.e., India) are listed in the Mahābhārata as the mountain ranges Vindhya (separating the Deccan from north India), Mahendra (the eastern Ghats), Malaya (southern half of the Western Ghats), Sahya (the northern half of the Western Ghats), Rakṣavat (northeast extension of the Vindhya), Pāripātra, and the Sūktimat (or Śuktimat), which is presumably another name for the one remaining significant mountain range, the Arbuda in the northwest.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
Kāla was the son of Anāthapiṇḍada (Pali: Anāthapindika), the merchant who donated to the Buddha the land for the Jetavana Monastery.
Another name of Kāla Mṛgāraputra, a disciple of the Buddha.
A city.
(1) A nāga king. (2) The son of Prince Viśvantara.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
A river in the hell called Raven Mouths.
An unvirtuous nāga king.

A certain dark-complected brahmin youth who became a sage, then heard the Dharma from the Buddha, became ordained, and manifested arhatship. Not to be confused with Black the yakṣa who also appears in his story, nor with Kāla the nāga king (whose name in Tib. is the same nag po).
A certain yakṣa tamed by the Buddha and subsequently sworn to protect the people of Rājagṛha. Not to be confused with Black the brahmin who also appears in his story, nor with Kāla the nāga king.
A certain nāga king who praised Gautama prior to his enlightenment. Not to be confused with Black (nag po), the yakṣa; nor with Black (nag po), the brahmin.
One of the ancient kings.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
A nāga king.
Grove offered to the Buddha by Kālaka, a wealthy man of Sāketa.
An elephant.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
A goddess; one of Durgā’s attendants.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
A goddess; a rākṣasī in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559); one of Durgā’s attendants.
1011–1064. His personal name was Tsultrim Gyalwa (tshul khrims rgyal ba). A translator who brought Atiśa to Tibet and wrote an important record of his travels to India.
A mountain on Videha.
One of the māras.
A forest in Moving in Mixed Environments.
A river on Great Slope.
A city in Videha.

term: ནགས་ཚལ་ གྱི་ མེ་ མུན་པ་ ལྟར་ འཁྲིགས་པ
en: Forest Fires Like an Enveloping Darkness
comment_en: One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A class of spirit being.
A class of spirit being.
A region in South India.
A queen of Rāhu, king of asuras.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A buddha realm.
A yakṣa.
A monk disciple of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A river.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A lake in Supreme Strength.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A great bodhisattva.
A householder, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 29.
One of the notorious “group of six’ monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct. Also known as Punarvasuka.
A nāga. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2562.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; the name of a pair of nakṣatras.
An nickname of Revata, a disciple of the Buddha.
The youngest brother of Śāriputra.
Śrāvaka arhat.
The youngest brother of Śāriputra.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Zeta Pisicum in the occidental tradition.
A disciple of the Buddha.
The name of a nakṣatra; also a yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
A bodhisattva.
Name of the twenty-second meditative stability.

en: Roar of the Arrays of Space
comment_en: A buddha.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད་ ཀྱི་ སྙོམས་འཇུག
en: Meditative absorption of the sense field of infinite space
comment_en: First of the four meditative absorptions.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད་ བསྒྲུབས་ ཏེ་ གནས་པ
en: One achieves and abides in the sense field of infinite space, thinking, ‘Space is infinite.’
comment_en: Fourth of the eight aspects of liberation. Also the fifth of the nine serial steps of meditative equipoise.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད་ ལ་ གནས་པ
en: Abides in the sense field of infinite space
comment_en: Seventh of the eight sense fields of mastery. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-209.
Name of the first of the four formless realms and of the first formless meditative absorption, so termed because in its preparatory phase limitless space is the object of meditation.
First of four states in the formless realm.

en: Sphere of the Infinity of Space
comment_en: First of the four heavens of the formless realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing one of the formless meditative absorptions.

en: Abode of the infinity of space
comment_en: A formless state, either a meditative state or its resultant realm of existence, i.e., a class of deities of the formless realm.
The first meditative state pertaining to the formless realm.

The first of the four states of imperturbability. In the formless realm (Skt. ārūpyadhātu), no bodies or materiality of any kind exist, only mind; rebirth there is the result of accomplishing four formless meditative absorptions (Skt. ārūpya­samāpatti; five absorptions, i.e., if one includes the stage of Skt. saṃjñā-vedayita-nirodha or nirodhasamāpatti).
Alt. “the activity field infinite as boundless space” (Rangjung Yeshe Dictionary). Here the Blessed One begins an enumeration of the four formless realm states.
One of the three lower formless realms among the four formless realms, so termed because in its preparatory phase infinite space is the object of meditation.

en: Sphere of the infinity of space
comment_en: First of the four formless absorptions.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
An absorption.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Lamp of the Sky of Dharma. Likely the same as the world system Palmyra Trees Reaching the Sky.
An area in Eyes Beyond the World.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A buddha in the southern direction.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ ལྟར་ ཆགས་པ་ མེད་ ལ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གྲོལ་ ཞིང་ གོས་པ་ མེད་པ
en: Unattached, Liberated, and Uncovered Like Space
comment_en: Name of the 111th meditative stability.
A semi-divine bird.
A class of divine creatures with the bodies of giant birds.
A supernatural being that is a gigantic bird with humanoid features.
As a personal name this refers to the deity who is said to be the ancestor of all birds and became the steed of Viṣṇu; he is also worshipped in his own right.
A class of nonhuman beings who have the form of eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally considered enemies of the nāgas.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A class of divine creatures with the bodies of giant birds.
A class of celestial birds with bodies half human and half bird.

Lower class of divine beings described as eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine beings described as eagle-like birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A class of nonhuman beings with the form of an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan.
A mythical creature which is half bird, half man, and is the enemy of serpents.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A kind of semidivine bird. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-like bird with a gigantic wing span. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas . In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought ambrosia from the heavens to Earth.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine beings, described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They are enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth..
Magical bird, which protects from snakes.
A class of nonhuman beings who have the form of eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans.
A mythical creature which is half bird, half man, and is the enemy of serpents.
Semidivine beings classified among the animals, they are a kind of fantastic bird akin to the eagle, and said to be enemies of nāgas and snakes.
A class of nonhuman beings who have the form of eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally considered enemies of the nāgas.

Lower class of divine beings described as eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine being,described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A class of divine creatures with the bodies of giant birds.
Mythical bird.
A kind of semidivine bird. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine beings described as eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are said to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
Classified among the animals, they are a kind of fantastic bird akin to the eagle, and said to be enemies of nāgas and snakes.

A class of nonhuman beings described as eagle-type birds with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

A class of supernatural being described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They are traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they are thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A class of divine creatures with the bodies of giant birds.
A large mythical bird.
A large mythical bird.
A class of celestial beings.
A class of divine creatures with the bodies of giant birds.
A celestial bird, enemy of serpents.
An epithet for the mythical, bird-like creature garuḍa.
A class of nonhuman beings who have the form of eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They are traditionally considered enemies of the nāgas.

A class of being described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine being, described as an eagle-type bird with a gigantic wingspan. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.

Lower class of divine beings, described as eagle-type birds with gigantic wingspans. They were traditionally enemies of the nāgas. In the Vedas, they were thought to have brought nectar from the heavens to earth.
A class of divine creatures with the bodies of giant birds.
One of the eight main bodhisattvas, the heart sons of the Buddha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Religious Practice.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A king in King of Thunderous Voice’s buddha realm.
The eleventh buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the distant past.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ -འི་ དཀྱིལ་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སེམས་པ
comment_en: The tathāgata of the northeastern buddhafield Pure Immaculate Dwelling.

en: Light Rays of the Space Sphere
comment_en: A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A god.
The eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past, and also the name of the sixty-second buddha in another kalpa. The Tibetan has dbyings in error for dbyangs for the sixty-second buddha.
Name of a nāga king. Also known as Gaganasvara.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ -འི་ དབྱིངས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཐ་ མྱི་ དད་པ་ -ར་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ དམྱིགས་པ་ -འི་ རིན་ཆེན་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ -ས་ བརྒྱན་པ་ -འི་ གཙུག་ཕུད
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ -འི་ དབྱིངས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ དབྱེ་ -ར་ མེད་པ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ ཤེས་པ་ -འི་ ནོར་བུ་ རིན་པོ་ཆེ་ -ས་ བརྒྱན་པ་ -འི་ གཙུག་ པུད
en: Crown Ornament Adorned by the Gem That Perceives the Indivisibility of All of Space
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A town in Videha.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
A nobleman in the retinue of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present with the Buddha at Śrāvastī, and also the name of a buddha in the distant past.

term: ནམ་མཁའ་ -འི་ མཛོད་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ བསྒྲིབས་པ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A bodhisattva.
Metaphorical expression for something unreal, illusionary.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
The name of a garuḍa.
A class of nonhuman beings, half-human and half-bird.
A buddha in the distant past.
The sixty-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
An important bodhisattva, his name means “essence of space.” He is one of the “eight great close sons” (aṣṭa­mahopa­putra, nye ba’i sras chen brgyad).
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A class of vidyādharas.
The forty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Gagana­megha­śirī.
A śrāvaka, the youngest brother of Śāriputra. Also known as Khadiravanīya. Elsewhere translated as nam gru.
A river to the south of Jambudvīpa.
A river in the Deccan (the modern Nerbudda).
A king who built stupas.
A river on Flocking Peacocks.
Azadirachta indica.
In the Tibetan, Śyāmā and Naṭi are confounded into one, sh+ya ma nu Di).
The western continent according to Buddhist cosmology. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-68.
The embryo in the second week of gestation.
A country.

(1) A king of the Pāla dynasty who ruled from 1077–1120 ce (rA ma phA la). (2) The alternate spelling, ne bai pA la, is tentatively identified to be the very same king of the Pāla dynasty. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-8447.
A river.
A river flowing past Bodhgaya.
The river where the Buddha used to meditate.
Name of the eightieth meditative stability.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A 13th century Tibetan historian. Personal name: Drakpa Mönlam Lodrö (grags pa smon lam blo gros).
During the time of Buddha Greatest of All, a certain mountain where seventy-seven thousand on the path of learning and the path of no more to learn pledged to stay during the rains.
One of the eight nāga kings.
“Great mass of wealth.” A precious householder of a cakravartin in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past.
A king in another world in the distant past.
King of an unspecified kingdom during the time of Buddha Dīpaṃkara.
Another name of King North Pañcāla.
A householder.
A certain householder in Rājagṛha during the time of the Buddha, he was father of Sudarśana.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: ནོར་ དང་ འབྲུ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ སྡུད་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ

comment_en: Name of a bodhisattva, “Wealth-Splendor.”
A buddha who lives in a buddha realm above called Moonlit.
Faith, discipline, generosity, learning, dignity, propriety, and wisdom.
The seven riches of noble beings: faith, morality, generosity, learning, modesty, humility, and insight.
The seven riches of noble beings: faith, discipline, generosity, learning, modesty, humility, and insight.
These are faith, diligence, discipline, modesty, learning, relinquishment, and insight.
The seven riches of noble beings: faith, discipline, generosity, learning, modesty, humility, and insight.
Faith, discipline, charity, knowledge, modesty, self-control, and wisdom.
The son of a prominent upāsaka, he is the main protagonist of the Gaṇḍavyūha Sūtra.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
A buddha.
A prince and a king who were the Buddha in former lives.
A certain trader from the country of Pāṭaliputra.
A yakṣa.
A village or town.
A brother of Kubera and a tutelary deity of merchants.
Name of a yakṣa general; brother of Pūrṇabhadra in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
God of wealth.
A buddha from the west.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A mountain in Moving in Vast Environments.
One of the tathāgatas.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.

term: ནོར་བུ་ རྣམ་པ་ སྣ་ཚོགས་ ཀྱིས་ མཛེས་པ་ -ར་ བྱས་པ་ -འི་ ཅོད་པན་ ཐོགས་པ

comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Jewel Flame.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Shining Star Lamp.
A nāga king.
A bodhisattva.
A mountain in Total Pleasure.

term: ནོར་བུ་ -འི་ ཆ་ཤས་ རྣམས་ ཀྱིས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ བཀྲ་བ
comment_en: A mountain in Total Pleasure.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A bodhisattva.
A class of asuras.
(1) A forest in Endowed with Migration (nor bu’i nags). (2) A forest on the upper level of Living on the Peak (rin po che’i nags).
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
“Jewel Light,” a certain young god who in the garden of Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī scattered flowers over the Buddha, sat before him to listen to the Dharma, and manifested stream entry.
A mountain in Godānīya.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Discriminating Intellect attains buddhahood.
Refers to Dwelling in Essence of Jewels.
A lake in Total Pleasure.
Name of a yakṣa.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Nāga king, well known in Indian mythology as being the serpent coiled around Meru that was used to churn the ocean at the origin of the world.
A nāga king, well known in Indian mythology as being the serpent coiled around Meru that was used to churn the ocean at the origin of the world.
(1) A virtuous nāga king (nor rgyas kyi bu). (2) A nāga who visits Saṅkāśa Mountain (bA su ki).
One of eight mythological nāga kings.
A king of the nāgas.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
One of the eight nāga kings.
Name of a nāga king.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A king at the time of the Buddha Ratnaśikhin.
The name of a nakṣatra.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An elephant.
An elephant who was sent to kill the Buddha.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode; one of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A Hindu and Buddhist god of wealth.
Epithet of Kubera.
Another name for Dravya Mallaputra, a disciple of the Buddha.
A brahmin.
A village.
A fast-growing fig tree that can quickly become a large tree. It features prominently in Indian stories and myths.
The Buddha’s father, King Śuddhodana, donated this park on the outskirts of the Śākya kingdom of Kapilavastu, in present day Nepal, to the Buddhist community.
Unidentified river, though there are Tibetan texts that use this name to refer to the source of the Brahmaputra.
A river.
A city in Jambudvīpa; present day Patna.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the ministers of King Nanda.
Śukra is both the planet Venus and the guru of the asuras. In the Vaiśnavite literature, he loses an eye from his encounter with the dwarf incarnation of Viṣṇu. The Sanskrit also means “bright.”
The planet Venus.
See “Śukra.”
A Tibetan translator, particularly known for translating important Mādhyamika texts, circa 1055–1145.
A Tibetan translator, particularly known for translating important Mādhyamika texts, circa 1055–1145.

The name of a famous Tibetan translator (b. 1055). He studied in Kashmir for twenty-three years and is best known for introducing into Tibet the philosophical works of Candrakīrti and other Indian scholars, but also brought the transmissions of new practice rituals and tantric deities.
The name of a Tibetan family to which belonged the renowned translator Patshap Nyima Drakpa.
An area to the west of Jambudvīpa.
A great bodhisattva.
A generic designation for the group of non-Buddhist mendicants of various religious outlooks, who lived as wandering spiritual seekers in India during the time of the Buddha.
An area in Kuru.
A river in Jambudvīpa.
The name given to Maudgalyāyana by his relatives because it seemed to them he had come to them from the lap of the gods.
Another name of Maudgalyāyana.
Another name of Mahā­maudgalyāyana.

term: པད་མ་ ཀུ་ ཤེ་ ཤ་ ཡ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: A mountain in Kuru.
A lake near Sudharma.
A nāga king.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
King of Magadha at the time of the Buddha’s birth, husband of Queen Bimbī, and father of Bimbisāra.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
One of the cold hells.
Nelumbo nucifera. The white variant of the red lotus, which is otherwise the same species.
A pleasure grove in Shaded by Garlands.
A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.

term: པད་མ་ དང་ ཟླ་བ་ ལྟར་ བཞིན་འཛུམ་ ཞིང་ བརྗིད་ ལ་ མདངས་ གསལ་བ
en: Smiling Face That Brightly Shines Like the Moon and a Lotus Flower
comment_en: One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A great bodhisattva in the buddha realm of Padmaśrī.
The name of a young bodhisattva, who is one of the interlocutors of the Buddha in this text.

en: Glory of the Manifestation of the Sublime Lotus
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Beautiful Lotus. Likely the same as the thus-gone one Skillful in the Glory of the Lotus Guru.
The buddha who receives the six-syllable mantra from Avalokiteśvara.
A buddha in the past.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
The name of a dhāraṇī.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
An absorption.
A buddha.
A buddha.

en: Skillful in the Glory of the Lotus Guru
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Beautiful Lotus. Likely the same as the thus-gone one Glory of the Manifestation of the Sublime Lotus.
The name of an eon.

A buddha who appears in other sūtras as a contemporary of Śākyamuni in another universe. In this sūtra, King Dṛḍhabala, the bhikṣu Supuṣpacandra, and King Varapuṣpasa are said to be his previous lives.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.

en: Light Rays of the Supreme Lotus
comment_en: A buddha.

en: Noble King of the Terrifying Lotus
comment_en: A buddha.

term: པད་མ་ འཇིགས་བྱེད་ མེ་ཏོག་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
en: Awesome Lotus King of Superior Flowers
comment_en: A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A forest in Moving in Mixed Environments.

en: Glorious Source of the Spreading of Lotus Flowers
comment_en: A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A forest in Dwelling in One Direction.

en: Great Splitting Open Like a Lotus Hell
comment_en: Name of one of the eight cold hells. The extreme cold of this hell turns the skin of its denizens blue, red, and then extremely red until they crack apart into a hundred or more pieces like the petals of a great lotus.
One of the eight cold hells.
See “Splitting Open Like a Great Lotus Hell.”

en: Splitting Open Like a Great Lotus Hell
comment_en: Eighth (and heaviest) of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. The extreme cold of this hell turns the skin of its denizens blue, red, and then extremely red until they crack apart in a hundred or more pieces. Also rendered here as “Great Lotus Hell.”
One of the eight cold hells.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.

en: Splitting Open Like a Lotus Hell
comment_en: Name of one of the eight cold hells. The extreme cold of this hell turns the skin of its denizens blue and then red until they crack apart into ten or more pieces like lotus petals.
See “Splitting Open Like a Lotus Hell.”

en: Splitting Open Like a Lotus Hell
comment_en: Seventh of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. The extreme cold of this hell turns the skin of its denizens blue and then red until they crack apart in ten or more pieces. Also rendered here as “Lotus Hell.”
One of the cold hells.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Siddhimati attains buddhahood as the tathāgata Vairocana.
A buddha.
Nelumbo nucifera. True lotus with a central pericarp. The Indian or sacred lotus.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its fifteenth week.
A buddha.
A future buddha.
A buddha realm.
A buddha realm.
Ca. late eighth century. An Indian monastic scholar important in the transmission of Buddhism to Tibet.
A lotus pond in the forest known as Incomparable.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.
A buddha realm.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A future buddha.
A buddha.

term: པད་མ་ -འི་ མཆོག་ འབུམ་ གྱིས་ བཀབ་ མ

comment_en: Handsome monk who went forth under Venerable Upasena, he was named for his complexion, which was the color of a lotus-heart.
The buddha of the distant world Realm of Lotuses; also, the name of a great bodhisattva in the audience of this sūtra.

term: པད་མ་ -འི་ འདབ་མ་ ལྟར་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ རྒྱུ་སྐར་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ མངོན་པར་ ཤེས་པ་ -འི་ མེ་ཏོག་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ
comment_en: One of the bodhisattva great beings.
The name of an eon.
A buddha.

term: པད་མ་ -འི་ འོད་ཟེར་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ རོལ་པ་ -ས་ མངོན་པར་ མཁྱེན་པ

comment_en: A buddha realm.
Śāriputra’s name when he becomes a buddha.
A rogue who was the Buddha in a former life.

en: King of the High Lotus Summit
comment_en: A buddha.
Ponds in the Forest of Amusements.
A realm in the distant past. BHS: Dharma­pradīpa­megha­śiri.
King of Takṣaśīla during the time of the Buddha, he was father of She Who Gathers.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
A brahmin.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Seven Precious Substances.
A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Lotus Guru.
Name of a meditative absorption.

en: World of the Glory of the Lotus
comment_en: Realm of tathāgatas.
A queen in another world in the distant past.
A bodhisattva of the nadir.
A buddha of the southeast.
The name of a god.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Beautiful Entrance. Likely an alternate name for the thus-gone one Departed to a Jewel Lotus.
See “red lotus.”

Nelumbo nucifera. The true lotus that has a central pericarp, while the “night lotus” and the “blue lotus” are actually lilies. Padma or nalinī refers to the red variety of the lotus, while the white lotus is called puṇḍarīka.
A buddha of the nadir.
A world realm in the eastern direction.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Moon.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Lotuses.
In chapter 29 it is the name of the ninth buddha in a list that begins with Kanaka­muni (pad mo’i bla). In chapter 44 it is the name of a future buddha in this kalpa (pad mo dam pa).
A buddha in the past.
Royal court.
A buddhafield in the east.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
An emanation of Avalokiteśvara usually depicted as a red, dancing figure; also the visualized deity for the semen after it enters the bhaga.
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
“The great lotus.” One of the four great treasures and the being who presides over it.
The name of an absorption.
One of the eight great yakṣiṇīs and one of the eight nāga queens.
One of the mantra deities, possibly Agni, the god of fire.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element of space.
The name of a samādhi.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Alternative name of the current eon, also known as the “Fortunate Eon.”
The lotus flower or plant; metaphorically, the female genital organ.
The lotus flower or plant; euphemistic name for the female genital organ.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The leader of the vidyārājas.
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
Another name of Amitābha.
‟Lotus-Eyed One,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the five buddha families.

This family is associated mainly with the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara, and includes deities such as Tārā, Bhṛkuṭī, and so forth. In the higher tantras, this family is presided over by the tathāgata Amitābha.
A bodhisattva in the presence of Śākyamuni at Śrāvastī.

term: པདྨོ་ བཟང་མོ་ མིག་ ཡིད་ དུ་ འོང་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ ཟླ་བ
comment_en: Refers to Padma­bhadrābhirāma­netra­śrī­candrā, a cakravartin’s princess in the distant past. Also called Samanta­jñānārci­padma­bhadrābhirāma­netra­śrī­candrā.

term: པདྨོ་ བཟང་མོ་ མིག་ ཡིད་ དུ་ འོང་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ ཟླ་བ
comment_en: A cakravartin’s princess in the distant past. Also called Samanta­jñānārci­padma­bhadrābhirāma­netra­śrī­candrā and Padma­bhadrābhirāma­netra­śrī.
The name of the thirty-fourth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Padumagarbhaśirī.
The nineteenth (eighteenth in the Sanskrit) buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.

Five brothers who were the sons of Paṇḍu. The most famous was Arjuna (of Bhagavadgīta fame); the other four were Yudhiṣṭhira, Nakula, Sahadeva, and Bhīmasena. The story of the Pāṇḍava brothers and their battle with their cousins, the Kauravas, is the subject of the Mahābhārata, India’s greatest epic. In the sūtra, Bali imprisons the Pāṇḍavas and Kauravas together.
One of the vedic sages who revealed some of the Vedas, and is believed to have written the first puraṇa.
A mountain in Godānīya.
Piper longum.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
A family of Indian chordophone instruments.
A class of godlings, probabably related to yakṣas.
A lotus grove in Blazing Splendor.
A short form of “Pilindavatsa,” a monk.

An arhat particularly remembered for being able to command the goddess of the Ganges River to make it stop flowing. She was annoyed by the brusque way he commanded her, but the Buddha said she was his servant for centuries in previous lifetimes and he addressed her that way out of habit, which is explained to be why his name means “leftover habits.”
A monk. Also referred to as “Pilinda.”
One of the kings of the piśācas.
One of the kings of the piśācas.
One of the great piśācas.

A monk of the Buddha’s order, declared by the Buddha as supreme among “lion roarers,” i.e., teachers of the Dharma. Cf. “Kuṇālavadāna,” ch. 27, v. 84 in the Divyāvadana, which details the noble one’s encounter in his old age with King Aśoka.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An ocean to the south of Jambudvīpa.
The name of a nakṣatra.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
One of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra.
Nelumbo nucifera. The white variant of the red lotus, which is otherwise the same species.
Valeriana wallichii (more likely), Tabernaemontana crispa (less likely).

The name of an Indian preceptor and translator (ca. 11th century). Little is known about him except that he was responsible with Patsap Nyima Drak for the translation of this text, and possibly for Toh 675.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
The name of a brahmin who appears in the āvadana literature as a ruler or chief of the town of Utkaṭa and alternately in the Mūlasarvāstivādavinaya as a king of Taxila (Edgerton 349.1).
A country in the northeastern part of India.

A Bengali Buddhist writer who lived during the reigns of King Gopāla I of Bengal (750–75 ce) and King Trisong Detsen of Tibet (775–97 ce), under whose auspices he came to Tibet. He contributed to the translation of seventy-seven Buddhist works from Sanskrit into Tibetan and is the author of three commentaries preserved in the Tengyur.

A Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth/early ninth centuries. Arriving in Tibet at the invitation of the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries included in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.

An Indian Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. Arriving in Tibet on an invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.

Indian scholar and translator of the sūtra. He lived during the eighth century and came to Tibet on the invitation of King Trisong Detsen. He contributed to the translation of 77 Buddhist works from Sanskrit into Tibetan during his stay in Tibet.

An Indian Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th / early 9th centuries. Arriving in Tibet on an invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.

Prajñāvarman was a Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He arrived in Tibet at the invitation of the Tibetan king Trisong Detsen (khri srong lde btsan, 742–ca. 800 ce) and assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He also authored a few philosophical commentaries himself, which were later included in the Tibetan Tengyur collection.
Indian paṇḍita and translator.

An Indian Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. Arriving in Tibet on an invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Indian preceptor resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

An Indian scholar and translator of the eighth to the ninth century who translated, in collaboration with other Indian and Tibetan scholars, about eighty texts of the Kangyur into Tibetan. He also composed commentaries that are preserved in the Tengyur.
Indian paṇḍit who translated and edited (among others) the sūtra Purification of Karmic Obscurations.

An Indian Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. Arriving in Tibet on an invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Indian preceptor.

An Indian Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth/early ninth centuries. Arriving in Tibet on an invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.

An Indian Bengali paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th to early 9th centuries. Arriving in Tibet on an invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.

A Bengali preceptor resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. Arriving in Tibet by invitation from the Tibetan king, he assisted in the translation of numerous canonical scriptures. He is also the author of a few philosophical commentaries contained in the Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
One of the two melāpakas.
Benincasa hispida.
One of the kings of Nepal.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

term: ཕ་རོལ་ གྱི་ སེམས་ཤེས་པ་ མངོན་སུམ་ དུ་ བྱ་བ་ ཤེས་པ་ -འི་ མངོན་པར་ ཤེས་པ
en: Extrasensory power realizing knowledge of other minds
comment_en: Fourth of the six extrasensory powers.
A set of practices to be completely mastered (until one reaches their “other shore”) for those on the bodhisattva path. They are listed as either six or ten.
See “six transcendent perfections.”
Most of the time this term refers to any of the six perfections—generosity, discipline, patience, diligence, concentration, and insight.
The trainings of the bodhisattvas, typically understood as the six trainings in generosity, discipline, patience, diligence, concentration, and knowledge.

This term is used to refer to the main trainings of a bodhisattva. Because these trainings, when brought to perfection, lead one to transcend saṃsāra and reach the full awakening of a buddha, they receive the Sanskrit name pāramitā, meaning “perfection” or “gone to the farther shore.” Most commonly listed as six: generosity, discipline, patience, diligence, concentration, and insight.

To have transcended or crossed to the other side; typically refers to one or more of the six practices of bodhisattvas: generosity, discipline, patience, diligence, meditative concentration, and wisdom.
Literally “to have crossed over” or “transcended”; typically this refers to the specific practices of the bodhisattva that are motivated by bodhicitta and embraced by wisdom.
The profound nondual understanding of the ultimate reality of emptiness of all things, it is personified as a goddess described as the “Mother of all Victorious Ones” (Sarvajinamātā).
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A set of practices to be completely mastered (until one reaches their “other shore”) for those on the bodhisattva path. They are listed as either six or ten.
The six or more perfections, starting from generosity (dāna), constitute the conduct of a bodhisattva.
The six perfections of generosity, conduct, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom.
The six perfections of generosity, conduct, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom.

The term is used to define the actions of a bodhisattva. Because these actions, when brought to perfection, lead one to transcend saṃsāra and reach full awakening, they receive the Sanskrit name pāramitā, meaning “gone across to the other side.”
To have transcended or crossed to the other side; typically refers to the practices of the bodhisattvas, which are embraced with knowledge.
The way of the perfections. Synonymous with Bodhisattva­yāna.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Non-Buddhist sectarians.
A lost verse text, which was possibly a Mūla­sarvāstivādin counterpart of the Pārāyanavagga of the Suttanipāta in the Pāli canon and included in the Kṣudraka­piṭaka of the Mūla­sarvāstivādins.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
One of the great mātṛs.
A mountain near Kuśāgrapura.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The four truths that the Buddha realized and transmitted in his first teaching: suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path one travels to end suffering.
See “four truths of the noble ones.”

en: Four preferences of the noble ones
comment_en: Simple food, simple clothing, a simple dwelling place, and simple possessions.
The Buddhist path as presented in the disciple vehicle: right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right concentration.
A buddha in the past.
A king in Royal Mountain of Great Intelligence’s buddha realm.
A town in Videha.
A buddha.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the four main monastic orders of Indian Buddhism.
One of the eighteen nikāya schools.

This vast Mahāyāna sūtra (also called the Buddhāvataṃsaka) deals with the miraculous side of the Mahāyāna. It is important in relation to the Vimalakīrtinirdeśa, since the latter’s fifth chapter, “The Inconceivable Liberation,” is a highly abbreviated version of the essential teaching of the former.
A collective name for the colloquial dialects of the Middle Indo-Aryan languages.
One who teaches a false doctrine.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the seven yakṣiṇīs.
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A great bodhisattva.
One of “the sixteen excellent men.”
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
A confessional practice for mending breaches of a bodhisattva’s discipline.

en: The Confession of the Three Heaps
comment_en: “The three heaps” is a term for the Buddha. This refers specifically to the Mahāyāna sūtra of that name, popularly known as The Thirty-Two Buddhas of Confession (Toh 284, Tri­skandhaka­sūtra).
A buddha in the world known as Illusory.
Name of a tathāgata.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.

The ordinary mind-body complex is termed the “five psycho-physical aggregates,” which comprise physical forms, feelings, perceptions, formative predispositions, and consciousness. For a detailed exposition of the five psycho-physical aggregates in accord with A­saṅga’s Abhi­dharma­samuccaya, see Jamgon Kongtrul, TOK Book 6, Pt. 2: 477–531.
The five constituents of a living entity: form, sensation, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.

The five aggregates (skandha) of form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected.
The constituents of a human being: form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
The basic components out of which the world and the personal self are formed, usually listed as a set of five: form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
Five collections of similar dharmas under which all dependently arisen dharmas may be included: form (materiality), feeling, notion, assembled factors, and consciousness.
In Buddhist philosophy, the five basic constituents upon which persons are conventionally designated. They are material forms, sensations, perceptions, formations, and consciousness.
The five “aggregates” comprising a living being.
Form, feeling, perception, formation and consciousness.

term: ཕུང་པོ་ ལྷག་མ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ མྱ་ངན་ ལས་ འདས་པ་ -འི་ དབྱིངས་ སུ་ ཡོངས་སུ་ མྱ་ངན་ ལས་ འདས་པ
en: Passed beyond all sorrow into the realm of nirvāṇa without any remainder of the aggregates
comment_en: See “parinirvāṇa.”
A great bodhisattva.
Five collections of similar dharmas, under which all compounded dharmas may be included; form, feeling, notions, factors, and consciousness.
Here, referring to the five collections of psycho-physical factors that constitute beings: form, feelings, perceptions, formations, and consciousness.
See “five psycho-physical aggregates.”
The constituents that make up a being’s existence: form, sensations, identifications, mental activities, and consciousnesses.
The five aggregates of form, sensation, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected.
See “five aggregates.”
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the personal self are formed.
The five psycho-physical components of personal experience: form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness.
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the personal self are formed.
The basic components out of which the world and the personal self are formed, usually listed as a set of five.
Five collections or “heaps” of impersonal mental and physical elements (dharma).
See “five aggregates for appropriation.”
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the personal self are formed: forms, feelings, perceptions, formative factors, and consciousness.

This translation of skandha is fairly well established, although some prefer the monosyllabic “group.” It is important to bear in mind that the original skandha has the sense of “pile,” or “heap,” which has the connotation of utter lack of internal structure, of a randomly collocated pile of things; thus “group” may convey a false connotation of structure and ordered arrangement. The five “compulsive” (upādāna) aggregates are of great importance as a schema for introspective meditation in the Abhidharma, wherein each is defined with the greatest subtlety and precision. In fact, the five terms rūpa, vedanā, samjñā, saṃskāra, and vijñāna have such a particular technical sense that many translators have preferred to leave them untranslated. Nevertheless, in the sūtra context, where the five are meant rather more simply to represent the relative living being (in the realm of desire), it seems preferable to give a translation—in spite of the drawbacks of each possible term—in order to convey the same sense of a total categorization of the psychophysical complex. Thus, for rūpa, “matter” is preferred to “form” because it more concretely connotes the physical and gross; for vedanā, “sensation” is adopted, as limited to the aesthetic; for samjñā, “intellect” is useful in conveying the sense of verbal, conceptual intelligence. For samskāra, which covers a number of mental functions as well as inanimate forces, “motivation” gives a general idea. And “consciousness” is so well established for vijñāna (although what we normally think of as consciousness is more like samjñā, i.e., conceptual and notional, and vijñāna is rather the “pure awareness” prior to concepts) as to be left unchallenged.

Five collections of similar phenomena, under which all compounded dharmas may be included: form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected.
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the individual self are formed.
The five constituents of a living entity: form, feeling, perception, karmic formation, and consciousness.
The five psycho-physical components of personal experience: form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness.
Five collections of phenomena under which all compounded phenomena may be included: form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
The five aggregates of form, sensation, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected.
Also known as the “five appropriated aggregates.”
The five psycho-physical components of personal experience: form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness.
The five aggregates, the bases upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected, are those of form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness.
In Buddhist philosophy, the five basic constituents upon which persons are conventionally designated. They are material forms, sensations, perceptions, formations, and consciousness.

The five aggregates of form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness. On the individual level, the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected. They are referred to as the “bases for appropriation” (Skt. upādāna), insofar as all conceptual grasping arises on the basis of these aggregates.
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the personal self are formed: form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness.
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the personal self are formed.

The five aggregates (Skt. skandha) of form, feeling, perception, formative predispositions, and consciousness. On the individual level, the five aggregates refer to the basis upon which the mistaken idea of a self is projected. They are referred to as the “bases for appropriation” (Skt. upādāna) insofar as all conceptual grasping arises based on these aggregates.
Five collections of similar dharmas, under which all compounded dharmas may be included: form, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
The psycho-physical components of personal experience. The five aggregates: form, feeling, perception, formative predispositions, and consciousness.
The fivefold basic grouping of the components out of which the world and the personal self are formed.
A city in Videha.
The aspect of Māra associated with the power of the five aggregates to obstruct awakening.
This is the figurative or embodied demon of the constituents in a being.
Wisdom, sensation, consciousness, matter, karmic formations, and discrimination.

term: ཕུང་པོ་ -འི་ ལྷག་མ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ མྱ་ངན་ ལས་ འདས་པ
comment_en: The attainment of nirvāṇa without any remainder of the physical and mental aggregates.
The five skandhas (pañcaskandha) are: forms (rūpa), sensation (vedanā), conception (saṃjñā), formations (saṃskāra), consciousness (vijñāna).
A buddha realm.
One of the great brahmās.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
(1) A mountain. (2) Another mountain mentioned in the story of Prince Sudhana, which is listed along with the mountain of the same name (differentiated in Tib. as phur pa’i dbyibs).
A king who was the Buddha in a former life.
Both the deity of the planet Jupiter and the guru of the devas.
The planet Jupiter. The Tibetan translation phur bu reflects the Sanskrit Kīlaka, which is also a name for the planet Jupiter.
Name of a past king, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A river in the Crushing Hell.
A bodhisattva.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
Female dūta.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.

Distinctive Indian assembly hall or temple with one ground-floor room and a high ornamental roof, sometimes a barrel shape with apses but more usually a tapering roof, tower, or spire, it contains at least one additional upper room within the structure. Kūṭāgāra literally means “upper chamber” and is short for kūṭāgāraśala, “hall with an upper chamber or chambers.” The Mahābodhi temple in Bodhgaya is an example of a kūṭāgāra.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Appearance of Countless Emanations.
A yakṣa.

term: ཕྱག་ དང་ ཞབས་ ཀྱི་ མཐིལ་ དམར་བ
comment_en: Fifty-fifth of the eighty minor marks.

term: ཕྱག་ དང་ ཞབས་ ཀྱི་ མཚན་ དཔལ་ གྱིས་ འབར་བ
en: Markings on their palms and soles blaze with splendor
comment_en: Seventy-seventh of the eighty minor marks. (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-403).

en: Hands and feet are utterly pure
comment_en: Sixty-second of the eighty minor marks.
One of the great piśācīs.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An epithet of Avalokiteśvara; also, one of the bodhisattva emanations of Avalokiteśvara.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the bodhisattvas.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.

He first appears in Buddhist literature as the yakṣa bodyguard of the Buddha, ready at times to shatter a person’s head into a hundred pieces with his vajra if they were to speak inappropriately to the Buddha. His identity as a bodhisattva did not take place until the rise of the Mahāyāna in such sūtras as the Kāraṇda­vyūha Sūtra.

He first appears in Buddhist literature as the yakṣa bodyguard of the Buddha, ready at times to shatter a person’s head into a hundred pieces with his vajra if he speaks inappropriately to the Buddha. His identity as a bodhisattva did not take place until the rise of the Mantrayāna in such sūtras as the Kāraṇḍavyūha. However, although listed (paradoxically along with Avalokiteśvara) as being in the assembly that hears the teaching of this sūtra, in the sūtra itself he is grouped with the worldly spirits that Avalokiteśvara frightens.
An important bodhisattva, “Wielder of the Thunderbolt,” whose compassion is to manifest in a terrific form to protect the practicers of the Dharma from harmful influences.

First appeared in Buddhist literature as the yakṣa bodyguard of the Buddha, ready at times to shatter a person’s head into a hundred pieces with his vajra if he speaks inappropriately to the Buddha. His identity as a bodhisattva did not take place until the rise of the Mantrayāna in such sūtras as the Kāraṇḍavyūha (Toh 116). However, although listed (paradoxically along with Avalokiteśvara) as being in the assembly that hears the teaching of this sūtra, in the sūtra itself he is grouped with the worldly spirits that Avalokiteśvara frightens.
A bodhisattva.
Wrathful aspect of Vajrasattva; the Buddhist counterpart of Indra.
A bodhisattva.
A Buddhist deity and a legendary bodhisattva; in the MMK he is regarded as the master of powerful nonhuman beings.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the pratyeka­buddhas.
A buddha in the distant past in both chapter 22 and chapter 43.
The impermanence of all conditioned phenomena, the suffering inherent to all conditioned phenomena, the selflessness of all phenomena, and nirvāṇa as the state of peace.
A great bodhisattva.

en: Emptiness of both external and internal phenomena
comment_en: Third of the eighteen aspects of emptiness.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.

term: ཕྱི་རོལ་ གྱི་ གཟུགས་ དཀར་པོ་ ལ་ ལྟ་བ
comment_en: Sixth of the eight sense fields of mastery.

term: ཕྱི་རོལ་ གྱི་ གཟུགས་ དམར་པོ་ ལ་ ལྟ་བ
comment_en: Fifth of the eight sense fields of mastery.

term: ཕྱི་རོལ་ གྱི་ གཟུགས་ སྔོན་པོ་ ལ་ ལྟ་བ
comment_en: Third of the eight sense fields of mastery.
A forest in Fine Complexion and Large Body.
An image of the Buddha.
A buddha.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: ཕྱིར་ མི་ ལྡོག་པ་ -འི་ ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ དབྱིངས་ ཀྱི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: A buddha in a world in the eastern direction in the past.

term: ཕྱིར་ མི་ ལྡོག་པ་ -འི་ ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ལོ
comment_en: The fact that the Dharma is not a single dogma, law, or fixed system, but instead an adaptable body of techniques available for any living being to aid in his development and liberation is emphasized by this metaphor. This wheel is said to turn by the current of energy from the needs and wishes of living beings, and its turning automatically converts negative energies (e.g., desire, hatred, and ignorance) to positive ones (e.g., detachment, love, and wisdom).

term: ཕྱིར་ མི་ ལྡོག་པ་ -འི་ བྱང་ཆུབ་ སེམས་དཔའ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གཞག་པ
en: Category of the bodhisattva who is irreversible

term: ཕྱིར་ མི་ ལྡོག་པ་ -འི་ འཁོར་ལོ་ རིན་པོ་ཆེ་ རྟག་ ཏུ་ དོན་ དཔལ
en: Eternally Glorious Meaning of the Precious Irreversible Wheel
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Free of Impurity.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha in the distant past. His name as given in verse. In the prose he is called Īśvara­guṇāparājita­dhvaja.
A legendary realm in which Śiva will attain buddhahood.
A river.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A buddha in the distant past.

comment_en: A group of world realms in the distant past.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
A certain king of the city of Pāṁśula who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. His son was Reṇu.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A mountain in White Body.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.

A king in the past.
A city in ancient India.
The hundred-and-seventh buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.

A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
