comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
The thirteenth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
Consort of Yellow Acala.
The fifth of the ten nonvirtuous actions.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Consort of Green ‌Acala.
The deity personifying the true nature of the faculty of smell.
A king of the asuras, present at the teaching of the sūtra.
A lord of the asuras; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A park in Born in a Tank.
A class of gods associated with the Four Great Kings.
“Garland-Holder,” a class of divine beings who live on Mount Sumeru.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
A class of godlings, probabably related to yakṣas.
An area in Kuru.
A monk disciple of the Buddha.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A rākṣasī known only from this sūtra.
The name of the people in the land where Maitreya was born. The sūtra states that it is in the south of India.
A god from whom Śakra heard the Dharma in a previous life.
A mountain in Kuru.
A mantra that surrounds the central item in a diagram or magical drawing.

One of the three classes of yakṣas at the base of Meru, below the paradises of the mahārājas, as part of the lowest class of paradises in the desire realm. Their name means “with māla beads in their hands,” and they are said to be constantly counting and therefore unable to follow the path to enlightenment.
Śrāvaka arhat; one of the sixteen sthavira arhats (see “elder”).
A yakṣa lord.
An arhat disciple of the Buddha and one of the sixteen elders.
Indian tree with a very fine flower.
The Mimusops elengi, also known as the bulletwood tree.
The western continent of the human world according to traditional Indian cosmology, characterized as “rich in the resources of cattle.”
This seems to be either another name for Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa, or an epithet referring to him, meaning “youth”.
An epithet of Mārīcī.
An epithet of Mārīcī.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A town in Videha.
Can be a name of several plants and substances.
A temple on Mount Gośṛṅga.
A snake demon.
The dwarf incarnation of Viṣṇu, who deceived the king of the asuras.
River in the hell known as Bursting Like Great Lotuses.
An ancient city in North India on the outskirts of which the Buddha first taught the Dharma.
City in northern India where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.

Also known as Benares, the oldest city of northeast India in the Gangetic plain. It was once the capital of its own small kingdom and was known by various names. It was an important religious center, as well as a major city in India, even during the time of the Buddha. The name may derive from being where the Varuna and Assi rivers flow into the Ganges.
City in North India where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.

Also known as Benares, the oldest city of northeast India in the Gangetic plain. It was once the capital of its own small kingdom and was known by various names. It was an important religious center, as well as a major city in India, even during the time of the Buddha. The name may derive from being the place where the Varuna and Assi rivers flow into the Ganges.
An ancient city in North India close to which the Buddha first taught the Dharma.
The capital city of Kāśi.
An ancient city in North India on the outskirts of which the Buddha first taught the Dharma.

A city in North India, on the banks of the Gaṅgā, where the Buddha gave his first sermon; this name can be applied also to the surrounding country or district. It lies in modern day Uttar Pradesh, India. The name is rendered elsewhere in this translation as its older name, “Kāśī.”
City in North India where the Buddha first taught the Dharma
Capital of the ancient country of Kāśi, west of Magadha and north of Kośala.
An epithet of Mārīcī.
A vidyādhara site on Kālaka.
A country in the western part of the Vindhya range.
Rinchen Drakpa (rin chen grags pa) 1040−1111 ce. He went to India at the age of fourteen and became a disciple of Vajrāsana. He later became the second head of the Sakya school.
In the CMT, he is the king of nāgas.
An ancient city located in the Saurashtra peninsula of Gujarat.

A particular kind of sandalwood, known as “ox-head,” that grows in southern India. It is reddish in color and has medicinal properties. It is said to have the finest fragrance of all sandalwood. The Sanskrit word go means “ox,” and śīrṣa means “head;” candana means “sandalwood.” The name of this sandalwood is said to derive from either the shape of or the name of a mountain upon which it grew. The Tibetan translated gośīrṣa as ba lang gi spos or “ox incense.”
A river in Jambudvīpa.
One of the first to join the Buddha’s order of monks. He followed his friend Yaśas into the Buddhist order.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
‟Excellent Mind,” the name of a female spirit summoned in a sādhana.
A south Indian king contemporary with Pulakeśin II.
A nāga.
A continent in the west.
The continent to the west of Mount Sumeru.
In ancient Buddhist cosmology, the western of the four continents in the cardinal directions.

The western continent of the human world according to traditional Indian cosmology, characterized as “rich in the resources of cattle.” It is named Aparāntaka (or sometimes Aparagodānīya or Aparagoyāna). It has a circular shape and is about 7,500 yojanas in circumference. Humans who live there are very tall, about 7.3 meters on average, and live for 500 years.
A south Indian king contemporary with Mahendra.
The people of the Balkh region, or Bactrians.
Appears in The Hundred Deeds as the name of a king and a people dwelling in the “barbaric outlying region” west of Jambudvīpa.
Justicia adhatoda.
A river in the south of Jambudvīpa.
“One with the Face of Vāsuki.” One of the eight nāga queens.
Goddess of the earth.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.

From a wealthy brahmin family, Bakkula is said to have become a monk at the age of eighty and lived to be a hundred and sixty! He is also said to have had two families, because as a baby he was swallowed by a large fish and the family who discovered him alive in the fish’s stomach also claimed him as their child. The Buddha’s foremost pupil in terms of health and longevity. It is also said he could remember many previous lifetimes and was a pupil of the previous buddhas Padmottara, Vipaśyin, and Kāśyapa.
Name that the Buddha will bear when he appears again in this world after three hundred eons.
A buddha realm.
Name of the eighty-second meditative stability.
Name of the 102nd meditative stability.
Literally “Great Array” or “Great Display.” The name of a future eon.
Name of a future buddha.
One of the bodhisatvas in attendance when the sūtra The Teaching of Akṣayamati was taught, he questions Akṣayamati during the exposition of the seventh imperishable: patient acceptance.
The name of one of the bodhisattvas in the assembly in Chap. 1.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ disciple foremost in miraculous powers and endeavor.

en: Stainless Light of the Entire Array
comment_en: The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to the east of the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
The world sphere where Tathāgata Amitāyurjñāna­viniścaya­rājendra lives.
The name of a world system in the southwestern direction.
A future buddha.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of the twenty-eighth meditative stability.
Name of a bodhisattva, the main recipient and interlocutor of the Ananta­mukhapariśo­dhana­nirdeśa Sūtra.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
The name of an eon (kalpa).
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching. Also present at the teaching of The King of Samādhis Sūtra (ting nge ’dzin gyi rgyal po’i mdo, Toh 127).
A bodhisattva who plays a minor role in the King of the Array of all Dharma Qualities.
The name of a previous eon.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A town in time and world system of the Buddha Jñānaprabha.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
The name of the lotus seat on which the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus sits.

term: བཀྲ་ མི་ ཤིས་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ མེད་པ་ -ར་ བྱེད་པ

comment_en: An editor of the Degé version of the Gaṇḍa­vyūha.
A buddha realm.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
An elephant.
A Brahmin in Kosala, father of Saṃjaya.
An ancient Indian symbol of auspiciousness and eternity.
Grass peddler who offered Gautama the grass that he would sit upon in meditation to attain enlightenment.

In later Tibetan translations, it is translated as g.yung-drung. In the early translations, it is bra shis and in the Mahāvyutpatti dictionary it is bkra shis ldan, while g.yung-drung translates nandyāvarta. It is an auspicious sign in Indian culture, and it is one of the auspicious marks on the chest of the Buddha, as well as the śrīvatsa.
A special symbol, considered auspicious in many South Asian traditions, whose name is derived from the word svasti, which is often used as a greeting.
Identified as the Cālukya king Maṅgalarāja, the predecessor and uncle of Pulakeśin II.
A monk.
An ancient country, possibly in the Himalayan region.
A forest in Endowed with Increasing Bliss.
A river in Garlands of Flowers.
A pond on Equal Peaks.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.

term: བག་ ཡོད་པ་ ལ་ མངོན་པར་ དགའ་བ་ བཀྲ་ཤིས
comment_en: A god who taught Musulundha the Dharma.
A latent propensity, proclivity, or disposition.

“Lord of obstacles,” although the Tibetan translates it as “lord of no obstacles.” One of the names of the elephant-headed deity that is the son of Śiva and Pārvatī, also known as Ganesh (Ganeśa or Gaṇapati; tshogs kyi bdag po).
A land in the south of India.
A certain buddha who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
An ancient country in the Ganges delta.
A forest near Sthūlakoṣṭhaka, a village in the country of Kuru.
A village in the country of Kuru.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
The Gupta emperor Dvādaśāditya (early eighth century).

One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK. The Tibetan translation of the MMK actually records this name as bcu drug sde pa’i dga’ byed, which appears to be an error that reads the next member of the list Nandana (dga’ byed) as part of the name Ṣoḍaśavargika.

en: Light Rays in the Ten Directions
comment_en: A buddha.

en: Light Rays in the Ten Directions
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
City located in modern-day Uttar Pradesh, India, historically renowned for its redstone Buddha images.
Name of several cities in India; traditionally, the birthplace of Kṛṣṇa.
Also rendered as “Bhagavatī.”
A general term of respect given to persons of spiritual attainment; in a Buddhist context, it is an epithet for the Buddha.
Epithet of the Buddha, meaning “one who has fortune” (explained as having six features); or “one who has vanquished (Māra).”
An epithet for a buddha.

Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni. According to Tibetan hermeneutics, the term defines a teacher or buddha who primordially subdues (bcom) the four demonic forces, possesses (ldan) the six attributes of greatness (che ba’i yon tan drug, viz: lordship, noble form, glory, fame, pristine cognition, and perseverance), and transcends (’das) all sorrow, without abiding in the extremes of existence and quiescence. Also translated here as “Lord” (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-121).

Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni. According to Tibetan hermeneutics, the term defines a teacher or buddha who primordially subdues (bcom) the four demonic forces, possesses (ldan) the six attributes of greatness (che ba’i yon tan drug, viz: lordship, noble form, glory, fame, pristine cognition, and perseverance), and transcends (’das) all sorrow, without abiding in the extremes of existence and quiescence. Also translated here as “Blessed One.” (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-121).
Epithet of the Buddha.

“One who has bhaga,” which has many diverse meanings including “good fortune,” “happiness,” and “majesty.” In the Buddhist context, it means one who has the good fortune of attaining enlightenment. The Tibetan translation has three syllables defined to mean “one who has conquered (the maras), possesses (the qualities of enlightenment), and has transcended (saṃsāra, or both saṃsāra and nirvāṇa).

In Buddhist literature, an epithet applied to buddhas, most often to Śākyamuni. The Sanskrit term generally means “possessing fortune,” but in specifically Buddhist contexts it implies that a buddha is in possession of six auspicious qualities (bhaga) associated with complete awakening. The Tibetan term‍—where bcom is said to refer to “subduing” the four māras, ldan to “possessing” the great qualities of buddhahood, and ’das to “going beyond” saṃsāra and nirvāṇa‍—possibly reflects the commentarial tradition where the Sanskrit bhagavat is interpreted, in addition, as “one who destroys the four māras.” This is achieved either by reading bhagavat as bhagnavat (“one who broke”), or by tracing the word bhaga to the root √bhañj (“to break”).
An epithet for a buddha.
A title used for the Buddha and other tathāgatas.
Epithet of a buddha.
An epithet of a buddha, used in this text to refer to the Buddha Śākyamuni.

In Buddhist literature, an epithet applied to buddhas, most often to Śākyamuni. The Sanskrit term generically means “possessing fortune,” but in specifically Buddhist contexts implies that a buddha is in possession of the virtuous qualities and wisdom associated with complete awakening.

An epithet of the Buddha. The Tibetan rendering can be explained as “one who has conquered the four māras and is endowed with the six excellent qualities.”
An epithet of a buddha, used in this text to refer to the Buddha Śākyamuni.
“Illustrious One,” an epithet of the Buddha.

In Buddhist literature, an epithet applied to buddhas, most often to Śākyamuni. The Sanskrit term generically means “possessing fortune,” but in specifically Buddhist contexts implies that a buddha is in possession of six auspicious qualities (bhaga) associated with complete awakening. The Tibetan term—where bcom is said to refer to “subduing” the four māras, ldan to “possessing” the great qualities of buddhahood, and ’das to “going beyond” saṃsāra and nirvāṇa—possibly reflects the commentarial tradition where the Sanskrit bhagavat is interpreted, in addition, as “one who destroys the four māras.” This is achieved either by reading bhagavat as bhagnavat (“one who broke”), or by tracing the word bhaga to the root √bhañj, “to break.”

“Lord” is chosen to translate the title Bhagavān because it is the term of greatest respect current in our “sacred” language, as established for the Deity in the Elizabethan version of the Bible. Indeed, the Skt. Bhagavān was given as a title to the Buddha, although it also served the non-Buddhist Indians of the day and, subsequently, it served as an honorific title of their particular deities. As the Buddha is clearly described in the sūtras as the “Supreme Teacher of Gods and Men,” there seems little danger that he may be confused with any particular deity through the use of this term [as indeed in Buddhist sūtras various deities, creators, protectors, etc., are shown in their respective roles]. Thus I feel it would compromise the weight and function of the original Bhagavān to use any less weighty term than “Lord” for the Buddha.

A general term of respect given to persons of spiritual attainment. Translations into English have been “Holy One,” “Blessed One,” and “World-Honored One.” It is here given in the Sanskrit nominative case, bhagavān.

In the Buddhist context, it is an epithet of the buddhas. In Sanskrit, it literaly means “One who has bhaga,” which has many diverse meanings, including good fortune, happiness, and majesty; and more specifically to this context, it is used to define someone who as possessor of six specific qualities as well as beeing a conqueror of māras. The usual definition of the Tibetan term is bcom (“subdue”), referring to the subduing of the four māras; ldan (“to possess”), referring to the possession of the great qualities of buddhahood; and ’das (“beyond,” “transcended”), meaning that such a person has gone beyond saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. In this text, it refers to the Buddha Śākyamuni.

Epithet of a buddha; “one who has fortune” (explained as having six features) or “one who has vanquished (Māra).”

A common epithet of the historical Buddha. The Sanskrit word bhaga means, among other factors, good fortune, happiness, prosperity, and excellence. The suffix -vat indicates possession. A common English translation is thus “the Blessed One” or “the Fortunate One.” The three syllables of the Tibetan translation mean that the Buddha has “overcome, conquered” (Tib. bcom), is “endowed with (qualities)” (Tib. ldan), and has “gone beyond (saṃsāra)” (Tib. ’das).
An epithet of the buddhas.
One of the standard epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni.

Literally “one who has bhaga,” which has many diverse meanings including “good fortune,” “happiness,” and “majesty.” In the Buddhist context, it means “one who has the good fortune of attaining enlightenment.” The Tibetan translation has three syllables defined to mean “one who has conquered (the māras), possesses (the qualities of enlightenment), and has transcended (saṃsāra, or both saṃsāra and nirvāṇa).”

Sometimes also translated “Lord.”
A great scholar of Narthang monastery in central Tibet. He lived from 1227 to 1305 and was one of the first compilers of the the Kangyur.
An unidentified Gauḍa (Bengali) king.
Nāga king, particularly known for sheltering the Buddha from a storm in Bodhgaya.

An unidentified mountain mentioned in a number of sūtras, not apparently connected to the well-known nāga of that name, but perhaps to the sacred mucilinda tree, known in English mainly as the bayur tree.

An unidentified mountain mentioned in a number of sūtras, not apparently connected to the well-known nāga of that name, but perhaps to the sacred mucilinda tree, known in English mainly as the bayur tree.
Name of a mountain.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
Name of a god who personifies a mountain of this name.
See Mucilinda.

An unidentified mountain mentioned in a number of sūtras, not apparently connected to the well known nāga of that name (who is also known as Mucilinda), but perhaps to the sacred mucilinda tree, known in English mainly as the bayur tree.
Name of a mountain.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
Name of a god who personifies a mountain of this name.
A merchant, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 8.
One of the kinnara kings.
A forest in Continuous Movement.
A forest in Moving in Mixed Environments.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.

A rishi of ancient India, said to be the author of the Nyaysūtrabhāśya and the famous Kāmasūtra.
The name of a kingdom south of Kośala that was ruled by Udayin/Udayana during the Buddha’s time. Its capital was Kauśāmbī.
Also translated here as “self.”
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; also the uṣṇīṣa goddess of the Vajra family.
A buddha.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
“No-self”; Heruka’s consort personifying the absence of self.
Another name of the king Ājita.

en: Conquering the entire retinue of Māra
comment_en: The name of an absorption.

term: བདུད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ འཇོམས་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
en: Melody That Conquers All the Throngs of Māras
comment_en: A bodhisattva.

term: བདུད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ འཐོར་བ་ -འི་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ རྒྱལ་མཚན་ གྱི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva from a southwestern realm. Also known as Sarva­māra­maṇḍala­vikiraṇa­jñāna­dhvaja.

term: བདུད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ འཐོར་བ་ -འི་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ རྒྱལ་མཚན
comment_en: A bodhisattva from a southwestern realm. Also known as Sarva­māra­maṇḍala­vikiraṇa­jñāna­dhvaja­rāja.

term: བདུད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ བཅོམ་ ཞིང་ མྱེད་པ་ -ར་ བྱེད་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲ
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
Lit. “Son of Māra.”

Deities in the Paranirmitavaśavartin paradise in which Māra is the principal deity. They attempt to prevent anyone from attaining liberation from saṃsāra. This is distinct from the four personifications of obstacles to enlightenment: Devaputra-māra (lha’i bu’i bdud), the Divine Māra, which is the distraction of pleasures; Mṛtyumāra (’chi bdag gi bdud), the Māra of Death; Skandhamāra (phung po’i bdud), the Māra of the Aggregates, which is the body; and Kleśamāra (nyon mongs pa’i bdud), the Māra of the Afflictions.

Deities in the Paranirmitavaśavartin paradise in which Māra is the principal deity. They attempt to prevent anyone from attaining liberation from saṃsāra. This is distinct from the four personifications of obstacles to enlightenment: Devaputra-māra (lha’i bu’i bdud), the Divine Māra, which is the distraction of pleasures; Mṛtyumāra (’chi bdag gi bdud), the Māra of Death; Skandhamāra (phung po’i bdud), the Māra of the Aggregates, which is the body; and Kleśamāra (nyon mongs pa’i bdud), the Māra of the Afflictions.

Devaputra-māra is one of the four forms of Māra and refers to the god of the sensuous realm, the personification of desire and temptation, who attempted to prevent the Buddha from attaining liberation. Here it refers to the deities ruled over by Māra in his realm.

The deities ruled over by Māra. This can also mean the devas in his paradise, which is sometimes identified with the Paranirmitavaśavartin, the highest paradise in the “realm of desire,” which incudes all ordinary samsaric existences.
The class of gods ruled over by Māra or living in his abode.

en: Defeater of the Force of Evil
comment_en: Name of a buddha.

term: བདུད་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ ཡུལ་ ལས་ འདས་པ
comment_en: A buddha.

term: བདུད་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ སྟོབས་ རབ་ཏུ་ འཇོམས་པ
བདུད་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རབ་ཏུ་ བཅོམ་པ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
en: Endowed with the Vanquisher of All Demons
comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Possessor of Victory.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Melody of Victory.

term: བདུད་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལ་ སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ སྐུ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ སྟོན་པ་ -འི་ ཁྱུ་མཆོག
en: Leader Who Displays the Body of the Buddhas to All Māras
comment_en: A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva in a story Buddha tells.
One of the subtle channels in the body.

en: Unstained by the Realm of Māras
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A being in the Buddha’s assembly.
A buddha.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Immaculate.
Lit. “Nectar Intelligence.”
One of eight children, a daughter, of King Siṃhahanu of Kapilavastu.
One of eight children, a son, of King Siṃhahanu of Kapilavastu.
A buddha.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its sixteenth week.
A buddha.
Name of a buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva, a former incarnation of the Buddha.
An epithet of perfect awakening.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha in the distant past.
A king.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
The name of an eon.
A buddha.
A forest on Heap in the Stream.
A bodhisattva.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a god in a story the Buddha tells.
A demon. See also “Māra.”
See “Māra.”
The personification of negativity. In the Sanskrit tradition, four Māras are usually listed: the aggregates, the afflictions, the god Māra (the god of infatuation), and death.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
Personification of everything that functions as a hindrance to awakening. See also “demonic force.”

(1) A deva, sometimes said to be the principal deity in Paranirmitavaśavartin, the highest paradise in the desire realm; also one of the names of the god of desire, Kāma in the Vedic tradition. He is portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment. In early soteriological religions, the principal deity in saṃsāra, such as Indra, would attempt to prevent anyone’s realization that would lead to such a liberation. (2) The devas ruled over by Māra, and assisting his attempts to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment; they do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra. More generally, they are symbolic of the defects within a person that prevent enlightenment. These four personifications are: Devaputra-māra (lha’i bu’i bdud), the Divine Māra, which is the distraction of pleasures; Mṛtyumāra (’chi bdag gi bdud), the Māra of Death; Skandhamāra (phung po’i bdud), the Māra of the Aggregates, which is the body; and Kleśamāra (nyon mongs pa’i bdud), the Māra of the Afflictions.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
The deities ruled over by Māra; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

Said to be the principal deity in Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin, the highest paradise in the desire realm. He is also portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment, as in early soteriological religions, the principal deity in saṃsāra, such as Indra, would attempt to prevent anyone’s realization that would lead to such a liberation. The name Māra is also used as a generic name for the deities in his realm, and also as an impersonal term for the factors that keep beings in saṃsāra.

Originally the name of Indra’s principal enemy among the asuras. In early Buddhism he appears as a drought-causing demon and eventually his name becomes that of Māra, the principal opponent of the Buddhadharma.
The demon opposing the Buddha’s teaching; in the plural (māras) it denotes all such nonhuman beings.
The demon opposing the Buddha’s teaching; in the plural (māras) it denotes all such nonhuman beings.
A generic name for the followers of Māra.
The main adversary of the Buddha and the embodiment of evil; in the latter sense it may also be used in the plural.
The demon opposing the Buddha’s teaching; in the plural (“māras”) it denotes all such nonhuman beings.

(1) The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening. (2) The deities ruled over by Māra who do not wish any beings to escape from saṃsāra. (3) Any demonic force, the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles. They are also symbolic of the defects within a person that prevent awakening. See also “four māras.”

The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening. When used in the plural, the term refers to a class of beings who, like Māra himself, are the primary adversaries and tempters of people who vow to take up the religious life. Figuratively, they are the personification of everything that acts as a hindrance to awakening, and are often listed as a set of four: the Māra of the aggregates, the Māra of the afflictions, the Māra of the Lord of Death, and the Māra of the gods.
The personification of negativity.
The demon who assailed the Buddha Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

Māra is the personification of spiritual death in Indian religious mythology. In Buddhism, it refers to the lord of death as well as his minions, who attempted in various ways to prevent the Buddha’s awakening and likewise try to thwart the spiritual aims of Buddhist practitioners. Figuratively, they are the personification of everything that acts as a hindrance to awakening, and are often listed as a set of four: the māra of the aggregates, the māra of the emotional defilements, the māra of the lord of death, and the māra of the sons of gods.
The main adversary of the Buddha and the embodiment of evil.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
Demon or demonic influence that creates obstacles for spiritual practice and awakening.
A class of beings related to Māra. The “four māras,” negative forces that impede the way to awakening, are the aggregates, the afflictions, death, and the sons of gods.
Māra represents worldly desire. It was he who attempted, unsuccessfully, to tempt and trick the Buddha on the eve of his awakening.

The devil, or evil one, who leads the forces of the gods of the desire-world in seeking to tempt and seduce the Buddha and his disciples. But according to Vimalakīrti he is actually a bodhisattva who dwells in the inconceivable liberation and displays evil activities in order to strengthen and consolidate the high resolve of all bodhisattvas.
The chief antagonist in the life of the Buddha, who tried to prevent the Buddha from achieving enlightenment and later attempted many times to thwart his activity.
Class of evil beings.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

A demonic being often bearing the epithet of the “Evil One” (pāpīyān, sdig can), sometimes said to be the principal deity in Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations, the highest paradise in the desire realm; also one of the names of the god of desire, Kāma in the Vedic tradition. He is portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s awakening. In early soteriological religions, the principal deity in saṃsāra, such as Indra, would attempt to prevent anyone’s realization that would lead to such a liberation.
Personification of everything that functions as a hindrance to awakening.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

The principal deity in Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin, the highest heaven in the desire realm. He is best known for his role in trying to prevent the Buddha’s awakening. The name Māra is also used as a generic name for the deities in his abode, and also as an impersonal term for destructive forces that keep beings imprisoned in saṃsāra.
The personification of negativity.

Originally the name of Indra’s principal enemy among the asuras. In early Buddhism he appears as a drought-causing demon and eventually his name becomes that of Māra, the principal opponent of the Buddha’s teaching. The name also applies to the deities ruled over by Māra who attempted to prevent the Buddha’s awakening and who do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
Demon who creates obstacles to practice and enlightenment.
The deities ruled over by Māra who attempted to prevent the Buddha’s awakening and who do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra.

The principal deity in the highest heaven in the desire realm. He is also portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s awakening. The name Māra is also used as a generic name for the deities in his realm and also as an impersonal term for the factors that keep beings in saṃsāra.

The deities ruled over by Māra, they are also symbolic of the defects within a person that prevent awakening. These four personifications are (1) devaputramāra (lha’i bu’i bdud), the divine māra, which is the distraction of pleasures, (2) mṛtyumāra (’chi bdag gi bdud), the māra of the Lord of Death, (3) skandhamāra (phung po’i bdud), the māra of the aggregates, i.e., the body, and (4) kleśamāra (nyon mongs pa’i bdud), the māra of the afflictive emotions.
The name of the demonic being or beings that work to reinforce and maintain the veils of ordinary existence that obscure the nature of reality.
Literally, “Death” or “Demon.” The personification of everything that functions as a hindrance to awakening.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

(1) A demonic being often bearing the epithet of the “Evil One” (pāpīyān, sdig can), sometimes said to be the principal deity in Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations, the highest paradise in the desire realm; also one of the names of the god of desire, Kāma in the Vedic tradition. He is portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment. In early soteriological religions, the principal deity in saṃsāra, such as Indra, would attempt to prevent anyone’s realization that would lead to such a liberation. (2) The devas ruled over by Māra and assisting his attempts to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment; they do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra. More generally, they are symbolic of the defects within a person that prevent enlightenment. These four personifications are the māra of the sons of gods (devaputramāra, lha’i bu’i bdud), which is the distraction of pleasures; the māra of death (mṛtyumāra, ’chi bdag gi bdud); the māra of the aggregates (skandhamāra, phung po’i bdud), which is the body; and the māra of the afflictions (kleśamāra, nyon mongs pa’i bdud).

A class of beings related to the demon Māra (literally “death” in Sanskrit) or a term for the demon Māra himself. Māra and the māras are portrayed as the primary adversaries and tempters of people who vow to take up the religious life, and māras can be understood as a class of demonic beings responsible for perpetuating the illusion that keeps beings bound to the world and worldly attachments and the mental states those beings elicit.
The demon Māra. See “māra.”
The demon who assailed the Buddha Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

A class of beings related to the demon Māra or a term for the demon Māra himself. Māra and the māras are portrayed as the primary adversaries and tempters of people who vow to take up the religious life, and can be understood as a class of demonic beings responsible for perpetuating the illusion that keeps beings bound to the world and worldly attachments and the mental states those beings elicit.

In Sanskrit and Pāli, lit. “Maker of Death”; a demon in Buddhism who is the personification of evil and spiritual death. He notoriously assailed the future Buddha as he sat beneath the Bodhi tree and similarly impedes the spiritual progress of Buddhist practitioners in general.
Personification of evil and creator of obstacles; the tempter of Buddha Śākyamuni.
An obstacle maker; a personification of evil.

The deities ruled over by Māra, they are also symbolic of the defects within a person that prevent awakening. These four personifications are (1) devaputramāra (lha’i bu’i bdud), the divine māra, which is the distraction of pleasures, (2) mṛtyumāra (’chi bdag gi bdud), the māra of the Lord of Death, (3) skandhamāra (phung po’i bdud), the māra of the aggregates, i.e., the body, and (4) kleśamāra (nyon mongs pa’i bdud), the māra of the afflictive emotions.

The name of the demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening, a generic name for the deities in Māra’s realm, and an impersonal term for the factors that keep beings in saṃsāra. Although Māra is said to be the principal deity in Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin, the highest paradise in the desire realm, in this sūtra they are different deities.

The deities ruled over by Māra, who attempted to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment; they do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra. Also, they are symbolic of the defects within a person that prevents enlightenment. These four personifications are devaputra māra (lha’i bu’i bdud) the “divine māra,” which is the distraction of pleasures; mṛtyumāra (’chi bdag gi bdud) the “māra of death”; skandhamāra (phung po’i bdud) the “māra of the aggregates,” which is the body; and kleśamāra (nyon mongs pa’i bdud) the “māra of the kleśas.”

The deity that attempted to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment, also one of the names of Kāma, the god of desire, in the Vedic tradition. Sometimes portrayed as the lord of the highest paradise in the desire realm, and the devas he rules are therefore all called “māras”; he does not wish any being to escape from that realm. He is also symbolic of the defects within a person that prevent enlightenment.

The personification of negativity who assaulted the future Buddha as he sat beneath the bodhi tree. Also translated here as “demon.” See also the four aspects of Māra, listed here as the demon of afflictions, the demon of the aggregates, the demon of the divine son, and the demon of the lord of death.
The being who orchestrates and perpetuates the illusion of cyclic existence.
The being who orchestrates and perpetuates the illusion of cyclic existence.

A class of beings related to the demon Māra or a term for the demon Māra himself. Māra and the māras are portrayed as the primary adversaries and tempters of people who vow to take up the religious life, and can be understood as a class of demonic beings responsible for perpetuating the illusion that keeps beings bound to the world and worldly attachments and the mental states those beings elicit.
The class of beings known as the māras is led by Māra, who is best known in Buddhist traditions as the demonic force that perpetuates the illusion of saṃsāra.
The leader of the class of beings known as the māras, Māra is best known in Buddhist traditions as the demonic force that perpetuates the illusion of saṃsāra.
A demonic being opposed to the spread of the Dharma and the happiness of beings.
The embodiment of evil, anti-spiritual forces.
This term, usually occuring in the plural, is applied to the followers of Māra, or the personified negative forces in general.
The demon opposing the Buddha’s teaching; in the plural (māras) it denotes all such nonhuman beings; a personification of evil.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.

In Sanskrit and Pāli, literally “maker of death”; a demon in Buddhism who is the personification of evil and spiritual death. He notoriously assailed the future Buddha as he sat beneath the Bodhi tree and similarly impedes the spiritual progress of Buddhist practitioners in general. Used in plural form, the term can refer to the members of Māra’s army or any other demonic force that impedes spirituality.

In Sanskrit and Pāli, literally “Maker of Death;” a demon in Buddhism who is the personification of evil and spiritual death. He notoriously assailed the future Buddha as he sat beneath the Bodhi tree and similarly impedes the spiritual progress of Buddhist practitioners in general.
An epithet of Māra.

Said to be the principal deity in Paranirmitavaśavartin, the highest paradise in the desire realm, and also portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment. In early soteriological Indian religions, the principal deity in saṃsāra, such as Indra, would attempt to prevent anyone’s realization that would lead to such a liberation. The name Māra, literally “death,” is also used as an impersonal term for the factors that keep beings in samsara.

Said to be the principal deity in Paranirmitavaśavartin, the highest paradise in the desire realm, and also portrayed as attempting to prevent the Buddha’s enlightenment. In early soteriological Indian religions, the principal deity in saṃsāra, such as Indra, would attempt to prevent anyone’s realization that would lead to such a liberation. The name Māra, literally “death,” is also used as an impersonal term for the factors that keep beings in samsara.
The name of the being who maintains the illusions of the world that bind beings in cyclic existence.

Originally the name of Indra’s principal enemy among the asuras. In early Buddhism he appears as a drought-causing demon, and eventually his name becomes that of Māra, the principal opponent of the Buddha’s teaching. The name also applies to the deities ruled over by Māra who attempted to prevent the Buddha’s awakening and who do not wish any being to escape from saṃsāra.

A class of beings related to the demon Māra or a term for the demon Māra himself. Māra and the māras are portrayed as the primary adversaries and tempters of people who vow to take up the religious life, and māras can be understood as a class of demonic beings responsible for perpetuating the illusion that keeps beings bound to the world and worldly attachments and the mental states those beings elicit.
The demon who assailed Śākyamuni prior to his awakening; any demonic force; the personification of conceptual and emotional obstacles.
The term is used to refer to negativity as a force. In ancient India, it was personified by the entity called “Māra,” whose sole intention is to harm beings or divert them from good.
The personification of negativity.
The personification of negativity. Four māras are usually listed: the aggregates, the afflictions, the māra of the gods (= the god of infatuation), and death.
The personification of negativity. In the Sanskrit tradition, four māras are usually listed: the aggregates, the afflictions, the god Māra (= the god of infatuation), and death.
A king.

en: Eighteen qualities of the blissful ones
comment_en: See “eighteen unique buddha qualities.”
Lay female pupil of the Buddha, who is only known from this sūtra.
An epithet for a buddha.

An epithet applied to buddhas, often interpreted to mean “one gone to bliss.” It should be noted, though, that in Sanskrit the prefix su- (Tib. bde bar) is adverbial, and that gata denotes a state of being rather than literal motion, hence the current rendering of “well-gone one,” that is, “one who has fared well.”
The name of the energy center (cakra) at the top of the head.
One of the epithets of Saṃvara.
A buddha realm.
The realm of Buddha Amitāyus, more commonly known as Amitābha, which was first described in the Sukhā­vatī­vyūha Sūtra.
The pure realm of the buddha Amitābha.
Meaning “the delightful” or “the land of delight,” the name of the buddhafield of Amitābha / Amitāyus, in the western direction from our world.
The realm of Buddha Amitābha, described in the Sukhāvatī­vyuha Sūtra, where Avalokiteśvara first appears in the sūtras.
The realm of Buddha Amitāyus, more commonly known as Amitābha, as first described in the Sukhāvatīvyuha Sūtra.
The buddha realm in which Buddha Amitābha lives.
The buddha realm in which Buddha Amitābha lives.
The buddha field in which the Buddha Amitābha lives.
The Buddha Amitābha’s buddha field known as the Land of Bliss.
The buddha realm in which the Buddha Amitāyus lives.
The pure land of Buddha Amitābha in which a practitioner can take rebirth through a combination of pure faith, sufficient merit, and one-pointed determination.
The buddhafield of Buddha Amitābha.
“Endowed with Happiness.”
The buddha realm, located in the western direction, in which Buddha Amitābha resides.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Infinite Renown.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Amitābha/Amitāyus.
The name of the western buddhafield of the tathāgata Amitābha.
The buddhafield of the Thus-Gone One Amitābha.
The buddhafield of the Thus-Gone Amitābha.
The paradise of Amitābha.
The buddha realm in which the Buddha Amitābha lives.
The realm of Buddha Amitāyus, more commonly known as Amitābha, as first described in the Sukhāvatīvyūha Sūtra.
The realm of Buddha Amitāyus, more commonly known as Amitābha, as first described in the Sukhāvatīvyūha Sūtra.
The realm where the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus resides.
The blissful western pure realm of the Buddha Amitābha/Amitāyus.
The pure realm of the Buddha Amitābha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Luminosity.
The realm of Amitābha.
An eastern buddha realm where the buddha Mārapramardaka resides.

A universe, or buddhafield, where the bodhisattvas live in a constant state of bliss. The Skt. of the Potala MS has Sarva­sukha­pratimaṇḍita, that of the excerpt cited in the Śikṣāsamuccaya has Sarvasukhamaṇḍitā.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.

term: བདེ་བ་ དང་ སྡུག་བསྔལ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལ་ མངོན་པར་ དགའ་བ་ མེད་པ
en: Absence of Joy with Respect to All Happiness and Suffering
comment_en: Name of the ninety-third meditative stability.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The realm of the Buddha Amitābha, also known as Amitāyus, which was first described in the Sukhāvatīvyūha Sūtra (Toh 115, The Display of the Pure Land of Sukhāvatī ).

An epithet of the buddhas meaning “one who has gone to bliss.” Here used also as an epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni.
Sometimes misinterpreted as “one gone to bliss”; the su or bde bar is adverbial, and gata denotes a state of being rather than literal motion. Therefore it means “one who has fared well.”

Epithet of a buddha.

Lit. “who goes to bliss,” a contraction of the Sanskrit sukham gatah). A name of the Buddha.
Synonym for a buddha.
An epithet for a buddha typically meaning “well-gone one,” but also interpreted as “bliss-gone one.”

One of the standard epithets of the buddhas. A recurrent explanation offers three different meanings for su- that are meant to show the special qualities of accomplishment of one’s own purpose (svārthasampat) for a complete buddha. Thus, the Sugata is “well” gone, as in the expression su-rūpa (“having a good form”); he is gone “in a way that he shall not come back,” as in the expression su-naṣṭa-jvara (“a fever that has utterly gone”); he has gone “without any remainder” as in the expression su-pūrṇa-ghaṭa (“a pot that is completely full”). According to Buddhaghosa, the term means that the way the Buddha went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su) and where he went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su).
Epithet of the Buddha.
One of the standard epithets of the buddhas. According to Buddhaghosa, the term means that the way the Buddha went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su) and where he went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su).
An epithet of the buddhas meaning “one who has gone to bliss.” Here used also as an epithet of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
An epithet of the buddhas, meaning “the blissfully gone one” or “the well gone one.”
An epithet of the buddhas meaning “one who has gone to bliss.” The Sanskrit term literally means “faring well.”
Epithet of a buddha.
An epithet of the buddhas meaning “well-gone one.”

An epithet applied to buddhas, often interpreted to mean “one gone to bliss.” It should be noted, though, that in Sanskrit the prefix su- (Tib. bde bar) is adverbial, and that gata denotes a state of being rather than literal motion, hence the current rendering of “well-gone one,” that is, “one who has fared well.”

The term sugata is formed by the preverb su- (“well,” “good,” “completely”) and the participle gata, from the root gam (“to go” but also “to understand”). A recurrent explanation offers three different meanings for su- that are meant to show the special qualities of accomplishment of one’s own purpose (svārthasampat) for a complete buddha. Thus, the Sugata is “well” gone, as in the expression su-rūpa (“having a good form”); he is gone “in a way that he shall not come back,” as in the expression su-naṣṭa-jvara (“a fever that has utterly gone”); he has gone “without any remainder” as in the expression su-pūrṇa-ghaṭa (“a pot that is completely full”). These three senses of su- distinguish the Buddha from non-Buddhist practitioners who are free of desirous attraction (bāhya-vītarāga), from Buddhist practitioners who are still in need of training (śaikṣa), i.e., are not liberated, and from Buddhist practitioners who have no more need of training (aśaikṣa), i.e., are liberated but have not obtained complete buddhahood (svārtha­sampat sugatatvena trividham artham upādāya praśastatvārthaṃ surūpavat apunarāvṛttyarthaṃ sunaṣṭajvaravat niḥśeṣārthaṃ supūrṇaghaṭavat arthatrayaṃ caitad bāhyavītarāga­śaikṣāśaikṣebhyaḥ svārtha­sampadviśeṣaṇārtham, Dignāga, Pramāṇa­samuccaya 1.1, Steinkellner 2005, p. 1; see also Prajñākaramati’s Pañjikā on Bodhi­caryāvatāra 1.1, de La Vallée Poussin 1901–14, pp. 2–3; and Artha­viniścaya­sūtra­nibandhana, Samtani 1971, p. 244). The sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa commentary on the Mahāvyutpatti, apart from the three explanations above, contains an additional interpretation of the preverb su-, as meaning “happiness/bliss/pleasure” (sukha), attributed to the Dharmaskandha (one of the abhidharma treatises of the Sarvāstivāda tradition); thus su-gata is understood as “one who has reached happiness” (su[khaṁ]gata): “The Bhagavat has happiness; he has heavenly happiness, since he is endowed with the untroubled dharma” (dharmmaskandha las ’byung ba sugata iti sukhito bhagavān | svargita avyathitadharmmasamanvāgata | tad ucyate sugata ces ’byung ste). The commentary further explains that the Tibetan rendering bde bar gshegs pa is in fact in accordance with the Dharmaskandha interpretation of the term (dharmaskandha las ’byung ba dang sbyar te bde bar gshegs pa zhes btags), which explains why the Tibetan rendering does not seem to match the more recurrent interpretations of sugata in Sanskrit treatises. The connection with sukham can also be found in lexicographical literature (see for example Subhūticandra’s Kavikāmadhenu commentary on the Amarakośa, Deokar 2014, p. 121; and also the Pāli Abhidhānappadīpikāṭīkā, Saggakaṇḍavaṇṇanā, which seems to be a shortened version of the Kavikāmadhenu gloss on sugata). The Pāli tradition offers a slightly different explanation, in four parts: “his way of going is good,” “he has gone to a beautiful place,” “he has gone in the right manner,” and, deriving gata not from gam but from gad (“to speak,” “to say”), “he speaks in the right manner” (sobhanagamanattā sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ gatattā sammā gatattā sammā ca gadattā sugato | Visuddhimagga, 1.134).

An epithet of the Buddha meaning “one who has gone to bliss” or, interpreting gata as denoting a state of being rather than literal motion, “one who has fared well.” The epithets sugata and tathāgata in this sūtra, which likely belonged to the canon of an early Buddhist school, seem to refer to the historical Buddha rather than to buddhas in general.
An epithet of the buddhas. Also rendered here as “sugata.”
“One gone to bliss.”An epithet of the buddhas. Also rendered here as “Gone to Bliss.”

One of the standard epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni. According to Buddhaghoṣa, the term means that the way the Buddha went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su) and where he went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su).

“One who fares well” or “one who is free from care.” Sometimes interpreted as “one gone to bliss.” The su or bde bar is adverbial, and gata, a past passive participle, denotes a state of being rather than literal motion and refers to a present state rather than a past one.
An epithet of the buddhas meaning “well-gone one.”
Synonym for a buddha.
“Bliss-gone one”; an epithet of the Buddha or a tathāgata.
An epithet for a buddha.

One of the standard epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni and other buddhas. According to Buddhaghoṣa, the term means that the way the Buddha went (Skt. gata) is good (Skt. su), and where he went (gata) is good (su).
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Departed to a Jewel Lotus. Likely the same as the world system Beautiful Entrance.
A river at Radiant Streams.
A bodhisattva in the distant past.
Princess of Kośala, child of King Prasenajit.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a Śākya youth.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
The son of King Brahmadatta (present) of Vārāṇasī and the younger brother of Princess Kṣemaṅkarā.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; a south Indian king, contemporary of Mahendra.
A god.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A leader of the asuras.
A buddha.

A buddha in the past. Note that there appear to be three distinct buddhas with the name Kṣemaṃkara as is listed at note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5407. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-5278.
A buddha.

“Pleasure of Bliss.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.

A buddha realm.
A royal palace.
A northeastern buddha realm.
A royal palace ruled by King Śobha during the time of Buddha Kanakamuni or, alternately, during the time of Buddha Krakucchanda.
The wife of Indra.
A goddess typically understood to be the wife of Indra/Śakra.
The wife of Śakra.
A goddess typically understood to be the wife of Indra/Śakra. In this text, a female asura who attempts to seduce Surata and later becomes one of his attendants.

One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.

Name of a bodhisattva.

A Jain who features prominently in the sūtra The Range of the Bodhisattva (Toh 146, Satyaka Sūtra). The Buddha states that he is a bodhisattva who takes on various forms to aid beings. Also translated elsewhere as bden pa po and bden par smra ba. The latter term is reconstructed into Sanskrit as Satyavādin by Lozang Jamspal in his translation of the Satyaka Sūtra.

comment_en: The third of the four stages of penetrative insight, typically rendered simply as kṣānti or “patience.”

The Buddha’s first teaching, which explains suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering.

The four truths of nobles ones are the truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Another classification of the truths referred to in the sūtra is that of the two truths, conventional and ultimate.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Truthful.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.

en: Sixteen aspects (of the four truths of noble beings)
comment_en: These are impermanence, suffering, emptiness, absence of self, origination, causality, production, conditionality, cessation, peace, excellence, deliverance, path, reason, practice, and release. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-4133 for an explanation of these.
A class of demons closely related to or identical with the rākṣasas.
A rākṣasa deity (one of the eight guardians of directions).
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Nairṛta guards the southwest quarter. Also known as Nirṛti.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Melody of Truth.

A Middle Indic word derived from the Sanskrit bhadanta. Meaning “venerable one” it is a term of respectful title for Buddhist monks.

A term of respect for Buddhist monks: bandé in Tibet and Nepal, bhante in the Pali tradition. A middle-Indic word, it is said to be derived from vande, the BHS vocative form of the Sanskrit vanda, meaning praiseworthy or venerable, although bhante is said to be a contraction of the vocative bhadante, derived from a respectful salutation.
The general term from ancient India for any member of the ordained Buddhist saṅgha.

An important translator of the Tibetan imperial period who lived during the eighth and ninth centuries.
A prolific Tibetan translator active during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He is credited with translating no fewer than 380 works.
Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni. See “Lord” or “Blessed One,” and also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-121.

Honorific term for an ordained person.

This name seems to refer to the founder of the Śuṅga dynasty, Puṣyamitra Śuṅga.

The name of King Śibi’s palace.

‟Gentle-Faced One/She with the Beautiful Face,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
(1) The parrot of Āmrapālī. (2) A haṃsa who was the Buddha in a former life.
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.

comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Supreme Goodness. Likely the same as the thus-gone one King Victory Banner at the Pinnacle of Goodness.

One of the five companions of Śākyamuni in asceticism, who abandoned him when he renounced asceticism. Later they became the Buddha’s first five pupils, with Bhadrika the second of them to become his follower.
A lay brother living in Nādikā.
A western buddha realm.
A river on Flocking Peacocks.
The name of the charioteer Subhadra’s son who is ordained, attains arhatship, and leads his parents to attain stream entry and go forth.
Meaning “good,” it is the name of this present kalpa, so called because over a thousand buddhas will appear within it.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight great śrāvakas.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ disciple foremost in insight.

en: King Victory Banner at the Pinnacle of Goodness
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Supreme Goodness. Likely the same as the thus-gone one Victory Banner at the Pinnacle of Goodness.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha in a world realm in the eastern direction.
An upāsaka in Dhanyākara.
A prince in the distant past.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
The queen of a cakravartin in the distant past, a previous life of the night goddess Pramudita­nayana­jagad­virocanā.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one King Victory Banner at the Pinnacle of Goodness. Another name for the world system Delight in Goodness.
A son of King Sarvārthasiddha.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ father.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva present with the Buddha at Śrāvastī in chapter 1.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
An upāsaka in Dhanyākara.
A buddha realm.
A city.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The kalyāṇamitra of chapter 48.
The king of the asuras.
In the context of this sūtra, this appears to refer to the “age of perfection.”

Supreme among the upper-class monks. He became an arhat in the first rainy season. One of the first group of Śākya princes to become a monk. He is said to have been a king in many successive previous lifetimes, which is why the title of “king” is added after his name in the sūtra. He is not to be confused with the Bhadrika who was one of the Buddha’s first five pupils.
A buddha realm.

One of the five excellent companions, with whom Siddhārtha Gautama practiced asceticism near the Nairañjanā River and who later heard the Buddha first teach the Four Noble Truths at the Deer Park in Sarnath.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the first five disciples of the Buddha.
A virtuous nāga king.
One of the first five disciples of the Buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ queen.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the kings of the Nāgasena dynasty, identified with Grahavarman; one of the ancient kings of Madhyadeśa.
A head merchant’s son.
“Artistic,” the artistic one; Prince Puṇyabala’s brother who exemplifies craftsmanship.
Name of a magician in a story Buddha tells; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
The king of Magadha.
King of Magadha, the Buddha established him in the truth in Gayā. Also rendered here as “Śreṇiya Bimbisāra.”
See “Bimbisāra.”
Name of a mendicant (pari­vrājaka). See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1154.

Buddha of the universe Marīci, located sixty-one universes away; mentioned also in other Mahāyāna sūtras, with the interesting coincidence that his teaching ceased at the moment Śākyamuni began teaching at Benares.

term: བཟོད་པ་ དང་ དེས་པ་ ཆེན་པོ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: Mahāvyutpatti 1115.
A buddha realm.
The third of the six perfections.
Third of the six perfections. Also translated here as “acceptance.”
One of the six perfections.
One of the six or ten perfections.
The third of the six perfections.
A state of mind of forbearance in the face of a situation that would otherwise provoke anger; one of the six perfections.
Forbearance, patience, and/or tolerance. One of the six perfections of the bodhisattva.
Forbearance, patience, and/or tolerance. One of the six perfections of the bodhisattva.

The third of the six perfections. As such it can be classified into three modes: the capacity to tolerate abuse from sentient beings, to tolerate the hardships of the path to buddhahood, and to tolerate the profound nature of ultimate reality.

The third of the six perfections. As such it can be classified into three modes: the capacity to tolerate abuse from sentient beings, to tolerate the hardships of the path to buddhahood, and to tolerate the profound nature of ultimate reality.
Forbearance, tolerance, acceptance.
Third of the six transcendent perfections.
The ninety-fourth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Kṣānti­pradīpa­śirī.

en: Armor of the power of patience

comment_en: Name of the Buddha Śākyamuni in a past life, when he was a sage practicing bodhisattva conduct.
Foretold as the son of a future King Mahendrasena of Kauśāmbī. Not to be confused with Mahendrasena of Videha in the Buddha’s time.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the distant past.

In the time of the Kāraṇḍavyūha this was a group of four demons that created obstacles. This later became the name for the deity Ganesh (as a remover of obstacles), but that is not what is intended here.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
One of the mantra deities, possibly the same as Jvaloṣṇīṣa.
One of the rāśis.
A lake in Godānīya.
A mountain range in the Heaven Free from Strife.
The lord of the gods of the Thirty-Three.
King of the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. Also known as Indra.
Epithet of Indra.
Name of a god (deva), also known as “Indra.”

More commonly known in the West as Indra, the deity that is called “lord of the devas,” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru, and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu: one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. The highest Vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice, and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing them.
An epithet of Indra.
Chief of the gods of the Thirty-Three, who presides over the desire realm heaven.

More commonly known in the West as Indra, the deity who is called “lord of the devas” and dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, “one who has performed a hundred sacrifices.” The highest vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing them.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. Another name for Indra.

More commonly known in the West as Indra, the deity that is called “lord of the devas” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. The highest vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice, and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing them. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra; therefore this sutra mentions them in the plural.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. Also known as Indra.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Name of the god who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Usually (when spelled with the capital letter) this is one of the names of Indra; in this case is denotes any of the ruling gods in the Realm of the Thirty-Three Gods.
Another name of Indra, the chief god in the Realm of the Thirty-Three Gods.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Hindu god of fire; a central deity in the Vedas.
King of the gods of Trāyastriṃśa, another name for Indra.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty Three; equivalent to, or identified with, Indra.
An epithet for Indra, the king of the gods in Hindu mythology.
The lord of the gods. Also called “Kauśika.”
The lord of gods (Indra).
Another name for Indra, the divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A prominent god who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three, often identified with Indra; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. Also known as Indra.
An alternative name for Indra, lord of the devas, who, according to Buddhist cosmology, resides in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
The king of the gods.

In Buddhist texts, usual name for Indra, king of gods of the desire-realm (kāmadhātu) of a particular universe; hence a Śakra is lower in status than a Brahmā, who resides at the summit of the realm of pure matter (rūpadhātu). As in the case of Brahmā, a title, or status, rather than a personal name; each universe has its Śakra.

The lord of the gods. Alternatively known as Indra, the deity that is called “lord of the gods” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra.
The lord of the gods.

The Tibetan name used in this text corresponds to the Sanskrit “Śakra,” another name for the preeminent vajra-wielding Vedic deity Indra who is called “lord of the deities” and is associated with storms and righteous warfare. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, “one who has performed a hundred sacrifices.” In Buddhism, he is the god of the realm equivalent to the second heaven of the desire realm, the heaven of Thirty-Three Gods. In the Buddhist Avataṃsaka cosmology of innumerable (asaṃkhyeya) interpenetrating buddha realms, there are myriad Śakras (aka Indra), each presiding over his own world-system.

The lord of the gods. Also known as Indra, the deity who is called “Lord of the Gods” dwells on the summit of Mount Meru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on a creative etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Meru has a Śakra.
One of the chief Vedic deities. God of war and Lord of heaven.

Common epithet of the god Indra, in Skt. meaning “Mighty One,” and in Tib., “Hundred Gifts” (because he is said to have attained his state by performing one hundred pūjās). This epithet often appears together with the title “Lord of Gods.” He is ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

The lord of the gods. Alternatively known as Indra, the deity that is called “lord of the devas” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra.
A powerful deity who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three. Another name for Indra.
Alternate name for Indra, the king of the gods in Hindu mythology.
Another name for Indra, the god who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

The lord of the gods, more commonly known in the West as Indra, he dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a śakra.
An alternative name for Indra, lord of the gods, who, according to Buddhist cosmology, resides in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Alternate name for Indra, the lord who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Literally, “The one who performed a hundred offerings.” Name of Indra.
The lord of gods (Indra).

Common epithet of the god Indra, in Skt. meaning “Mighty One,” and in Tib., “Hundred Gifts” (because he is said to have attained his state by performing one hundred pūjās). This epithet often appears together with the title “King of Gods.” He is ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

The lord of the gods. More commonly known in the West as Indra, the deity who is called “lord of the gods” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra. Also referred to by the epithet Kauśika.

The lord of the gods. More commonly known in the West as Indra, the deity that is called “lord of the devas” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra. He is also called “Kauśika.”
An alternative name for Indra, lord of the gods, who, according to Buddhist cosmology, resides in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
See Indra.
One of the principal Hindu gods, the leader of the gods of the realm of Thirty-Three.
One of the names of Indra.
One of the principal gods. He rules over the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

Also known as Indra, he is the deity who is called “lord of the devas” and dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru, wielding the vajra. The Tibetan translation is based on the etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu (“one who has performed a hundred sacrifices”). The highest Vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice, and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing them. In this sūtra there are numerous Śakras in various worlds.

Also commonly known as Indra, he is the deity, called “lord of the devas,” who dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu: one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. The highest Vedic sacrifice was the horse sacrifice, and there is a tradition that he became the lord of the gods through performing them.
A common alternate name for Indra, the king of the gods.
The king of the gods, synonymous with the Vedic god Indra.

Common epithet of the god Indra, in Skt. meaning “Mighty One,” and in Tib., “Hundred Gifts” (because he is said to have attained his state by performing one hundred pūjās). This epithet often appears together with the title “Lord of the Gods.” He is ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty Three; equivalent to, or identified with, Indra.
King of the gods of the desire realm.
“Destroyer of Cities,” an epithet of Indra.
See “Indra.”
Epithet of Indra. Literally, “he who contains one hundred sacrificial rites.”
Alternate name for Indra, the lord who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Alternate name for Indra, the lord who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

The lord of the gods. Also known as Indra, the deity who is called “lord of the devas” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on a creative etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra.

Another name for Indra, a Vedic god who eventually emerged as one of the most important in the Vedic pantheon; Indra retains his role as the “Lord of the Gods” in Buddhist literature, where he is often referred to by the name Śakra.
The chief god in the realm of the thirty-three gods, also known as Śakra.
Another name for Indra, the chief god in the realm of the thirty-three gods.
An epithet used in many Buddhist texts to refer to Indra.
Epithet of Indra. Literally, “he who contains one hundred sacrificial rites.”

The lord of the gods. Alternatively known as Indra, the deity that is called “lord of the gods” dwells on the summit of Mount Sumeru and wields the thunderbolt. The Tibetan translation brgya byin (meaning “one hundred sacrifices”) is based on an etymology that śakra is an abbreviation of śata-kratu, one who has performed a hundred sacrifices. Each world with a central Sumeru has a Śakra.
The name of the king of the thirty-three gods, also known as Indra, who presides over the desire realm heaven called “the gods of the thirty-three.”
Sometimes functioning as an alternate name for Indra, Śakra is considered to be the ruler of the god realm and the leader of the army of devas.
The name of the king of the worldly gods, synonymous with the name Indra.
The lord of the gods.
The lord of the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A divine being who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Also known as Kauśika and as Indra. King of the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
A ṛṣi in the past.
A buddha realm.
A māra.
Name of the twentieth meditative stability.
The name of an absorption.
This is the name for epilepsy, but also refers to the demon that causes epilepsy and loss of consciousness, as in the Kāraṇḍavyūha. The Tibetan specifically means “causing forgetting.”
A demon that causes epilepsy.
A class of nonhuman beings believed to be responsible for epilepsy.
A class of spirits causing memory loss.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha.
A goddess.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A monk who has been ordained at least five or ten years without incurring an offense is considered stable.
A lay brother living in Nādikā.
King at the second level of the asuras.
An asura king.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A capital city in South India.
One of the grahas.
Another name for the great bodhisattva Dṛḍhamati.
A great bodhisattva and interlocutor in several long passages of this sūtra. Also called as Dṛḍhamati­kumāra­bhūta. Dṛḍhamati is the main interlocutor in the Śūraṃgamasamādhisūtra, Toh 132.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva and householder.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its eighteenth week.
A king in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
An earth goddess at the bodhimaṇḍa.

To accept charge of monk apprentices and monk journeymen, a monk must himself be both stable, meaning he has been ordained at least five or ten years without incurring an offense, and knowledgeable, meaning he has at least one of the twenty-one sets of five qualities described in “The Chapter on Going Forth.”
A town.
The king identified with Dhruvasena II of the Maitraka dynasty.
The forty-fifth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A great bodhisattva.
A head merchant’s son in Dhanyākara.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the kings of the Nāgasena dynasty.
Eldest son of the universal monarch Nimiṃdhara.
A buddha in the distant past.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
Name of the eighty-seventh meditative stability.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a yakṣa.
A village. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2552
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.

term: བརྩོན་འགྲུས་ ཀྱི་ ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་ སྤང་བ་ -འི་ འདུ་བྱེད་ དང་ ལྡན་པ་ -འི་ རྫུ་འཕྲུལ་ གྱི་ རྐང་པ
en: Support for miraculous ability combining meditative stability of perseverance with the formative force of exertion
comment_en: Second of the four supports for miraculous abilities.
Fourth of the six transcendent perfections.

term: བརྩོན་འགྲུས་ ཀྱི་ ཤུགས་ ཐུབ་པ་ -ར་ དཀའ་བ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ

Both the name of the fourteenth meditative stability and the second of the five powers.

comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Awakening of Beautiful Thought.

comment_en: A future buddha.
The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.

The fourth of the six perfections and second of the five powers.

Enthusiasm for virtue. One of the six perfections, the seven limbs of awakening, the five abilities, the four bases of magical power, and the five powers.
Fourth of the six perfections and one of the seven limbs of awakening, the five abilities, the four bases of magical power, and the five powers.
A state of mind characterized by joyful persistence when engaging in virtuous activity.
The fourth of the six perfections, it is also among the seven branches of enlightenment, the five abilities, the four bases of magical power, and the five powers. Also translated here as “effort.”

Although the name “Nepal” derives from it, the ancient Nepāla would probably not extend beyond the Kathmandu Valley.

(1) One of the seven golden mountains. (2) The city of the Thirty-Three Gods.
A city in the realm Dwelling in Excellent View.

Son of the householder Dhanika in Rājagṛha during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. After he and his parents heard the Dharma from the Buddha, he went forth and manifested arhatship. Also the name of a future buddha, see “Sudarśana.”

Son of the householder Dhanika in Rājagṛha during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. After he and his parents heard the Dharma from the Buddha, he went forth and manifested arhatship. Also the name of a future buddha, see “Sudarśana.”
A divine city filled with crowds of gods.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; a vidyā attendant upon Mañjuśrī; one of the great yakṣiṇīs.

The four levels of meditative absorption of form realm beings.

The four progressive levels of concentration of the form realm that culminate in pure one-pointness of mind, and are a requirement for cultivation of the five or six superknowledges, and so on. These are part of the nine gradual attainments.
Also translated as “concentrating.”
