One of the five undefiled aggregates (zag med kyi phung po lnga), the others being the aggregates of concentration (samādhi), discriminative awareness (prajñā), liberation (vimukti), and insight of the primordial wisdom of liberation (vimukti­jñāna­darśana).

One of the five undefiled aggregates (pañca anāsravaskandha, zag med kyi phung po lnga), also known as the five aggregates beyond the world (lokottaraskandha, ’jig rten las ’das pa’i phung po lnga), the others being the aggregates of absorption (samādhi), insight (prajñā), liberation (vimukti), and liberated wisdom vision (vimuktijñānadarśana).
First of the five pure aggregates.

en: Endowed with the Light of Ethical Conduct
comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Mount Sumeru.
A king in Jambudvīpa, Musulundha’s rebirth.
A head merchant’s son in Dhanyākara.
The Tibetan translator of this text. His dates are unknown but he lived sometime during the late 10th century to the middle of the 11th century.

Prolific 11th century Tibetan translator also known as Naktso Lotsawa (nag tsho lo tsā ba). He was sent to India by Lhalama Yeshe-Ö (lha bla ma ye shes ’od), the king of Western Tibet, and his grand-nephew Changchub-Ö (byang chub ’od) to invite Atiśa to Tibet.
One of the three translators responsible for the canonical translation of the SEV.
“Banner of Discipline;” the name of the person who sponsored the writing of the manuscript of the JAA.
The primary translator of this scripture.

Morally virtuous or disciplined conduct and the abandonment of morally undisciplined conduct of body, speech, and mind. One of the six perfections of the bodhisattva. Also often rendered as “ethics,” “discipline,” and so on.

The second of the six perfections. Morally virtuous or disciplined conduct and the abandonment of morally undisciplined conduct of body, speech, and mind. Also commonly called discipline and ethical conduct.

The second of the six perfections. Morally virtuous or disciplined conduct and the abandonment of morally undisciplined conduct of body, speech, and mind. Also commonly called discipline and ethical conduct.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A brahmin devotee of Buddhism.

comment_en: “Unlimited Life and Wisdom,” the name of the tathāgata who resides in the buddha field Aparimitaguṇasaṃcaya at the zenith; it can also be rendered Amitāyus.
Literally “long-lived.” A title referring to an ordained monk.
A respectful form of address between monks and also lay companions of equal standing. Literally: one who has a [long] life.
A respectful form of address between monks and also lay companions of equal standing. Literally, one who has a [long] life.
Literally “long-lived,” a term (often honorific) used to address a Buddhist monk.
An honorific title, literally meaning “life possessing,” that is applied especially to royal personages and Buddhist monks.
Honorific term for an ordained person.
A respectful form of address between monks, and also between lay companions of equal standing. It literally means “one who has a [long] life.”
Literally “long-lived.” A title referring to an ordained monk.
This seems to be another name for Amitavyūhavatī, the buddhafield where Tathāgata Amitāyurjñāna­viniścaya­rājendra lives.

term: ཚེ་ དཔག་ ཏུ་ མེད་པ་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ ངེས་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK. His name is elsewhere also given as “Amitāyurviniścaya­rājendra.”
The Buddha of Boundless Life, one of the three deities of longevity in the Tibetan tradition.
“The One Who Has Immeasurable Longevity.” For more details on this buddha, see Peter Alan Roberts and Emily Bower, trans. The Aparimitāyurjñāna Sūtra (1), Toh 674, Introduction at i.9.

“The One Who Has Immeasurable Longevity.” The shortest form of Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s name. For more details on this buddha, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-091-072.html#UT22084-091-072-14.

“The One Who Has Immeasurable Longevity.” The shortest form of Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s name. For more details on this buddha, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-091-073.html#UT22084-091-073-14.

The Buddha in the western realm of Sukhāvatī. Later and presently better known by his alternative name Amitābha. Not to be confused with the buddha of long life, Aparimitāyus, whose name has been incorrectly back-translated into Sanskrit as Amitāyus also.
Buddha especially associated with life energy and long life; the Sambhogakāya aspect of Amitābha. Also a name of Amitābha.

The buddha in the realm of Sukhāvatī. Later and presently, he is better known by his alternative name, Amitābha. Not to be confused with the buddha of long life, Aparimitāyus, whose name has been incorrectly back-translated into Sanskrit as Amitāyus also.
In the Ratnaketudhāraṇī, he is one of the six “directional” tathāgatas.
Celestial buddha of infinite life, another name for the Buddha Amitābha.
The buddha associated with longevity.
Another name for Amitābha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Sukhāvatī. Alternate name for Amitābha.
The name of a buddha.
Name of a buddha.
The buddha who presides over the buddhafield Sukhāvatī; also known as Amitābha.
The buddha who presides over the buddhafield Sukhāvatī; also known as Amitābha.
This seems to be another name for Amitavyūhavatī, the buddhafield where Tathāgata Amitāyurjñāna­viniścaya­rājendra lives.
The buddha associated with longevity.

Amitāyus is commonly used as the short form of the Buddha Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s name. It also often refers to Amitābha, as it was also the principal name for Amitābha in the earlier sūtras on Sukhāvatī.

Amitāyus is commonly used as the short form of the Buddha Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s name. It also often refers to Amitābha, as it was also the principal name for Amitābha in the earlier sūtras on Sukhāvatī.
“Unlimited Life,” the name of the tathāgata who resides in the buddha field Sukhāvatī in the west; it can also be rendered Amitāyus and is synonymous with Amitābha.
The buddha residing in the western buddha realm of Sukhāvatī. He is also known as Amitābha.
The buddha associated with longevity.
A world system.
Forty-seventh of the eighty minor marks.

term: ཚེམས་ རྩེ་མོ་ མཐོ་ ཞིང་ རྣོ་ ལ་ དཀར་བ
en: Teeth whose tips are long, sharp, and white
comment_en: Twenty-third of the thirty-two major marks.
One of Upananda’s two novices whose homoerotic play led the Buddha to forbid allowing two novices to live together.

A follower of a heterodox mendicant movement that emerged about the time of the Buddha around a pupil of Mahāvīra named Gośāla and survived until the 13th century; its followers adhered to a type of determinism and practiced strict asceticism.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A name that appears twice in the list of buddhas from whom Śākyamuni in previous lifetimes received the Samādhirāja, and who is described in particular in chapter 38.
“Great Gaṇapati,” an epithet of Gaṇeśa.
Gaṇapati, or Ganeśa, is the lord of the gaṇas, a class of asuras usually associated with the god Śiva. In the Purāṇic traditions Gaṇapati is portrayed as the elephant-headed son of Śiva and Pārvatī.
‟Lord of gaṇas,” an epithet of Gaṇeśa, the elephant-headed god invoked to remove obstacles.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A realm in the Heaven Free from Strife (multiple slightly variant versions are extant in the Tibetan, making the term sound more like a description than a proper noun).
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A river on Deer Abode.
An area in Kuru.
One of the Hindu gods, often identified with Gaṇeśa.

Gaṇapati, or Ganeśa, is the lord of the gaṇas, a class of demigods usually associated with the god Śiva. In the Purāṇic traditions Gaṇapati is portrayed as the elephant-headed son of Śiva and Pārvatī.
Name of a nāga king.
The name of the bodhisattva Aśoka when he became a buddha.

en: Leader of the Supreme and Infinite Gathering
comment_en: A buddha.
A buddha realm.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A market in Virtuous Castle.
A certain nun who is tricked in The Hundred Deeds by the Band of Six. She resided at the nunnery Royal Garden.
A buddha realm.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
A realm that neigbors the Black Line Hell. (The term Samāhṛtavedana is reading, on the authority of the Tib., samāhūta˚ as samāhṛta˚)

term: ཚོར་བ་ རྩུབ་ ཅིང་ ཚ་ལ་ བཟོད་པ་ དཀའ་བ
comment_en: One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
Second of the five psycho-physical aggregates.
Name of the thirty-first meditative stability.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
An important Buddhist monastery located in Bengal (modern day Bangladesh), founded by King Rāmapāla (ruled 1077–1120 ce).

Jasminum grandiflorum. Also known as Spanish or Catalonian jasmine, even though it originates in South India. Particularly used as offerings in both Buddhist and Hindu temples. In other sūtras, jāti is translated as sna ma.
Jasminum grandiflorum.
An Indian master, whose precise dates are unknown, and who wrote a commentary on the Entry into Laṅka Sūtra.
One of the “four sisters” invoked in a mantra.
Sesbania sesban.
“Flaming Mouth.” One of the eight nāga queens.
One of the four pīṭhas.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
This seems to be another name of Jambhala.
God of wealth.
One of the gods of wealth.
A goddess invoked to crush wayward beings.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāyabindupiṇḍārtha (Toh 4233), which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha (Toh 4233), which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries and named as one of the translators of this sūtra.

A Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha (Degé no. 4233), which is contained in the Tengyur (bstan ’gyur).
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha (Toh 4233),<Reference Toh 4233> which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
Indian paṇḍit who translated and edited (among many others) the sūtra Purification of Karmic Obscurations.
An Indian preceptor and translator who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of a number of sūtras.
A Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

A Kashmiri preceptor who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of various sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha , which is contained in the Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.

Jinamitra was invited to Tibet during the reign of King Trisong Detsen (r. 742–98 ce) and was involved with the translation of nearly two hundred texts, continuing into the reign of King Ralpachen (r. 815–38 ce). He was among the small group of paṇḍitas responsible for the Mahā­vyutpatti Sanskrit–Tibetan dictionary.

Jinamitra was invited to Tibet during the reign of King Trisong Detsen (khri srong lde btsan, r. 742–98 ce) and was involved with the translation of nearly two hundred texts, continuing into the reign of King Ralpachen (ral pa can, r. 815–38 ce). He was one of the small group of paṇḍitas responsible for the Mahāvyutpatti Sanskrit–Tibetan dictionary.
An Indian preceptor and translator who lived in the ninth century.
An Indian preceptor and translator who lived in the ninth century.
“Friend of the Victor,” an Indian paṇḍita who traveled to Tibet during the time of King Trisong Detsen to serve as a translator.
Eighth-century Indian teacher and translator.
An Indian paṇḍiṭa resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha (Toh 4233), which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha (Toh 4233), which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur collection.
An Indian paṇḍita and translator who was one of the great scholars invited to Tibet during the reign of King Trisong Detsen.

An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries. He worked with several Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras. He is also the author of the Nyāya­bindu­piṇḍārtha (Degé no. 4233), which is contained in the Tibetan Tengyur (bstan ’gyur) collection.
An Indian preceptor from Kashmir who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He was a frequent collaborator of Yeshé Dé.
An Indian Kashmiri paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries. He worked with multiple Tibetan translators on the translation of several sūtras.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

A short form of Jetavana, a park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kosala, which had been owned by Prince Jeta. Anāthapiṇḍada bought it from him at a high price in order to offer it to the Buddha as a place to house the monks during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery.

A grove owned by Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala (presently an area within Uttar Pradesh). It was bought by Anāthapiṇḍada and became the monastery that the Buddha spent most rainy seasons in, and is therefore the setting for many sūtras.

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kosala, which had been owned by Prince Jeta. Anāthapiṇḍada bought it from him at a high price in order to offer it to the Buddha as a place to house the monks during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery. Also known as Jetadhvaja. Other sūtras translate as rgyal bu rgyal byed kyi tshal.

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala. It was owned by Prince Jeta, and Anāthapiṇḍada bought it at a great price from him to offer to the Buddha as a place where the monks could be housed during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery.

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala. It was owned by Prince Jeta, and Anāthapiṇḍada bought it at a great price from him to offer to the Buddha as a place where the monks could be housed during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery.

An alternative name for Jetavana Park in Śrāvastī, the capital of Kosala, which had been owned by Prince Jeta. Anāthapiṇḍada bought it from him at a high price in order to offer it to the Buddha as a place to house the monks during the monsoon period, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery.
A holy city on the banks of the Gaṇgā in modern day Uttar Pradesh.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.

Nickname of the child of wealthy householders in Śrāvasti, so called because of his penchant for eating excrement and drinking urine. After taking instruction from the philosophical extremist Pūraṇa Kāśyapa, who admired his ostenisible austerities, he heard the Dharma from the Buddha, went forth, and manifested arhatship.
Another name of Bhavanandin, a half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A religious tradition derived from Śākyamuni’s elder contemporary Mahāvīra.
A snake.
An assistant translator and editor of this scripture.
Forty-first of the eighty minor marks.

comment_en: Twenty-seventh or thirty-first of the thirty-two major marks.
Thirty-seventh of the eighty minor marks.
A buddha.
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other technique being “special insight.”
Meditation of peaceful stability.
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other technique being “special insight.”
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation that focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being special insight.
One of the two primary forms of meditation in Buddhism, the other being insight.
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being “special insight.”
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as one of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other technique being “extraordinary insight.”
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other technique being “special insight.”
The first of the two main branches of Buddhist meditation (along with “expanded vision”) aiming at developing insight into the nature of reality.
Remaining with the object of meditation single-pointedly without distraction; the cause of higher meditative states.

One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other technique being special insight (Skt. vipaśyanā, Tib. lhag mthong).
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other technique being “insight” (vipaśyana).
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, centering on a peaceful focus. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other technique being “special insight.”
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other being “special insight.”
The first of the two main branches of Buddhist meditation, aiming at rendering the mind stable, subtle, and pliable.
Pacification or calm abiding.

Sometimes also translated as “mental quiescence.” Refers to a calm state without thought, or the meditative practice of calming the mind to rest free from the disturbance of thought. One of the two basic forms of Buddhist meditation, the other being transcendent insight (vipaśyanā, lhag mthong).

Refers to the meditative practice of calming the mind to rest free from the disturbance of thought. One of the two basic forms of Buddhist meditation, the other being special insight (vipaśyanā, lhag mthong).
Single-pointed meditative concentration developed through the techniques of settling the mind (Rigzin 352).

One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other technique being “special insight.” (Note that the term “tranquility” has also been used in this translation to render other terms related to zhi ba.)
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation, which focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, with the other technique being special insight.
One of the basic forms of Buddhist meditation that focuses on calming the mind. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being special insight.

The famed seventh-century Indian Buddhist master known most for his Madhyamaka treatises commenting on the works of the second- to third-century master Nāgārjuna. In Tibet, where Candrakīrti’s exegetical writings form the foundation for the study of Indian Madhyamaka thought, he is celebrated as a proponent of the Prāsaṅgika Madhyamaka approach in particular.
A prominent seventh-century master of the Madhyamaka (Middle Way) tradition.

(c. sixth century). The most important Mādhyamika philosopher after Nāgārjuna and Āryadeva, he refined the philosophical methods of the school to such a degree that later members of the tradition considered him one of the highest authorities on the subject of the profound nature of reality.

The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ son.
A buddha.
(1) A mountain to the north of Jambudvīpa (zla ba’i ri bo). (2) A mountain upon which the gods of the Four Great Kings will take position while awaiting the asura army (ri bo zla ba).
Name of a yakṣa.
A great bodhisattva.

en: Crest of the Victory Banner of the Moon
comment_en: Name of fifth meditative stability.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha realm.
A realm in the distant past.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
‟Moon Goddess,” in the Bhūtaḍāmara maṇḍala she is one of the eight goddesses of offerings.
A bodhisattva.
A king.
A river in Godānīya.

en: Lamp of the Moon [or Immaculate Moon]
comment_en: Name of the forty-seventh meditative stability.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Replete with Coral Trees.
A buddha from the past.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Another name of the king Gopendra.
Name of a brahmin, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha realm to the south.
A king in an age prior to that of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The name of an ancient king.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
The tenth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
The young man of Rājagrha who is the principal interlocutor for the Samādhirājasūtra. He is frequently addressed as “youth” or “young man,” (Skt. kumāra; Tib. gzhon nu).
A bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s retinue.
A buddha.
A buddha.
The name of an eon.
The young man of Rājagrha who is the principal interlocutor for the Samādhirājasūtra. He is frequently addressed as “youth” or “young man,” (Skt. kumāra; Tib. gzhon nu); see “the youth Candraprabha.”
A nobleman in the retinue of the Buddha. Also the name of a prophesied buddha.
(1) One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching. (2) A buddha in the eastern buddha realm Pariśuddha.
A buddha in a far-away world.
One of the bodhisattva great beings. He is also the principal interlocutor of The King of Samādhis Sūtra .
(1) Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Possessing Sun. (2) Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Supreme Fragrance.
A buddha.
A certain compassionate king of Vārāṇasī and a previous incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A buddha.
Name of a past king in a story Buddha tells.
A bodhisattva.

These three aspects, literally “circles” or “provinces,” are the doer, the action, and the object of the action. Their purity is variously described as being free of self-interest or free of conceptualization.
The name of the Tathāgata Aparimitāyus’ palace in the realm Sukhāvatī.
Alternative name for the realm of Retinue.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the six buddhas who preceded Śākyamuni in this Fortunate Eon.
One of the tathāgatas.
The first buddha of the Fortunate Eon.
Name of a former buddha usually counted as the first of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Kanakamuni, Kāśyapa, and Śākyamuni.

The first buddha of our eon; the fifth buddha of the “seven generations of buddhas” (sangs rgyas rab bdun). Also found as Kakutsanda, Kakutsunda, etc. See Edgerton (1985), s.v. Krakucchanda, for the various spellings.

The first Buddha of the “Good Eon” (bhadrakalpa) of one thousand buddhas, our own Śākyamuni having been the fourth, and Maitreya expected to come as the fifth. Also spelled Krakutsanda, Kukutsunda, Kukucchanda.
The first buddha of the Fortunate Eon (our current eon).
A previous buddha of this eon, often listed as the first of five buddhas of the present eon.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas.
A buddha in the past.
The wife of the brahmin Agnidatta.
A thus-gone one of the past.
City where Buddha Śākyamuni gave his first teaching.
Name of a mountain range in Buddhist cosmology.
A mountain range.
Unidentified mountain, probably synonymous with Cakravaḍa, which sometimes refers to the mountain that leads to hell.

“Circular mass.” There are at least three interpretations of what this name refers to. In the Kṣitigarbha Sutra it is a mountain that contains the hells, in which case it is equivalent to the Vaḍaba submarine mountain of fire, also said to be the entrance to the hells. More commonly it is the name of the outer ring of mountains at the edge of the flat disk that is the world, with Sumeru in the center. This is also equated with Vaḍaba, the heat of which evaporates the ocean so that it does not overflow. Jambudvīpa, the world of humans is in this sea to Sumeru’s south. However, it is also used to mean the entire disk, including Sumeru and the paradises above it.
The name of a mountain range.
Name of a mountain range in Buddhist cosmology.
A mountain range.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.

en: One like a Jewel Wheel and Fire
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Infused with the Fragrance of Flowers.
A ring of mountains at the end of the sea.

en: Bearer of the Armor of the Unimpeded Wheel
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
This title only appears in The Hundred Deeds. It may be a shortened title for one of the various versions of the Dharmacakrapravartanasūtra .
This title only appears in The Hundred Deeds. It may be a shortened title for one of the various versions of the Dharmacakrapravartanasūtra .

term: འཁོར་ལོ་ ལྟར་ ཡོངས་སུ་ བསྐོར་བ་ མཚན་མ་ -འི་ བར
comment_en: A place in Ultimate Torment.
A world realm in the distant past.
One of the mantra deities.
A king with a magical wheel, and wherever it rolls becomes his kingdom, so that he may rule over one to four continents.
A king with a magical wheel—wherever it rolls becomes his kingdom, so that he may rule over one to four continents.

A cakravartin is a king who rules over at least one continent, and gains his territory by the rolling of his magic wheel over the land. Therefore he is called a king with the revolving wheel. This is as the result of the merit he has accumulated in previous lifetimes.
Literally “wheel-wielder,” denotes a powerful being who has control over vast regions of the universe.
A king with a magical wheel; wherever it rolls becomes his kingdom, so that he may rule over one to four continents.
A king with a magical wheel. Wherever the wheel rolls becomes his kingdom, so that he rules from one to all four continents.

Apart from the standard meaning of a universal emperor or wheel-turning monarch, this term, often along with “tathāgata,” is used as an epithet describing a class of mantra deities also referred to as “uṣṇīṣa kings.”
One of the eight uṣṇīṣa kings.
It is not clear who this name refers to.

A cakravartin is a king who rules over at least one continent and who secures his territory by the rolling of his magic wheel over the land. Therefore, he is called a king with the revolving wheel. This is as the result of the merit he has accumulated in previous lifetimes.

A term for an idealized, utopic vision of kingship in South Asian cultures. A cakravartin reigns over vast regions of the universe in accordance with principles of righteous law ( dharma ). Such a king is called a cakravartin because he possesses a wheel or discus (cakra) that rolls across different realms and brings them all under his power.
A universal monarch who conquers the entire world without violence.

A term for an idealized, utopic vision of kingship in South Asian cultures. A universal ruler reigns over vast regions of the universe in accordance with principles of righteous law (dharma). Such a king is called a cakravartin because he possesses a wheel or discus (cakra) that rolls across different realms and brings them all under his power.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
One of the muhūrtas.
A virtuous nāga king.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
A river on Forest Garlands.
One of the epithets of Bhūtaḍāmara.
A bodhisattva.
The Buddha’s cousin and one of his ten principal pupils, he was renowned for his clairvoyance. Often translated elsewhere as ma ’gags pa.

en: Appeasing of All Deviations and Obstacles
comment_en: Name of the ninety-eighth meditative stability.
See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-039.html#UT22084-072-039-314.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element fire.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.

en: Noble truth of the cessation of suffering
comment_en: Third of the four noble truths.

en: Knowledge of the cessation of suffering
comment_en: Seventh of the eleven aspects of knowledge.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
11th century translator and teacher of Guhya­samāja­tantra.
A yakṣiṇī.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
Twentieth of the thirty-two major marks.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a dance instructor in a story Buddha tells.

term: འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱིས་ སངས་རྒྱས་ མཐོང་བ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྨིན་པ་ -འི་ དགེ་བ་ -འི་ རྩ་བ་ ལས་ བྱུང་བ
comment_en: “The Vision of the Buddha by All Beings Arisen from Ripened Roots of Virtue.” The name of a ray of light.

term: འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ན་ རྒྱན་ གྱི་ དམ་པ་ ཕུལ
comment_en: The palace of Mahābrahmā. The name could be translated as “The Essence of the Array of All Worlds.” Jagad can also mean “beings” and therefore is regularly translated as ’gro ba (“beings”) in this sūtra. Here garbha, usually meaning “essence,” is translated as phul (“perfection”).

term: འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ བསྲུང་བ་ -འི་ སྨོན་ལམ་ ལ་ བརྩོན་པ་ -འི་ འོད
comment_en: A night goddess at the bodhimaṇḍa.
The seventy-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.

term: འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལ་ ཕན་པ་ -འི་ སྨོན་ལམ་ ཟླ་བ
comment_en: The second of five hundred buddhas in a kalpa in the distant future.

term: འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལ་ མངོན་དུ་ གྱུར་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲོན་མ
comment_en: “The Lamp of the Manifestation of All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.

en: Light That Shines on All Beings
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.

term: འགྲོ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ སྡུག་བསྔལ་ རབ་ཏུ་ ཞི་བ་ -ར་ བྱ་བ་ -འི་ དབུགས་ འབྱིན་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
‟Protectress of the World,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A bodhisattva.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.

A bodhisattva layman of Vaiśālī, who is saved by Vimalakīrti from being fooled by Māra posing as Indra. This bodhisattva is mentioned in Mvy, No. 728, and in the Rāṣṭra­pāla­paripṛccha (Toh 62, in the Ratnakūṭa; see Lamotte, p. 204, n. 120 and Vienna Buddhist Studies Translation Group, trans., The Questions of Rāṣṭrapāla , 1.2).
Name of a bodhisattva.

term: འགྲོ་བ་ སྡུག་བསྔལ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ དབུགས་ འབྱིན་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
en: Song That Relieves All the Suffering of Beings
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A garuḍa.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
The thirty-fifth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods.
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
A nāga. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2561.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Another name for the Dravidian, non-Aryan people and language(s) of South India and northern Sri Lanka. Dramiḍa (actually spelled drāmiḍa in the Sanskrit of the quote from this text in the Śikṣāsamuccaya) is the origin of the word Tamil; other Dravidian languages are Telugu, Malayalam, and Kannada.
One of the prominent peoples of the Indian Subcontinent who were already present there prior to the arrival of the Aryans in around 1500 ce.
(1) A country of the Deccan region of India. (2) A kingdom in southern India.
The hundred-and-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
A village or town in Kosala. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1909.
King of the country of Suvīra during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
See “Udayin.”
Name of an ascetic in a story the Buddha tells.
The pupil of the Buddha who is said to be foremost in inspiring faith among laypeople.
One of the kings of Nepal, possibly Udayadeva of the seventh century; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha.

The son of the court priest in Kapilavastu, the Buddha’s home town. Also called Kālodāyin (black Udāyin) because of his dark skin. He and his wife Guptā became monk and nun. He became an arhat who was a skilled teacher. However he also figures prominently in accounts of inappropriate sexual behavior that instigated vinaya rules. He and Guptā are also said to have conceived a son after their ordination.
A king of Vatsa, contemporary of the Buddha; also, a king based in Ujjain, contemporary of the Buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Śrāvaka arhat.

term: འཆི་བ་ ཤེས་པ་ འགོག་པ་ ཤེས་པ་ ལ་ མཁས་པ
en: Skilled in the Knowledge of Cessation as Related to the Knowledge of Death
comment_en: A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Another name for King Yama (Skt. yamarāja; Tib. gshin rje rgyal po), the deity who judges the dead and rules over the hell realms of the underworld.

en: Demon of the lord of death
comment_en: The aspect of Māra that is death itself.

en: Māra of the Lord of Death
comment_en: This is the figurative or embodied demon of death.

The name of the dhāraṇī that confers rebirth in Sukhāvatī taught by the Buddha Śākyamuni in The Noble Dhāraṇī “Essence of Immeasurable Longevity and Wisdom.” Also the name of a buddha traditionally equated with Amitābha or Amitāyus. Also called Dundubhi­svara­rāja.

en: Radiant Flower of the Realization of Immortality
comment_en: A buddha.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell. Alternatively referred to as Impossible to Die (gsod med) in the Tibetan text.
A bodhisattva.
A goddess of pestilence; pestilence personified.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The bodhisattva Mañjuśrī; literally “Youthful Mañjuśrī.”
Name of a bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom, with the additional honorific title for a young man. Also rendered here as “Mañjusvara” and “Mañjuśrī.”
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom, with the additional honorific title for a young man.
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom.
Also rendered here as “Mañjuśrī.”
See “Mañjuśrī.”
Mañjuśrī who takes the form of a youth, an epithet by which the well-known bodhisattva is often referred.
One of the eight main bodhisattvas, the heart sons of the Buddha.
An epithet of the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.
An epithet of the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.

Mañjuśrī who takes the form of a youth, an epithet by which the well-known bodhisattva is often referred. He is considered to be the embodiment of the transcendent perfection of insight and is portrayed wielding a sword in his right hand that cuts through delusion and a volume of the Prajñā­pāramitā­sūtra in his left that contains teachings on transcendent insight.
The bodhisattva Mañjuśrī, who is considered the embodiment of wisdom, with the additional honorific title for a young man.
The bodhisattva of wisdom. One of the most popular bodhisattvas of the Mahāyāna pantheon. Also know simply as Mañjuśrī.
One of the most popular bodhisattvas of the Mahāyāna pantheon. Another name of Mañjuśrī.
A bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva of wisdom; same as Mañjuśrī.

Evolved from the gandharva Pañcaśikha in early Buddhism, which remains one of Mañjuśrī’s alternate names. Pañcaśikha was a gandharva who lived on a five-peaked mountain, and who brought the Buddha information on what was occuring in the paradises. Mañjuśrī is the first prominent bodhisattva after Maitreya in the early Mahāyāna sūtras, where he is known as Mañjughoṣa (“Having a Beautiful Voice”). He came to embody wisdom, and became one of the eight great bodhisattvas. In the early tantras he was the lord of one of the three buddha families. In the Sanskrit version of the sūtra, Kumārabhūta is a separate word rather than a compound with his proper name. This means that it could be the second of his names, and it is glossed as meaning “always young.” Alternatively it could be treated simply as an adjective, as in “the youth Manjuśrī.”

Evolved from the gandharva Pañcaśikha in early Buddhism, which remains one of Mañjuśrī’s alternate names. Pañcaśikha was a gandharva who lived on a five-peaked mountain, and who brought the Buddha information on what was occuring in the paradises. Mañjuśrī is the first prominent bodhisattva after Maitreya in the early Mahāyāna sūtras, where he is known as Mañjughoṣa (“Having a Beautiful Voice”). He came to embody wisdom, and became one of the eight great bodhisattvas. In the early tantras he was the lord of one of the three buddha families. In the Sanskrit version of the sūtra, Kumārabhūta is a separate word rather than a compound with his proper name. This means that it could be the second of his names, and it is glossed as meaning “always young.” Alternatively it could be treated simply as an adjective, as in “the youth Manjuśrī.”
A common epithet for the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.
Bodhisattva of wisdom and one of the Buddha’s principal interlocutors in many sūtras.
Mañjuśrī who takes the form of a youth, an epithet by which the well-known bodhisattva is often referred.
A disciple of Āryadeva.
A great bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom. Also known as Mañjuśrī­kumāra­bhūta.
The bodhisattva of wisdom; one of the bodhisattvas in the retinue of the Buddha.
Toh 360.
Name of a bodhisattva, “Beautiful Glory, Lovely Splendor.”
The bodhisatva of wisdom.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom. Also called “Mañjusvara” and “Mañjuśrī Kumārabhūta.”
A great bodhisattva, one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha; considered the embodiment of wisdom.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom. Also known as Mañjuśrī Kumārabhūta, Mañjughoṣa or Pañcaśikha.
Name of a bodhisattva, “Beautiful Glory,” or “Lovely Splendor.”
The bodhisattva of wisdom; one of the bodhisattvas in the retinue of the Buddha.
Also rendered here as “Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta.”
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom. In this text, he is one of the main interlocutors of the Buddha.
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha; the embodiment of wisdom.
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha; the embodiment of wisdom.
The bodhisatva of wisdom.

The eternally youthful crown prince (kumārabhūta), so called because of his special identification with the Prajñā­pāramitā, or Transcendence of Wisdom. He is the only member of the Buddha’s retinue who volunteers to visit Vimalakīrti, and he serves as Vimalakīrti’s principal interlocutor throughout the sūtra. Traditionally regarded as the wisest of bodhisattvas, in Tibetan tradition he is known as rgyal ba’i yab gcig, the “sole father of buddhas,” as he inspires them in their realization of the profound. He is represented as bearing the sword of wisdom in his right hand and a volume of the Prajñā­pāramitā­sūtra in his left. He is always youthful in appearance, like a boy of sixteen.
A great bodhisattva, one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom. Also called here Mañjuśrī­kumāra­bhūta, literally “Youthful Mañjuśrī.”
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of insight (prajñā). Also known as Youthful Mañjuśrī.
Bodhisattva embodying wisdom. Also rendered here as Mañjuśrī­kumāra­bhūta.
A well-known bodhisattva who often figures prominently in the Great Vehicle teachings.
Bodhisattva of wisdom. Also called Mañjuśrī­kumāra­bhūta and Mañjughoṣa in this sūtra.
Bodhisattva of wisdom.
The bodhisattva known for his mastery of wisdom. Also rendered here as Mañjuśrī­kumāra­bhūta.
Bodhisattva of wisdom.
A great bodhisattva, one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom.
The deified bodhisattva of wisdom; one of the original sixteen bodhisattvas.
The bodhisattva who is considered the embodiment of wisdom.
See Mañjuśrīkumārabhūta.
One of the most popular bodhisattvas of the Mahāyāna pantheon. Also known as Mañjuśrīkumārabhūta.
A great bodhisattva, one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom.
The bodhisattva Mañjuśrī.
The bodhisattva and the deity of wisdom.
Name of a bodhisattva.
See “Mañjuśrī Kumārabhūta.”
See “Mañjuśrī Kumārabhūta.”
A great bodhisattva, one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of wisdom.
The bodhisatva of wisdom.
A bodhisattva known for his mastery of wisdom.
See “Mañjusvara.”
Meaning “gentle or beautiful voice,” this is an alternative name for Mañjuśrī. It is synonymous with Mañjughoṣa, which is also translated into Tibetan as ’jam dbyangs. See also “Mañjuśrī.”
Name of a tathāgata, a form of Mañjuśrī.
An alternative name for Mañjuśrī, meaning, “gentle or beautiful voice.”
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Resolver of Doubts Regarding Transgressing All Vows.
An alternate name for Mañjuśrī.
See “Mañjuśrī.”
“One with a sweet voice,” an epithet of the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī. The name is also written as “Mañjusvara.”
See “Mañjughoṣa.”
An epithet of Mañjuśrī.
One of the future buddhas.
One of the peaceful forms of Mañjuśrī.
Emanation of Mañjuśrī; the deity delivering the SEV.
A peak on Sumeru.
Pongamia pinnata.
Name of a tathāgata.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Gandharva king present at the teaching of the sūtra.
One of the grahas.

term: འཇིག་ཚོགས་ ལ་ ལྟ་བ་ -འི་ རི་ -འི་ རྩེ་མོ་ མཐོན་པོ་ ཉི་ཤུ
en: Twenty high peaks of the mountain of views concerning the transitory collection
comment_en: “The body is not the self nor does the self have a body; / The self is not based on the body [n]or body on self. / Know that these four relations apply to all skandhas; / So these are considered the twenty views of self.” (Goldfield 387).
A temple on Mount Gośṛṅga.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ ཀྱི་ ཁམས་ དུ་མ་པ་ ཁམས་ སྣ་ཚོགས་པ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ ཇི་ལྟ་བ་ བཞིན་ དུ་ རབ་ཏུ་ ཤེས་པ
en: Definitive knowledge of multiple world systems and diverse dispositions
comment_en: Fourth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
Name of a future buddha.
A bodhisattva present at the sūtra’s teaching.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གསུམ་ གྱི་ ཁྱུ་མཆོག་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གནོན་པ
en: Powerful Leader of the Three Realms
comment_en: A buddha.
Name of a buddha.
A bodhisattva.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ གནོད་པ་ དང་ སྐྱོ་བ་ ལས་ རབ་ཏུ་ བརྒལ་བ
comment_en: A buddha in the western direction.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གནོན
comment_en: A bodhisattva.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལས་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ ཅོད་པན
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
The world system presided over by the Buddha Śākyamuni.

This universe of ours, or the trichiliocosm (but sometimes referring to just this world system of four continents), presided over by Brahmā. The term is variously interpreted as meaning the world of suffering, of endurance, of fearlessness, or of concomitance (of karmic cause and effect).
A world where Mahā­maudgalyāyana’s mother was reborn.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས་ སྟོང་གསུམ་ གྱི་ སྟོང་ ཆེན་པོ
comment_en: A very large universe.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས་ སྟོང་གསུམ་ གྱི་ སྟོང་ ཆེན་པོ
comment_en: The largest universe spoken of in Buddhist cosmology, consisting of one billion smaller world systems.
The fourth of the four stages of penetrative insight.

en: King Who Is Lord of the World’s Orb
comment_en: A buddha.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ དབང་པོ་ དམ་པ་ -འི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

According to abhidharma cosmology, when different world systems form, they drift near each other, but remain divided by the spaces (small according to some descriptions, immense according to others) between the massive rings of stone that surround each of them. These spaces are completely dark, unreached by any light from the suns of the worlds they lie between. Often classified as one kind of hell, these frigid and desolate places are populated by beings brought there by very negative karma. They cling to the cliffs, climbing around in darkness searching for sustenance. When they encounter fellow sufferers, they fight and try to push each other off, and tumble into the icy waters below.
Places that are said to be miserable, dark, and gloomy.

The places between adjacent world systems, outside their defining ring of mountains, that are said to be miserable and in utter darkness as the suns and moons of the world systems can shed no light there. They are nevertheless said to be inhabited by numerous beings and are sometimes counted among the hell realms.

“Guardians of the world.” Also called “guardians of the directions” (digpāla; phyogs skyong), which are specifically listed to be Śakra (Indra, lord of the devas, for the east), Yama (lord of the dead, for the south), Varuṇa (lord of water for the west), Kubera (Vaiśravaṇa, lord of yakṣas, for the north), Agni (lord of fire, for the southeast), Vāyu (lord of air, for the northwest), Īśāna (Śiva, for the northeast), Nairṛta (Rākṣasa, lord of the rākṣasas, for the southwest), Brahmā (lord of the universe, for above), and Pṛthvī (or Pṛthivī, goddess of the earth, for below).
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Placid River of Jambu.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great piśācīs.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ འཇིགས་པ་ དང་ ཕམ་པ་ དང་ བག་ཚ་བ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ འཇོམས་པ
comment_en: A buddha in the northeastern direction.
A summit in Ornament of the Mind.
The fourth of five hundred buddhas in a kalpa in the distant future.
Name of the 103rd meditative stability; could also be translated “Illuminator in all Respects.”

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལས་ ཁྱད་པར་ དུ་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ སྤོབས་པ
འཇིག་རྟེན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལས་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ ཅོད་པན
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Lokendra­teja­śiri­bhadra.
Name of a yakṣa.

en: Song of the Lord of the World
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ དབང་པོ་ -འི་ ལུས་ ནི་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ འོད
comment_en: The fifty-second buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
Probably a metrically shortened variant of Lokeśvara.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK; also used as an epithet of Avalokiteśvara, or the name of one of Avalokiteśvara’s emanations.
An unidentified mantra deity. The Sanskrit could be corrupt.

There are five supernatural faculties resulting from meditative concentration and that can be attained by both Buddhist and non-Buddhist practitioners: divine sight, divine hearing, knowing others’ minds, recollecting past lives, and the ability to perform miracles.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
“Lord of the World,” an epithet of Avalokiteśvara.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
One of the great mātṛs.
One of the grahas.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
“World Bearer.” One of the bodhisattvas in the entourage of the Buddha Śākyamuni when he taught the girl Vimalaśraddhā.
A bodhisattva and the main interlocutor of this sūtra.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The name of a nakṣatra.
An ancient Indian philosophical system that is based on adherence to materialism and atheistic skepticism.

A school of thought that rejected the Vedas and other religious texts and considered only empirical knowledge and inference to be valid. More commonly known in later literature as Cārvāka and in its Anglicized form Charvaka. It preexisted and was contemporary with the early centuries of Buddhism. Its literature no longer exists unless one takes the ninth-century text Tattvopaplava­siṃha by Jayarāśi Bhaṭṭa as associated with that school, which most scholars do not.
While this term is used as a name for the ancient materialists, it can also refer to non-Buddhist extremists in general.
While this term is used as a name for the ancient materialist Skt. lokacārvāka school, it can also refer to non-Buddhist extremists in general.
While this term is used a name for the ancient Indian school of materialist philosophy, it can also refer to non-Buddhists in general.

Also called the Cārvāka school, it was an ancient Indian school with a materialistic viewpoint accepting only the evidence of the senses and rejecting the existence of a creator deity or other lifetimes. Their teachings now survive only in quotations by opponents.
An ancient school of Indian philosophy whose doctrine, outlined primarily in the Bārhaspatya Sūtras, is characterized by atheism and a strict form of materialism.
An ancient school of Indian philosophy whose doctrine, outlined primarily in the Bārhaspatya Sūtras, is characterized by atheism and a strict form of materialism; also known as the Cārvāka.
Followers of a materialistic school of philosophy.
The name Surata is known by after he becomes enlightened.
One of the two bodhisattvas standing by the gateway in the Mañjuśrī maṇḍala.
One of the kinnara kings.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode; one of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.

Lit. “World-Protectors.” They are the same as the four Mahārājas, the great kings of the quarters (rgyal chen bzhi), namely, Vaiśravaṇa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Virūḍhaka, and Virūpākṣa, whose mission is to report on the activities of mankind to the gods of the Trāyastriṃśa heaven and who have pledged to protect the practitioners of the Dharma. Each universe has its own set of four.

term: འཇིག་རྟེན་ སྐྱོང་བ་ བཞི་ དང་ ལྔ་ -འི་ དཔལ

comment_en: The Four Great Kings of the cardinal directions.
See “Four Great Kings.”
Four deities guarding the four quarters, namely, Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūḍhaka in the south, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Vaiśravaṇa in the north. Also referred to as the Four Great Kings.
One category of Dharma protectors in Buddhism.
“World protector,” a class of guardian deities, usually presiding over the quarters of the world.
One category of Dharma protectors in Buddhism.
A group of four nonhuman beings who stand guard over the four directions.
Name of a buddha.
A buddha.
Name of a king; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
One of the rāśis; a king of the Gauḍa dynasty.

term: འཇིགས་པ་ དང་ བག་ཚ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ འཇིག་པ་ -ར་ མཛད་པ
en: Destroyer of All Fear and Anxiety
comment_en: A buddha.
Inhabitants of the Equal Peaks mountain in Kuru.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.

The name of both a previous life of Buddha Śākyamuni as a king (translated as ’jigs pa’i bla ma) and the name of one of the buddhas (translated as ’jigs mchog) that Śākyamuni received the samādhi teaching from in a previous life.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering; one of the five ḍākinīs visualized on the five prongs of the vajra scepter.
A tathāgata associated with Jñānolka.

term: འཇིགས་པ་ -འི་ སྤུ་ ཟིང་ ཞེས་ བྱེད་པ་ དང་ བྲལ་བ
comment_en: A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
The names of millions of buddhas within one eon in the distant past, and also the name of a particular buddha in chapter 19.
A banker’s son who purchases the favors of the courtesan’s daughter Suvarṇottama­prabhāśrī in The Miraculous Play of Mañjuśrī sūtra.
A king.
Fierce and terrifying Hindu goddess identified as the consort of Bhairava.
The location of a deer park, alternately indentified in the Karmaśātaka as located on Mount Sabkang and on Mount Śiśumāri.
The location of a deer park, alternately indentified in the Karmaśātaka as located on Mount Sabkang and on Mount Śiśumāri.

term: འཇིགས་ བྲལ་ བག་ཚ་ མི་ མངའ་ སྤུ་ ཟིང་ མི་ བྱེད
comment_en: The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to the northeast of the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
A ṛṣi, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 11.
A buddha.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to the northwest of the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
A buddha realm.
A future solitary buddha.
One of the five yakṣa generals.
One of the deities invited to partake in the oblation offering.

term: འཇིགས་ ཤིང་ འཇིགས་ སུ་ རུང་བ་ -ས་ མི་ འཇིགས་པ
en: Not Intimidated by Fears or the Fearsome
comment_en: A buddha realm.
A nāga king.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
One of the four guardian goddesses who can be indicated to a fellow practitioner by her pledge sign.
A famous polymath of the Tibetan Ancient (rnying ma) tradition (1846-1912) whose collected writings fill thirty-three volumes.
A location in Heaven Free from Strife.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A nāga king.
A nāga king, who is well known from his role in the Indian epic the Mahābhārata. Said to dwell in the northwestern city of Taxila (Takṣaśilā), in present-day Pakistan.
A nāga king who is well known from his role in the Indian Mahābhārata epic. He dwells in the northwestern city of Taxila (Takṣaśilā), in present-day Pakistan.
A virtuous nāga king.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of eight mythological nāga kings.
A brahmin who is the Buddha in a former life.
A “ruler of the world” who belongs to the class of the māras.
Lord of the Yāma heaven, lowest of the group of four heavens immediately above the peak of Mount Meru.
A god realm.
The third of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The third (fourth highest) of the six levels of gods of the Desire Realm.
One of the gods’ realms.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The third of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

The third of the six heavens of the desire realm. The Tibetan translation ’thab bral, “free from strife or combat,” derives from the idea that these devas, because they live in an aerial abode above Mount Meru, do not have to engage in combat with the asuras who dwell on the slopes of the mountain.
The third lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, counted among the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology included among the six heavens of the desire realm. It is characterized by freedom from difficulty.
The third of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The lowest of the heavenly realms. Characterized by freedom from difficulty.
The lowest of the heavenly realms. Characterized by freedom from difficulty.
A city ruled by King Mahā­sena long before the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni. Also said to have been ruled by King Nāgadeva (rgyal po klu lha) before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
This patience is an acceptance of the true nature of things. It is a patience that is in concord with the nature of phenomena.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A future buddha.
One of the grahas.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the garuḍa kings.
One of the garuḍa kings.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the garuḍa kings.
One of the garuḍa kings.
A legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
A town near Rājagṛha, it is home to the brahmin Tiṣya, father of Śāriputra Upatiṣya.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.

A village presumed to be near Pāṭaliputra (present day Patna) but whose exact location is unknown. Rendered in Tibetan in other texts as sgra can or chu bo can. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-012.html#UT22084-072-012-52.
(1) A wandering mendicant. (2) A mendicant living in Nālandā.
A great bodhisattva.

en: Wisdom of the hour of death

term: འདས་པ་ དང་ མ་འོངས་པ་ དང་ ད་ལྟར་ བྱུང་བ་ -འི་ གོ་ཆ་ ཐོགས་པ་ མེད
en: Unimpeded Armor of Past, Future, and Present
comment_en: A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.

term: འདས་པ་ -འི་ དུས་ ལ་མ་ ཆགས་ མ་ཐོགས་པ་ -འི་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ གཟིགས་པ་ -ར་ འཇུག་ གོ
en: Engage in the perception of pristine cognition which is unobstructed and unimpeded with respect to the past
comment_en: Sixteeenth of the eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas.
Fourth of the five psycho-physical aggregates.

en: Conditioning process of the mental factors

comment_en: Also translated here as “conditioned phenomena.”
Third of the five psycho-physical aggregates.
A bodhisattva.
Twelfth god realm of the form realms, meaning “Beings without Concepts,” it is the third of the three heavens that make up the fourth dhyāna heaven in the form realm. Also called Bṛhatphala.

A class of beings in the form realm, and the thirteenth heaven of the form realm on a level just below the devas of the Pure Abodes. The Insentient Beings are characterized by having a body but no conscious experience at all; this state is the karmic result of an ordinary or worldly form of the fourth meditative absorption called the attainment of the meditative state without consciousness. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-14.

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
en: Sphere of neither Perception nor Nonperception
comment_en: Fourth of the four formless realms, also the name of the fourth of the four concentrations (dhyāna).

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
comment_en: Fourth of four states in the formless realm.

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
en: Sphere of Neither Perception nor Non-perception
comment_en: The highest of the four heavens of the formless realm, so termed because conceptions there are weak but not entirely absent. Also called “the peak of existence.”

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
en: Abode of neither perception nor no perception
comment_en: A formless state, either a meditative state or its resultant realm of existence, i.e., a class of deities of the formless realm.

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
en: Sphere of Neither Perception nor Non-Perception
comment_en: The highest of the four formless realms, so termed because conceptions are weak in it, but not entirely absent.

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
en: Sphere of neither perception nor non-perception
comment_en: Fourth of the four formless absorptions.

term: འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ འདུ་ཤེས་ མེད་ མིན་ སྐྱེ་མཆེད
en: Sense source of neither perception nor nonperception
comment_en: The highest of the four divine concentration realms in the formless realm, and the fourth of the four formless absorptions. The other three are infinite space, infinite consciousness, and nothingness.
One of the gods’ realms, literally “Without Consciousness.”
A “ruler of the world” who belongs to the class of the māras.

The term is used in an ordinary sense in Sanskrit to mean “notion,” “sign,” “conception,” “clear understanding.” It is also used more specifically in Buddhist scholastic contexts in the phrase “the aggregate of perceptions” (saṃjñāskandha).
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
One of the notorious “group of six” monks whose antics and heavy-handed interference prompted a great many of the Buddha’s injunctions on conduct.
The Bodhisattva’s charioteer.

term: འདུན་པ་ -འི་ ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་ སྤང་བ་ -འི་ འདུ་བྱེད་ དང་ ལྡན་པ་ -འི་ རྫུ་འཕྲུལ་ གྱི་ རྐང་པ
en: Support for miraculous ability combining meditative stability of resolution with the formative force of exertion
comment_en: First of the four supports for miraculous abilities.
The dome-shaped assembly hall where Indra teaches the Dharma located on the southwest side of Mount Meru.
A householder who was the Buddha in a former life.

term: འདུལ་བ་ འདི་ ལ་ མི་ སྐྱེ་བ་ -འི་ ཆོས་ཅན
en: Will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya
comment_en: Someone for whom there are factors that prevent giving rise to the vows (Kalyāṇamitra, folio 292.a.4).
Those who are expert in monastic discipline.
A term used to designate someone who is a master of Buddhist monastic discipline.
The Buddha’s teachings that lay out the rules and disciplines for his followers.
The vows and texts pertaining to monastic discipline.
The section of the Buddha’s teachings that focuses on conduct.
The Buddha’s teachings that lay out the rules and disciplines for his followers.
One of the three Piṭakas, or “Baskets,” of the Buddhist canon; the one dealing specifically with the code of the monastic disipline.
The collection of monastic rules and regulations.
The Buddha’s teachings that lay out the rules and disciplines for his followers.
The vows and texts pertaining to monastic discipline. One of the three piṭakas, or “baskets,” of the Buddhist canon, the one dealing specifically with the code of monastic discipline.
“Discipline”; one of the Three Baskets (Tripiṭaka), the Vinaya is the body of literature on monastic discipline and training.
The vows and texts pertaining to monastic discipline.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.

An anthology of Great Vehicle Sūtras. A collection of seventeen sūtras under this title is available in Chinese translation, but The Questions of Sāgaramati is not included among them. It is thus likely that there were more than one anthology using this title.

A collection of seventeen sūtras on a range of themes, compiled as a separate collection. Today, this collection only exists in Chinese translation, although several of the individual scriptures exist in Sanskrit and Tibetan translation.
See “Kātyāyana.”
This phrase occurs throughout a number of Perfection of Wisdom discourses and several other sūtras (Apple 2014). See, for example, the Vajracchedikā Prajñāpāramitā §7 (Harrison 2006, p. 145).
Princess of Takṣaśīla, child of Padmagarbha, mother of Kātyāyana, and spouse of Riu. During the Buddha’s time she defeated all the scriptural exegetes from neighboring lands in debate.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra (the other two being the form and formless realms).
In Buddhist cosmology, it is our sphere of existence where beings are driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification.
In Buddhist cosmology, it is our sphere of existence where beings are driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification.

One of the three realms of saṃsāra, it is comprised of the traditional six realms of saṃsāra, from the hell realm to the realm of the gods, including the human realm. Rebirth in this realm is characterized by intense cravings via the five senses and their objects.

One of the three realms of saṃsāra, it is comprised of the traditional six realms of saṃsāra, from the hell realm to the realm of the gods, including the human realm. Rebirth in this realm is characterized by intense cravings via the five senses and their objects.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Consort of Red Acala.
A deity personifying the true nature of the faculty of taste.
First of the five fetters associated with the lower realms.
Passion, attachment, and/or lust. One of the affective behavior patterns or “afflictions” known as the three poisons.
Passion, attachment, and/or lust. One of the affective behavior patterns known as the three poisons.

One of the three basic mental afflictions (together with aversion and confusion) within which all other mental afflictions can be subsumed. The term rāga comes from the root rañj, which can also have the sense of “to color,” thus making it possible to create significant double-meanings in Sanskrit (rakta can thus mean “impassioned,” but also “red” or “blood”). Liberated beings are often described as vītarāga, “free from attraction.”
One of the three root afflictions that bind beings to cyclic existence.
One of the three root afflictions that bind beings to cyclic existence.
One of the six root afflictions (Skt. mūlakleśa), often listed as one of the three poisons (Skt. triviṣa) along with anger (Skt. dveṣa) and delusion (Skt. moha).
A mountain.
A pleasure grove in Promotion
A forest in Shining in Manifold Ways.

en: Deva in one of the six heavens of sensuous pleasure

comment_en: A village.
A forest near the village Icchānaṅgalā.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
An emanated forest created upon the shoulders of Airāvaṇa.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A city in the asura realm called Moon Garland.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by the prevalence of sense desire.
In Buddhist cosmology, our sphere of existence where beings are driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification and attachment to material substance. See also “three realms.”
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by a prevalence of desire.

One of the three realms of saṃsāra, it is comprised of the traditional six realms of saṃsāra, from the hell realm to the realm of the gods, including the human realm. Rebirth in this realm is characterized by intense cravings via the five senses and their objects.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by a prevalence of desire.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by a prevalence of desire.

In Buddhist cosmology, our sphere of existence where beings are driven primarily by the urge for sense gratification and attachment to material substance. It is one of the three basic divisions of the realms of existence that constitute saṃsāra. The other two are the form realm and the formless realm. See Gethin 1998, 116–18.

This realm is composed of the six classes of existence: hell beings, pretas, animals, humans, asuras, and devas. These are all existences where a being is reborn through karma. In the two higher realms beings are reborn there through the power of their meditation.
The worlds where beings are reborn through their karma, from the hells up to the Para­nirmita­vaśa­vartin paradise.
One of the three realms of saṃsāra, characterized by a prevalence of desire.
Of the three realms of existence, the realm whose beings are tormented by desire and attachment to material substance.
A river in the Swan Forest.
An epithet of a Hindu god, Kubera.
Literally, “Lord of Desire.” Name of Kubera/Vaiśravaṇa.
Literally, “Lord of Desire.” Name of Kubera/Vaiśravaṇa.
Literally “Lord of Desire.” Name of Kubera/Vaiśravaṇa, who presides over the Desire Realm.
‟Goddess of Desire,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs as well as one of the eight great yakṣinīs.
A mudrā gesture formed with both hands, representing male and female sexual organs in the state of arousal.
A treatise on love.
Visibles, sound, scent, taste, and tangibles.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The lowest of the three planes of existence, where coarse desires for all the sense objects are present.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
One of the four parasites that are said to be inside the birth canals of women.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
God of love; the name of a vetāla.
Another name of the king Mādhava.
A member of the Śākya clan.
The name of a bodhisattva prophesied to become the tathāgata presiding over the buddhafield Full of Pearls after the tathāgata King of Jewels passes into parinirvāṇa.
A monk, main character of the sūtra Purification of Karmic Obscurations.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A great bodhisattva.
A forest on the third asura level, Excellent Abode.
A mountain on the continent of Kuru.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
A grove in the forest known as Incomparable.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Literally, “Pūraṇa, descendant of Kāśyapa,” he was one of the six tīrthika teachers contemporaneous with Śākyamuni.
(1) A ṛṣi in the past (’drob skyong gi bu). (2) A ṛṣi (’od srung). (3) A buddha in the past (’od srung). (4) Another name of Mahākāśyapa (’od srung).

term: འཕགས་པ་ ཉན་ཐོས་ དང་ རང་ སངས་ རྱས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ དཔལ

comment_en: A practitioner of the Disciple Vehicle teaching who has reached at least the initial stages of realization.
This great Indian philosopher lived in the fourth century and was the founder of the Vijñānavāda, or “Consciousness-Only,” school of Mahāyāna Buddhism.
See “noble path.”
One of the great masters of Indian Buddhism. The main disciple of Nāgārjuna, he lived in the early a.d. centuries and wrote numerous important works of Mādhyamika philosophy.
Someone who has entered the “path of seeing,” i.e., who has a direct and stable realization of selflessness, ceases to be an “ordinary person” and becomes a noble one.

The Sanskrit ārya generally has the common meaning of a noble person, one of a higher class or caste. In Dharma terms it means one who has gained the realization of the path and is superior for that reason.
This term in particular applies to stream enterers, once-returners, non-returners, and worthy ones.
A term for realized beings in Buddhism. Also translated here as “ārya.”

The Sanskrit ārya generally has the common meaning of a noble person, one of a higher class or caste. In Dharma terms it means one who has gained the realization of the path and is superior for that reason.
Someone who has entered the “path of seeing,” i.e., who has a direct and stable realization of selflessness, and therefore ceases to be an “ordinary person” and becomes a “noble one.”

An honorific term used to refer to anything of exalted status. Thus, it can refer to a noble person, one of a higher class or caste. In the context of Buddhism, it refers to one who has gained realization on the path of seeing and thus understands selflessness.

Someone who has entered the “path of seeing,” i.e., who has a direct and stable realization of selflessness, ceases to be an “ordinary person,” and has entered the path that culminates in becoming an arhat.

When referring to a person, it is someone who has entered the “path of seeing”—someone who has a direct and stable realization of the four truths of the noble ones and who thus ceases to be an “ordinary person,” becoming a “noble one.”
A person who has directly realized the noble truths.
Also known as a “noble being,” “exalted being,” “a superior”; one who has attained the third path, i.e., the path of seeing upon which one becomes a real saṅgha refuge.
See “noble one.”
Another name of Abhyudgatoṣṇīṣa.

en: Seven treasures of a noble being
comment_en: Dungkar Rinpoche gives two similar lists of the seven treasures of a noble being: (1) faith, ethics, generosity, learning, samaya, a conscience, and wisdom; and (2) faith, ethics, learning, generosity, a conscience, propriety, and wisdom (dung dkar, 2002, pp. 1370–71).

en: Seven jewels of the noble ones
comment_en: (1) Faith (sŕaddhā, dad pa), (2) moral discipline (śīla, tshul khrims), (3) hearing (śruta, thos pa), (4) generosity (tyāga, gtong ba), (5) a sense of shame (hrī, ngo tsha shes pa), (6) dread of blame (āpatrāpya, khrel yod pa), (7) wisdom (prajñā, shes rab) (Rigzin 271).
Faith, discipline, learning, generosity, a sense of shame, fear of blame, and wisdom.

The four noble truths, as stated in this sūtra, are: the comprehension of suffering, the abandoning of the cause of suffering, the actualization of the cessation of suffering, and the practice of the path.

The four noble truths, as listed in note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-153, comprise (1) the noble truth of suffering, (2) the noble truth of the origin of suffering, (3) the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, and (4) the noble truth of the path. (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-154). On the twelve aspects pertaining to the four noble truths, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1530.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The truth of suffering, the cause of suffering, the path, and the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The four truths that the Buddha realized and transmitted in his first teaching: (1) suffering, (2) the origin of suffering, (3) the cessation of suffering, and (4) the path to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The Buddha’s first teaching, which explains suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The first teaching of the Buddha, covering (1) suffering, (2) the origin of suffering, (3) the cessation of suffering, and (4) the path to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The four truths of the noble ones are the truths of (1) suffering, (2) the origin of suffering, (3) the cessation of suffering, and (4) the path.
The first teaching of the Buddha covering suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The four truths the Buddha realized at his enlightenment: the truth of suffering, the truth of the origin, the truth of cessation, the truth of the path.
The first teaching of the Buddha covering suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: A paradigmatic set of teachings traditionally believed to have been taught in the Buddha’s very first sermon. They are the truths of suffering, the arising of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path that leads to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones

comment_en: The first teaching of the Buddha, covering suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering.

en: Four truths of the noble ones
comment_en: The first teaching of the Buddha, covering suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the path to the cessation of suffering.
See “four noble truths.”
The four truths that the Buddha realized: suffering, origin, cessation, and path. They are named “truths of noble beings” since only “noble beings” with knowledge of reality can understand them.
See “four truths.”
The attributes of a practitioner; the first three are garments, food, and bedding, and the fourth is the dedication to the path of liberation.
The attributes of a practitioner: the first three are garments, food, and bedding, and the fourth is dedication to the path of liberation.
This refers to four rigors that typify noble ones: contentment with the robes, food, and bed that one receives, and devotion to the path of liberation.
Being content with one’s garments, food, and lodging and observing ethical behavior.

These are right view (samyagdṛṣṭi), right consideration (samyak­saṃkalpa), right speech (samyakvāk), right terminal action (samyak­karmānta), right livelihood (samyagajiva), right effort (samyag­vyāyāma), right remembrance (samyak­smṛti), and right concentration (samyak­samādhi). They are variously defined in the different Buddhist schools. These eight form a part of the thirty-seven aids to enlightenment (see entry).
The Buddhist path as presented in the Śrāvakayāna: right view, right intention, right speech, right conduct, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right samādhi.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Part of the thirty-seven aspects of awakening.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
