comment_en: Correct view, intention, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration. These eight are included in the thirty-seven elements of awakening.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Correct view, thought, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and absorption. These eight are part of the thirty-seven factors of awakening.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Correct view, intention, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration.

en: Eight branches of the path of the noble ones
comment_en: Correct view, intention, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and absorption. These eight are part of the thirty-seven factors of awakening.

(1) Right view, (2) right understanding, (3) right speech, (4) right action, (5) right livelihood, (6) right effort, (7) right mindfulness, and (8) right meditation. See also thirty-seven wings of enlightenment.

en: Eight-fold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Eight factors whereby the training on the path of cultivation takes place.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
Eight limbs of the noble path
comment_en: Right view, intention, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration.

The noble eightfold path, enumerated in note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-165, comprises (1) correct view, (2) correct ideation, (3) correct speech, (4) correct action, (5) correct livelihood, (6) correct effort, (7) correct recollection, and (8) correct meditative stability.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Path leading to the attainment of an arhat, consisting of right (1) view, (2) intention, (3) speech, (4) action, (5) livelihood, (6) effort, (7) mindfulness, and (8) meditative concentration.
Right view, thought, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and absorption.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Eight factors constituting the path of cultivation, namely: right view, right intention, right speech, right activity, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right absorption.. These are further explained in this text, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-4043–note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-4044.
Right view, right thinking, right speech, right activity, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.

en: Eightfold path of the noble ones
comment_en: Correct view, intention, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration.
Right view, examination, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and samādhi. These eight are included in the thirty-seven factors for enlightenment.
Generally has the common meaning of a noble female, one of a higher class or caste. In Dharma terms it means a female who has gained the realization of the path and is superior for that reason.
The kingdom of King Anantanemi.
See “Ujjayinī.”
A city in ancient India, corresponding to modern Ujjain.
The Buddhist path as presented in the śrāvaka vehicle: right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right samādhi.

en: Eight aspects of the noble path
comment_en: Eight factors whereby the training on the path of cultivation takes place.
One of the Four Great Kings, guardian of the south.

A son of King Prasenajit of Kosala, who first served as a general in his father’s army, but later usurped the throne. As a boy he discovered that his mother, who had been offered to his father by the Śākyas, had originally only been a servant rather than a noblewoman as the Śākyas had claimed; and later, as king, in revenge he attacked and destroyed Kapilavastu, slaughtering most of the Śākya inhabitants. However, he then died there in a flood. Not to be confused with the Virūḍhaka who is one of the Four Great Kings.
One of the four mahārājas. He is the guardian of the southern direction and the lord of the kumbhāṇḍas.
One of the four mahārājas. He is the guardian of the southern direction and the lord of the kumbhāṇḍas.
One of the Four Great Kings.

(1) A general, son of King Prasenajit. (2) One of the Four Great Kings. The Tib. lus ’phags po is probably erroneous; see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1933 and note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-1979.
One of the Four Great Kings, or guardians of the world, he presides over the southern quarter and rules over the preta kumbhāṇḍa spirits that live there.
One of the four great kings.
Literally, “Noble Birth.” Name of one of the four great kings who rule over the four directions in the desire realm.
A certain prince, son of King Prasenajit (’phags skyes po, his name in Tibetan, is also the Tibetan name of Virūḍhaka).
One of the four great kings, protector of the cardinal direction to the south of Mount Meru. (’phags skyes po, his name in Tibetan, is also the Tibetan name of Videha).
One of the Four Mahārājas, he is the guardian of the southern direction and the lord of the kumbhāṇḍas.
One of the four great kings, the protectors of the world; guardian of the south.
“Noble Birth” (Tib.) or “Sprouting/Growing Forth,” (Skt.) guardian of the southern direction. Also the name of a king of Kosala during the lifetime of Śākyamuni Buddha.
The king of kumbhāṇḍas (one of the four great kings of the directions).
One of the “four great kings, guardians of the world,” he is held to dwell in the south, presiding over the preta kumbhāṇḍa spirits that live there.
One of the Four Great Kings, he presides over the southern quarter and rules over the kumbhāṇḍas.
One of the great kings of the four cardinal directions, Virūḍhaka guards the southern quarter of the heavens.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
An ancient city corresponding to modern Burdwan.

A rākṣasī known as such only in this sūtra. She is, however, listed in the tantra The Great Peahen Incantation along with Hārītī as one of ten piśācīs who protected the Buddha while he was in the womb.

A tailor whose name means “a person who crawls,” he was the child of wealthy householders in Śrāvastī, born with paralyzed legs. Not to be confused with the Paṅgu who caused all those who went to see him to succeed in all their endeavors.
Upon his birth his parents’ household and those of all who went to see him began to succeed in all their endeavors. Not to be confused with the tailor Paṅgu.

Pre-reform Tibetan term for lha’i mig (“divine eye,” “clairvoyance”) one of the six supramundane powers (Skt. abhijñā) and of the three knowledges (Skt. trividyā): the ability to see things that are far away, mind-made bodies (of enlightened beings and advanced meditators), and the destinies of all beings according to their actions.
One of the four garuḍa kings, present at the teaching of the sūtra.
A god realm.
Fifth god realm of desire, meaning “delighting in emanation.”
The fifth (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm.
The fifth of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The fifth (second highest) of the six levels of gods of the Desire Realm.
One of the gods’ realms.
The fifth of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The second highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The second highest of the six god realms of the desire realm, meaning “Enjoying Emanations.” Its inhabitants magically create the objects of their own enjoyment.
A class of gods in the fifth of the six heavens in the desire realm.
The fifth of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
Enjoying Emanation, the fifth heaven in the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The fifth of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The fifth of the six heavens of the desire realm. Its inhabitants magically create the objects of their own enjoyment.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The fifth of the six heavens of the desire realm. Its inhabitants magically create the objects of their own enjoyment and dispose of them themselves.
The second of the heavens of the form realm and of the three Brahmā heavens. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the first meditative absorption.
The second highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, counted among the six heavens of the desire realm. Its inhabitants magically create the objects of their own enjoyment, and also dispose of them themselves.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, counted among the six heavens of the desire realm. Its inhabitants magically create the objects of their own enjoyment, and also dispose of them themselves.
The second highest paradise in the desire realm, the name means “delight in emanations.”
“Delighting in Emanations.” The second highest paradise in the desire realm, so named because the devas there delight in emanations.
The penultimate heaven in the desire realm.
The second highest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three and the name of a tree that grows there.
Mythological figure of great wealth and splendor.
One of the kings of the Nāgasena dynasty, the successor of Viṣṇu (i.e., Viṣṇuvardhana).
A rākṣasī with hundreds of children that the Buddha converted into a protector of children. There is a temple specifically for her in Kathmandu.
A female yakṣa, previously an eater of children but tamed and converted by the Buddha and seen as a protectress. Consort of Pāñcika.
A yakṣiṇī; after conversion to Buddhadharma she became the protectress of children.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A child-eating demoness who was tamed by the Buddha and became a protectress of children, women, the saṅgha, and all beings.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
A park in Delighting in Flower Garlands.
A forest in Total Pleasure.
A mountain in Shining in Manifold Ways.
A forest on Great Slope.
A lotus pool in Lateral.
A mountain range, actually a series of mountain ranges, which extends across central India.
A range of mountains located to the north of the Narmada River.
A mountain in the south of Jambudvīpa.
An Indian mountain chain.
The Vindhya Mountains are a complex, broken chain of mountain ridges, hill ranges, highlands, and plateau escarpments in west-central India.
A low mountain range in central India.

en: Five Sets of One Hundred Thousand
comment_en: (1) The long Prajñā­pāramitā (Toh 8), which contains 100,000 ślokas; (2) the Mahā­pari­nirvāṇa (Toh 119–120), which contains 100,000 testaments given by the Buddha at the time of his pari­nirvāṇa; (3) the Ratna­kūṭa (Toh 45–93), which contains 100,000 distinct names of the Buddha; (4) the Avataṃsaka (Toh 44), which contains 100,000 aspirations; and (5) the Laṅkāvatāra (Toh 107-108), which contains 100,000 discourses that are ways of subjugating the rākṣasas. These five sets of 100,000 features are also said to correspond to the Buddha’s body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities, respectively.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An emanated mountain on the trunk of Airāvaṇa.
A buddha realm.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the rāśis.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
‟Tamer of Spirits,” the titular deity of the Bhūtaḍāmara Tantra; a wrathful form of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.

A ghost in the Indian tradition, sometimes haunting houses where they were killed. They can appear in human or animal form. They cast no shadow and their feet are always backward. In Hindi they are called bhoot.
A generic term for “spirit” or “ghost.” They can be malevolent or benevolent.
This can be a general name for spirits or demons, but is also used specifically for ghosts.
A class of spirits; any nonhuman being.
A kind of spirit.
A general term for spirit, ghost, or demon (either positive or negative).
A general term for spirit, ghost, or demon.
A generic term for “spirit” or “ghost.” They can be malevolent or benevolent.
The name of a certain brahmin who lived in Rājagṛha. Not to be confused with Bhūta, the name of a merchant and a dog, and a certain class of evil beings.

The name of a certain householder’s dog and the name given to the lost infant it carried home to its owner one night, which would one day be reunited with his birth mother. Also the name of a certain brahmin who lived in Rājagṛha, and the name of a certain class of evil beings.
A class of spirits.
A general term for spirit, ghost, or demon (either positive or negative).
A specific class of nonhuman supernatural beings, or a term for spirits in general.
A generic term for spirits or ghosts.
A class of demonic sprit being.
A class of demonic sprit beings.
A class of spirits, usually of the lower order.
A general term for spirit, ghost, or demon (either positive or negative).
A class of spirits; in the Bhūta­ḍāmara Tantra this term can refer to all nonhuman beings, including gods.
A general term for spirit, ghost, or demon (either positive or negative).
A class of spirit.
A generic term for “spirit” or “ghost.” They can be malevolent or benevolent.
A general term for spirit, ghost, or demon (either positive or negative).
Name of place in the Adumā region.
An epithet of Caṇḍakātyāyanī.
‟Lord of Bhūtas,” one of the eight bhūta kings.
One of the rāśis.
A past world where the Tathāgata Glorious Secret lived along with the bodhisattva Smṛtibuddhi, a past incarnation of the bodhisattva Prajñākūṭa.
The buddha realm of King of Thunderous Voice.
A realm in the distant past.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A female bhūta.
Female bhūta.
A female bhūta or any nonhuman female being; in some mantras it seems to be used as a proper name.
A son of Bhava and half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A householder and the father of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the grahas.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
An ancient king of Aṅga.
A son of Bhava and half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A son of Bhava and half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A village.
A city.
A river that flows down from the lake Anavatapta.
Name of an important Buddhist site in Andhra, near Amarāvatī.
The third level of the fourth concentration.

The twelfth of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing an ordinary form of the fourth meditative absorption. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-273.
Twefth god realm of form, meaning “great fruition.”
Second of three heavens of gods on the fourth concentration level.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, third of three levels of the fourth dhyāna realm.
Eighth of the eight progressive sections of clear realization.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A forest of the asuras.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
A realm inhabited by garland-bearer gods.
A city.
A city ruled by King Meru before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A mountain in the sea south of Jambudvīpa.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: འབྲུག་སྒྲ་ སྦྱངས་ སྙན་ སྐར་མ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ མེ་ཏོག་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past. Also the name of a prince in the distant past.
Name of a nāga king; name of Rāvaṇa’s son in the Rāmāyaṇa.
A buddha from the past.
One of the five yakṣa generals.
A yakṣa general.
A certain yakṣa lord tamed by the Buddha.
A yakṣa.
A yakṣa king.
Name of a yakṣa general.
A city in Videha.
992 or 993 to 1043 or 1072; Tibetan translator (of an early phase of the later translation period) and important figure in the Lamdré (lam ’bras) lineage.
Drokmi Śākya Yeshé, the great 11th century translator from Lhatsé in Western Tsang.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Endowed with Sublime Happiness.

A follower of a non-Buddhist mendicant movement founded by Makkhali Gosāla (fifth century BCE). The Ājīvikas adhered to a fatalist world-view according to which all beings eventually reach spiritual accomplishment by fate, rather than their own actions.
A town in Magadha.

Jīvaka is a title meaning “physician.” Kumārabhṛta means “raised by the prince,” in this case Prince Abhaya, who was said to have fostered the future physician. He was personal physician to King Bimbisāra and the Buddha. He asked that ill persons would not be accepted into the order, for it would prove too great a burden on the king’s treasury, which paid for all the treatment he administered, and his own health.
The physician of King Bimbisāra.

comment: person-Jīvaka; Jīvika; Kumārabhṛta Jīvaka; Kumārabhūta Jīvaka; Vaidyarājajīvaka
comment_en: A highly skilled healer and personal physician of Buddha Śākyamuni, he figures into many stories of the Buddha, his disciples, and other associates.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, signifying either the known human world, or sometimes more specifically the Indian subcontinent. The name comes from the jambu (“rose apple” or “black plum”) tree said to grow near Lake Anavatapta in the continent’s northern mountains, considered to be the source of the four great rivers of India.
The continent to the south of Mount Sumeru, according to Abhidharma cosmology.

The rivers that flow down from the immense lake at the foot of the legendary Jambu tree, including the Ganges. The fruits of that tree are golden and are carried down by the rivers through Jambudvīpa.
Legendary river carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.

term: འཛམ་བུ་ ཆུ་ ཀླུང་ གི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.

term: འཛམ་བུ་ ཆུ་ ཀླུང་ གི་ གསེར་ གྱི་ རི་རབ་ རི་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
en: Majestic Mount Meru of Gold from the Jambū River
comment_en: A buddha from the past.

term: འཛམ་བུ་ ཆུ་ ཀླུང་ གི་ མདོག་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: An eastern buddha realm.
A divine river.
A divine river.
A divine river whose gold is believed to be especially fine.
A divine river.
A divine river whose gold is believed to be especially fine.
A forest in Born in a Lap.
An alternative name for Jambudvīpa (rose-apple continent), which means “rose-apple banner.”
An alternative name for Jambudvīpa (“Rose-Apple Continent”), which means “Rose-Apple Banner.”
River carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.
Legendary river carrying the remains of the golden fruit of a legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.
The river flowing down Mount Meru.
A river that runs in the heavenly realms.
A river famed for its excellent gold
A divine river whose gold is especially fine.
One of the four continents surrounding Mount Sumeru, which is located in the south, according to Buddhist cosmology.

The name of the southern continent in Buddhist cosmology, which can signify either the known human world, or more specifically the Indian subcontinent, literally “the jambu island/continent.” Jambu is the name used for a range of plum-like fruits from trees belonging to the genus Szygium, particularly Szygium jambos and Szygium cumini, and has commonly been rendered “rose apple” although “black plum” may be a less misleading term. Among various explanations given for the continent being so named, one (in the Abhidharmakośa) is that a jambu tree grows in its northern mountains beside Lake Anavatapta, mythically considered the source of the four great rivers of India, and that the continent is therefore named from the tree or the fruit. Jambudvīpa has the vajrāsana at its center and is the only continent upon which buddhas attain awakening.
An island to the north of Jambudvīpa.

en: Waves of the Seas of Jambudvīpa
comment_en: An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa.

Legendary river carrying the golden fruit fallen from the legendary jambu (“rose apple”) tree. This term is used as an adjective for the gold found in rivers. When used as an adjective, the Sanskrit is jāmbūnada.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of the World.
A river.
Name of a mythological river that carries the remains of the golden fruit of the legendary jambu (rose apple) tree.
See “Jāmbūnada­prabhāsa.”
Mahākātyāyana’s name when he becomes a buddha in the distant future. Also rendered in Sanskrit in a shorter form as “Jāmbūnadābhāsa,” (Tibetan remains the same).
A particularly high quality of gold mined from the Jambu River.
A particularly pure gold or golden color.
An alternative name for Jambudvīpa meaning “rose-apple banner.”
Syzygium cumini. At present mainly called the jambul tree, it is the Indian version among the various species of rose apple trees.
One of the seven great rishis of ancient India. Also known as the father of Paraśurāma, the sixth incarnation of Viṣṇu.
A rishi who was a pupil of Vyāsa, the first master of the Sāmaveda and the source of the Mīmāṃsā tradition.

Another name of Maudgalyāyana, one of the Buddha’s two principal pupils. Kolita was the name of his home village, or was (according to The Chapter on Going Forth) a name given by his relatives meaning “born from the lap” [of the gods].

Son of the high brahmin Grasping of Rājagṛha. As he was lying ill, Venerable Śāriputra gave him a teaching on the four immeasurables. Admonishing Venerable Śāriputra for a lack of foresight, the Buddha then gave him an additional teaching on the four noble truths, leading him to manifest the resultant state of a non-returner and take rebirth as a god.
A certain high brahmin of Rājagṛha, father of Son of Grasping.
A buddha realm.

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: The first of the six heavens of the desire realm.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.

The name of one of the Buddha’s arhat disciples, a former king, renowned as foremost among those who teach monks. This spelling is attested in the present text but in other texts his name is spelled Mahākapphiṇa, Kapphiṇa, Kapphina, Kaphiṇa, Kasphiṇa, Kaṃphina, Kaphilla, or Kaphiṇḍa.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
The fourth of the eight hot hells. In later translations it is ngu ’bod, which also means “wailing” as a compound of the words for “weep” and “shout.”
Name of a hell.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
Identified in the Mahābhārata and Lalitavistara as a variety of date tree.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
A sea to the north of Jambudvīpa.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
One of the goddesses in one of the paintings of Mañjuśrī.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; also a yakṣiṇī invoked in magical rites.
One of the five pure abodes within the realm of form.
Fifth of the pure abodes, meaning “highest.”

The highest of the seventeen paradises in the form realm. Within the form realm is the highest of the eight paradises of the fourth dhyāna. Within the fourth dhyāna is the highest of the five Śuddhāvāsika (“pure abode”) paradises.

The eighth and highest level of the Realm of Form (rūpadhātu, gzugs khams), and thus part of the world of the Brahmā gods (brahmaloka, gtsang ris); it is only accessible as the result of specific states of dhyāna. According to some texts this is where non-returners (anāgāmin) dwell in their last lives. In other texts it is the realm of the enjoyment body (saṃbhoga­kāya, longs spyod rdzogs pa’i sku) and is a buddhafield associated with the Buddha Vairocana; it is accessible only to bodhisattvas on the tenth level. (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-054-003.html#UT22084-054-003-67).

The highest of the seventeen paradises in the form realm. Within the form realm it is the highest of the eight paradises of the fourth dhyāna. Within the fourth dhyāna it is the highest of the five Śuddhāvāsika (pure abode) paradises.
The highest heaven of the form realm.
One of the gods’ realms.
One of the gods’ realms.
Seventeenth god realm of form, meaning “highest,” it is the highest of the five heavens that make up the “pure abodes” in the form realm.
A class of gods who inhabit the fifth and highest of the “pure abodes.”
The highest level of the form realm.
The highest heaven of the form-world, where a buddha always receives the anointment of the ultimate wisdom, reaching there mentally from his seat of enlightenment under the Bodhi-tree.
The highest heaven of the form realm.

The eighth and highest level of the realm of form (rūpadhātu); it is only accessible as the result of specific states of concentration. According to some texts this is where non-returners (anāgāmin) dwell in their last lives. In other texts it is the realm of the enjoyment body (saṃbhogakāya) and is a buddhafield associated with the Buddha Vairocana that is accessible only to bodhisattvas on the tenth level.
The highest of the seventeen heavens in the form realm, the highest of the five Śuddhāvāsa heavens.
The fifth of five realms associated with the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.

The highest of the seventeen heavens of the form realm and the fifth and highest of the five Pure Abodes. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the fourth meditative absorption. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-284.
The highest level of the form realm.
See “Supreme.”
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, fifth and highest of the five so-called pure realms of the form realm. Also rendered here as Akaniṣṭha.

The highest of the buddhafields. The term can be used to indicate the pure realm of the dharmakāya in general or can refer to the six realms between the highest heaven of the form realm and the realm of dharmakāya.
The highest paradise in the form realm, and therefore the highest point within the universe. The name is used with other meanings in the tantra tradition.
The highest paradise among the Śuddhāvāsa paradises, which are the five highest in the form realm; therefore, this is the highest point within a world realm.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The highest heaven in the realm of form; also the name of the gods living there.
The highest of the five pure abodes (Skt. śuddhāvāsa) among the form realms.
The highest of the heavenly levels of the form realm, but also in many Mahāyāna texts the buddhafield of the saṃbhogakāya buddhas.
The highest of the heavenly levels of the form realm, but also in many Mahāyāna texts the buddhafield of the saṃbhogakāya buddhas.
Highest heaven of the form realm (rūpadhātu).
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
A bodhisattva.

term: འོད་ ཀྱི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ བསྒྲགས་པ་ གྲགས་པ
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.

en: Splendorous King of the Luminous Sphere
comment_en: A buddha.

term: འོད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ གསེར་ གྱི་ མེ་ཏོག
comment_en: A park in another world in the distant past. The name as given in the prose. In verse it is called Svarṇa­puṣpa­prabhava.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.

term: འོད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ འབྱུང་གནས
en: Radiant Disk That Is the Source of Infinite Wisdom
comment_en: A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A tathāgata.
Name of a tathāgata.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.

term: འོད་ ཀྱི་ ཟླ་བ་ དྲི་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ
comment_en: One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: འོད་ ཀྱི་ ཟླ་བ་ དྲི་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ དཔལ
en: Splendid with Light and Fragrance All Around
comment_en: A tathāgata invoked in a mantra.
A buddha.
A buddha.
The twenty-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past, and also the eighty-seventh in the same kalpa. BHS in verse: Prabha­ketu­śirī.

term: འོད་ ཀྱིས་ གསལ་བ་ -ར་ མཛད་ ཅིང་ གཤེགས་པ
comment_en: Sixty-fourth of the eighty minor marks.
Name of a bodhisattva.

term: འོད་ ཀྱིས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ རྩེ་བ་ མངོན་པར་ ཤེས་པ
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: འོད་གཟེར་ གྱི་ མེ་ཏོག་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ རྒྱས་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲོན་མ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: འོད་གཟེར་ གྱི་ ཚུལ་ རབ་ཏུ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ ཟླ་བ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: འོད་གཟེར་ གྱི་ རི་བོ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ སྤྲིན
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A prince in another world in the distant past. Also known as Suraśmi.
“Excellent Light Rays.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
A prince in another world in the distant past. Also known as Suraśmiketu.
A buddha in the distant past.

term: འོད་གཟེར་ ཡོན་ཏན་ གྱི་ ཅོད་པན་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ དང་ ཤེས་རབ་ ཀྱི་ འོད
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past.

Luminosity refers to the subtlest level of mind, i.e., the fundamental, essential nature of all cognitive events. Though ever present within all sentient beings, this luminosity becomes manifest only when the gross mind has ceased to function. It is said that such a dissolution is experienced by ordinary beings, naturally, at the time of death, but it can also be experientially cultivated through certain meditative practices.
A forest in Dwelling in Excellent View.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the five pure abodes within the realm of form.
Sixth god realm of form, meaning “luminosity.”
The highest of the three paradises that are the second dhyāna paradises in the form realm.
The sixth heaven of the form realm.
Sixth god realm of form, meaning “luminosity,” it is the highest of the three heavens that make up the second dhyāna heaven in the form realm.
A class of gods who inhabit the sixth heaven of the realm of form.
A heaven.
Third of three heavens of gods on the second concentration level.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Fire.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Possessor of Great Bliss.
The uppermost level of the second concentration in the form realm.

The sixth of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the second meditative absorption. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-261.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, third of three levels of the second dhyāna realm.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
A bodhisattva and Dharma preacher.
(1) Celestial city occupied by Rāhu, king of the asuras (’od can). (2) A forest on the lower level of Living on the Peak (’od ’phro ba ).
A temple on Mount Gośṛṅga.
Fourth god realm of form, meaning “little radiance.”
The second of the three paradises that are the third dhyāna paradises in the form realm.
The fourth heaven of the form realm.
First of three heavens of gods on the second concentration level.
The lowest level of the form realm’s second concentration.
The fourth of the heavens of the form realm. Rebirth there is the karmic result of accomplishing the second meditative absorption.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, first of three levels of the second dhyāna realm.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Immeasurable.
“Great Light.” A kalpa in the distant past.
A city in South India.
Name of a past king in a story the Buddha tells.
Name of a tathāgata.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
One of the form realms.
A nāga king.

term: འོད་ ཉི་མ་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of the uṣṇīṣa kings attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Shining with Beryl.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
“Infinite Light.”
Originally primarily known as Amitāyus, the buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī. Rebirth in that realm has been an important goal since early Mahāyāna.
Originally primarily known as Amitāyus, the buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī. Rebirth in that realm has been an important goal since early Mahāyāna.
The buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī. In the sūtras more commonly known as Amitāyus.

Buddha associated with Sukhāvatī; buddha of the western direction; principal buddha of the Pure Land tradition; as the bodhisattva Dharmākara, he made fourty-eight original vows (praṇidhāna) to bring beings to enlightenment, thus establishing Sukhāvatī for their benefit; in tantrism he is one of the five dhyāni-buddhas and is associated with the aggregate of notions (saṃjñā­skandha).
The buddha who resides in Sukhāvatī.
Buddha of the Sukhāvatī buddha field.
The buddha residing in the western buddha realm Sukhāvatī.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Sukhāvatī. Alternate name for Amitāyus.
A buddha of the west; buddha of the Sukhāvatī buddhafield.
One of the five buddhas.
The buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī.
The buddha who presides over the buddhafield Sukhāvatī; also known as Amitāyus.
Also known as Amitāyus in the sūtras, he is the buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī.
A tathāgata, his names mean "infinite life;" another name for Amitābha, “Infinite Light.”
One of the most important buddhas in the Mahāyāna and Vajrayāna pantheon, Amitābha is the buddha presiding over the western Pure Land of Sukhāvatī.
The buddha residing in the western buddha realm of Sukhāvatī. He is also known as Amitāyus.
The buddha residing in the western buddha realm Sukhāvatī.
The buddha residing in the western buddhafield Sukhāvatī.
The twenty-first buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A bodhisattva of the past world Stainless who received a dhāraṇī from the Tathāgata Stainless Illumination. A past incarnation of the bodhisattva Dhāraṇīśvara­rāja.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of the thirty-eighth meditative stability.
Name of the ninety-ninth meditative stability.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.

term: འོད་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ བཟང་པོ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
The name of an absorption.
A bodhisattva present in the opening assembly, who later tells the story of his encounter with Vimalakīrti, who discourses to him about the seat of enlightenment.
A tathāgata in the northwestern buddhafield Free of Darkness.
A buddha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Essence.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
One of the garuḍa kings. The Tib. ’od bzang reads the Skt. Suprabha.
A sage; former incarnation of the Buddha.
A buddha realm.

“Excellent Light.” In chapter 41 it is the name of a kalpa in the distant past. Also in chapter 41 it is the name of a future kalpa with five hundred buddhas. In chapter 45 it is the name of another kalpa in the distant past.
One of the eminent sons from Dhanyākara who in chapter 3 came with Sudhana to see Mañjuśrī.
In chapter 21 it is the name of a city in the south of India. It is also the name of a forest in another world in the distant past during the kalpa of that name. The name means “excellent light.”
Realm of a tathāgata.
A ruler in South India.
A nāga king. The name means “having a hundred rays” and may be an alternate name for the nāga king Vasuki, Takṣaka, or Utpalaka.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A tathāgata associated with Jñānolka.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The name of a bodhisattva stage.
The third bodhisattva bhūmi.
The third ground of the bodhisattvas.
The third bodhisattva level.
The third bodhisattva bhūmi
A great bodhisattva.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of a past king in a story the Buddha tells, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A river.
A village.
A divine being.
A bodhisattva in the distant past who was a previous life of Mañjuśrī. Also known as Śrīgarbha.

term: འོད་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ སངས་རྒྱས་ མེ་ཏོག་ འབྱུང
en: Source of Buddha Flowers of Limitless Light
comment_en: A buddha.
A buddha.
“Infinite Light,” the name of the buddha who presides over Sukhāvatī, also called Amitāyus or Aparimitāyus. Traditionally equated, too, with Dundubhi­svara­rāja.
A buddha.
A buddha.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to the east of the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
The residence of a king.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist community during the time of the Buddha.
The park of Veṇuvana was the first settled residence specifically dedicated to the Buddhist saṅgha, offered to the Buddha by King Bimbisāra of Magadha.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and, as such, was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist comunity during the time of the Buddha.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha, the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist comunity during the time of the Buddha.

“Bamboo Grove,” a garden in Rājagṛha and a favorite residence of the Buddha and his disciples. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist community during the time of the Buddha.
A grove near Rājagṛha in Magadha.
A park near Rājagṛha. It was the first settled residence dedicated to the Buddhist saṅgha, offered to the Buddha by King Bimbisāra of Magadha.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and, as such, was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist comunity during the time of the Buddha.
King Bimbisāra’s park (lit. “Bamboo Grove”) near Rājagṛha. Here the Buddha dwelled regularly and gave many teachings.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist saṅgha during the time of the Buddha.
King Bimbisāra’s park (lit. “Bamboo Grove”) near Rājagṛha. Here the Buddha dwelled regularly and gave many teachings.
A grove of bamboo trees in Rājagṛha, where Buddha Śākyamuni sometimes dwelt.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist community during the time of the Buddha.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha and, as such, was the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist community during the time of the Buddha.
A park in Rājagṛha where the Buddha taught.
A bamboo grove or forest containing a monastery, north of Rājagṛha, where Buddha Śākyamuni spent several monsoon retreats and delivered many Great Vehicle teachings.

The famous bamboo grove near Rājagṛha where the Buddha regularly stayed and gave teachings. It was situated on land donated by King Bimbisāra of Magadha, the first of several landholdings donated to the Buddhist comunity during the time of the Buddha.
A park or garden near Rājagṛha, donated to the Buddha by King Bimbisāra, and the setting for a number of sūtras.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Fully Joyous.

en: Splendorous with the Gentle Glow of Light and Fragrance
comment_en: The name of a tathāgata.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

term: འོད་ཟེར་ ཀུན་ ནས་ མངོན་ འཕགས་ དཔལ་ བརྩེགས་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: The name of Prince Ratnākara once he attains awakening.

term: འོད་ཟེར་ ཀུན་ ནས་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ བརྩེགས་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: “King of Heaped Splendors That Shine Above All.” The name that Avalokiteśvara will have when he becomes a tathāgata. The Sanskrit name is attested in the Karuṇā­puṇḍarīka­sūtra.
A bodhisattva of the east.
Name of Heroic Strength when he becomes a buddha.

term: འོད་ཟེར་ གྱི་ དྲ་བ་ ཆེན་པོ་ རབ་ཏུ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A mountain in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.
“Array of Light Rays.” Name by which Vimalaśraddhā will be known upon her attainment of buddhahood.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A forest on the lower level of Living on the Peak.
A buddha in the past.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Shining Jewel.
A buddha of a previous eon. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-073-001.html#UT22084-073-001-748.
The guardian deity of the gate at the Buddha’s monastery near Rājagṛha.

A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.

One of the mahoraga kings.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.

comment_en: Either the thirtieth of, or a supplement to, the thirty-two major marks.

comment_en: Sixty-third of the eighty minor marks.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.

The fourth bodhisattva bhūmi.
A wife of the ancient king Prajñāsārathi.

comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past.
A past buddha realm where the buddha Teacher of the Power of Great Wisdom resided.
A vast family of world realms that contains our Sahā universe of a thousand million worlds.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A king who was the Buddha in a former life.
An uncle of Ānanda.
One of the kings of Nepal.

One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A forest in Shining in Manifold Ways.

The buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī, he is also known as Amitāyus. The Tibetan translation of Amitābha in this sūtra differs from the usual translations, either ’od dpag med or snang ba mtha’ yas. It is also the name in chapter 44 of a future buddha in this kalpa. In that instance the Tibetan is mi dpogs ’od.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha.
Name of a monk disciple of the Buddha Śākyamuni. Also refered to as Mahākāśyapa.
A buddha.
One of the Buddha’s principal pupils, who became the Buddha’s successor on his passing. Also the name of the Buddha who preceded Śākyamuni.
One of the six buddhas who preceded Śākyamuni in this Fortunate Eon. Also the name of the one of the Buddha’s principal pupils.
See “Mahākāśyapa.”

One of the Buddha’s principal pupils, who became the Buddha’s successor on his passing. Also the name of the preceding Buddha, the third in this eon, with Śākyamuni as the fourth. Also one of the seven great rishis of ancient India at the origin of Vedic culture. He is portrayed in this sūtra as coming to make offerings to the Buddha along with the other great rishis.
One of the Buddha’s closest hearer disciples; the name of the third buddha of the Fortunate Eon.
A previous buddha, the third of this current eon.
Name of a former buddha usually counted as the third of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Śākyamuni.
Another name of Mahākāśyapa.
Same as Mahākāśyapa.
One of Buddha’s attendants. Also called Mahākāśyapa.
The sixth of the “seven previous buddhas.”
The sixth of the seven tathāgatas/buddhas. Identified in other texts as the third buddha to appear in the present eon, and thus the immediated predecessor of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A previous buddha.
“Kāśyapa” occurs in this sūtra as the name of the disciple of the Buddha, Venerable Mahākāśyapa, and also of the past buddha, Tathāgata Kāśyapa.

Buddha of a previous age. Not to be confused with the monk Kāśyapa of Buddha Śākyamuni’s order, nor with Uruvilvā Kāśyapa, Nadī Kāśyapa, or Pūraṇa Kāśyapa, nor with Nirgrantha Kāśyapa, nor Foremost Kāśyapa.

Given name of “Nirgrantha Kinsman of the Kāśyapas.” Not to be confused with Kāśyapa, buddha of a previous age; the monk Kāśyapa of Buddha Śākyamuni’s order; nor with Uruvilvā Kāśyapa, Nadī Kāśyapa, or Pūraṇa Kāśyapa; nor Foremost Kāśyapa.
See “Mahā­kāśyapa.”
The buddha who preceded Śākyamuni in this Excellent Eon.

One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas; one of the previous buddhas; one of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; also a short name of Mahākāśyapa.
1) Close disciple of the Buddha; 2) Sixth of the seven buddhas of the past, and third in this kalpa.
The sixth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The third buddha in this Bhadraka eon.
The sixth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The third buddha in this Bhadraka eon.
Close disciple of the Buddha.
In Mahāyāna, a buddha who preceded the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The buddha who preceded Buddha Śākyamuni.

A brahmin who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. In The Hundred Deeds he is said to have lived in the wilderness, gone forth in front of a certain sage, and manifested the four meditations and the five superknowledges.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples. Also known as Kāśyapa.
Name of an elder.
One of the Buddha’s principal pupils, who became the Buddha’s successor on his passing. Also rendered here as “Kāśyapa.”
Śrāvaka arhat, one of the most important followers of the Buddha.
One of the principal students of the Buddha.
One of the Buddha’s principal disciples, he became the Buddha’s successor on his passing.
A senior student of the Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his austere lifestyle.
A senior student of the Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his austere lifestyle.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A senior disciple of the Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his austere lifestyle.
Foremost disciple of the Buddha; he inherited the leadership of the saṅgha after the Parinirvāṇa. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-924.
A senior student of Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his austere lifestyle.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
One of the Buddha’s foremost disciples.
Another name for the Buddha’s attendant Kāśyapa.
Mahākāśyapa was one of the principal disciples of the Buddha.
One of the eight great śrāvakas.
A senior student of Buddha Śākyamuni, famous for his austere lifestyle.
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.
One of the principal students of the Buddha, known for his ascetic practice.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.
One of the six outsider teachers.
One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.

One of the Buddha’s principal pupils, he became the Buddha’s successor on his passing. Also the preceding Buddha, the third in this kalpa, with Śākyamuni as the fourth. He is also called Kāśyapa. Elsewhere often spelled ’od srung chen po.
Also translated here as “aureole.”
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The name of a nakṣatra.
The name of various kings.

A yakṣa in this tantra. Although yang dag is normally translated as “Viśuddha,” we have rendered it here as “Samprajñāna” since this is the Sanskrit rendering of this particular yakṣa’s name in the list of name mantras at 2.14.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
First of the three provisions.

term: ཡང་དག་པ་ དང་ ལོག་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ སེལ་བ
en: Complete Elimination of Right and Wrong
comment_en: Name of the ninety-sixth meditative stability.
Third of the noble eightfold path.
To show others—by means of teaching, debate, and writing—the nature of reality free from conceptual elaborations (Rigzin 377). See also “noble eightfold path,” “thirty-seven wings of enlightenment.”
Eighth of the noble eightfold path.
See “right meditation.”

term: ཡང་དག་པ་ -འི་ བྱང་ཆུབ་ ཀྱི་ ཡན་ལག་ རིན་པོ་ཆེ་ བདུན
en: Seven precious factors of perfect awakening
comment_en: Otherwise known as the seven branches of awakening (byang chub kyi yan lag bdun): (1) awakened mindfulness, (2) awakened discernment of phenomena, (3) awakened diligence, (4) awakened rejoicing, (5) awakened pliancy, (6) awakened absorption, and (7) awakened equanimity.

en: Heroic at the Limit of Reality
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
One of the tathāgatas.
Fourth of the noble eightfold path.

Also called “right conduct,” it is convincing others that your activities conform with the doctrine and are harmonious with pure ethics (Rigzin 377). See also “noble eightfold path,” “thirty-seven wings of enlightenment.”

A relic of the Sinitic vocabulary in Tibetan texts (see McKeown 2010, 23). yang dag par gshegs pa renders Chinese ru lai 如來, which in turn renders Sanskrit tathā + āgata (“thus come”). This was apparently given preference by the Chinese translators of canonical texts over ruqu 如去, Sanskrit tathā + gata (“thus gone”). According to R. A. Stein, Tibetan translators, while aware that ru lai 如來 was a translation of the Sanskrit compound tathāgata , chose to translate ru lai as yang dag par gshegs pa “perfectly (or purely) come (or gone).” By thus deviating from the original sense of the epithet they indirectly marked the Tibetan translation as potentially Chinese in origin (McKeown 2010, 23).
A great bodhisattva.

term: ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ བླངས་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལས་ རྒལ་བ་ ཐེ་ཙོམ་ གཅོད་པ
en: Resolver of Doubts Regarding Transgressing All Vows
comment_en: Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Gentle Voice.
Name of the fifteenth meditative stability.
Manifesting the complete enlightenment of a buddha.
A term commonly used to describe the complete spiritual awakening of a buddha.
See “genuinely perfect buddha.”

The attainment of a buddha, who has gained total freedom from conditioned existence, overcome all tendencies imprinted on the mind as a result of a long association with afflicted mental states, and fully manifested all aspects of buddha body, speech, and mind. Also translated here as “completely perfect buddha.”
Literally, “perfectly and completely awakened one,” this refers to a buddha who teaches the Dharma, as opposed to a pratyeka­buddha.

A term used to emphasize the superiority of buddhahood when contrasted with the achievement of the arhats and pratyekabuddhas. A samyaksaṃbuddha is considered superior by virtue of his compassionate activity, his omniscience and his ten special powers.
An epithet of the buddhas, used both as an honorific and to distinguish them from beings of lesser realization such as arhats, solitary buddhas, and the like.
One of the standard epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni, and other buddhas as well.
A buddha who teaches the Dharma, as opposed to a pratyekabuddha.
A buddha who teaches the Dharma, as opposed to a pratyekabuddha.
The Connected Discourses, one of the four divisions of the Sūtrapiṭaka.
Relinquishing negative acts in the present and the future, and enhancing positive acts in the present and the future.
Relinquishing negative acts in the present and the future and enhancing positive acts in the present and the future. These four are part of the thirty-seven factors of awakening.
One of seven qualities cultivated on the path of seeing: mindfulness, discernment, diligence, joy, ease, absorption, equanimity.
A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past.
A young Brahmin, son of Lucky.
Name of a yakṣa general.
One of the five yakṣa generals.
The son of Kubera, about whom very little is known. His name is often rendered as yang dag shes in Tibetan translation, reflecting a frequent variant in the Sanskrit, Sañjñeya.
Name of a yakṣa general.
One among the eight hot hells.
One of the eight hot hells.
One of the eight hot hells.
Name of one of the great hells (Skt. mahānaraka); see also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-145.

First (and lightest) of the eight hot hells of Buddhist cosmology. Born frightened of one another, the inhabitants of the Reviving Hell fight with each other using sharp weapons, die, and are instantly revived over and over to continue fighting.
“Reviving,” one of the hells.
One of the eight hot hells.
One of the eight hot hells.
The ancient capital of the Licchavi republic.
The city of the Licchavis.

The ancient capital of the Licchavi republican state, the Buddha visited this city several times during his lifetime. It is perhaps most famous as the location where, on different occasions, the Buddha cured a plague, admitted the first nuns into the Buddhist order, was offered a bowl of honey by monkeys, and announced his parinirvāṇa three months prior to his departure.
The ancient capital of the Vṛji (q.v.) confederacy and Licchavi republic.
Great city during the Buddha’s time, capital of the Licchavi republic; at present the town of Basarh, Muzaffarpur district, in Tirhut, Bihar province of India. (See Lamotte, pp. 80-83; p. 97, n. 1.).

The ancient capital of the Licchavi republican state, the Buddha visited this city several times during his lifetime. It is perhaps most famous as the location where, on different occasions, Buddha cured a plague, admitted the first nuns into the Buddhist order, was offered a bowl of honey by monkeys, and announced his parinirvāṇa three months prior to his departure.
The site where Buddha Śākyamuni laid down various rules of the Vinaya, gave other teachings, and, on his last visit, announced his approaching parinirvāṇa.
A river in Godānīya.
A great city during the Buddha’s time, the capital of the Licchavi republic. It was an important location where a number of Buddhist sūtras are said to have been taught.
An ancient city founded by Viśāla, Vaiśālī was an important location where a number of Buddhist sūtras are said to have been taught, particularly in the Mahāyāna literature.

The ancient capital of the Licchavi republican state, Vaiśālī is located near present-day Patna in Bihar, India. The Buddha visited this city several times during his lifetime. It is perhaps most famous as the location where, on different occasions, the Buddha cured a plague, admitted the first nuns into the Buddhist order, was offered a bowl of honey by monkeys, and announced his parinirvāṇa three months prior to his departure.
One of a number of towns where the Buddha Śākyamuni is said to have taught.
The capital city of the Licchavis, where the Buddha gave his last sermon.
The ancient capital of the Licchavi state. The Buddha visited this city several times during his lifetime.

A great city during the Buddha’s time, the capital of the Licchavis and part of the Vṛji republic, near present-day Patna in Bihar. An important location where a number of Buddhist sūtras are said to have been taught.
A buddha realm below.
A city.
The site where the Buddha Śākyamuni laid down various rules of the Vinaya, gave other teachings, and, on his last visit, announced his approaching parinirvāṇa.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
A major city during the Buddha’s time, the capital of the Licchavi republic. It was an important location where a number of Buddhist sūtras are said to have been taught.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A great bodhisattva.
A village.
A potter who was the Buddha in a former life.
The realm where in the future there will be Buddha Śālendrarāja.
The eight qualities of water: (1) sweet-tasting; (2) cool; (3) soft; (4) light; (5) transparent; (6) clean; (7) not harmful to the throat; and (8) beneficial to the stomach.

en: Speech endowed with the eight aspects
comment_en: The eight qualities of a buddha’s voice are variously presented. According to the Pāli Mahāgovindasutta (Dīghanikāya 19) a buddha’s voice is fluent, intelligible, sweet, audible, sustained, distinct, deep, and resonant.
The path leading to the attainment of an arhat, consisting of correct view, intention, speech, action, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and absorption.
Right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right absorption.

en: Water that has the eight qualities
comment_en: Water that has the eight qualities of being sweet, cool, pleasant, light, clear, pure, not harmful to the throat, and beneficial for the stomach.
Eight qualities of water: sweet, cool, pleasant, light, clear, pure, not harmful to the throat, and beneficial for the stomach.
Eight qualities of water: sweet, cool, pleasant, light, clear, pure, not harmful to the throat, and beneficial for the stomach.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Beyond All Sorrow and Harm/Liberation from All Sorrow and Harm.
The Buddhist counterpart of Kāmadeva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A standard grouping of five classical instruments into non-membranous percussion, membranous percussion, windblown, plucked string, and bowed string.
A bodhimaṇḍa in another world in the distant past.
Name of the sixty-third meditative stability.
The four armed goddess who is the embodiment of the six-syllable mantra. Though female in Sanskrit, it is translated into Tibetan as a male name.

Oṁ maṇipadme hūṁ. This appears to be a vocative call to Avalokiteśvara under the name of Maṇipadma (see Introduction, note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-051-004.html#UT22084-051-004-23). Ṣadakṣarī (q.v.) is also the name of the four-armed goddess who personifies the mantra.

en: Establishing the Sameness of All Letters
comment_en: Name of the sixty-second meditative stability.
A class of beings said to dwell in the east under the jurisdiction of the great king Dhṛtarāṣṭra.

Literally “the departed” and analagous to the ancestral spirits of Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. They live in the realm of Yama, the Lord of Death, analogous to the underworld of Pluto in Greek mythology. In Buddhism they are said to suffer intensely, particularly from hunger and thirst.

Literally “the departed” and analagous to the ancestral spirits of the Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. They live in the realm of Yama, the Lord of Death, analogous to the underworld of Pluto in Greek mythology. In Buddhism they are said to suffer intensely, particularly from hunger and thirst.
A class of spirits of the lower order, sometimes called “hungry ghosts.”
A class of beings who, in Buddhist traditions, are particularly known to suffer from hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.
Class of beings; literally “hungry spirit;” one of the six realms of existence.

The Sanskrit preta literally means “departed” and generally refers to the spirits of the dead. More specifically in Buddhism, it refers to a class of sentient beings who belong to the lower or unfortunate rebirth-destinies and who suffer from moderate to extreme dearth and want as a karmic result of negative actions based on craving, hatred, and attachment (see Exposition of Karma, Toh 338, folio 281.a). The common English rendering “hungry ghost” is a literal translation of the Chinese translation of preta, 餓鬼 e gui.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, considered to be the karmic fruition of past miserliness. In Sanskrit, literally “the departed”; they are analogous to the ancestral spirits of Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. They live in the realm of Yama, the Lord of Death. They are particularly known to suffer from great hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, considered to be the karmic fruition of past miserliness. In Sanskrit, literally “the departed”; they are analogous to the ancestral spirits of Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. They live in the realm of Yama, the Lord of Death. They are particularly known to suffer from great hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.
A class of spirits sometimes called hungry ghosts.

Literally “the departed” and analogous to the ancestral spirits of Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. They live in the realm of Yama, the Lord of Death. In Buddhism they are said to suffer intensely, particularly from hunger and thirst.
A class of spirits ever afflicted by hunger and thirst; also, spirits of deceased people in general.

The inhabitants of one of the three lower realms of cyclic existence, these are a type of spirit known for being tormented by unceasing and insatiable hunger and thirst. Often rendered as “hungry ghost.”

Literally “the departed” and analogous to the ancestral spirits of the Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. In Buddhism they are said to suffer intensely, particularly from hunger and thirst, and their realm is one of the three or four unfortunate realms of rebirth.
A restless wandering ghost. In the Buddhist tradition, they are particularly known to suffer from hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire such sustenance.
A class of sentient beings constantly suffering from hunger and thirst, one of the six (or five) possible realms of rebirth.
A type of spirit known for being tormented by unceasing hunger and thirst.
A class of sentient beings constantly suffering from hunger and thirst, one of the six (or five) possible realms of rebirth.
A class of beings who, in the Buddhist tradition, are particularly known to suffer from hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.
“Ghost,” “Hungry ghost.”
A class of beings who, in the Buddhist tradition, are particularly known to suffer from hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.
A class of spirits; one of the three lower realms.

Literally “the departed” and analogous to the ancestral spirits of Vedic tradition, the pitṛs, who starve without the offerings of descendants. They live in the realm of Yama, the Lord of Death. In Buddhism, they are said to suffer intensely, particularly from hunger and thirst.
One of the rāśis.
A class of beings who, in the Buddhist tradition, are particularly known to suffer from hunger and thirst and the inability to acquire sustenance.
An epithet of deities, such as Mañjuśrī or Yamāntaka, whose mantras consists of a single syllable (ekākṣara).

Most of the Buddha’s life and ministry took place in the Middle Country. Its land extended to the Likara Forest in the east; the city of Śarāvatī and the Śarāvatī River in the south; the brahmin towns of Sthūṇa and Upasthūṇa in the west; and Uśīragiri in the north.

In Indian mythology, a tree in Indra’s heaven that is said to fulfill all desires.

Nyctanthes arbor-tristis. Presently in Hindi called parijat, pārijāta in Kannada, and so on. It features prominently in Indian legends and is one of the earthly trees that are are said to be in paradise. Some dictionaries equate it with the coral tree (māndārava).

One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A lake in Living by Rājanina.
One of the two bodhisattvas standing by the gateway in the Mañjuśrī maṇḍala.
A sambhogakāya deity to which the practitioner has a samaya commitment, commonly known by the students of Tibetan Buddhism as yidam.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
The forty-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.

term: རང་བཞིན་ ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ བླ་མ་ ངེས་པ་ འབྱུང

comment_en: One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The hundred-and-tenth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Prakṛtīśarīra­śiri­bhadra.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
An epithet for Buddha Śākyamuni, or for any fully awakened buddha.
(1284–1339). An important master in the Karma Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism (karma bka’ brgyud). He is considered the third master in the lineage to have the title of Karmapa.
A person who in his final life achieves realization through contemplating the twelve links of dependent origination without following an external teacher.
Those who, in times when there is no buddha, reach enlightenment on their own, but do not teach the Dharma to others.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
The way or vehicle of the pratyeka­buddhas.
The way of the pratyekabuddha, particularly characterized by contemplation on the twelve phases of dependent origination.
An individual who, in their last life, attains realization by awakening to the nature of dependent arising without relying upon a spiritual guide.
An individual who, in their last life, attains liberation by realizing the nature of interdependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.
A being who attains nirvāṇa without the help of a buddha.
An individual who, in his or her last life, attains realization by realizing the nature of interdependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.

Beings who attain buddhahood without relying on a teacher in their final lifetime. They may live alone or with peers, but do not teach the path of liberation to others because of a lack of motivation or the requisite merit.
One who has attained awakening and lives in solitude, without teaching others.
An individual who in their last life attains realization by realizing the nature of dependent origination, without relying upon a spiritual guide.

One who, in their last birth in saṃsāra, attains the realization of the selflessness of the person and a partial realization of the selflessness of phenomena, by observing the suchness of all that arises through interdependence on their own, without relying on a teacher.

Literally, “buddha for himself,” or “solitary realizer.” Those who attain buddhahood in a time when the Buddha’s doctrine is no longer available in the world, and who remain either in solitude or among peers, without teaching the path to liberation to others. Their attainment is the result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, they do not have the necessary accumulated merit nor the motivation to teach others.
An individual who, in their last life, attains realization by realizing the nature of dependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.
An individual who, in his or her last life, attains realization by realizing the nature of interdependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.
Someone who obtains personal liberation through very little or no instruction from others.

One who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.
An individual who, in his or her last life, attains realization by realizing the nature of interdependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.

Literally, “buddha for himself,” or “solitary realizer.” Those who attain buddhahood in a time when a buddha’s doctrine is no longer available in the world, and who remain either in solitude or among peers, without teaching the path of liberation to others. They are sometimes called “rhinoceros-like” for their preference to stay in solitude.
Individuals who, in their last life, attain realization by realizing the nature of dependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.
An individual who, in their last life, attains realization by realizing the nature of interdependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.

Literally, “buddha for himself,” or “solitary realizer.” Those who attain buddhahood in a time when the Buddha’s doctrine is no longer available in the world, and who remain either in solitude or among peers, without teaching the path to liberation to others. They are sometimes called “rhinoceros-like” for their preference to stay in solitude.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.

An individual who attains a certain level of realization and liberation (different in some respects from those of an arhat and well short of those of a buddha) through understanding the nature of interdependent origination, without relying upon a teacher in that lifetime.

One who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.
An individual who, in his or her final life, attains realization by realizing the nature of dependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.
These are beings who in their final existence achieve a lower enlightenment than that of the complete and perfect buddhas, and do so without relying on a teacher.
A being who attains nirvāṇa without the help of a buddha.
Someone who obtains personal liberation through very little or no instruction from others.

Someone who has attained liberation entirely through their own contemplation as a result of progress in previous lives but, unlike a buddha, does not have the accumulated merit and motivation to teach others.
Someone who obtains personal liberation through very little or no instruction from others.
An individual who, in his or her last life, attains realization by realizing the nature of dependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.
Someone who obtains personal liberation through very little or no instruction from others.
An individual who, in their last life, attains liberation by realizing the nature of interdependent origination without relying upon a spiritual guide.

An individual who attains a certain level of realization and liberation (different in some respects from those of an arhat and well short of those of a buddha) through understanding the nature of interdependent origination, without relying upon a spiritual guide.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A yakṣa lord.
A buddha.

A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva present during the delivery of the King of the Array of all Dharma Qualities.
A king based in Ujjain; contemporary of the Buddha.
A mountain.
One of the seven golden mountains that surround Mount Sumeru.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife. Also called Serene Form.
Alternative name for Serene.
A nāga king.
A nāga king.

A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

A bodhisattva.

The first bodhisattva level.
The first bodhisattva bhūmi.

A buddha realm.

A mountain range in the Heaven Free from Strife.

A part of Mountainous Garland.

One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

A river. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2169.

A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.

Seventh of the eight hot hells of Buddhist cosmology. Inhabitants of this hell undergo all the sufferings of the Hot Hell, as well as being seared, beaten, and skewered.
“Very Hot,” one of the hot hells.
One of the eight hot hells.
One of the eight hot hells.
One of the kings of the asuras; also, the king of all animals.

A certain mendicant. Not to be confused with Subhadra the charioteer of King Śuddhodana. After his death, a series of miracles confirmed that he had been a practitioner of the Buddha’s monastic code.
(1) A nāga king (rab brtan). (2) The king of banyan trees (shin tu rab gnas).
A certain stūpa in Magadha located near Forest of Reeds.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Demonstrator of Consequences attains buddhahood as the tathāgata Lamp of Fire.

A divine heaven, and the suyāma (“free from strife”) class of gods who inhabit it.

A buddha realm.
Name of a rākṣasī and Dharma protector.
King of the gods of Nirmāṇarati.
The principal deity in the Nirmāṇarati paradise, the second highest paradise in the desire realm.
The principal deity in the Nirmāṇarata paradise, the second highest paradise in the desire realm.
The principal deity in Nirmāṇarata, the second highest paradise in the desire realm.
The principal deity in the Nirmāṇarati paradise, the second highest paradise in the desire realm.

A buddha realm.
A buddha realm.
Son of King Anantanemi of Ujjayinī.
See “Caṇḍapradyota.”
A virtuous nāga king.
Another name of Anāthapiṇḍada.
One of the seven golden mountains that surround Mount Sumeru.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.

A vidyādhara site on Kālaka.
King of Tibet, who reigned 815–838 ce. Also known as Tritsuk Detsen (khri gtug lde btsan).
A king of Tibet who reigned from 815 to 838.

The Brahmā of the universe Aśoka, who is personally called Śikhin to distinguish him from Brahmās of other universes (see Brahmā). The second of the “seven buddhas of the past” is also called Śikhin but his name is rendered in Tibetan as gtsug gtor can.
A rākṣasī.
A forest on Deer Abode.
The Tibetan king who reigned from 815–38 ce.
A king of Tibet, born circa 806, who reigned from 815 to 838. His formal name was Tritsuk Detsen (khri gtsug lde btsan).
A goddess.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

(1083–1161). A close disciple of Milarepa, who traveled to India and brought back some of the teaching cycles that Marpa had not transmitted, as well as the Amitāyus tradition he received from the yoginī Siddharājñī.
Where Buddha converted a noble band of sixty youths.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
One of the female deities in the retinue of Hevajra.
A verse text possibly included in the Kṣudraka­piṭaka of the Mūla­sarvāstivādins and preserved in the Bhaiṣajyavastu of the Mūla­sarvāstivāda Vinaya.
A mountain in Pleasant Sound.
The hill in Khotan from which the Buddha deliveres his prophecy. Gośṛṅga means “cow horn” in Sanskrit and the hill is said to have received this name due to having two pointed peaks.
A mountain in Pleasant Sound.
A mountain on Videha.
A mountain in Kuru.

The forest, located outside of Vārāṇasī, where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.

The forest, located outside of Vārāṇasī, where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.

A town in South India.

term: རི་ དགའ་ -ས་ འཛིན་ གྱི་ བུ་ ནག་པོ

term: རི་ དགའ་ -ས་ འཛིན་ གྱི་ མ་ ས་ག
comment_en: A lay follower of the Buddha.
Another name for Viśākhā Mṛgāramātā, a lay follower of the Buddha.

This is the nickname of an upāsikā (female lay practitioner), actually called Viśākhā, who is sometimes considered the most prominent among female lay followers of the Buddha. She had married the son of a man called Mṛgāra, who was originally a Jaina but went to meet the Buddha and even become a stream enterer thanks to her. Feeling indebted to her, he said that she was like his mother, which is the origin of the nickname.
The name of a rich man.
One of King Prasenajit’s two chief ministers in Śrāvastī.
Śarabha Aiṇeya, the king of ungulates, is a mythical creature, alternatively represented as a spotted antelope (kṛṣṇa­sāra) or as an eight-footed antelope (bse kha sgo).
A lay follower of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

en: Song Offering the Royal Lord of Mountains
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The forest, located outside of Vārāṇasī where the Buddha first taught the Dharma.

The Nine Black Mountains found on the northern edge of the continent of Jambudvīpa. There are three sets of three of these peaks, and behind them lies the great snow mountain that is the source of the Ganges River. A description of this cosmology can be found in chapter three of the Abhidharmakośabhāṣya of Vasubandhu.
A mountain.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A mountain.
One of ten “kings of mountains” according to Abdhidharma cosomology.
A mythical mountain.
A mythical mountain.
A mountain.

A certain mountain south of Rājagṛha.
(1) The son of the brahmin Agnidatta (ri bo can). (2) The son of the nāga Apalāla (ri bo).
Name of a yakṣa.
One of the tathāgatas.
A mountain.
A mountain.
A river on Saṅkāśa.

A nāga king who was a devotee of the Buddha. King Bimbisara once banished him and another nāga because they did not honor him. A drought occurred, and on the Buddha’s advice, he asked the nāgas for their forgiveness.
The mountain at the center of a world system and surrounded by the four continents.
A world realm of ten thousand million worlds in the distant past.
A nāga king.
(1) A ṛṣi. (2) A ṛṣi who is a nephew of Kaineya.
A future buddha.
A future buddha.
A buddha of a previous eon.
Sage who lived with five hundred devotees in the forest and spent time on the banks of Lake Mandākinī, his maternal uncle was the sage Kaineya.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva.

Several ranges of mountains in west and central India, traditionally held to be the boundary between North and South India.
