The great mountain at the center of the universe according to ancient Indian cosmology.
The central mountain of the universe, by the reckoning of Buddhist cosmology, identified with Mount Kailas in western Tibet.
The highest mountain at the center of our world according to traditional Buddhist cosmology.
The mountain located in the center of the world in Buddhist cosmology.
A mythical mountain located at the center of the universe.

According to ancient Indian cosmology, Meru is the great mountain forming the axis of the universe. At its summit lies Sudarśana, home of Śakra and his thirty-two gods, and on its flanks live the asuras. The mount has four sides facing the cardinal directions, each of which is made of a different precious stone. Surrounding it are several mountain ranges and the great ocean where the four great island continents lie: in the south, Jambudvīpa (our world); in the west, Godānīya; in the north, Uttarakuru; in the east, Pūrvavideha. Above it are the abodes of the gods of the realm of desire.
Center of the universe according to Buddhist and Hindu cosmology.
The highest mountain at the center of our world according to traditional Buddhist cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, the sacred mountain at the center of the world.
A name for a large mountain, esp. the one at the center of the world according to Buddhist cosmology.
According to the ancient Indian cosmological system, Mount Meru is a mountain which forms the centre of the universe.
The great mountain at the center of the universe according to ancient Indian cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, the mountain at the center of a world system surrounded by the four continents.
A gigantic mountain which forms the center of the universe in classical Indian cosmology.
(1) The highest mountain at the center of our world according to traditional Buddhist cosmology. (2) Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with the Light of Ethical Conduct.
The highest mountain at the center of our world according to traditional Buddhist cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, the great mountain at the center of the known universe.
The mountain in the center of the disk of the world with the four continents around it. Also known as Meru.
The gigantic mountain in the center of the world, portrayed as a flat disk with the four continents around it. Also known as Sumeru.
The gigantic mountain in the center of the world, portrayed as a flat disk with the four continents around it. Also known as Meru.
The mountain at the center of the world in ancient Indian cosmology, an axis mundi.
The great mountain at the center of the universe according to ancient Indian cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, the great mountain at the center of the universe.
In Buddhist cosmology, the sacred mountain at the center of the world.
A thus-gone one of the past.
The mountain in the center of the disc of the world with the four continents around it.
The mountain in the center of the disc of the world with the four continents around it.
The central mountain according to Buddhist cosmology.
In Buddhist cosmology, the great mountain at the center of the universe.
In Buddhist cosmology, the sacred mountain at the center of the world.
The great mountain at the center of the universe, according to ancient Indian cosmology. At its summit lies Sudarśana city, home of Śakra (Indra) and his thirty-two gods.

comment_en: A class of vidyādharas.

Vidyā is synonymous with mantra. Although grammatically it is a female word, the Tibetan has it translated as a male noun.

A common description of buddhas. According to some explanations, “wisdom” refers to awakening, and “conduct” to the three trainings (bslab pa gsum) by means of which a buddha attains that awakening; according to others, “wisdom” refers to right view, and “conduct” to the other seven elements of the eightfold path.

A common description of buddhas. According to some explanations, “wisdom” refers to awakening, and “conduct” to the three trainings (bslab pa gsum) by means of which a buddha attains that awakening; according to others, “wisdom” refers to right view, and “conduct” to the other seven elements of the eightfold path.

The Nibandhana explains this as a metaphor of the eye and the feet, which, operating together, allow one to move; knowledge, interpreted as either “right view” or as “the training in wisdom,” is like the eye, while the other seven parts of the noble eightfold path, or the two other trainings in discipline and samādhi, function as the “feet.” This explanation is also found in the sgra sbyor bam po gnyis pa commentary on the Mahāvyutpatti, which further clarifies that zhabs is here simply the honorific term for “foot” (caraṇa ni rkang pa). Thus, although it is not uncommon to translate caraṇa here with “conduct,” this loses the significance of the metaphor.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.

A stream on Saṅkāśa.

A class of semi-divine beings that are famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.
“Knowledge holder”; one possessed of magical powers; a class of semi-divine beings.

A type of semi-divine being whose identiy has shifted over time and genre. In their most popular form they are spell (vidyā) wielding (dhara) beings capable of granting magical abilities to those they favor. The Buddhist tradition associated them more closely with soteriological aims, identifying them as realized beings who possess (dhara) knowledge or awareness (vidyā).
One of the rāśis.
A bodhisattva.
Wisdom, knowledge, cognition, quality of awareness (Rigzin 396).
Literally “logic,” Nyāya is one of the six great philosophical systems of ancient India.
Literally “knowledge holder”—this term refers either to someone who has mastered the vidyā, i.e. the power of the mantra, or to a class of semidivine beings.
A deity invoked in the rite of vanquishing enemies and accomplishing all actions.
See “vidyārāja.”
“Vidyā king,” a class of mantras and mantra deities; an epithet of Vajrapāṇi; an epithet of any powerful vidyā or mantra.
The textual base for Brahmanism in India is the Vedas: 1) Ṛgveda, 2) Yajurveda, 3) Sāmaveda, and 4) Atharvaveda.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the ancient sacred Scriptures of Brahmanism, most famous of which is the Ṛg Veda.
Name of the ancient sacred scriptures of Hinduism, the most famous of which is the Ṛg Veda.
See “consort (female).”

A class of semi-divine being that is famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.

Popular in Indian literature as a race of superhuman beings with magical powers who lived high in the mountains, such as in the Malaya range of southwest India. The term vidyā could be interpreted as both “knowledge” and “mantra.”

A class of semidivine beings who are famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and Kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.

One possessed of vidyā ; this could refer to any being who is an adept of magical lore, but in particular to the class of semidivine, nonhuman beings of the same name. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “knowledge holder” or “adept of vidyās.”
“Knowledge holder,” a being possessed of magical powers.
A class of semidivine beings possessed of magical powers (vidyā); also any person or being possessed of such powers, usually derived from the mastery of a mantra (vidyā) of a female deity (vidyā).
A race of superhuman beings with magical powers who lived high in mountains, such as the Malaya range of southwest India. Also used for humans who have gained powers through their mantras.

The list of seven precious things varies. Either they are gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire; or else they are ruby, sapphire, beryl, emerald, diamond, pearls, and coral.

The usual list is: (1) the precious golden wheel (Skt. cakraratna; Tib. ’khor lo rin po che); (2) the precious jewel (Skt. maṇiratna; Tib. nor bu rin po che); (3) the precious queen (Skt. strīratna; Tib. btsun mo rin po che); (4) the precious minister (Skt. puruṣaratna or pariṇāyakaratna; Tib. blon po rin po che); (5) the precious elephant (Skt. hastiratna; Tib. glang po rin po che); (6) the precious horse (Skt. aśvaratna; Tib. rta mchog rin po che); and (7) the precious general (Skt. khaḍgaratna or senāpatiratna; Tib. dmag dpon rin po che). Here the precious queen is substituted by a precious woman (Tib. bud med rin po che) and the precious general is substituted by a precious householder (Tib. khyim bdag rin po che). However, in this text they appear listed slightly differently (see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-076-001.html#UT22084-076-001-269). Here the precious queen is substituted by a precious woman (Tib. bud med rin po che), and the precious general is substituted by a precious householder (Tib. khyim bdag rin po che).

The seven precious things in this context‌ comprise the seven precious metals and stones, namely, gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire. More generally‌, they may also comprise the symbols of royal dominion, namely, the wheel, gem, queen, minister, elephant, general, and horse. See Dudjom Rinpoche (1991), vol. 2, p. 156.

In this sūtra they are specified to be gold, silver, beryl, white coral, emerald, red pearl, and chrysoberyl. When associated with the seven heavenly bodies, and therefore the seven days of the week, they are the seven jewels: ruby for the sun; moonstone or pearl for the moon; coral for Mars; emerald for Mercury; yellow sapphire for Jupiter; diamond for Venus; and blue sapphire for Saturn. An alternative list is: gold, silver, beryl, crystal, coral, emerald, and white coral.

The seven precious things comprise the seven precious metals and stones, namely, gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire. More generally‌, they may also comprise the symbols of royal dominion, namely, the wheel, gem, queen, minister, elephant, general, and horse.
The list of seven precious materials varies. Either they are gold, silver, turquoise, coral, pearl, emerald, and sapphire; or else they are ruby, sapphire, beryl, emerald, diamond, pearls, and coral.

The Kāraṇḍavyūha in the Vaidya edition references a group of islands, the distinction between singular and plural being lost in the Tibetan. Ratnadvīpa was one of the ancient names of Laṅka, as it was a rich source of jewels. In this same passage, however, Laṅka is identified as the land of the rākṣasīs. The theme of an ocean island rich in jewels appears frequently in Buddhist narratives.

term: རོལ་མོ་ -འི་ སྒྲ་ ཅན་ གྱི་ ཤིང་ ལྗོན་པ
comment_en: A tree in Vaiśālī at whose base the Buddha Śākyamuni taught The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Blessed Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha.

term: རྐ་ ལག་ ཕྲ་ ཞིང་ མཉེན་ ལ་ གཞོན་ཤ་ ཆགས་ ཤིང་ སྲ་བ་ ལ་འཇམ་ ཞིང་ མེ་ཏོག་ ལྟར་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ གཞོན་ ལ་ རྐ་ ལག་ གི་ སེན་མོ་ ཟངས་ ཀྱི་ མདོག་ འདྲ་བ
en: Slender, Supple, Firm, Fine, and Smooth Limbs Youthful Like Flowers and with Copper-Colored Nails
comment_en: One of the bodhisattva great beings.

en: Copious Parasites in Marrow and Bones
comment_en: One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Four qualities that eliminate negative factors: zeal, vigor, attention (Tib. sems pa, Skt. citta), and investigation (Tib. dpyod pa, Skt. mīmāṃsā).
One of the kings of Nepal.

en: Subjugating the Three Worlds under One’s Feet
comment_en: Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the garuḍa kings.
A son of King Ikṣuvāku.
A being who attains victory (i.e. awakening) through specific circumstances. Almost certainly a synonym for a solitary buddha.
Refers to a pratyekabuddha. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-057-004.html#UT22084-057-004-583.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha.
One of the great mātṛs.
‟One with an Aged Face,” one of the eight demonesses who inhabit the eight great charnel grounds.
A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
Name of a mountain by Rajghir in Bihar, which is the setting for many sutras.
See “Vulture Peak.”
A mountain by Rajghir in Bihar, which is the setting for many sutras. Also rendered here as “Gṛdhrakūṭa.”

Also known as “Vulture Peak,” a hill located in modern-day Bihar, India, and in the vicinity of the ancient city of Rājagṛha. A location where many sūtras were taught and which continues to be a sacred pilgrimage site for Buddhists to this day.
‟Laughing One,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the grahas.
One of the grahas.
One of the twenty-seven realms of the Heaven Free from Strife, presumably the same as Moving in Mixed Environments.

The name of one of the bodhisattvas in the Buddha Śākyamuni’s presence in Śrāvastī in chapter 1 (where it is translated as rgya chen po’i ’od), and the name of the king, one of Sudhana’s kalyāṇamitras, in chapter 22 (where it is translated as ’od chen po).
The forty-first buddha in a kalpa in the distant past, and also the eighty-eighth buddha in another kalpa in the distant past.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
A mountain on Videha.

term: རྒྱ་མཚོ་ ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ སྤྲིན་སྒྲ་ སྒྲོགས་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.

term: རྒྱ་མཚོ་ དམ་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ་ དྲི་མ་ མེད་པ་ -ར་ སྣང་བ་ འོད་གསལ་བ་ -འི་ གཟུངས
en: Dhāraṇī of the immaculately shining clear light of the essence of the sublime oceanic assembly

comment_en: An unidentified river in India.
“Ten Lakes,” the country southeast of Madhyadeśa.
A town in South India.
A short form of Sāgara­vara­dhara­buddhi­vikrīḍitābhijña, the name that Ānanda will have when he is a buddha.

term: རྒྱ་མཚོ་ མཆོག་ འཆང་ བློ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ རོལ་པ་ -འི་ མངོན་པར་ ཤེས་པ
comment_en: The name of Ānanda when he becomes a buddha in the future.
A bodhisattva.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Triumphant on the Seat of Awakening with His Brilliance.
An area in the south of India.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A nāga king.
A buddha realm.
The principal nāga king. In the Samādhi­rāja Sūtra (Toh 127) this is said to be another name for Vaṛuna, the deity of the water.
The principal nāga king; in this sūtra another name for Vaṛuna.
Literally meaning “ocean,” he is a king of the nāgas, a class of semidivine snake creatures.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A nāga king.
A king of the nāgas.
One of the kings of nāgas; also, the ocean personified.
The ocean personified; the Gupta emperor Samudragupta who ruled Gauḍa and Magadha in the third quarter of the fourth century.
A nāga king; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a nāga king.
A nāga king.
An area in the Laṅka region of South India.

term: རྒྱ་མཚོ་ -འི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རབ་ཏུ་ ཀློངས་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
en: Song That Stirs All the Oceans
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha who lived in the distant past.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The name of an absorption and the name of a dhāraṇī.
One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
An absorption.
A bhikṣu who was a pupil of Śāriputra.

term: རྒྱ་མཚོ་ -འི་ མཆོག་ མངའ་བ་ -འི་ བློ་ -ས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ རོལ་པ་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ མགནོན་པ་ -ར་ མཁྱེན་པ
en: Master of the Ocean with Noble and Playful Super-knowledge
comment_en: A buddha that resides in a world system below our world called Adorned with Immaculate and Countless Precious Qualities.
One of the charnel grounds.
A province in South India.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A bhikṣu, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 9.
The son of King Glacier Lake Deity, a past monarch of the city of Campā.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha.
An area in the south of India.
A buddha in the distant past.

en: Fragrant with an Ocean of Incense
comment_en: Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Shining with Immeasurable Incense.
A bhikṣu, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 5.
One of four cronies of Devadatta.
One of the members of a group of four monks described in the Vinaya as followers of Devadatta that attempted to create a schism in the Buddhist saṅgha.
Another name of Bhavatrāta, a half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.

The Bharatas of southern Punjab were one of the prominent peoples mentioned in the Ṛgveda. Here, we believe the term Bharatas denotes the Aryan people, in contrast to the Drāviḍians who are mentioned below.
One of four parks that surround the city of Radiant.
The wife of Prince Viśvantara.
Name of a tathāgata.
A buddhafield at the zenith, where the Tathāgata Sovereign of Supreme Reverberating Sound resides.
The name of an apsaras.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Light of Incense.
A great park in South India.
The name of an absorption.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.

term: རྒྱན་ དང་ གདུགས་ ཀྱི་ དབྱངས་ ཀྱི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.
“Winner at Dice,” a previous life of Prince Puṇyabala and the Buddha himself. Also called King Jaya.
A bodhisattva.
‟Adorned One,” one of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.

term: རྒྱན་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ བཀོད་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རབ་ཏུ་ སྣང་བ་ -ར་ སྟོན་པ་ -འི་ སྙིང་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A four-continent world in the distant past.

term: རྒྱབ་ ནས་ ཀླུང་ ཀུན་ དུ་ གང་བ་ -ར་ འབབ་པ
comment_en: A river on Saṅkāśa.
A brahmin; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Gods of the four directions and the first heaven in the desire realm.
The divine kings who rule the four directions: Vaiśravaṇa (who in this text appears under his alternative name Kubera), Virūḍhaka, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Virūpākṣa.

en: Abode of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: First of six levels of gods in the desire realm.
First god realm of desire, meaning “abode of the four great kings.”

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: The first of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Realm of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: One of the gods’ realms.

en: (gods) attendant on the Four Great Kings
comment_en: A class of gods who inhabit the lowest among the six heavens of the desire realm, the dwelling place of the Four Great Kings.

en: Realm of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, lowest among the six heavens of the desire realm. Dwelling place of the Four Great Kings, traditionally located on a terrace of Mount Meru.

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Realms of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: The four respective realms of the Four Great Kings—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa. They are the lowest of the god realms and found on the slopes of Mount Meru, one in each of the four directions.

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Retinue of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: The realm of the Four Great Kings and their retinue constitutes the first and lowest heaven of the form realm on the slopes of Mount Meru. The Four Great Kings are Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūḍhaka in the south, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Vaiśravaṇa in the north.

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: The lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm.

en: Abodes of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, lowest among the six heavens of the desire realm. Dwelling place of the four great kings, traditionally located on a terrace of Sumeru, just below the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
Heaven of the Four Great Kings
Heaven of the Four Great Kings
Gods of the Four Great Kings

comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
The king of the Kośala kingdom (located in Northern India, in present day Uttar Pradesh) and Vimalaśraddhā’s father.
The guardian kings of the four quarters who rule, respectively, over yakṣas, kumbhāṇḍas, gandharvas, and nāgas

The powerful non-human guardian kings of the four quarters—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nagas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
Four deities on the base of Mount Meru, each one the guardian of his direction: Vaiśravaṇa in the north, Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east; Virūpākṣa in the west; and Virūḍhaka in the south.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
Divine guardians of the four directions, namely, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, and Vaiśravaṇa. Also referred to as the Four Protectors of the World.

Four gods who live on the lower slopes (fourth level) of Mount Meru in the Heaven of the Four Great Kings and guard the four cardinal directions. Each is the leader of a semidivine class of beings living in his realm. They are Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, and Vaiśravaṇa.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters of this universe—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
Four gods who preside over the cardinal directions.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
The four divine guardians at the four cardinal directions of Mount Meru.

The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters of this universe—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa or Kubera, as he is called in this text—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.

The powerful non-human guardian kings of the four quarters of this universe—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa or Kubera, as he is called in this text—who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
The kings Dhṛtarāṣṭra (east), Virūḍhaka (south), Virūpākṣa (west), and Vaiśravaṇa (north), who guard the four directions.
The kings Dhṛtarāṣṭra (east), Virūḍhaka (south), Virūpākṣa (west), and Vaiśravaṇa (north), who guard the four directions.

The Four Great Kings—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa. They are gods of the first god realm of the desire realm and known as powerful guardians of the four quarters who rule, respectively, over kumbhāṇḍas in the south, nāgas in the west, gandharvas in the east, and yakṣas in the north.
Four gods who preside over the cardinal directions: Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa. They are also referred to as the “four guardians of the world.”
The guardian kings of the four quarters who rule, respectively, over yakṣas, kumbhāṇḍas, gandharvas, and nāgas.
The powerful nonhuman guardian kings of the four quarters‍—Virūḍhaka, Virūpākṣa, Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and Vaiśravaṇa‍.
Four deities on the base of Mount Meru, each one the guardian of his direction: Vaiśravaṇa in the north; Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east; Virūpākṣa in the west; and Virūḍhaka in the south.
Four deities on the base of Mount Meru, each one the guardian of his direction: Vaiśravaṇa in the north; Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east; Virūpākṣa in the west; and Virūḍhaka in the south.
The four divine kings who preside over the lowest of the god realms, on the slopes of Mount Meru: Dhṛtarāṣṭra in the east, Virūḍhaka in the south, Virūpākṣa in the west, and Vaiśravaṇa in the north.
A deity in the paradises of the Four Mahārājas.

en: Realm of the four great kings
comment_en: One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
See “Four Great Kings.”

A king ruling over a particularly large territory, often including the territories of other petty rulers; a class of divine beings assigned to the cardinal directions who guard the earth, Buddhist practitioners, and Buddhist institutions against demonic forces.
See “Four Great Kings.”
A guardian of one of the four cardinal directions.
The last emperor of the Sātavāhana dynasty.

In addition to the Five Royal Sūtras: (6) Aparimitāyur­jñāna (tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa’i mdo, Toh 674); for extending longevity (tshe bsring). (7) gos sngon can gyi gzungs, perhaps Bhagavān­nīlāmbara­dhara­vajrapāṇi­tantra (Toh 498) but possibly another of the several texts on this form of Vajrapāṇi; for protection (srung ba). (8) Uṣṇīṣa­sitāta­patrā (gtsug tor gdugs dkar, Toh 590, 591, and 592); for averting (zlog pa). (9) Vasu­dhāra (nor rgyun ma, Toh 663 and 664); for increasing resources (longs spyod spel ba). (10) Ekākṣarīmātā­prajñā­pāramitā (sher phyin yi ge gcig ma, Toh 23); for the essence (snying po).

This set of sūtras is so called either because they represent distillations of the most profound scriptures, or because according to traditional histories they were recommended to King Trisong Detsen for his daily practice by Guru Padmasambhava. These are: (1) Bhadra­caryā­praṇidhāna (bzang spyod smon lam, (Toh 44-45a) in chapter 45 of the Avataṃsaka); for aspiration (smon lam), and described as vast (rgya chen). (2) Vajra­vidāraṇā­dhāraṇī (rdo rje rnam ’joms, Toh 750); for ablution (khrus). (3) Prajñā­pāramitā­hṛdaya (shes rab snying po, Toh 21 and 531); for the view (lta ba), and described as profound (zab mo). (4) Atyaya­jñāna (’da’ ka ye shes, Toh 122); for cultivation (sgom pa) and described as of definitive meaning (nges don). (5) bya ba ltung bshags (part of Vinaya­viniścayopāli­paripṛcchā, Toh 68); for purification of karmic obscurations (las sgrib dag pa). (6) Aparimitāyur­jñāna (tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa’i mdo, Toh 674); for extending longevity (tshe bsring). (7) gos sngon can gyi gzungs, perhaps Bhagavān­nīlāmbara­dhara­vajrapāṇi­tantra (Toh 498) but possibly another of the several texts on this form of Vajrapāṇi; for protection (srung ba). (8) Uṣṇīṣa­sitāta­patrā (gtsug tor gdugs dkar, Toh 590, 591, and 592); for averting (zlog pa). (9) Vasu­dhāra (nor rgyun ma, Toh 663 and 664); for increasing resources (longs spyod spel ba). (10) Ekākṣarīmātā­prajñā­pāramitā (sher phyin yi ge gcig ma, Toh 23); for the essence (snying po).

The father of the Buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A king in Khotan. Identified by Thomas (1935, p. 25) as Yehu-la.
One of the classes of people barred from joining the renunciate order.
One of the classes of people barred from joining the renunciate order.

term: རྒྱལ་པོ་ ལས་ གཞོན་ནུ་ -འི་ ཡོངས་སུ་ སྤང་བ་ ཐོབ
en: Secured from the king the liberty of a prince
comment_en: A stylized way to say that a person or group may govern itself and is not subject to the “law of the land.” The Buddhist saṅgha enjoyed such autonomy. The analogy means the king granted sovereignty to the saṅgha, which was then allowed to govern itself and was not subject to the law of the land. The legal exemption members of the saṅgha enjoyed made it an attractive sanctuary for those on the run from their masters, debt collectors, and the law, who would join the saṅgha for legal rather than spiritual reasons. “From ancient times the legal tradition recognized the right of properly constituted groups to formulate their own laws” (Olivelle, 1993, 209).

A grove formerly owned by Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala. It was bought by Anāthapiṇḍada and offered to the Buddha as a rainy season retreat. It is the setting for many sūtras.
The grove of Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī; the Buddha taught many of his discourses there, especially during the rainy season retreat.

“Prince Jeta’s Grove,” a grove near Śrāvastī that was given to the Buddha by the householder Anātha­piṇḍada. The Buddha is said to have spent most rainy seasons there, and it is therefore the setting for many discourses.

A park outside Śrāvastī. It was donated to the Buddha by Anāthapiṇḍada, who purchased it at great cost from Prince Jeta, and built there the monastery where the Buddha spent most rainy seasons and is therefore the setting for many sūtras.
A park in Śrāvastī that was offered to the Buddha and his monks by the wealthy lay disciple Anāthapiṇḍada.
A forest near Śrāvastī in Kosala where the householder Anāthapiṇḍada built a monastery for the Buddha and his disciples.

A park in Śrāvastī, the capital of the ancient kingdom of Kośala in northern India. It was owned by Prince Jeta, and the wealthy merchant Anāthapiṇḍada, wishing to offer it to the Buddha, bought it from him by covering the entire property with gold coins. It was to become the place where the monks could be housed during the monsoon season, thus creating the first Buddhist monastery. It is therefore the setting for many of the Buddha's discourses.

“Prince Jeta’s Grove,” a grove near Śrāvastī that was given to the Buddha by the householder Anāthapiṇḍada. The Buddha is said to have spent most rainy seasons there, and it is therefore the setting for many discourses.
A grove that was given to the Buddha. Prince Jeta sold the so-called garden of Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī to the householder Anāthapiṇḍika, who built a monastery there and offered it to the Buddha.

A grove owned by Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala. It was bought by Anāthapiṇḍada and became the monastery that the Buddha spent most rainy seasons in and is therefore the setting for many sūtras.

A grove owned by Prince Jeta in Śrāvastī, the capital of the kingdom of Kośala. It was bought by Anāthapiṇḍada and became the monastery that the Buddha spent most rainy seasons in, and it is therefore the setting for many sūtras.

A grove that was bought by the Buddha’s wealthy follower and supporter Anāthapiṇḍada from a prince named Jeta and donated to the Buddha and his saṅgha (the story of the purchase and the events leading to it is told in the Cullavagga of the Pāli Vinaya).

en: Heaven of the Four Great Kings
comment_en: One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm. It is located on the slopes of Mount Meru and ruled by the Four Great Kings.

The abbreviated name that the bodhisattva Incomparable/Stainless is prophesied to adopt when he takes his place as the tathāgata presiding over the buddhafield Full of Pearls after the tathāgata King of Jewels passes into parinirvāṇa. The full name of this tathagata in this work is Victory Banner King Whose Light Rays Illuminate All the World Realms in the Ten-Directional Unimpeded Circular Maṇḍala, Adorned with Completely Illuminating Sunlight, Endowed with a Space-Like Body Resembling Youthful Varuna, the Light of the Sun, a Moon Flower, and a Beautiful Golden Lotus.

A Tibetan translator and scholar (1147–1216), the third of the five Sakya forefathers and teacher of Sakya Paṇḍita; he translated and compiled a collection of 245 sādhanas in the Tengyur under the title Ocean of Sādhanas (sgrubs thabs rgya mtsho).

en: Acceptance of phenomena concurring with reality
comment_en: A particular realization attained by a bodhisattva on the sixth bodhisattva level. This realization arises as a result of analysis of the essential nature of phenomena (dharmas).

One of the Five Excellent Companions, with whom Siddhārtha Gautama practiced asceticism near the Nairañjanā River and later heard the Buddha first teach the Four Noble Truths at the Deer Park in Sarnath. He was renowned for his pure conduct and holy demeanor so Buddha sent him to attract Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana to the order.

The son of one of the seven brahmins who predicted that Śākyamuni would become a great king. He was one of the five companions with Śākyamuni in the beginning of his spiritual path, abandoning him when he gave up asceticism, but then becoming one of his first five pupils after his buddhahood. He was the last of the five to attain the realization of a “stream entrant” and became an arhat on hearing the Sūtra on the Characteristics of Selflessness (An­ātma­lakṣaṇa­sūtra), which was not translated into Tibetan. Aśvajit was the one who converted Śariputra and Maudgalyāyana into becoming followers of the Buddha.
One of the five ascetics, the companions of the Buddha during his early practice of austerities.
One of the five ascetics who became the first disciples of the Buddha.
One of the first five disciples of the Buddha.
A disciple of the Buddha. Before the Buddha’s awakening, Aśvajit was one of the five ascetics with whom he practiced.
A sage.

A great submarine fire in the far south-east of the ocean, which is the fire that will ultimately burn up the world. Also regarded as the entrance to the hells.

A bodhisattva in the distant past, whose name has been translated to mean “Constantly Ridiculed” (sadā-pari­bhūta) in Tibetan and by Burnouf from the Sanskrit. The Chinese translation and Kern from the Sanskrit translate it as “Never Ridiculed” (sadā-apari­bhūta). The difference results from how the compound is broken apart. It is the Chinese and Kern version that better fits the context.

The word vajra refers to the “thunderbolt,” the indestructible and irresistible weapon that first appears in Indian literature in the hand of the Vedic deity Indra. As a symbol of indestructibility and great power it is used in the Kāraṇḍavyūha to describe the qualities of the maṇi mantra.
An impenetrable substance, used both as a reference to diamond and in particular to the thunderbolt held by the god Indra; also denotes indestructibility.

The term stands for indestructibility and perfect stability. According to Indian mythology, the vajra is the god Indra’s weapon, which made him invincible. According to the Purāṇas, the vajra was made of the bones of the sage Dadhichi, who gave up his life, so that the gods could defeat the asuras.

The term stands for indestructibility and perfect stability. According to Indian mythology, the vajra is the all-powerful god Indra’s weapon, likened to a thunderbolt, which made him invincible. It also relates to the diamond which is the hardest physical material.
The term can refer to both a diamond and a thunderbolt.

The term stands for indestructibility and perfect stability. According to Indian mythology, the vajra is the all-powerful god Indra’s weapon, likened to a thunderbolt, which made him invincible. It also relates to the diamond which is the hardest physical material.
Diamond; thunderbolt; scepter used in tantric rituals; non-duality; male sexual organ.
A ritual sceptre; thunderbot; a diamond; a general term denoting an indestructible non-dual state.

The word vajra refers to the “thunderbolt,” the indestructible and irresistible weapon that first appears in Indian literature in the hand of the Vedic deity Indra. According to context it may also mean “diamond.”

The word vajra refers to the “thunderbolt,” the indestructible and irresistible weapon that first appears in Indian literature in the hand of the Vedic deity Indra. The word vajra is also used for “diamond.”

The seat upon which a full realization of a buddha is attained. This attainment is one of the twelve great deeds of a tathāgata.

Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.

These are: emptiness as a gateway to liberation, absence of marks of all phenomena as a gateway to liberation, and absence of wishes as a gateway to liberation. Among them, emptiness is characterized as the absence of inherent existence, absence of marks as the absence of mental images, and absence of wishes as the absence of hopes and fears.
Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.

As one of the four mahārājas, he is the lord of the northern region of the world and the northern continent, though in early Buddhism he is the lord of the far north of India and beyond. He is also the lord of the yakṣas and a lord of wealth.

As one of the four mahārājas, he is the lord of the northern region of the world and the northern continent, though in early Buddhism he is the lord of the far north of India and beyond. He is also the lord of the yakṣas and a lord of wealth.
One of the Four Great Kings; a god of wealth.
One of the Four Great Kings and god of wealth.
One of the Four Great Kings, or guardians of the world, he presides over the northern quarter and rules over the yakṣas that live there. He is also known as Kubera.
One of the four great kings, also known as Kubera.
Literally, “Child of He who has Heard a Lot.” Name of one of the four great kings who rule over the four directions in the desire realm.
A god of wealth. One of the four great kings, protector of the cardinal direction to the north of Mount Meru. Also called “Kubera.” Not to be confused with King Vaiśravaṇa.
King of an unspecified land during the reign of King Maitrībala in Vārāṇasī. Not to be confused with great king Vaiśravaṇa.
One of the four great guardian kings, he presides over the northern quarter and rules over the yakṣas. He is also known as Kubera.

The “Son of Viśrava (Completely Renowned),” guardian of the northern direction. He and his father are both also referred to as Kubera, and he is also known as Jambhala. He rules over spirits called guhyakas (literally “secret/hidden ones”), described in various capacities, giving rise to his epithet Guhyakādhipati, “Lord of the Guhyakas.”
One of the “four great kings, guardians of the world,” he is held to dwell in the north, presiding over the yakṣa spirits that live there.
One of the Four Great Kings, he presides over the northern quarter and rules over the yakṣas. He is also known as Kubera.
One of the four great guardian kings, he presides over the northern direction and rules over the yakṣas.

A yakṣa.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Vaiśravaṇa guards the northern quarter. Also known as Kubera.
Another name of Kubera.
Another name for Kubera, king of the yakṣas. Among the four great kings who preside over the directions, Vaiśravaṇa is the king in the north.

In early Buddhism the first of seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas—Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhuk—appeared in a kalpa earlier than our Bhadra kalpa, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha.

In early Buddhism, the first of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas —Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhu—are in an earlier eon than the Bhadraka eon, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha.

In early Buddhism, the first of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The first three buddhas —Vipaśyin, Śikhin, and Viśvabhu—are in an earlier eon than the Bhadraka eon, and therefore Śākyamuni is more commonly referred to as the fourth buddha.

comment_en: Fifth of the five definitive aggregates.
Fifth of the five pure aggregates.

The eight aspects of liberation ensue: (1) when corporeal beings observe physical forms [in order to compose the mind]; (2) when formless beings endowed with internal perception observe external physical forms; (3) when beings are inclined toward pleasant states; (4) when one achieves and abides in the sense field of infinite space, thinking, ‘Space is infinite.’ (5) The fifth ensues when one achieves and abides in the sense field of infinite consciousness, thinking, ‘Consciousness is infinite.’ (6) The sixth is when one achieves and abides in the sense field of nothing-at-all, thinking, ‘There is nothing at all.’ (7) The seventh is when one achieves and abides in the sense field of neither perception nor non-perception. (8) The eighth is when one achieves and abides in the cessation of all perceptions and feelings. For a more complete description, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-176.

The eight aspects of liberation ensue: (1) when corporeal beings observe physical forms [in order to compose the mind]; (2) when formless beings endowed with internal perception observe external physical forms; (3) when beings are inclined toward pleasant states; (4) when one achieves and abides in the sense field of infinite space, thinking, ‘Space is infinite.’ (5) The fifth ensues when one achieves and abides in the sense field of infinite consciousness, thinking, ‘Consciousness is infinite.’ (6) The sixth is when one achieves and abides in the sense field of nothing-at-all, thinking, ‘There is nothing at all.’ (7) The seventh is when one achieves and abides in the sense field of neither perception nor non-perception. (8) The eighth is when one achieves and abides in the cessation of all perceptions and feelings.

term: རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ ཐར་པ་ བསམ་ གྱིས་ མི་ ཁྱབ་པ་ ལ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ ཞུགས་པ
རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ ཐར་པ་ བསམ་ གྱིས་ མི་ ཁྱབ་པ
comment_en: Inconceivable liberation of the bodhisattvas, a name of the Avataṃsaka, and a subtitle of the Vimala­kīrti­nirdeśa.
A bodhisattva.

term: རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ ཐར་པ་ སྒྲིབ་པ་ མེད་པ་ ལ་ སངས་རྒྱས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ རོལ་པ
comment_en: The name of an absorption.

Eight such accomplishments are traditionally enumerated: the liberation of form observing form, the liberation of the formless observing form, the liberation of observing beauty, the liberation of infinite space, the liberation of infinite consciousness, the liberation of nothing whatsoever, the liberation of neither presence nor absence of perception, and the liberation of cessation. (Note that “liberation” has also been used to render rnam par grol ba).
See Hayal 1978: 229.
See “eight aspects of liberation.”

The eight kinds of liberation refer to eight meditative states: (1) the perception of material form by one who has form; (2) the perception of material form by one without form; (3) the beautiful; (4) infinite space; (5) infinite consciousness; (6) nothingness; (7) neither perception nor absence of perception; and (8) the cessation of perception and feeling.

In certain contexts this is a term for a method for attaining liberation. There is a traditional list of eight: liberation through (1) seeing that which has form as form (perceiving dependent origination, etc.), (2) seeing the formless as form (perceiving emptiness, etc., as dependent origination), (3) beauty (perceiving emptiness as beautiful), (4) the formless meditation of infinite space, (5) the formless meditation of infinite consciousness, (6) the formless meditation of nothingness, (7) the formless meditation of neither perception nor nonperception, and (8) cessation.
There are three doors to liberation: emptiness, the absence of characteristics, and the absence of aspiration.
The state of freedom from suffering and saṃsāra that is the goal of the Buddhist path.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
See “three liberations.”
Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.
Emptiness, absence of marks, and wishlessness.
Absence of marks, absence of wishes, and emptiness.
Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.

en: Signlessness as a gateway to liberation
comment_en: Second of the three gateways to liberation.

en: Emptiness as a gateway to liberation
comment_en: First of the three gateways to liberation.

en: Aspirationlessness as a gateway to liberation
comment_en: Third of the three gateways to liberation.

There are three, namely emptiness as a gateway to liberation, signlessness as a gateway to liberation, and aspirationlessness as a gateway to liberation. Among them, emptiness is characterized as the absence of inherent existence, signlessness as the absence of mental images, and aspirationlessness as the absence of hopes and fears.
Emptiness, absence of attributes, and absence of aspiration.

There are three, namely emptiness as a gateway to liberation, signlessness as a gateway to liberation, and aspirationlessness as a gateway to liberation. Among them, emptiness is characterized as the absence of inherent existence, signlessness as the absence of mental images, and aspirationlessness as the absence of hopes and fears.
Three qualities related to ultimate reality: emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness. In this sūtra, alse referred to as the three liberations.
There are three doors to liberation: emptiness, featurelessness, and aspirationlessness.
A set of three points associated with the nature of reality that when contemplated and integrated lead to liberation. The three are emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.
A buddha realm.

“The Illuminator” is in this sūtra an epithet for the Buddha Śākyamuni, who appears in millions of places simultaneously. This is also the name of the principal buddha in the Caryā and Yoga tantras.

“The Illuminator.” Used in this sūtra as an epithet for the Buddha Śākyamuni, who appears in millions of places simultaneously, or, one could say, the buddha who emanates millions of buddhas including Śākyamuni. This is also the name for the principal buddha in the Caryā and Yoga tantras. In this sūtra it is also the name of a buddha that Muktaka sees in a distant realm, and also the name of a buddha in the distant past that Āśā was a student of in a previous life. In chapter 29 the layman Veṣṭhila refers to Vairocana as the principal example of present buddhas, presumably referring to Śākyamuni.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight tathāgatas; one of the five buddhas (who preside over the five buddha families).

A kettledrum with ends played horizontally. Unlike the mṛdaṅga, one half of the drum is wider than the other. Another description says that the heads of the drum are smaller than those of the mṛdaṅga.
One of the goddesses in the maṇḍala of Vajrasattva.

A kettledrum played horizontally, wider in the middle, with the skin at both ends played with the hands. One drumhead is smaller than the other. It is a South Indian drum, and maintains the rhythm in Karnataka music.

A kettledrum played horizontally, wider in the middle, with the skin at both ends played by the hands. One drumhead is smaller than the other. It is a South Indian drum, and maintains the rhythm in Karnataka music.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
A lotus pond where the nāga king Supratiṣṭhita lives.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
One of the auxiliary charnel grounds.

The four supports for miraculous ability, as enumerated in note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-161, comprise (1) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of resolution with the formative force of exertion, (2) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of perseverance with the formative force of exertion, (3) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of mind with the formative force of exertion, and (4) the support for miraculous ability combining the meditative stability of scrutiny with the formative force of exertion.
Aspiration, diligence, attention, and analysis.
These are (1) single-pointed intention, (2) single-pointed thoughts, (3) single-pointed diligence, and (4) single-pointed investigation.
Part of the thirty-seven aspects of awakening.

The first basis of magical power consists of the energy from the conscious cultivation of concentration of will (chanda­samādhi­prahāṇa­saṃskāra­samanvāgataḥ). The second consists of the energy from the conscious cultivation of concentration of mind (citta‑). The third consists of concentration of effort (vīrya‑). The fourth consists of concentration of analysis (mīmāṃsa‑). These four form a part of the thirty-seven aids to enlightenment.
Concentration based on (1) will, (2) effort, (3) mind, and (4) analysis.
Determination, discernment, diligence, and concentration.
The four are intention (chandas), diligence (vīrya), attention (citta), and discernment (mīmāṃsā).
One-pointed intention, one-pointed thought, one-pointed diligence, and one-pointed investigation.
Intention, diligence, attention, and discernment.
Four types of absorption related to intention, diligence, attention, and analysis as they manifest on the greater path of accumulation.
Four types of absorption related to intention, diligence, attention, and analysis, respectively.
See “four bases of supernatural power.”
The four supports for supernatural abilities: determination, discernment, diligence, and meditative concentration.
Determination, discernment, diligence, and concentration.
Eagerness, vigor, thought, and examination.
Determination, discernment, diligence, and meditative concentration.
Determination, discernment, diligence, and absorption. These are among the thirty-seven factors of awakening.
Determination, discernment, diligence, and concentration. These four are part of the thirty-seven factors of awakening.
Four qualities belonging to the thirty-seven aids to awakening, these are concentration based on (1) intention, (2) diligence, (3) attention, and (4) analysis.
Four types of absorption related respectively to intention, diligence, attention, and analysis.

The four bases of magical power (Skt. ṛddhipāda, Tib. rdzu ’phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi) are: (1) concentration through will (Skt. chanda, Tib. ’dun pa); (2) concentration through vigor (Skt. vīrya, Tib. brtson ’grus); (3) concentration through the mind (Skt. citta, Tib. bsam pa); (4) concentration through investigation (Skt. mīmāṃsā, Tib. dpyod pa).
Determination, discernment, diligence, and meditative concentration.
One of the kinnara kings.
The ability to make manifest miraculous displays evident to ordinary beings.
See “bases of miraculous power.”
One of the five supernormal knowledges.

The supernatural powers of a śrāvaka correspond to the first abhijnā: “Being one he becomes many, being many he becomes one; he becomes visible, invisible; goes through walls, ramparts and mountains without being impeded, just as through air; he immerses himself in the earth and emerges from it as if in water; he goes on water without breaking through it, as if on [solid] earth; he travels through the air crosslegged like a winged bird; he takes in his hands and touches the moon and the sun, those two wonderful, mighty beings, and with his body he extends his power as far as the Brahma world” (Lamotte 2003: 20). The great supernatural powers (mahāṛddhi) of bodhisattvas are: “causing trembling, blazing, illuminating, rendering invisible, transforming, coming and going across obstacles, reducing or enlarging worlds, inserting any matter into one’s own body, assuming the aspects of those one frequents, appearing and disappearing, submitting everyone to one’s will, dominating the supernormal power of others, giving intellectual clarity to those who lack it, giving mindfulness, bestowing happiness, and finally, emitting beneficial rays.” (Lamotte 2003: 30).
The ability to make manifest miraculous displays evident to ordinary beings.
One of the four garuḍa kings, present at the teaching of the sūtra.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
An abbreviation of Pūraṇa Kāśyapa.
Extremist teacher at the time of the Buddha

A certain brahmin, child of wealthy householders in Śrāvastī, who became an attendant of Venerable Aniruddha before returning home at his parents’ request and manifesting arhatship. Appears in the Story of Pūraṇa.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
One of the eight bhūta kings.

In chapter 29 it is the name of the sixth buddha in a list that begins with Kanaka­muni. In chapter 44 it is the name of a future buddha in this kalpa. Mahāvyutpatti and other sūtras translate puṣya as rgyal.

The first of the four ages of human life in Jambudvīpa. Humans in this age enjoy good qualities such as long lifespans free from disease (see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-068-021.html#UT22084-068-021-8228). Over the course of the four ages humans will lose a quarter of these qualities between each age.
The most auspicious in the cycle of four eons.
A mountain in Godānīya.
(1) A mountain in the sea south of Jambudvīpa. (2) A river on Upward Ocean.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A mountain in Kuru.
One of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples.

One of the Five Excellent Companions, with whom Siddhārtha Gautama practiced asceticism near the Nairañjanā River and who later heard the Buddha first teach the Four Noble Truths at the Deer Park in Sarnath.

One of the five companions of Śākyamuni in asceticism and later one of his first five pupils, attaining the state of a stream entrant. After the Buddha’s death he is said to have headed the great council of ten thousand that established a canon of the Buddha’s teachings (while Kāśyapa was the head of a smaller council elsewhere who did the same).

The father of the wife of a Vārāṇasī merchant in The Hundred Deeds. Not to be confused with the Vāṣpa who was among the group of five monks (bhadravargīya) that received the Buddha’s teaching on the four noble truths.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
(1) An ocean far off the coast of Jambudvīpa (rlabs chen po). (2) A river in the south of Jambudvīpa (rlabs chen).
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A bodhisattva.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks (rlabs rab tu ’jug pa). (2) A river to the south of Jambudvīpa (rlabs ldan). (3) A river on Saṅkāśa (rlabs ’byung ba).
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
The wind; the god of wind.
The god of wind.
A forest in Living on the Peak.
The seventy-seventh buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Anilavegaśirī.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
(1) Alternative name for Enjoying the Wind (rlung gi rgyu). (2) One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife (rlung gi rgyu ba).
The deity of the air and the wind.
One of the eight guardians of the directions, Vāyu guards the northwest quarter.
One of the great mātṛs.
A forest of the asuras.
A river on Saṅkāśa.
A nāga king.
A realm of the vessel-bearer gods. Also known as Movement of Wind.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Another name of Śakuna.
A king in the past. Also referred to as “Mahāśakuni.”
A country corresponding in area to modern Gujarat.
An acceptable form of cloth for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
One of the kings of the nāgas.
A class of ḍākinīs.
One of the seven types of ḍākinīs.
One of the fathers-in-law of Śākyamuni: the father of Gopā, one of Śākyamuni’s wives.

One of the three classes of yakṣas at the base of Sumeru, below the paradises of the mahārājas, as part of the lowest class of paradises in the desire realm. Their name means “those who have basins in their hands.” They are said to be at the very base of Sumeru, and worry that the rising ocean is going to flood them. Because they are continually bailing out water with the basins, they are unable to follow the path to enlightenment.

An alternate form of the name Daṇḍapāṇi, a Śākya clan member and the father of Gopā and Yaśodharā. In The Hundred Deeds he is noted as the father of mda’ thogs, rendered here with the potential back-translation Iṣudhara.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva of the southeast.

term: ལག་ ན་ ཕྱག་རྒྱ་ རིན་ཆེན་ གཞོན་ནུ་ -ར་ གྱུར་པ
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Lit. “Jewel Mudrā in Hand.”
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a class of gods, a group of yakṣa associated with the Four Great Kings.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.

In the Kāraṇdavyūha Sūtra he is described in Śākyamuni’s memories as the bodhisattava who questions Buddha Vipaśyin. He is the principal bodhisattva being addressed by Śākyamuni in chapter 35 of the Avatamsaka Sūtra. In the early tantras he is one of the sixteen bodhisattvas in the dharmadhātu mandala. In the higher tantras he is associated with the Ratna family of Buddha Ratnasambhava.

In the Kāraṇḍavyūha he is, as well as being listed as present at Buddha Śākyamuni’s teachings, the one who is described in Śākyamuni’s memories as the bodhisattva who questions Buddha Vipaśyin. He is the principal bodhisattva being addressed by Śākyamuni in chapter 35 of the Avatamsaka Sūtra. In the early tantras he is one of the sixteen bodhisattvas in the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. In the higher tantras he is associated with the ratna family of Buddha Ratnasambhava.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva from Displaying Leonine Power’s buddha realm.
One of the earliest bodhisattvas of Mahāyāna Buddhism, representing the skillful ability of the awakened state.
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of power.
A yakṣa.
A leader of the yakṣas.
A bodhisattva.

He first appears in Buddhist literature as the yakṣa bodyguard of the Buddha, ready at times to shatter a person’s head into a hundred pieces with his vajra if they speak inappropriately to the Buddha. His name means that he wields a vajra. His identity as a bodhisattva did not take place until the rise of the Mantrayāna.
These vajra wielders are like the Vajrapāṇi who was the yakṣa that acted as the Buddha’s bodyguard. In the Mantrayāna there appeared the bodhisattva named Vajrapāṇi.

In the sūtra tradition, Vajrapāṇi was a yakṣa who acted as the Buddha Śākyamuni’s bodyguard. Also identified as being a manifestation of Śakra and could appear as a number of vajrapāṇis to guard the Buddha. With the advent of the Mantrayāna he is a bodhisattva. Also a euphemism for Indra or a group of vajra-wielding deities in Indra’s realm.
An important bodhisattva who manifests in a terrific form to protect Dharma practitioners.
One of the most popular bodhisattvas in the Mahāyāna Buddhist pantheon.
‟Vajra in Hand,” the deity who teaches the Bhūta­ḍāmara Tantra; in the first half of this text he is referred to primarily as Vajradhara.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A head merchant’s son in Dhanyākara.
A great bodhisattva.
Hand (body part); cubit (unit of length); the eleventh (sometimes thirteenth) lunar asterism.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; one of the kings of asuras.
Synonym for Subāhu, translated as if it was Subāhu into Tibetan.
A principal bodhisattva in the Mahāyāna sūtras.
A merchant.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; an ancient king, contemporary of the Buddha.
One of the first to join the Buddha’s order of monks. He followed his friend Yaśas into the Buddhist order.
A bodhisattva, the protagonist of this text.
A royal elephant belonging to the stables of King Bimbisāra.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.

en: Massaged and Touched with the Palm of the Hand
comment_en: A river in the realm of the gods in Dwelling on Summits within the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A son of King Ikṣuvāku.
The island presently called Sri Lanka, it was known as Ceylon while it was a British colony.

term: ལང་ཀ་ -འི་ གྲོང་ཁྱེར་ ན་ ངེས་པར་ གནས་པ་ -འི་ སྲིན་པོ
comment_en: An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Unidentified; the Tibetan translation could suggest the island of Langkawi. The Sanskrit text may be corrupt.
A sea between Videha and Jambudvīpa
One of the two pīlavas.
A mountain.

en: Traveler on the Path of Goodness
comment_en: A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the two chandohas.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
One of the disciples of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Another name for Cūḍapanthaka, a disciple of the Buddha.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
Fourth of the four noble truths.
“Path Bearer.” One of the bodhisattvas in the entourage of the Buddha Śākyamuni when he taught the girl Vimalaśraddhā.
Correct view, intention, speech, actions, livelihood, effort, mindfulness, and concentration. These eight are included in the thirty-seven factors of awakening.
A buddha realm.
Lit. “action seal,” a worldly (human) consort. Also rendered here in Sanskrit as “karmamudrā.”
One of the pīlavas.
One of the five buddha families.

term: ལས་ ཀྱི་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྨིན་པ་ ལས་ བྱུང་བ་ -འི་ བསོད་ནམས་ དང་ དགེ་བ་ -འི་ རྩ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ བསགས་ ཤིང་ སྟོན་པ་ -ར་ བྱེད་པ
en: Accumulation and demonstration of all merit and roots of virtue arisen from ripened action
comment_en: Name of an absorption.

term: ལས་ ཀྱི་ སྒྲུབ་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྦྱོང་ ཞིང་ རེ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡོངས་སུ་ སྐོང་བ
en: Purifying All Karmic Obscurations and Fulfilling All Hopes
comment_en: An alternate title for The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Seven Thus-Gone Ones

term: ལས་ ཀྱི་ སྒྲུབ་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྦྱོང་ ཞིང་ རེ་བ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡོངས་སུ་ སྐོང་བ
en: Purifying All Karmic Obscurations and Fulfilling All Hopes
comment_en: An alternate title for The Detailed Account of the Previous Aspirations of the Thus-Gone Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha.
A ruler of the Heaven Free from Strife.
A god.

term: ལས་ དང་པོ་པ་ -འི་ བྱང་ཆུབ་ སེམས་དཔའ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གཞག་པ

comment_en: A mountain range surrounding the hell of Embers Within.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

Literally “maker of sundry things,” Viśvakarma is the architect of the gods. He was an important deity in early Hinduism. In the Ṛg Veda, he is regarded as the personification of ultimate reality, the abstract creative power inherent in deities and in living and nonliving beings in this universe.

Literally “maker of sundry things,” Viśvakarma is the architect of the gods. He was an important deity in the Vedic tradition. In the Ṛg Veda, he is regarded as the personification of ultimate reality, the abstract creative power inherent in deities, living, and nonliving being in this universe.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The impact of past actions in the present and future. Also rendered here as “karma.”
Activity, action, or karma (karmic accumulation).
Any act or deed done with body, speech, or mind. Also translated here as “the potential of their past actions.”
Any volitional act, whether of body, speech, or mind. Also rendered here as “act,” “karma,” and “deed.”

A ritual activity (such as pacifying, nourishing, etc.). This term is also translated in other instances as “rite,” “karma,” “karman,” or “karmic accumulation.” In the latter three cases the term refers to karmic accumulation, positive or negative, that will produce results in the future, unless it is purified.

Generally meaning “work,” or “action,” it is an important concept in Buddhist philosophy as the cumulative force of previous actions, which determines present experience and will determine future existences. In this text, it is left untranslated when this specific conception of moral causation is implied.
See “karma.”
Also rendered in this sūtra as “karma.”
The name of a people that inhabited the Licchavi republican state located in present-day north India.
Name of the tribe and republican city-state whose capital was Vaiśālī.
The ancient republican state of the Licchavi people. Its capital was Vaiśālī.
A tribe based in Vaiśālī, part of the Vṛji confederacy.
One of the great Indian clans during the time of the Buddha, their home was Vaiśālī.

An ancient kingdom, located on the southern branch of the Silk Route that passed through the Tarim Basin. The kingdom, which was an important oasis and center for trade, existed during the first millennium ce.
Name of the tribe and republican city-state whose capital was Vaiśālī, where Vimalakīrti lived, and the main events of this sūtra take place.
An ancient republican state, located in northern India.
A tribe or clan based in Vaiśālī.
A clan and a dynasty of kings contemporary with the Buddha; also the name of a Nepalese dynasty ca. fifth to eighth centuries ce.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A householder.
See “Meṣa.”
Aries (zodiac sign and constellation).

The Mūlasarvāstivādin tradition grouped the Buddha’s early sūtra discourses into four divisions, or Āgama (Tib. mdo sde’i lung sde bzhi): the Dīrghāgama (Tib. lung ring po), the Madhyamāgama (Tib. lung bar ma), the Ekottarikāgama (Tib. lung gcig las ’phros pa), and the Saṃyuktāgama(Tib. lung dag ldan /yang dar par ldan pa’i lung). They are more familiar to many English-speaking Buddhists through the translations of their Pali correlates: the Dīgha Nikāya, Majjhima Nikāya, Aṅguttara Nikāya, and the Samyutta Nikāya, for which see the Wisdom Publications titles: The Long Discourses of the Buddha, The Middle-Length Discourses of the Buddha, The Numerical Discourses of the Buddha, and The Connected Discourses of the Buddha, respectively.
See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-001.html#UT22084-001-001-1639.

en: King Who Holds Great Meru’s Peak
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
The garden where the Buddha was born.
The place where the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The birth place of the Bodhisattva, located in southern Nepal.
The place where the Buddha was born, located in what is now Southern Nepal.

term: ལུས་ ཀྱི་ མདོག་ བཟང་ ཞིང་ ཆེ་བ
comment_en: A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

term: ལུས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་ཟེར་ ཐོགས་པ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva in a northwestern realm. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-1030.
Name of the 109th meditative stability.
A god of wealth, sometimes (as in the Ratnaketudhāraṇī) identified with Vaiśravaṇa, one of the Four Great Kings.
An epithet for Vaiśravaṇa, the god of wealth.
One of the four great kings, also known as Vaiśravaṇa.
The king of yakṣas and an important wealth deity, he is also one of the four great kings in Buddhist cosmology. In this capacity he is commonly known as Vaiśravaṇa.
The god of wealth and the king of the yakṣas; one of the four great kings of the directions.
Another name for Vaiśravaṇa, the king of the yakṣas.
One of the great kings of the four directions, Kubera guards the northern quarter of the heavens. Also known as Vaiśravaṇa.
The term is used as a reference to the northern direction, which is governed by the deity Kubera.
A god.
The god of wealth.
Epithet of Vaiśravaṇa.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Also rendered in this translation as “embodied being,” and “corporeal being.”

term: ལུས་ཆེན་པོ་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ སྒྲ་ འབྱིན་ འཇིགས་ འཇིགས་ ལྟར་ འདུག་པ
comment_en: A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
One of the garuḍa kings present at the teaching of the sūtra.
A ruler of the garuḍas.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
An upāsikā in Dhanyākara.
A buddha.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
The continent to the east of Mount Sumeru.
The queen of King Bimbisāra of Magadha and the mother of his successor, King Ajātaśatru.
The wife of King Bimbisāra and mother of Ajātaśatru.
A mountain in Videha.
The eastern continent of the human world according to traditional Indian cosmology, characterized as “sublime in physique”
(1) A country. (2) The continent in the east.
A certain brahmin of high caste, father of More Majestic. He heard the Dharma from the Buddha and attained stream entry.

An ancient kingdom whose seat was the city of Mithilā. One of its borders was the Ganges River, and it abutted the kingdoms of Kośala and Kāśi. The name Videha, in ancient Buddhist cosmology, refers to the eastern of the four continents in the cardinal directions.
Alternative name for Copious Parasites in Marrow and Bones.
One of the great mātṛs.
A Tibetan translator.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the past.
A head merchant, the father of a previous life of Gopā.
A queen of King Sarvārthasiddha.
The name of a bodhisattva stage.
The ninth ground of the bodhisattvas.
The ninth bodhisattva level.
The ninth bodhisattva bhūmi.
A great bodhisattva.
The ninth bodhisattva bhūmi.
A thus-gone one of the past.
A mountain between Godānīya and Videha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Sunlight.
The name of an eon (kalpa).
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A monk.

en: Special Intelligence of Excellent Concern and Attention
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bhikṣu who was a pupil of Śāriputra.

Sudatta was a great lay patron of the Buddha and philanthropist of Śrāvastī, and is more commonly called Anāthapiṇḍada (mgon med zas sbyin); he known as “the foremost of donors” (Pāli; aggo dāyakānaṃ).
“Well arisen.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past.
A mountain between Kuru and Godānīya.
A south Indian king contemporary with Mahendra.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Departed to a Lotus. Likely the same as the world system Joyful Entrance.
One of the kings of the rākṣasas.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

en: Majestic King with the Elegant Peaceful Voice
comment_en: A buddha who lives to the east of this world.
A brahmin statesman.
Name of Buddha Śākyamuni in a past life, when he was a merchant practicing bodhisattva conduct.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A buddha.
The name of Surata's buddhafield after he becomes awakened.
A future buddha realm where Vaiśravaṇa will awaken.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
An ancient king of Kāmarūpa. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-088-038.html#UT22084-088-038-7458.
An ascetic statesman.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Susaṃbhava­viyūha .
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
(1) King who appears during the elephant Airāvaṇa’s previous life as a brahmin (legs mthong). (2) The city of Śakra (legs mthong and lta na sdug).
A future buddha. Also the name of the son of a householder, see “Sudarśana.”
A wheel-turning king who was the Buddha in a former life.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha realm.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

A pupil of the Buddha, originally a destitute beggar, who, in particular, accidentally drank alcohol offered by villagers after he had tamed a nāga to end a drought. This resulted in the Buddha’s adding abstention from alcohol as part of the monastic rules.

Svāgata was a pupil of the Buddha, originally a destitute beggar, who, in particular, accidentally drank alcohol offered by villagers after he had tamed a nāga to end a drought. This resulted in the Buddha’s adding abstention from alcohol as part of the monastic rules.
A disciple of the Buddha.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there; the city of Indra.
(c. a.d. 400). A major Indian philosopher, a master of the Mādhyamika school of Buddhism, who founded a sub-school known as Svātantrika.
A monk.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

A certain lay vow holder in Śrāvastī. Though in the Lalitavistara Sūtra and elsewhere a young woman named Sujātā is among those said to have given food to Gautama prior to his enlightenment, in this text and in the Divyāvadāna that deed is credited to Nandā and Nandabalā.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A great bodhisattva.
A householder.
A self-awakened one.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

en: Liberated their minds from the defilements, without further appropriation
comment_en: To achieve liberation without needing to take further rebirth, or appropriation of the five aggregates, in saṃsāra.
Ninth of the twelve links of dependent origination.
The ninth link of dependent arising.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A village.
A river on Forest Garlands.

term: ལོ་མ་ -འི་ མཚམས་ ནས་ དུས་གསུམ་ གྱི་ དེ་བཞིན་ གཤེགས་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ ཡུལ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྟོན་པ་ -འི་ འོད་གཟེར་ གྱི་ སྤྲིན་ གྱི་ རྒྱན
comment_en: The name of a magical lotus in the distant past; the name means “An Array of the Clouds of the Light Rays from between the Petals That Reveal the Range of All the Tathāgatas of the Three Times.”
A town in Videha.
A river in India.
Fourth of the seven buddhas of the past, and first in this kalpa.

en: Bearer of the Armor against Wrongdoing
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
“Destroyer of Saṃsāra.”

The fourth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. Also the first of the buddhas in this eon, with Śākyamuni as the fourth. The Tibetan translation in the Kāraṇḍavyūha is “elimination of incorrect faith,” and this is found in the Mahāvyutpatti, whereas the later standard Tibetan translation is ’khor ba ’jig or “destruction of saṃsara.” It is a Sanskritization of the middle-Indic name Kakusaṃdha. Kaku may mean summit and saṃdha is the inner or hidden meaning.
A buddha in the past.
The fourth of the “seven previous buddhas.”
The fourth of the seven tathāgatas/buddhas. Identified in other texts as the first buddha to appear in the present eon.

The first of the buddhas in this kalpa, with Śākyamuni as the fourth. Also listed as the fourth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. The Tibetan translation in this sūtra and in others, such as the Kāraṇḍa­vyūha Sūtra ( The Basket’s Display , Toh 116), means “elimination of incorrect faith.” This version is also found in the Mahāvyutpatti, whereas the later standard Tibetan translation is ’khor ba ’jig (“destruction of saṃsāra”). Krakucchanda is a Sanskritization of the Middle-Indic name Kakusaṃdha. Kaku may mean “summit,” and saṃdha is “inner meaning” or “hidden meaning.”

The fourth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. Also, the first of the buddhas in this Bhadraka eon, with Śākyamuni as the fourth. The name is a Sanskritization of the Middle Indic name Kakusaṃdha, and is therefore an example of hybrid Sanskrit. It is also found in a semi-Sanskritized form: Krakutsanda. The ninth-century Mahāvyutpatti Sanskrit-Tibetan dictionary lists Kakutsunda as the Sanskrit for ’khor ba ’jig, but has a separate entry log par dad sel for Krakucchanda, though later, as in this sūtra, Krakucchanda became translated as ’khor ba ’jig.

The fourth of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh. Also, the first of the buddhas in this Bhadraka eon, with Śākyamuni as the fourth. The name is a Sanskritization of the Middle Indic name Kakusaṃdha, and is therefore an example of hybrid Sanskrit. It is also found in a semi-Sanskritized form: Krakutsanda. The ninth-century Mahāvyutpatti Sanskrit-Tibetan dictionary lists Kakutsunda as the Sanskrit for ’khor ba ’jig, but has a separate entry log par dad sel for Krakucchanda, though later, as in this sūtra, Krakucchanda became translated as ’khor ba ’jig.
A former buddha.
A place in Ultimate Torment.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Another name of Gaṇeśa.
A mountain on Videha.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
(1) A lake on Equal Peaks (longs spyod du gyur ba). (2) Refers to Dwelling in Enjoyment (dga’ ba).
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.

The buddha body of perfect resource denotes the luminous, immaterial, and unimpeded reflection-like forms of enlightened mind, which become spontaneously present and naturally manifest to tenth level bodhisattvas.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A nāga realm.
(1) Another name of Prince Water Born. (2) A non-Buddhist ascetic teacher.
A general of yakṣas.
Name of a nāga king.

en: Feasts on the fifth, the eighth, the fourteenth, or the full moon
comment_en: Feasts falling on these days of the lunar month are considered an acceptable form of food for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Traditionally the head of the yakṣa army serving Vaiśravaṇa, and the consort of Hariti.
A leader of the yakṣas.
A yakṣa.
Name of a yakṣa general in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
A mountain off Videha.

term: ལྕགས་ ཀྱི་ ཕྱེ་མ་ མེ་མདག་ གི་ ར་བ
en: Heap of Live Coals of Iron-dust
comment_en: One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell. Alternatively referred to as Metallic Fire (lcags kyi me).
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell. Alternatively referred to as Heap of Live Coals of Iron-dust (lcags kyi phye ma me ma dag gi ra ba).
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
A goddess.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
