en: Excruciating Splitting and Cutting by Means of a Black Iron Thread
comment_en: One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
The precise identity of this metal or metal compound is currently unclear. The Tibetan translation of the term means “high-quality metal.”
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
The world of yakṣas ruled over by Kubera.
The realm of Kubera.

A thunderbolt or flash of lightning.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Forty-ninth of the eighty minor marks.
Twenty-fifth of the thirty-two major marks.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the kinnara kings.
One of the kinnara kings.
One of the kinnara kings.
One of the four kings of the kinnaras. He is present at the teaching of the sūtra.
King of the kinnaras.
A kinnara king.
A king of the kinnaras.
One of the kinnara kings.
A prince; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A forest in Moving in Mixed Environments.

The forest outside of Rājagṛha where King Bimbisāra, along with 80,000 gods and many hundreds of thousands of Magadhan brahmins and householders, were converted to Buddhism.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
An absorption.
A deity personifying the true nature of the element of earth; a goddess invoked to cause downfall.
Twenty-sixth of the eighty minor marks.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK; a legendary king before the time of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A lotus pool in Lateral.
A class of asuras.
A disciple of the Buddha.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
Ordained by the Buddha in Vārāṇasī shortly after the Buddha’s enlightenment; brother of Nadī Kāśyapa.
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.

Known in Pali as Uruvela, Uruvilvā is another name for Gayā. The Buddha inspired a group of one thousand dreadlocked ascetics to join his order of monks and ordained them there. Also spelled Urubilvā.
A river on the banks of which the Buddha engaged in ascetic practice before his awakening.
Not far from Bodhimaṇḍa, it was the place where a thousand long-haired ascetics went forth in the Buddha’s following, among them Uruvilvā Kāśyapa.
A mountain off Videha.
A class of semidivine beings that have the form of a large serpent.
Demons shaped like enormous serpents.
A class of subterranean geomantic spirits whose movement through the seasons and months of the year is deemed significant for construction projects.
A serpent deity that inhabits specific localities.
A class of semi-divine being that takes the form of a large serpent.
A serpent deity that inhabits specific localities.
A type of nonhuman being with the form of an enormous serpent.
A serpent deity that inhabits specific localities.
Literally “large serpent.” A subterranean semi-divine being that takes the form of a large serpent, sometimes with a human torso and head.
A class of serpentine nonhuman beings.

Literally “large serpent.” A semidivine being that takes the form of a large serpent, sometimes with a human torso and head. They are a class of subterranean geomantic spirits whose movement through the seasons and months of the year is deemed significant for construction projects.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas in the maṇḍala of Mañjuśrī (it is not clear if upāriṣṭa here is a variant spelling of upariṣṭa, i.e. one of the eight chief pratyeka­buddhas).
A south Indian king contemporary with Mahendra.
Speech with undisclosed meaning; speech that is indirect and therefore requires further interpretation.
Speech that is allusive, indirect, or contains undisclosed meaning and therefore requires further interpretation.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A yakṣa, attendant of King Māndhātṛ.
In former times, the king of the city of Mithilā. His two chief ministers were Nanda and Upananda. In other contexts, sometimes an epithet of the god Śiva, see “Mahā­deva.”

An epithet of the god Śiva. Though not in this text, in other texts this term may also appear as an epithet of the Buddha. Alternatively a certain king of Mithilā who lived before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni, see “Mahā­deva (the king).”
‟Great God,” one of the epithets of Śiva.
A certain mango grove in the country of Mithilā where the Buddha once stayed.
A lake on Equal Peaks.

comment_en: Another name for Śakra, aka Indra.
A buddha in the distant past in chapter 36, and another buddha in the distant past in chapter 41.
The kalyāṇamitra of chapter 45, a goddess of the Trāyastriṃśa paradise.

A bodhisattva who appears in The Teaching by the Child Inconceivable Radiance.

comment_en: A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods) who are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
The asuras are the enemies of the devas, fighting with them for supremacy.
The asuras are the enemies of the devas, fighting with them for supremacy.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods), who are frequently portrayed in Brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

One of the six classes of sentient beings. The asuras are dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility and are incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods. They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical and Buddhist mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

The asuras, sometimes called the demi-gods or titans, are the enemies of the devas, fighting with them for supremacy. They are powerful beings who live around Mount Sumeru, and are usually classified as belonging to the higher realms.

One of the six classes of living beings, sometimes included among the gods and sometimes among the animals. A class of superhuman beings, sometimes misleadingly called demigods, engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility, who are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in a dispute with the gods over the possession of a magical tree.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods) who are frequently portrayed in the Brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
A class of titans or demigods.

Powerful beings who live around Mount Meru and are usually classified as belonging to the higher realms. They are characterized as jealous and ambitious, forever in conflict with the gods.
The traditional adversaries of the gods (devas) who are frequently portrayed in the Brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

One of the six classes of sentient beings according to the Buddhist tradition. The asuras are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility, who are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (deva). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

The asuras, sometimes called the demigods, are the enemies of the gods, fighting with them for supremacy. They are powerful beings who live around Mount Sumeru and are usually classified as belonging to the higher realms.

A class of semidivine beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.

One of the six classes of living beings, sometimes included among the gods and sometimes among the animals, they are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility and are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (devas). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

Also called “antigods” or “titans,” these are a lower type of celestial being who out of jealousy are forever in conflict with the gods. See also “five destinies.”

One of the six classes of sentient beings. The asuras are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility and are described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (deva). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
A demi-god.
A class of demi-gods.
One of the six classes of sentient beings, the asuras are the enemies of the devas, fighting with them for supremacy.

One of the six classes of living beings, sometimes included among the gods and sometimes among the animals. A class of nonhuman beings, sometimes misleadingly called demigods, engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility, who are metaphorically described as being incessantly embroiled in a dispute with the gods over the possession of amrita.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods) who are frequently portrayed in the Brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
A class of long-lived gods or demigods.
A class of long-lived gods or demigods.
A class of celestial beings.
The demigods, traditional adversaries of the devas (gods), who are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
One of the rāśis.

A class of semidivine beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods), who are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

One of the six classes of sentient beings. The asuras are engendered and dominated by envy, ambition, and hostility and are described as being incessantly embroiled in disputes with the gods (deva). They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

They are frequently portrayed in brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.

A class of nonhuman beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.

The asuras, sometimes called the demigods or titans, are the enemies of the devas, fighting with them for supremacy. They are powerful beings who live around Mount Sumeru and are usually classified as belonging to the higher realms.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods) who are frequently portrayed in the Brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
The traditional adversaries of the devas (gods) who are frequently portrayed in the brahmanical mythology as having a disruptive effect on cosmological and social harmony.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A Śākya village once ruled by Śākya Suprabuddha.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Delta Scorpii in the occidental tradition.
The name of a nakṣatra.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs; also, one of the group of seven yakṣiṇīs.
The chief queen of the king Utpalavaktra.
A nāga king.

A class of semidivine beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.
A class of celestial beings.
A class of divine beings ranking below gods (deva), known for their jealous and warlike disposition.
A class of demons.
“Glorious Great Goddess.” This is also a widespread name in Hindu contexts; it is, for example, an epithet of Śiva’s consort.
Another name of Umā, one of Śiva’s wives.
A female deity in a variant of the maṇḍala of Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The name of a nakṣatra.
The queen who was the mother of Śākyamuni Buddha.
See “Mahā­māyā.”
Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother.
See “Mahā­māyā.”
Buddha’s mother.

Umādevī is also known as Pārvatī. The name is of obscure origin, but can mean “splendor,” “tranquility,” or “light.” She is the consort of Śiva, also known as Maheśvara, and believed to be the rebirth of Sīta, his previous consort.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the eight great bhūtinīs.
‟One Who Captivates the Gods,” One of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha in the distant past.
A Hindu deity.
The names of two buddhas in the distant past. One may have been Devaśrīvara, where the last part of the compound was translated into mchog. BHS: Devaśirigarbha.
Another name of the king identified by Jayaswal as king Skanda (Jayaswal 1934, p. 33).
Sixth of the ten recollections.
A pond in Continuous Movement.

term: ལྷ་རྫས་ ཀྱི་ རྔ་ སྐད་ ཡན་ལག་ ལྔ
comment_en: See “five types of musical instruments.”
A forest on Forest Garlands.

A xylograph Kangyur printed in 1934. Based mainly on the Narthang (snar thang) Kangyur but with some texts following the Degé Kangyur, it is among several Kangyurs of “mixed” lineage, including elements from the Thempangma (them spangs ma) in addition to the predominating Tshalpa (tshal pa) traditions.
A disciple of the Buddha.

The historical Buddha’s cousin, and brother of Ānanda. He became notorious through his schemes to become the Buddha’s successor—to the point of attempting to kill the Buddha—and through the splitting of the Saṅgha.
The Śākyan cousin of the Buddha traditionally depicted as eager for gain and jealous of the Buddha’s fame.

The Buddha’s cousin and fellow Śākya clan member as well as his brother-in-law; brother of Ānanda and Upadhāna. His hostility toward Buddha Śākyamuni is widely recorded in Buddhist literature, and as a result he often represents the paradigm of improper behavior and attitudes toward the Buddha and the Buddhist saṅgha.

A cousin of the Buddha Śākyamuni who broke with him and established his own community. He is portrayed as engendering evil schemes against the Buddha and even succeeding in wounding him. He is usually identified with wicked beings in accounts of previous lifetimes.

One of the five or six classes of living beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in realms higher than that of the human realm within in the world system of desire (kāma­dhātu), and also in the world system of form (rūpa­dhātu).
A being in the paradises from the base of Mount Meru upward. Also can refer to a deity in the human world, or can be used as an honorific form of address for kings and other important personages.
A being in the realms above the human-inhabited world.
A being in the paradises from the base of Mount Meru upward. Also can refer to a deity in the human world.

One of the five or six classes of living beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in realms higher than that of the human realm within in the world system of desire (kāma­dhātu), and also in the world system of form (rūpa­dhātu).
A celestial being from the highest realm (in the sixfold division) of saṃsāra.
See “gods.”

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically influenced by exaltation, frivolousness, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods live in many divine realms within the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.. Also rendered here as “devas.”

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in realms higher than that of the human realm within in the world system of desire (kāma­dhātu), and also in the world system of form (rūpa­dhātu).

According to the Buddhist tradition, one of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. The gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, within in the desire realm (kāma­dhātu), and also in the form realm (rūpa­dhātu) and the formless realm (ārūpya­dhātu).

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the devas are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, in the desire realm, in the form realm, and in the formless realm.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, within in the desire realm, in the form realm, and in the formless realm.
One of the six classes of beings.
General term for all sorts of gods and deities.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, in the desire realm, in the form realm, and in the formless realm.
One of the six classes of sentient beings. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms.
Gods; a class of beings in the higher planes of existence in the desire realm, as well as in the form and formless realm.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically engendered and dominated by exaltation, indulgence, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods are said to exist in many levels of celestial or divine realms, higher than that of the human realm, within in the desire realm, in the form realm, and in the formless realm.

One of the five or six classes of sentient beings, specifically influenced by exaltation, frivolousness, and pride. According to Buddhist cosmology, the gods live in many divine realms within the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.

Cognate with the English term divine. The devas are most generically a class of divine, celestial beings who populate the narratives of Indian mythology. Devas make regular appearances in Buddhist literature at the head of the assemblies of celestial and supernatural beings who attend the teachings, interact with the Buddha, bodhisattvas, and other spiritual figures, and celebrate the delivery of their sermons. In Buddhist cosmology, the devas are subdivided into numerous classes based on the specific devalokas, the “heavens” in which they reside. Traditionally there are between twenty-six and twenty-eight devalokas, divided between the desire realm (kāmadhātu), form or material realm (rūpadhātu), and formless or immaterial realm (arūpyadhātu). The state of deva is reached either through meritorious acts or the cultivation of subtle meditative states, and is therefore considered a higher mode of rebirth in comparison to rebirth among hell beings, pretas, and animals. Nonetheless, all the devalokas are within the three realms of saṃsāra and therefore transitory. Thus while the devas occupy the highest strata within the scheme of the five or six “destinies” (gati), the realms within saṃsāra where beings take rebirth, their state is still one determined by the fetters (saṃyojana) that bind one to the perpetual cycle of rebirth. Also rendered here as “gods.”
See “god.”
In most cases used to refer to a class of long-lived celestial being, but occasionally appears as an honorific term of address for royalty, similar to “Your Majesty,” here rendered as “Deva.”

A being in the paradises from the base of Mount Meru upward. It can also refer to a deity in the human world and is sometimes (as in the present work) used as a term of endearment for a ruler or leader (translated as “lord”).
A being in the realms above the realm of humans.
A being in the paradises from the base of Mount Meru upward, this can also refer to a deity in the human world.

In Buddhist cosmology, the gods are one of the five or six classes of beings, and are said to populate realms higher than the human realm within the realm of desire (kāma­dhātu), and to exist in the realm of form (rūpa­dhātu) and the formless realm (ārūpyadhātu) as well.

Devas make regular appearances in Buddhist literature at the head of the assemblies of celestial and supernatural beings who attend the teachings, interact with the Buddha, bodhisattvas and other spiritual figures, and celebrate the delivery of their sermons. The deities that dwell in the heavens of the highest realms of cyclic existence.
A class of celestial beings.
One of the rāśis; the Gupta emperor Devagupta II (seventh to eighth centuries).

Devas make regular appearances in Buddhist literature at the head of the assemblies of celestial and supernatural beings who attend the teachings, interact with the Buddha, bodhisattvas and other spiritual figures, and celebrate the delivery of their sermons. A forest on Flocking Peacocks.
As defined in the Bodhisattvabhūmi, this is a bodhisattva’s determined, deeply informed enthusiasm for the Buddhist teachings that is grounded in faith and careful study of the Dharma.
A strong sense of determination, often associated with altruism.
A strong sense of determination, often associated with altruism.
A “ruler of the world” who belongs to the class of the māras.

comment_en: The attainment of nirvāṇa without any remainder of the physical and mental aggregates.
An important form of Buddhist meditation focusing on developing insight into the nature of phenomena. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being “tranquility.”
The first of the seven buddhas, with Śākyamuni as the seventh.

The second of the two main branches of Buddhist meditation (along with “peaceful meditation”) aiming at developing insight into the nature of reality.

An important form of Buddhist meditation focusing on developing insight into the nature of phenomena. Often presented as part of a pair of meditation techniques, the other being “tranquility” (śamatha).
The mental factor or power that discerns phenomena and ascertains the true nature of things.

Child of the high brahmin Majestic Body, he visited Lord Buddha to inquire about the proper way to perform the sacrifice, and hearing the Dharma that the Buddha taught in reply he attained stream entry.
A meditation teacher who was one of the Buddha’s teachers before he attained awakening.
Although the spelling Rudraka is attested in the Sanskrit of this sūtra, in most other texts his name is Udraka, or Udraka Rāmaputra (“Udraka the son of Rāma”).
The fourth joy.

Although referred to as the “fourth” in the fourfold division of the joys, the innate joy does not fit into a sequential order in quite the same way as the other three joys. It is first discerned when the supreme joy gives way to the joy of cessation, and is gradually extended through practice until it becomes ever present.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva. Main interlocutor of the king of the kinnaras in the sūtra The Questions of the Kinnara King Druma.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
A forest in Happiness.

“Divine Splendor.” The name of a past kalpa. BHS: Devaśiri.

Another name for Śakra, or Indra, literally “Lord of Devas.”
Another name for Indra, Śakra.

An courtesan in Ratnavyūha.
A god.
A chief god who abides in the pure heavens. In Buddhism, Maheśvara is typically portrayed as mounted on a white bull, showing his close association with the Hindu god Śiva.
A god.

comment_en: A minor mountain on Lofty Peak.
Literally “daughter of a deva.” A female deva.
A god.
Generic term for a class of long-lived celestial beings.
A being of any of the many levels of celestial or divine realms according to Buddhist cosmology.
A common epithet for gods.
The form of Māra who assaulted the Buddha prior to his awakening.
This is the figurative or embodied demon of pleasure.
Second of the five eyes. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1117.
One of the five supernormal knowledges.

One of the six “superknowledges” (q.v.) as well as one of the “five eyes,” this is the supernormal ability to see to an unlimited distance, observe events on other worlds, see through mountains, etc. The five eyes consist of five different faculties of vision: the physical eye (māṃsa­cakṣu), the divine eye (dīvya­cakṣu), the wisdom eye (prajñā­cakṣu), the Dharma-eye (dharma­cakṣu), and the Buddha-eye (buddha­cakṣu).
Superknowledge achieved by the power of meditative absorption.

A cousin of Śākyamuni, who broke with him and established his own community. His tradition was still continuing during the first millennium ce. He is portrayed as engendering evil schemes against the Buddha and even succeeding in wounding him. He is usually identified with wicked beings in accounts of previous lifetimes, but not in The White Lotus of the Good Dharma, where he is a teacher of the Buddha in a previous lifetime, and the Buddha prophesies his future buddhahood.

Early Mahāyāna sūtras identify this as separate from Sumeru, the mountain at the center of the world. This refers to a legendary mountain in such epics as the Mahābhārata, which, while sacred, is not situated in the world’s center. This is presumably identical to the Mount Meru that is the source of one of the two main tributaries of the Ganges and lies within the territory of India.

(The rendering Merugāja is according to Dutt.)
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.

Buddhafield beyond buddhafields as numerous as the sands of thirty-six Ganges rivers, administered by the Buddha Meru­pradīpa­rāja, whence Vimalakīrti obtains the lion-thrones on which he seats his visitors.

term: ལྷུན་པོ་ -འི་ རྩེ་མོ་ -འི་ ཁང་པ་ བརྩེགས་ པའ་ གཟུངས
comment_en: One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva in the Buddha’s retinue.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Meru’s Inner Chamber.”
Name of a tathāgata.
Buddha of the universe Merudhvaja.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the two kings of the country of Pañcāla.
Appears in The Hundred Deeds as the name of a king and a people dwelling in the “barbaric outlying region” south of Jambudvīpa.
An Indian scholar from the eighth century named as one of the translators of this sūtra.
Literally, “the Bull of the Śākyas.” This is similar to Śākyamuni, “the Sage of the Śākyas,” the Śākyas being the Buddha’s clan.
A yakṣa that was the protective deity for the Śākya clan, which was the Buddha’s clan. The Śākyas had a temple devoted to him and he is represented in sculpture as being present at his birth.
An epithet of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The clan into which the Buddha was born.
Name of the tribe dwelling in Northern India in which Gautama, or Śākyamuni, Buddha was born as prince Siddhārtha.
Name of the clan into which the Buddha was born.
Name of the clan into which Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
An epithet of the Buddha.
Streblus asper.
Householder who lived in the past at the time of the buddha King of All Qualities’ Light Rays.
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
One of the great piśācīs.
A female member of a class of nonhuman beings traditionally associated with the wild, remote places of the earth. They are considered particularly violent and known to devour flesh.
One of the great piśācīs.
One of the great piśācīs.
One of the great piśācīs.
Female piśāca.
A female member of a class of semidivine beings traditionally associated with the wild, remote places of the earth. They are considered particularly violent and known to devour flesh.
Female piśāca.
“Demoness of the Ear,” female spirit who reveals hidden facts or the future by whispering them into one’s ear; very likely another name for Śravaṇa­piśācī.

A spirit that haunts the night, feeds on corpses, and is fatal to see. The Tibetan means “flesh eater.” The Sanskrit does not have “eat” as part of the name, but piśa means “flesh.” An alternative etymology is that they are called piśāca because they are yellow in color, from the Sanskrit piśita, meaning “yellow.”
A spirit that haunts the night, feeds on corpses, and is fatal to see.

A flesh-eating demon, or a demon who can possess the body of a human and cause various illnesses or insanity. They are often depicted as red-eyed, dark-skinned, bug-eyed creatures, although they seem to be able to assume many shapes.
A class of flesh-eating spirits.

A flesh-eating demon, or a demon who can possess the body of a human and cause various illnesses or insanity. They are often depicted as red-eyed, dark-skinned, bulging-eyed creatures, although they seem to be able to assume many shapes.
A class of demons. Literally “flesh eaters.”
A type of malevolent ghost, considered to belong to the preta realm. Tibetan translates the term as “flesh-eaters.”
Class of demons; literally “flesh eater.”
A class of flesh-eating demons.
A type of demonic being.
A class of spirits.
A class of semidivine beings traditionally associated with the wild, remote places of the earth. They are considered particularly violent and known to devour flesh.

A spirit that haunts the night, feeds on corpses, and is fatal to see. The Tibetan means “flesh eater.” The Sanskrit does not have “eat” as part of the name, but piśa means “flesh.” An alternative etymology is that they are called piśāca because they are yellow in color, from the Sanskrit piśita, meaning “yellow.”
A class of demonic spirit beings.
A class of flesh-eating demons.
One of the rāśis.
A class of spirits.
A class of flesh-eating demons

A flesh-eating demon, or a demon who can possess the body of a human and cause various illnesses or insanity. They are often depicted as red-eyed, dark-skinned, bulging-eyed creatures, although they seem to be able to assume many shapes.

A flesh-eating demon, or a demon who can possess the body of a human and cause various illnesses or insanity. They are often depicted as red-eyed, dark-skinned, bulging-eyed creatures, although they seem to be able to assume many shapes.
More widely known as Śāriputra—the contracted version of his name—he was one of the Buddha’s foremost hearer disciples. Renowned for unparalleled knowledge of the teachings.
Name of an elder and senior disciple of Buddha Śākyamuni, sometimes contracted as Śāriputra.
Lit. “Son of Śāri,” also known as “Śāriputra,” one of two main male disciples of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.
One of the Buddha’s chief disciples, more commonly known as Śāriputra.
The mother of Śāriputra.
Māṭhara’s daughter and mother of Upatiṣya (aka Śāriputra).

One of the major śrāvaka disciples, paired with Maudgalyāyana, and noted for having been praised by the Buddha as foremost of the wise; hence, the most frequent target for Vimalakīrti’s attacks on the śrāvakas and on the Hinayāna in general. (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-902)

One of the major hearers, paired with Maudgalyāyana, and noted for having been praised by the Buddha as foremost of the wise; hence, the most frequent target for Vimalakīrti’s attacks on the śrāvakas and on the Hinayāna in general. Also known as Śāradvatīputra.
Albizzia lebbeck Benth. (Acacia Sirissa.)
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
See “Śāriputra.”
“The son of Śāri,” the Buddha’s principal pupil, who passed away before the Buddha.
Close disciple of the Buddha.
The wisest of Buddha’s disciples. Śāriputra’s father Tiṣya named him Śāriputra, “Śārikā’s Son,” to honor Śāriputra’s mother Śārikā.
The Buddha’s principal pupil, who passed away before the Buddha. Also called “Śārisuta”, “Tiṣya” and “Upatiṣya.”
Alternative name for Śāriputra.
Śrāvaka arhat, one of the most important followers of the Buddha.
“The son of Śāri.” The Buddha’s principal pupil, who passed away before the Buddha.
Synonym for Śāriputra.
One of the Buddha’s primary śrāvaka followers, known as the compiler of the Abhidharma teachings.
One of the main disciples of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni, known for his pure observance of discipline.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha. (2) A disciple of a buddha in the past. (3) A disciple of a Buddha in the future.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his wisdom.
One of the main disciples (śrāvaka) of the Buddha.

One of the principal hearer disciples of the Buddha, paired with Maudgalyā­yana, he was renowned for his discipline and for having been praised by the Buddha as foremost of the wise. His father, Tiṣya, named him Śāriputra, “Śārikā’s Son,” to honor Śāriputra’s mother Śārikā.
A monk (bhikṣu) and disciple of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.

Along with Maudgalyāyana, Śāriputra was one of the two main disciples of the Buddha. Known as a great arhat, he requested some important teachings such as the Prajnāpāramitā sūtras, and is particularly famous for his discriminating insight (prajñā).
The same as Śāradvatīputra.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.
One of the principal disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure discipline.
One of Buddha’s main disciples.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure observance of discipline.
One of the two chief disciples of the historical Buddha.
Along with Maudgalyāyana, one of Buddha Śākyamuni’s two foremost disciples, known for his erudition. His full given name is Śāriputra Upatiṣya; also rendered here as Upatiṣya.
One of the Buddha’s two principal monastic disciples.
One of the Buddha’s two principal monastic disciples.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure discipline.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight great śrāvakas.
One of the main disciples of the Buddha, known for his wisdom.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha Śākyamuni, known for his insight.
Along with Maudgalyāyana, one of Buddha Śākyamuni’s two main disciples, known as the foremost in insight.
One of the chief disciples of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his wisdom and pure observance of discipline.
Close Śravaka disciple of the Buddha.
One of the closest disciples of the Buddha, known for his pure discipline and, of the disciples, considered foremost in wisdom.
One of the rāśis.
The buddha in the realm of Enduring, who is the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama. He was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan. Also a buddha in the realm of Joy and in the realm of Jñānabala.
Our historical buddha.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama. In The White Lotus of the Good Dharma he is said to be in the northeast of the Sahā universe.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama; he was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
“The sage of the Śākya clan,” an epithet of the Buddha.

An epithet for the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama: he was a muni (“capable one”) from the Śākya clan. Usually counted as the fourth of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama; he was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
(1) The present Buddha. (2) A buddha in the past. (3) A buddha in the future.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha. The buddha of the world Enduring (Sahā).
The “Sage of the Śākyas,” name of the Buddha of our era, who lived c. 563-483 B.C.
The current buddha of this age.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama; he was a muni (sage) from the Śākya clan.

An epithet for the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama: he was a muni (“capable one”) from the Śākya clan. Usually counted as the fourth of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa. He will be followed by Maitreya, the next buddha in this eon.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
Lit. “Sage of the Śākya.” In Great Vehicle literature, this is one of the most common epithets of the historical Buddha, the buddha of our time, also known as Gautama Buddha.
The buddha of this eon and world.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama; he was a muni (able one) from the Śākya clan.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
“The sage of the Śākya clan,” an epithet of the Buddha.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The name of the buddha of our era, the fourth buddha of the Bhadraka eon.

An epithet for the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama: he was a muni (“capable one”) from the Śākya clan. Usually counted as the fourth of the first four buddhas of the present Good Eon, the other three being Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama; he was a muni (“sage”) from the Śākya clan.
The buddha of this age; the historical buddha.
The name of the buddha of our era, the fourth buddha of this Bhadraka eon.
The name of the buddha of our era, the fourth buddha of this Bhadraka eon.
A common epithet of the historical Buddha, Siddhārtha Gautama, meaning “the sage (muni) of the Śākya clan.”
The historical Buddha.
The name of the historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama; he was a muni (“sage”) from the Śākya clan.
In the sūtra this term used by non-Buddhists to refer to Buddhists.
A buddha.

comment: person-(not in the Skt. source of the MMK)
comment_en: The name of an important translator who was active during the early Sarma (gsar ma) period (c. 11th century).
The name of an eon in which the Buddha Glorious Array of Eloquence in All Teachings resides.
An Indian paṇḍita involved in translating this sūtra.
King of Vṛji, father of Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother Mahā­māyā. See “Suprabuddha.”
“Śākya lion.” Synonymous with Śākyamuni, “Śākya sage.”
Literally, “Lion of the S̄ākyas,” this is the name under which Buddha Śākyamuni was prophesied for awakening by Buddha Dīpaṃkara.
One of the epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
In Sanskrit, "Lion of the Śākyas," an epithet for the Buddha.
The name of the clan into which the Buddha was born.
The clan in which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The name of the family clan into which Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The name of the family clan into which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The family name of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The family into which the Buddha Śākyamuni was born.
The clan from which the Buddha was descended.
The clan into which the Buddha was born.
An ally of King Śrī.
A short form of Śaṅkaroṣṇīṣa; also another name of Śiva.
“Conch Player.” One of the eight nāga queens.
An Indian paṇḍita involved in translating this sūtra.
A goddess invoked to counter the effects of poison.

The hell of the Simul trees, also called cotton trees, that have vicious thorns. The Tibetan had a corrupted, transliterated version of the name. This is classed among the neighboring hells. It is where beings continually climb up and down the trees in search of a loved one.
See Śāradvatīputra.
First of the five eyes. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1114.
A legendary mountain in Khotan.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
This term may refer to any country in the east of India; in some contexts, however, it seems to refer to a specific country of this name.
A country in the east, possibly the same as Prācī.
Son of King Śatānīka of Kauśāmbī.
A mountain in the eastern sea beyond Jambudvīpa.
Salmalia malabarica.
Bombax heptaphyllum or Salmalia malabarica (a lofty and thorny tree).

Bombax ceiba. Also known as the red cotton tree. It has red flowers and ripened capsules that contain cotton-like fibers. In particular, the trunk is covered in spikes to deter climbing animals, and therefore it is an iron version of this tree that is found in the hells.
A village.
Name of a bodhisattva in a story Buddha tells.
A king who is the Buddha in a former life.

A king who ruled in the palace of Catuṣka before the time of Śākyamuni Buddha. He was a previous incarnation of the Buddha who as a bodhisattva bargained his own flesh and blood away to Śakra (appearing in the guise of a cannibal demon) in return for hearing the verse that appears as the first in the Udānavarga collection.
(1) A name sometimes used for King Śrīsena’s country. (2) The name of a country he once ruled in previous lifetimes.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell. Alternatively referred to as Life Isochronous with Death.
A buddha realm.
An Indian preceptor and translator who lived in the ninth century.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian preceptor resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
The name of the capital city of Bharga (see “Garga”). (Edgerton 531.2).
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
The fiftieth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.

term: ཤིང་ གི་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ ལྟར་ སྐྱེས་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ

comment_en: A generic term for a tree under which a tathāgata sits and a synonym for the Bodhi tree.
Another name of Bhavila, a half brother of Pūrṇa from Sūrpāraka.
A class of spirit being.
A class of spirit being.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A ṛṣi who became the Buddha’s disciple. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-693.
(1) A forest in Dwelling in Excellent View (shing chen po). (2) A lotus pond on the fifth minor mountain on Lofty Summit (ljon shing).
A tree, Ficus benghalensis, native to the Indian subcontinent, that can cover large areas by putting down aerial roots that become subsidiary trunks.
A grove of banyan trees (Skt. nyagrodha) near Kapilavastu where the Buddha sometimes took residence. It was a gift to the Buddhist community by King Śuddhodana, the father of the Buddha.

A grove of banyan trees (Skt. nyagrodha, Tib. nya gro dha) near Kapilavastu where the Buddha sometimes took residence. It was a gift to the Buddhist community by King Śuddhodana, the father of the Buddha.
A specific kind of mangosteen.
A buddha realm.
Maudgalyāyana’s birthplace.

term: ཤིང་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ མེ་ཏོག་ རྒྱས་པ་ -ར་ བདེ་བ་ -ར་ གནས་པ
comment_en: A goddess of the night at the bodhimaṇḍa.
An acceptable form of shelter for a monk, as identified in the Four Supports section of the ordination ritual.
Butea frondosa.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).
One of the sages (ṛṣi).

term: ཤིང་ པི་ ལུ་ དང་ ལྡན་ མ
comment_en: One of the great piśācīs.
A village.
For definition, see “shrub cotton”.
A showy tree (Saraca indica) of the family Leguminosae of tropical Asia that is cultivated for its orange scarlet flowers and is used to decorate temples.
A forest at Shining Jewel Light.

term: ཤིང་ འཛེག་ གི་ ཤིང་ ལྟ་བུ་ -འི་ མདོ
en: Sūtra of the Parable of Pole Climbing
comment_en: A sūtra in the section of the path in the Saṃyuktāgama, which corresponds to SĀc 619, SN 47.19, etc.
In chapter 36 the name of a buddha in the distant past (shing rgyal). In chapter 44 the name of one of the future buddhas in this kalpa (shing gi rgyal po).
A lake near Sudharma.

“The son of Daśaratha” is actually Rāma. At the point in the Kāraṇḍavyūha where Nārāyaṇa, really Viṣṇu, rescues the kṣatriyas, he is inexplicably called by this name, which may reference a Rāma story. Rāma came to be viewed as one of the ten incarnations of Nārāyaṇa.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A great bodhisattva.
A species of tree; Vatica robusta.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A buddha in the past.
“The Garden of Chariots”; one of the four parks in Sudarśana city, home of Śakra (Indra) and his thirty-two gods, located on the summit of Mount Meru.
A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A forest in Living on the Peak.
(1) A forest on the eastern face of Sumeru. (2) Śakra’s arsenal.
See “Dwelling in Various Chariots.”
A future solitary buddha.
A buddha in the past.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
A grove in Dwelling in Essence of Jewels.
Prosopis spicigera or Mimosa suma.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell.
A forest located to the north of the city of Ujjayinī. The śiṃśapā is identified as the tree D albergia sissoo or Indian Rosewood in the Atharva Veda (Monier-Williams 1069.3).

en: Wealthy as the Great Sal Tree

comment_en: A realm in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
Usually identified as Shorea robusta, known as the kind of tree under which the Buddha was born and passed away.
Usually identified as Shorea robusta, this is known as the kind of tree under which the Buddha was born and passed away.
A hardwood tree that is widespread on the Indian subcontinent.
A hardwood tree, Shorea robusta, widespread on the Indian subcontinent.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
Saraca asoca. The aromatic blossoms are clustered together as orange, yellow, and red bunches of petals.
Calotropis gigantea.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of a yakṣa general.
The name of a world system.
One of the ten absorptions of the bodhisattvas.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A buddha.
A buddha.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A river on Deer Abode.
A god; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
One of the five celestial bodhisattvas associated with Mañjuśrī.

In the list of buddhas from whom Śākyamuni received the Samādhirāja this name appears twice, perhaps in error. Translated the first time in Tibetan as shin tu dul ba’i sems, and the second time as dul bar sems.
A kingdom where the buddha named Voice Proclaiming the Cloud of Dharma dwelled.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
One of the five celestial bodhisattvas associated with Mañjuśrī.
A world system.
A buddha.
One of the kings of the asuras.
Name of the seventy-ninth meditative stability.
Name of a brahmin, a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A bhikṣu, the kalyāṇamitra of chapter 6.
A hearer who lived in the past and was a disciple of the buddha Merugandha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A forest on Forest Garlands.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
One of the seven golden mountains that surround Mount Sumeru.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Fourth of the pure abodes, meaning “extreme insight.”
The second highest of the seventeen paradises in the form realm, and therefore the second highest of the five Śuddhāvāsika (pure abode) paradises.
The second highest of the seventeen heavens in the form realm.
Sixteenth god realm of form, meaning “Great Vision,” it is the fourth of the five heavens that make up the “pure abodes.”
One of the five pure abodes.
The fourth of five realms associated with the fourth concentration into which only noble beings are born.
One of the pure abodes within the form realm.
A royal palace.

The third highest of the Pure Abodes in the form realm; non-returners and those who have mastered the fourth meditative absorption are reborn there. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-072-007.html#UT22084-072-007-282.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, fourth of the five so-called pure realms of the form realm.
The second highest of the Śuddhāvāsa paradises, the highest paradises in the form realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of Being Immersed in Incalculable Effort.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Manifestation of the Sublime Lotus.
The name of a world system in the southeastern direction.
A world system.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; one of the kings of rākṣasas.
A hill in the town of Tosala in South India.
One of the eight hot hells.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A pool in Swan Forest.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.

A great bodhisattva.
As one of the twelve aspects of the Dharma, it means an extensive teaching on a subject. See also “twelve wheels of the Dharma.”
Literally “extensive”/“elaborate,” it is a denomination applied to a limited number of important sūtras, including the Lalitavistara , the Suvarṇaprabhāsa , and a few others.

en: Vaipulya sūtras of the Heap of Jewels
comment_en: This could refer to the Ratnakūṭa collection of sūtras as it is known in the Kangyur and Chinese canons; however, as the collection is not known to have existed, as such, in earlier times, this could also be either a general term covering Mahāyāna sūtras as a category, or a synonym for the Kāśyapa­parivarta.

Manu is the archetypal human and the progenitor of humanity in Indian lore. Thus, “son of Manu” is a synonym for humanity in general. Also rendered “born of Manu.”

Manu being the archetypal human, the progenitor of mankind, in the Mahā­bhārata, the Purāṇas, and other Indian texts, “son of Manu” is a synonym of “human being” or mankind in general. Also rendered “born of Manu.”

Manu being the archetypal human, the progenitor of mankind, in the Mahā­bhārata, the Purāṇas, and other Indian texts, “born of Manu” is a synonym of “human being” or mankind in general. Also rendered “son of Manu.”
Literally “born from Manu,” considered the first ancestor of all humans.

In the Indian tradition, Manu, similar to Noah in the Biblical tradition, was the survivor of a flood that covered the world, and so is the ancestor of all humans. On divine advice, he built a boat in which he saved his family and all the plants, seeds, and animals necessary to reintroduce to the world after the flood had diminished.

Transcendental wisdom, being the profound nondual understanding of the ultimate reality, or voidness, or relativity, of all things; personified as a goddess, she is worshiped as the “Mother of all Buddhas” (Sarva­jina­mātā).

en: Eighteen distinct qualities of the buddhas
comment_en: See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-257.
Eighteen special features of a buddha’s physical state, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by ordinary beings.

en: Eighteen distinct qualities of a buddha
comment_en: There are eighteen such special qualities unique to a buddha. They are as follows: he never makes a mistake; he is never boisterous; he never forgets; his concentration never falters; he has no notion of distinctness; his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; his motivation never falters; his endeavor never fails; his mindfulness never falters; he never abandons his concentration; his wisdom never decreases; his liberation never fails; all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; his knowledge and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; his knowledge and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and his knowledge and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

en: Eighteen unique qualities of a buddha
comment_en: Eighteen special features of a buddha’s behavior, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by other beings.

en: Eighteen unique qualities of a buddha
comment_en: Eighteen special features of a buddha’s physical state, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by ordinary beings.

en: Eighteen special qualities of the Buddha
comment_en: They are as follows: He never makes a mistake; he is never boisterous; he never forgets; his concentration never falters; he has no notion of diversity; his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; his will never falters; his energy never fails; his mindfulness never falters; he never abandons his concentration; his wisdom never decreases; his liberation never fails; all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom; his knowledge and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; his knowledge and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and his knowledge and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

en: Eighteen unique qualities of a buddha
comment_en: Eighteen special features of a buddha’s behavior, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by other beings.

en: Eighteen unique qualities of a buddha
comment_en: Eighteen qualities that are exclusively possessed by a buddha. These are listed in the Dharma­saṃgraha as follows: The tathāgata does not possess: (1) confusion; (2) noisiness; (3) forgetfulness; (4) loss of meditative equipoise; (5) cognition of distinctness; or (6) nonanalytical equanimity. A buddha totally lacks: (7) degeneration of motivatedness; (8) degeneration of perseverance; (9) degeneration of mindfulness; (10) degeneration of samādhi; (11) degeneration of prajñā; (12) degeneration of complete liberation; and (13) degeneration of seeing the wisdom of complete liberation. (14) A tathāgata’s every action of body is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (15) every action of speech is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (16) a buddha’s every action of mind is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom. (17) A tathāgata engages in seeing the past through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed and (18) engages in seeing the present through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed.

en: Eighteen distinctive qualities of a buddha
comment_en: They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake; (2) he is never boisterous; (3) he never forgets; (4) his concentration never falters; (5) he has no notion of distinctness; (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; (7) his motivation never falters; (8) his endeavor never fails; (9) his mindfulness never falters; (10) he never abandons his concentration; (11) his wisdom (prajñā) never decreases; (12) his liberation never fails; (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (16) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; (17) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and (18) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

en: Eighteen dharmas exclusive to a buddha
comment_en: This refers to eighteen properties/qualities that are unique to buddhas, “property” being one of the possible meanings of the term dharma.
