term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཆོས་མ་ འདྲེས་པ་ བཅྭ་ བརྒྱད
en: Eighteen unique features of a buddha
comment_en: They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake; (2) he is never boisterous; (3) he never forgets; (4) his concentration never falters; (5) he has no notion of distinctness; (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; (7) his motivation never falters; (8) his endeavor never fails; (9) his mindfulness never falters; (10) he never abandons his concentration; (11) his insight (prajñā) never decreases; (12) his liberation never fails; (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna); (16) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; (17) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and (18) his wisdom (jñāna) and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཆོས་མ་ འདྲེས་པ་ བཅྭ་ བརྒྱད
en: Eighteen distinct qualities of a buddha
comment_en: Eighteen special features of a buddha’s physical state, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by ordinary beings.

They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake; (2) he is never boisterous; (3) he never forgets; (4) his concentration never falters; (5) he has no notion of distinctness; (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration; (7) his motivation never falters; (8) his endeavor never fails; (9) his mindfulness never falters; (10) he never abandons his concentration; (11) his wisdom (prajñā) never decreases; (12) his liberation never fails; (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (ye shes); (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (ye shes); (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (ye shes); (16) his wisdom (ye shes) and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance; (17) his wisdom (ye shes) and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance; and (18) his wisdom and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

Eighteen qualities that are exclusively possessed by a buddha. These are listed in the as follows: The tathāgata does not possess (1) confusion, (2) noisiness, (3) forgetfulness, (4) loss of meditative equipoise, (5) cognition of distinctness, or (6) nonanalytical equanimity. A buddha totally lacks (7) degeneration of zeal, (8) degeneration of vigor, (9) degeneration of mindfulness, (10) degeneration of absorption, (11) degeneration of insight, (12) degeneration of complete liberation, and (13) degeneration of seeing the wisdom of complete liberation. (14) A tathāgata’s every action of body is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (15) every action of speech is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (16) a buddha’s every action of mind is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; and (17) a tathāgata engages in seeing the past through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed and (18) engages in seeing the present through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed.

Eighteen special features of a buddha’s behavior, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by other beings. They are as follows: (1) he never makes a mistake, (2) he is never boisterous, (3) he never forgets, (4) his concentration never falters, (5) he has no notion of distinctness, (6) his equanimity is not due to lack of consideration, (7) his motivation never falters, (8) his endeavor never fails, (9) his mindfulness never falters, (10) he never abandons his concentration, (11) his insight never decreases, (12) his liberation never fails, (13) all his physical actions are preceded and followed by wisdom (jñāna), (14) all his verbal actions are preceded and followed by wisdom, (15) all his mental actions are preceded and followed by wisdom, (16) his wisdom and vision perceive the past without any attachment or hindrance, (17) his wisdom and vision perceive the future without any attachment or hindrance, and (18) his wisdom and vision perceive the present without any attachment or hindrance.

The specific qualities of a buddha; may sometimes be used as a general term, and sometimes referring to sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four discernments, the eighteen distinct qualities of a buddha, and so forth; or, more specifically, to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion. Alternatively, in the context of this sūtra, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html#UT22084-055-001-425-note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-055-001.html#UT22084-055-001-429.

This term can refer to the general qualities of a buddha or to specific sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four discernments, and the eighteen unique buddha qualities; or even more specifically to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion.

The specific qualities of a buddha; may sometimes be used as a general term, and sometimes referring to sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four correct discriminations, the eighteen unique qualities of buddhahood, and so forth; or, more specifically, to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion. Alternatively, in the context of this sūtra, see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-058-001.html#UT22084-058-001-1103.

The term can mean “teachings of the Buddha” or “buddha qualities.” In the latter sense, it is sometimes used as a general term, and sometimes it refers to sets such as the ten strengths, the four fearlessnesses, the four discernments, the eighteen distinct qualities of a buddha, and so forth; or, more specifically, to another set of eighteen: the ten strengths; the four fearlessnesses; mindfulness of body, speech, and mind; and great compassion.
A bodhisattva.
According to the Lotus Sūtra the one true way to buddhahood, equivalent to the Mahāyāna, which is the only teaching given by buddhas who do not live in a degenerate eon.
A term used to denote the teachings of the Buddha, which in the case of this sūtra can be anything that the Buddha taught or any statement that precisely accords with what the Buddha taught.
A buddha who does not possess the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks.
Fifth of the five eyes. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-1129.
A pure realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations.
Also translated as “buddha realm.”
Also translated as “buddha field.”
A pure realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations.
The realm influenced by the activity of a specific buddha.
A pure realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations.
A realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations.
A pure realm manifested by a buddha or advanced bodhisattva through the power of their great merit and aspirations.
The realm permeated by a buddha’s teaching and blessing.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཞིང་ ཐམས་ཅད་ གདུགས་ གཅིག་པ་ -ས་ ཁྱབ་པ
en: Pervading All Buddha Realms with a Single Parasol
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཞིང་ ཐམས་ཅད་ དུ་ སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ གཅད་ དུ་ མེད་པ་ -འི་ སྤོབས་པ
en: Acumen That Does Not Leave Out Any Being throughout All Buddhafields
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཞིང་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཡོངས་སུ་ དག་པ་ -ར་ སྒྲ་ འབྱིན་པ་ -འི་ གཟུགས་བརྙན་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ དམིགས་པ
comment_en: “The Perception of the Speech Emitted by All the Pure Buddha Realms.” The name of a ray of light.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཞིང་ སྟོང་ གི་ རྗེས་སུ་ འཐུན་པ
en: Harmony with a Thousand Buddha Realms
comment_en: A buddha realm.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་ ཀྱི་ དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ དཔལ་ གྱི་ སྒྲོན་མ
comment_en: A world realm in the eastern direction.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཡུལ་ བསམ་ གྱིས་ མི་ ཁྱབ་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: “The Voice That Reveals the Range of Countless Buddhas.” The name of a ray of light.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ ཡུལ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྤྲུལ་པ་ ཇི་ལྟ་བ་ བཞིན་ དུ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ སྟོན་པ
en: Display of the emanation of the buddha domain exactly as it is
comment_en: The name of a tathāgata absorption.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ རིགས་ མི་ཟད་པ་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ སྟོན་པ
comment_en: A buddha realm in the upward direction.

Lit. “family” or “lineage of the Buddha.” One becomes a member on the first bodhisattva stage. In another sense, all living beings belong to this exalted family because all have the capacity to wake up to enlightenment, conceiving its spirit within themselves and thenceforward seeking its realization (see note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#chapter-7).
The name of an absorption.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ རྒྱན་ བྱིན་ གྱིས་ བརླབས་པ
comment_en: The name of a dhāraṇī.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ རྒྱན་ བྱིན་ གྱིས་ རླབས་པ
comment_en: One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.
The name of a bodhisattva stage.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཀྱི་ སྐུ་ -འི་ ཁ་དོག་ ཡོངས་སུ་ རྫོགས་པ་ མངོན་པར་ སྒྲུབ་པ
en: Accomplishment of the colors of the buddha body
comment_en: One of the twelve retentions of the bodhisattvas.

One of the five “eyes,” or qualities of vision, possessed by a buddha, viz., the eye made of flesh (māṃsacakṣus), the divine eye (divyacakṣus), the eye of insight (prajñācakṣus), the eye of Dharma (dharmacakṣus), and the buddha-eye. The buddha-eye is the omniscience seeing both how things are ultimately and how they manifest in their variety.

en: Eighteen unshared qualities of a buddha
comment_en: The list of eighteen unshared qualities in the Ananta­mukhapariśo­dhana­nirdeśa varies slightly from other canonical lists. Elsewhere, the first quality is that the buddhas are “consistent in their actions.” The list in the Ananta­mukhapariśo­dhana­nirdeśa also includes an additional member at position thirteen: “their liberated wisdom vision never wanes.” The eighteen are generally given as: (1) their actions are consistent; (2) their speech is not jarring; (3) they are not forgetful; (4) their state of cessation is not a state of indifference; (5) their perception is not discursive; (6) their minds are always composed; (7) their diligence never wanes; (8) their recollection never wanes; (9) their effort never wanes; (10) their meditative absorption never wanes; (11) their insight never wanes; (12) their liberation never wanes; (13) their physical actions are guided by wisdom and are in alignment with wisdom; (14) their verbal actions are guided by wisdom and are in alignment with wisdom; (15) their mental actions are guided by wisdom and are in alignment with wisdom; (16) their wisdom vision is unobstructed and unaffected by the past; (17) their wisdom vision is unobstructed and unaffected by the future; and (18) their wisdom vision is unobstructed and unaffected by the present.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ སྐུ་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ སྟོན་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ
en: Splendid Display of the Body of All the Buddhas
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ སྤྲུལ་པ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ གཙུག་ཕུད
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

en: Crown of the Womb from which All Buddhas Are Born
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
A world system.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
Name of a bodhisattva, “Intellect-Splendor.” However, the Tibetan suggests “Buddha-” rather than “Buddhi-,” which would then mean “Buddha-Splendor.”

en: Incomparable Buddha Who Is a Splendorous Source of Flowers
comment_en: A buddha.
A buddha in the distant past.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
See Avataṃsaka.
Presented as a single, long sūtra, many of its 45 chapters are independent works. See table of contents of Toh 44.
A collection of forty-five sūtras presented as a single, long sūtra, although many of its chapters are independent works.
A great bodhisattva.
The first king of the “yakṣa” dynasty, most likely Kadphises I.

Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni and general way of addressing the enlightened ones. See “Lord” or “Blessed One.” (See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-121).
An epithet of the buddhas.
A great bodhisattva.
(c. fourth century). A great Mādhyamika master, who was later regarded as the founder of the Prāsaṅgika sub-school.
A bodhisattva.

en: Bearer of the Armor of Never Parting from the Buddhas
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A buddha.

en: Light Rays of the Buddha Flower
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ འཕྲུལ་པ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ གཙུག་ པུད
en: Crown Ornament That Illuminates All the Buddha’s Emanations
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A wealthy householder from Śrāvastī who fathered Saṅgharakṣita.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
A realm in the distant past.
First of the ten recollections.

The Sanskrit term buddhānusmṛti (Pali buddhānussati), meaning “mindfulness or recollection of the Buddha,” is a common practice in all Buddhist traditions that involves taking a buddha such as the Buddha Śākyamuni or Amitābha as one’s meditative object.
First of the seven buddhas of the past.

term: སངས་རྒྱས་ རྣམས་ ཀྱི་ མ་ འདྲ་ -ས་ ཆོས
comment_en: Eighteen qualities that are exclusively possessed by a buddha. These are listed in the Dharma­saṃgraha as follows: The tathāgata does not possess (1) confusion; (2) noisiness; (3) forgetfulness; (4) loss of meditative equipoise; (5) cognition of distinctness; or (6) nonanalytical equanimity. A buddha totally lacks (7) degeneration of motivation; (8) degeneration of perseverance; (9) degeneration of mindfulness; (10) degeneration of samādhi; (11) degeneration of prajñā; (12) degeneration of complete liberation; and (13) degeneration of seeing the wisdom of complete liberation. (14) A tathāgata’s every action of body is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (15) every action of speech is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom; (16) a buddha’s every action of mind is preceded by wisdom and followed through with wisdom. (17) A tathāgata engages in seeing the past through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed and (18) engages in seeing the present through wisdom that is unattached and unobstructed.
A yakṣa in Heaped Up. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2468.
“The Eye of the Buddha,” one of the mantra deities.
Goddess invoked in divination and soothsaying.
Tibetan short form of Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha, also known as the Medicine Buddha.
Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni and general way of addressing the enlightened ones.
A fully awakened being; when spelled with a capital letter it refers to the Buddha Śākyamuni, one of the Three Jewels.

Lit. “awakened one.” Title of one who has attained the highest attainment possible for a living being. “The Buddha” often designates Śākyamuni because he is the buddha mainly in charge of the buddhafield of our Sahā universe.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Forever Passed Beyond Sorrow.
A fully awakened being; when spelled with a capital letter it refers to the Buddha Śākyamuni, one of the Three Jewels, unless another buddha is specified.

The Indic term buddha means "The Awakened One" and is used in Buddhism as an epithet for the historical Buddha Siddhārtha Gautama as well as other spiritually enlightened beings in general. “Buddha” is the past participle of the Sanskrit root budh, meaning "to awaken," “to understand," or “to become aware.”
A fully realized (“awakened”) being; when referring to a particular buddha or tathāgata, this term is capitalized.
Also rendered “buddha.”
Sometimes also translated “awakened one.”
The best known of many sets of past buddhas, including Śākyamuni as the seventh, his three predecessors in this eon, and the three last buddhas of the eon that preceded the present one.

Also commonly known by the names Senalek Jingyön (sad na legs mjing yon) and Mutik Tenpo (mu tig bstan po), he was a Tibetan king who reigned ca 800/804–15. He was the youngest son of King Trisong Detsen (khri srong lde btsan, r. 742–98).
A buddha in the past.
A mountain that is home to The Terrifying Forest (’jigs byed ma’i tshal) and a deer park where Devadatta’s disciple Kokālika is said to have lived.

en: Lordly King of the Sal Tree
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.

en: King of the Roar of the Grounds
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The buddha realm of Earth Deity.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-037-007.html#UT22084-037-007-4920.

The underworlds, of which there are said to be seven, include the realms of the daityas and yakṣas. The lowest is the realm of the nāgas. They are said to be pleasant and free from distress and even more beautiful than the higher realms.
One of the seven subterranean semiparadises, the abode of dānavas.
One of the seven subterranean semiparadises, the abode of nāgas and asuras.
The goddess of wealth; a goddess in one of the paintings of Śākyamuni.
A buddha who lives in the direction below in a buddha realm called Earth Melody.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
An important bodhisattva disciple of the Buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A river.

According to traditional accounts, the Kashmiri preceptor Sarvajñādeva was among the “one hundred” paṇḍitas invited by Trisong Deutsen (r. 755–797/800) to assist with the translation of the Buddhist scriptures into Tibetan. Sarvajñādeva assisted in the translation of more than twenty-three works, including numerous sūtras and the first translations of Śāntideva’s Bodhicaryāvatāra and Nāgarjuna’s Suhṛllekha. Much of this work was likely carried out in the first years of the ninth century and may have continued into the reign of Ralpachen, who ascended the throne in 815 and died in 838 or 841 ce. (See Dotson, 2007, for a summary of the imperial chronology between Trisong Deutsen’s abdication in 797 and Ralpachen’s ascension in 815).
One of the translators of the Tibetan Vinayavastu of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya from Kashmir.

According to traditional accounts, the Kashmiri abbot Sarvajñādeva was among the “one hundred” paṇḍitas invited by Trisong Detsen (r. 755–797/800) to assist with the translation of the Buddhist scriptures into Tibetan. Sarvajñādeva assisted in the translation of more than twenty-three works, including numerous sūtras and the first translations of Śāntideva’s Bodhi­caryāvatāra and Nāgārjuna’s Suhṛllekha. Much of this work was likely carried out in the first years of the ninth century and may have continued into the reign of Ralpachen, who ascended the throne in 815 and died in 838 or 841 ce.
Indian editor of the sūtra.
The river Ganges in India.
The editor of the Degé Kangyur (1700–1774).
Tibetan polymath, founder of Palpung (dpal spungs) Monastery (1700–1774).
Another name of Laṅkā.

Sri Laṅka, formerly Ceylon. The Rāmāyaṇa epic specified that Laṅka is inhabited by rākṣasas. Siṃhala was the name by which Laṅka was referred to in the Mahābhārata. The indigenous Buddhist population and their language is still called Singhalese.
The island of Lanka.
“Perfect Eye,” one of the mantra deities.
Lit. “The Mountain of Sindhu.” A king of the ancient Darada kingdom, which lay in the Gilgit region of larger Kashmir, the mountainous area through which the river Indus (Sindhu) flows.
A river.
An area located in present day Pakistan.
One of the charnel grounds.
Sindh (the country around the Indus).
Vitex negundo. A member of the verbena family. Also known in English as the Chinese chaste tree, the five-leaved chaste tree, and horseshoe vitex.
A river in western India.

en: Merging of the Sindhū and the Sea
comment_en: An area to the west of Jambudvīpa.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Boundless Melody.
A traditional Indian classification of musical instruments enumerates non-membranous percussion, membranous percussion, wind-blown, plucked string, and bowed string.

term: སིལ་སྙན་ རྣམ་པ་ སྣ་ཚོགས་ ཀྱི་ སྒྲ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: A forest in Engaging in Clarification.
A mountain to the west of Jambudvīpa.
A country ruled by King Udaya during the Buddha’s time.
A land to the west of Jambudvīpa.
A forest on Great Slope.
A translator of the sūtra.
Unidentified river. Possibly the Son River.
Jasminum sambac.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
A mountain in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
An Indian master who came to Tibet during the reign of King Ralpachen (r. 815–838 ce) and helped in the translation of 43 Kangyur texts.

One of the Indian teachers invited to Tibet at the time of the emperor Ralpacan (early ninth century). He was one of the great Indian pandits who assisted the Tibetan translators such as Yeshé Dé with the translation of Buddhist texts from Sanskrit.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.
An Indian paṇḍiṭa resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian paṇḍita who was resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.

One of the Indian teachers invited to Tibet at the time of the emperor Ralpachen (early ninth century). He was one of the great Indian pandits who assisted the Tibetan translators such as Yeshé Dé with the translation of Buddhist texts from Sanskrit.

Surendrabodhi came to Tibet during reign of King Ralpachen (r. 815–38 ce). He is listed as the translator of forty-three texts and was one of the small group of paṇḍitas responsible for the Mahāvyutpatti Sanskrit–Tibetan dictionary.

One of the Indian teachers invited to Tibet at the time of the emperor Ralpachen (early ninth century). He was one of the great Indian scholars who assisted the Tibetan translators with the translation of Buddhist texts from Sanskrit.
An Indian paṇḍiṭa resident in Tibet during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.
An Indian paṇḍita resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
An Indian scholar and translator invited to Tibet in the ninth century by King Ralpachen.

One of the Indian teachers invited to Tibet at the time of the emperor Ralpacan (early ninth century). He was one of the great Indian pandits who assisted the Tibetan translators such as Yeshé Dé with the translation of Buddhist texts from Sanskrit.

Surendrabodhi came to Tibet during reign of King Ralpachen (ral pa can, r. 815–38 ce). He is listed as the translator of forty-three texts and was one of the small group of paṇḍitas responsible for the Mahāvyutpatti Sanskrit–Tibetan dictionary.
One of the Indian teachers invited to Tibet in the time of Emperor Ralpachan (early ninth century).
An Indian paṇḍiṭa resident in Tibet during the late eighth and early ninth centuries.
A mountain in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
Second of six levels of gods in the desire realm.
The second heaven of the desire realm located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra and thirty-two other gods.
One of the goddesses invited to partake in the oblation offering.
A class of gods.
Second god realm of desire, abode of the thirty-three gods.
In Buddhist cosmology, an important heaven of the desire realm ruled by Śakra.
The second (fifth highest) of the six levels of gods of the Desire Realm.
Name of a god realm.
The paradise of Śakra, also known as Indra, on the summit of Sumeru. The names means “Thirty-Three,” from the thirty-three principal deities that dwell there.
A class of gods who inhabit the heaven of the desire realm just above the heaven of the Four Great Kings atop Sumeru.
The second lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm, located on top of Mount Sumeru in the Buddhist cosmology.
A heaven within the upper reaches of the desire realm.
The second heaven of the desire realm located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra and thirty-two other gods.
The second heaven of the desire realm located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra, otherwise known as Śakra, and thirty-two other gods.
The second heaven of the desire realm located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra and thirty-two other gods.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology. Counted among the six heavens of the desire realm, it is traditionally located atop Sumeru, just above the terrace of the Abodes of the Four Great Kings.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The second heaven of the desire realm, located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Śakra (Indra) and thirty-two other gods.
Indra’s paradise on the summit of Sumeru.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The second heaven of the desire realm, it is found at the top of Mount Meru and is the abode of Śakra and the thirty-three gods.
The second heaven of the desire realm located above Mount Meru.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.
The second of the six heavens of the desire realm. It is traditionally located atop Mount Meru, just above the terrace of the abodes of the Four Great Kings. Its chief is Śakra/Indra.
The second lowest of the six heavens of the desire realm.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology. Counted among the six heavens of the desire realm, it is traditionally located atop Sumeru, just above the terrace of the Abodes of the Four Great Kings.
One of the heavens of Buddhist cosmology, the second heaven of the desire realm. It is located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra, otherwise known as Śakra, and thirty-two other gods.
The second heaven of the desire realm located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra, otherwise known as Śakra, and thirty-two other gods.
The second heaven of the desire realm, located above Mount Meru and reigned over by Indra and thirty-two other gods.
One of the gods’ realms; also used as the name of the gods living there.
In Sanskrit lit. “the 3x10” (in round numbers for 3x11) Trāyastriṃśa heaven, to be found on the top of Mount Meru, the abode of Indra and the thirty-three gods.

The paradise of Indra on the summit of Sumeru, where there are thirty-three leading deities, hence the name “Heaven of the Thirty-Three.” The second (counting from the lowest) of the six paradises in the desire realm.
One of the six heavens of the desire realm.

Sumpa is the name of an ancient people living to the north-west of Tibet. They may be the same as the people known as Supiya in Gāndhāran Kharoṣṭhī texts, or may be Hephthalites (see Thomas 1935, pp. 42, 156-9).
One of the gods’ realms.
The heaven of the desire realm just above the heaven of the Four Great Kings atop Sumeru.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
A land to the north of Jambudvīpa.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A certain village during the Buddha’s time, home to Nandā and Nandabalā.
A buddha.
The bodhisattva who will become sixth buddha of the fortunate eon.
Name of a tathāgata.
(1) A buddha in the past. (2) A general.
One of the bodhisattvas attending this teaching.
An elder of the Licchavis.
A Licchavi inhabitant of Vaiśālī and the father of Ratnadatta.
A past and future buddha.

In The Hundred Deeds, a certain army chief in Vaiśālī by this name appears twice (in part 4: “note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-073-001.html#UT22084-073-001-2238” and in part 5: “note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-073-001.html#UT22084-073-001-2604”). It is not clear whether this army chief refers the same person or not. In the first story, he is the father of a ugly and stinking son who heard the Dharma from the Blessed One, went forth, and was healed of his afflictions. In the second story, he is the father of Good Compassion who was sentenced to death but was released and went forth under the Buddha.
The sixth buddha in this kalpa, following Maitreya.
Name of a yakṣa.
See “Siṃha.”
Leo (zodiac sign and constellation).
A Licchavi king, contemporary of the Buddha; a dynasty in Orissa contemporary of Prakaṭāditya.
A hypothetical buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A village. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-2043.
A buddha.
A king in South India.
Indian commentator (fl. late eighth century).
An absorption.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield at the nadir below the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
One of the buddhas who teach the Tathāgata­guhyaka on certain occasions in Vimalakīrti’s house.
A figure from an unidentified avadāna narrative.
A buddha.
A lion-faced goddess in the retinue of Jñānaḍākinī.
One of the eight great bhūtinīs.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
A bodhisattva who is attending the Buddha’s teaching in this sūtra.
The eighty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Harisumeruśirī.
A four-continent world in the distant past.
A buddha in the distant past when Śākyamuni was Prince Mati.
A buddha in the distant past.
Name of the twenty-seventh meditative stability.
A buddha in the distant past.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
Name of the 3rd meditative stability.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva and the main interlocutor of The Teaching on How Phenomena Are without Origin.
An ancient city, probably corresponding to the modern Panchakesari in Orissa.
A great bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
A town in South India.

en: King Rhythm of a Lion’s Roar
comment_en: A buddha of a past eon.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Flowers.
Lit. “Lion Crest.” The bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly who requests a discourse from Dhāraṇīśvara­rāja.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A king in the past.
A buddha.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Wilderness.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Nāgas.
A great bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Bhikṣuṇī pupil of the Buddha, who is only known from this sūtra.
A buddha.

term: སེང་གེ་ -འི་ ཡོན་ཏན་ ལས་ བྱུང་བ་ འབྲུག་ གི་ ང་རོ་ -ས་ འགྲོ་བ
en: Born from the Lion’s Virtues and Moving with a Thunder Roar
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva present in the Buddha’s assembly.
A buddha in the southeastern direction.
A buddha from the south.

term: སེང་གེ་ -འི་ རྩལ་ གྱིས་ མངོན་པར་ བསྒྲགས་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲ
comment_en: A bodhisattva; one of the primary interlocutors in this sūtra.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.

term: སེང་གེ་ -འི་ སྒྲ་ མངོན་པར་ བསྒྲགས་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས་ ཡིད་ དུ་ འོང་བ་ རྗེས་སུ་ སྒྲོས་པ
en: Imitating the pleasant sound of the lion’s roar
comment_en: Name of an absorption.
A buddha in the distant past.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha in the southeastern direction.
One of the buddhas who teach the Tathāgata­guhyaka on certain occasions in Vimalakīrti’s house.

en: Gait is that of a lion
comment_en: Forty-second of the eighty minor marks.
The name of a past Buddha.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
An island in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
A bodhisattva.
Acacia catechu.
One of the seven golden mountains.
A buddha.
King of Kapilavastu. His children were Amṛtā, Droṇā, Śuklā, Śuddhā, Amṛtodana, Droṇodana, Śuklodana, and Śuddhodana.

term: སེན་མོ་ ཟངས་ ཀྱི་ མདོག་ ལྟ་བུ་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: First of the eighty minor marks.

“He Who Has Long Fingernails,” Koṣṭhila’s name after he joined an order of wandering ascetics to continue his studies of Lokāyata philosophy. He later joined the Buddhist order and was known as Koṣṭhila again.

term: སེམས་ ཀྱི་ ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་ སྤང་བ་ -འི་ འདུ་བྱེད་ དང་ ལྡན་པ་ -འི་ རྫུ་འཕྲུལ་ གྱི་ རྐང་པ
en: Support for miraculous ability combining meditative stability of mind with the formative force of exertion
comment_en: Third of the four supports for miraculous abilities.
A land in Godānīya.
A bodhisattva; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the fifty-second meditative stability.

term: སེམས་ ཅང་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ རང་བཞིན་ གྱི་ རྗེས་སུ་ འཇུག་པ
en: Perceiving the Nature of All Beings
comment_en: A king; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A buddha.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཀུན་ གྱི་ དགེ་བ་ -འི་ རྩ་བ་ རབ་ཏུ་ སྒྲོག་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲ
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཀུན་ གྱི་ སེམས་ ཀྱི་ མོས་པ་ -འི་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ མཐོང་བ
en: Wisdom Vision of the Wishes of All Beings
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཀུན་ ཏུ་ སྐྱོང་བ་ -འི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ དཔལ
comment_en: A night goddess.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཀུན་ ལས་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ གོ་ཆ
en: Armor That Excels among All Sentient Beings
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ གཞན་དག་ དང་ གང་ཟག་ གཞན་ རྣམས་ ཀྱི་ དབང་པོ་ མཆོག་ དང་ མཆོག་མ་ ཡིན་པ་ ཉིད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ ཇི་ལྟ་བ་ བཞིན་ དུ་ རབ་ཏུ་ ཤེས་པ
en: Definitive knowledge of whether the acumen of other sentient beings and other individuals is supreme or not
comment_en: Sixth or fifth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ གཞན་དག་ དང་ གང་ཟག་ གཞན་ རྣམས་ ཀྱི་ མོས་པ་ སྣ་ཚོགས་ ཉིད་ དང་ མོས་པ་ དུ་མ་ ཉིད་ ཡང་དག་པ་ ཇི་ལྟ་བ་ བཞིན་ དུ་ རབ་ཏུ་ ཤེས་པ
en: Definitive knowledge of the diversity of inclinations and the multiplicity of inclinations that other sentient beings and other individuals have
comment_en: Fifth or sixth of the ten powers of the tathāgatas.
A buddha.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ གྱི་ བསམ་པ་ ངེས་པ་ -འི་ དོན་ གྱི་ ཕ་རོལ་ ཏུ་ བགྲོད་པ་ -ར་ དོང་བ
en: Reaching the Far Shore of Definitive Meaning to Fulfill Beings’ Aspirations
comment_en: The name of a bodhisattva in the Buddha’s audience.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ གྱི་ བསམ་པ་ ཞི་བ་ -ར་ མཛད་པ་ -འི་ སྐུ་ -འི་ དཔལ
སེམས་ཅན་ གྱི་ བསམ་པ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ སྟོན་པ་ -འི་ ཁྱུ་མཆོག
en: Leader Who Reveals the Wishes of Beings
comment_en: A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A rākṣasī known only from this sūtra.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ ལས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྨིན་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: “The Voice That Ripens the Karma of All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ སེམས་ ཀྱི་ སྤྱོད་པ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གནོན
en: Heroic in the Mental Deeds of All Sentient Beings
comment_en: A bodhisattva.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱིས་ མཐོང་ ན་ དགའ་བ
comment_en: The name of Mahāprajāpatī when she becomes a buddha in the future. Also the name of a bodhisattva.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱིས་ མི་ ཤིགས་པ་ -འི་ གོ་ཆ
en: Armor That No Sentient Being Can Destroy
comment_en: A buddha.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.

en: Bearer of the Armor of Caring for All Beings
comment_en: A buddha.
Name of a bodhisattva.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རབ་ཏུ་ དགའ་བ་ དང་ སྤྲོ་བ་ དང་ མོས་པ་ ཡོངས་སུ་ འབྱུང་བ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: “The Voice That Gives Rise to Joy, Delight, and Aspiration in All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རྡུལ་ དང་ འབྱེད་པ་ -འི་ སྒྲོན་མ
comment_en: “The Lamp That Removes the Dust from All Beings.” The name of a ray of light.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལ་ མངོན་དུ་ ཕྱོགས་ མ་ -འི་ དཔལ

comment_en: A buddha.
Name of a Mahābrahmā in the eastern direction.

en: He Who Looks at All Beings with Love
Making the Hair of All Beings Stand on End
comment_en: A place in Ultimate Torment.
A particular hell.
A buddha in the distant past.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ བསམ་པ་ -ར་ མཉམ་པ་ སྐུ་ ཡི་ དཔལ
comment_en: The hundred-and-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: sattvāśayaiḥ sama­śarīri­śiri.

en: Bearer of the Armor of the Forms of Sentient Beings
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.

term: སེམས་ཅན་ ལ་ གཡོ་ ཞིང་ རྡུལ་ དང་ བྲལ་བ
comment_en: A bodhisattva who seeks a prophecy from Śākyamuni.

term: སེམས་ དང་པོ་ བསྐྱེད་པ་ ལྡན་པ་ -འི་ མི་ འཁྲུགས་པ
en: Immutable One Endowed with the Original Generation of the Mind
comment_en: A buddha.

term: སེམས་ དང་པོ་ བསྐྱེད་པ་ -འི་ བྱང་ཆུབ་ སེམས་དཔའ་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ གཞག་པ
en: Category of the bodhisattva who has generated the initial thought of awakening
Bodhisattva who has generated the initial thought of awakening

comment_en: “Great being”; a frequent epithet of bodhisattvas.
See “bodhisattva” and note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-915–note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-918.
Literally “great being.” An epithet for a bodhisattva of great accomplishment.
An epithet for an accomplished bodhisattva.
This translation follows the Tib. (lit. “great mind- hero”), whose translation from Skt. derives from the lo tsā ba’s analysis of sattva as meaning “hero,” rather than simply “being.”

An epithet of advanced bodhisattvas, often defined as having attained at least the seventh bhūmi and the path of vision. These bodhisattvas have several special qualities that bodhisattvas on the lower bhūmis do not have.
Great being.
An epithet often applied to bodhisattvas.
“Great being.” An epithet for an accomplished bodhisattva.

An epithet for an accomplished bodhisattva. The White Lotus of Compassion Sutra goes further and says only those praying to attain buddhahood in an impure realm during a kaliyuga deserve the title, even though the early part of the sūtra uses it for all accomplished bodhisattvas.

An epithet for an accomplished bodhisattva. The White Lotus of Compassion Sutra goes further and says only those praying to attain buddhahood in an impure realm during a kaliyuga deserve the title, even though the early part of the sūtra uses it for all accomplished bodhisattvas.
A great bodhisattva.
An alternate name for a bodhisattva.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the grahas.

term: སེམས་བསྐྱེད་ མ་ ཐག་ ཏུ་ ཆོས་ ཀྱི་ འཁོར་ལོ་ བསྐོར་བ་ གཞོན་ནུ་ -ར་ གྱུར་པ
en: Youth Who Turns the Dharma Wheel Upon Generating the Mind of Awakening
comment_en: A bodhisattva.

The hometown of Śākyamuni Buddha. There are two sites, one on either side of the present border between Nepal and India, that have been identified as its remains. Also known as “Kapilāhvaya.”
The capital city of the Śākya kingdom, where the Buddha had grown up as Prince Siddhārtha.
The capital city of the Śākya kingdom, where the Buddha grew up.

The city in the Śākyan kingdom where Gautama Buddha grew up. It is located on the northern side of the Gangetic plain near Lumbini.

Name of one of the eight cold hells. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
Third of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
One of the cold hells.

These four unhindered discernments—the essentials through which the buddhas impart their teachings—comprise (1) unhindered discernment of meaning, (2) unhindered discernment of the doctrine, (3) unhindered discernment of etymology, and (4) unhindered discernment of inspiration. See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-253. On the philological origins of these four unhindered discernments, see Konow (1941): 40, and the reconstructed Sanskrit on p. 107; also Dayal (1932): 259–267, and Sparham (2012 IV): 78–79.

One of the greatest Tibetan translators. He lived in the eighth to ninth century. Also known as Paltsek Rakṣita. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-058-006.html#UT22084-058-006-827.

One of the three main varieties of chrysoberyl, the third-hardest gemstone. The cat’s-eye gem (cymophane) is light green or yellow and contains the distinctive appearance of a band of light, resembling a cat’s eye. It has been mined since ancient times in India and particularly in Sri Lanka. Jyoti can mean both “light” and “star,” and in describing this jewel the Sanskrit more likely means “banner of light.” However, the Tibetan translates the term as “banner of stars.”
See “cat’s eye.”
A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
An asura city.

Alternative name for Śāriputra, as he was born in the month of the constellation Tiṣya. He was also called Upatiṣya.

Our present eon in which over a thousand buddhas will appear. The meaning is “good” because of the number of buddhas that will appear. In the sūtra, it is usually called bhadraka.

One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.

Hindu god of war, leader of the demons that cure illness in children, and god of thieves.
An epithet of Kārttikeya; also the name of Kārttikeya as one of the grahas.

The Gaṇḍa­vyūha uses the same terminology as the Jain text Tandulaveyāliyua and differs from other sūtras. In the Nanda­garbhāvakranti­nirdeśa­sūtra , arbuda is translated as mer mer po.

en: In charge of providing clean drinking water
comment_en: One of several official administrative or managerial positions at a monastery.
A future solitary buddha.
A buddha realm.

Aruṇa is the deity of the dawn in Indian mythology, personified as the sun’s charioteer, and the name refers to the morning star Venus, according to de Visser (1931), p 24, n 1. In this context, Aruṇa functions as a messenger for Ākāśagarbha.
One of the grahas.
A bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.

A wealthy merchant in the town of Śrāvastī who became a patron of the Buddha Śākyamuni. He bought Prince Jeta’s park, the Jetavana, to be the Buddha’s first monastery, a place where the monks could stay during the monsoon. Although his Sanskrit name is Anāthapiṇḍada, he is better known in the West by the alternative form Anāthapiṇḍika. Both mean “one who gives food to the destitute.” Pali: Anāthapiṇḍika.

In this ninth-century Tibetan translation, Dhanyākara is translated as “Source of Happiness.” More common is the translation ’bras spung, meaning “Rice Heap.” The famous Gelugpa monastery Drepung takes its name from this city, which was the capital of the kingdom of the Satavahana dynasty that ruled South India from the first to third century ce. Known primarily as Dhānyakaṭaka, the present remains are in the village of Dharaṇikoṭa, a few miles from the site of the great Amarāvatī stupa, in Andhra Pradesh on the southeastern coast of India. Before 1953 this was in the state of Madras.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
Name of a god (deva).

term: སྐྱེ་དགུ་ -འི་ བདག་མོ་ ཆེན་ མོ་ གཽ་ ཏ་ མཱི
comment_en: The Buddha’s mother’s sister and his step-mother. She was the mother of Nanda. She became the first bhikṣuṇī after the death of the Buddha’s father. Gautamī is the family name, the female equivalent to Gautama. The family line is said to descend from the Gautama who was one of the seven rishis that established the religion and culture of India. His sūtra specifies that a renunciant should be called a bhikṣu, have a shaved head, and wear yellow robes. Also rendered here simply as “Mahāprajāpatī.”

term: སྐྱེ་དགུ་ -འི་ བདག་མོ་ ཆེན་ མོ་ གཽ་ ཏ་ མཱི
comment_en: See “Mahā­prajāpatī Gautamī.”

term: སྐྱེ་དགུ་ -འི་ བདག་མོ་ ཆེན་ མོ་ གཽ་ ཏ་ མཱི
comment_en: Siddhārtha Gautama’s aunt, who raised him following his mother’s death and who later became the first woman to go forth as a member of Buddha Śākyamuni’s monastic saṅgha. Also rendered here as “Mahā­prajāpatī.”

term: སྐྱེ་དགུ་ -འི་ བདག་མོ་ ཆེན་ མོ་ གཽ་ ཏ་ མཱི

en: Category of the bodhisattva who has taken rebirth
Thirty-two marks of a great being
comment_en: The main identifying physical characteristics of both buddhas and universal monarchs, to which are added the eighty excellent signs.
Brahmin who was reborn as Airāvaṇa.
Name of a prostitute in a story Buddha tells.
One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A town in Videha.
A pond on Equal Peaks.
A great bodhisattva.
Lit. “their gates to the sense fields are excellent;” thirty-sixth of the eighty minor marks.
A bodhisattva.
Sixteenth of the eighty minor marks.
One way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and mental objects).

These can be listed as twelve or as six sense sources (sometimes also called sense fields, bases of cognition, or simply āyatanas): In context of epistemology, it is one way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources, which can be divided into inner and outer sense sources, namely: (1–2) eye and form, (3–4) ear and sound, (5–6) nose and odor, (7–8) tongue and taste, (9–10) body and touch, (11–12) mind and mental phenomena. In the context of the twelve links of dependent origination, only six sense sources are mentioned and they are the inner sense sources (similar to the six faculties) of eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

These can be listed as twelve or as six sense sources (sometimes also called sense fields, bases of cognition, or simply āyatanas): In context of epistemology, it is one way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources, which can be divided into inner and outer sense sources, namely: 1-2) eye and form, 3-4) ear and sound, 5-6) nose and odor, 7-8) tongue and taste, 9-10) body and touch, 11-12) mind and mental phenomena. (These are subsumed in the eighteen elements, where to the twelve sense sources, the six consciousnesses are added.) In the context of the twelve links of dependent origination, only six sense sources are mentioned and they are the inner sense sources (similar to the six faculties) of eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
One way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and smell, tongue and taste, body and physical objects, mind and mental phenomena).
One way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and mental objects).

The six “inner” sense organs (eyes, ears, nose, tongue, tactile sense, and mind), and their respective six “outer” objects of forms, sounds, smells, flavors, tactile objects, and mental objects, are sometimes called collectively the “six sense sources” (q.v.), but are also sometimes taken as two separate groups, making twelve.
See “six sense sources.”

These can be listed as twelve or as six sense sources (sometimes also called sense fields, bases of cognition, or simply āyatanas). In context of epistemology, it is one way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources, which can be divided into inner and outer sense sources, namely, (1–2) eye and form, (3–4) ear and sound, (5–6) nose and odor, (7–8) tongue and taste, (9–10) body and touch, (11–12) mind and mental phenomena. These are subsumed under the eighteen elements, where to the twelve sense sources the six consciousnesses are added. In the context of the twelve links of dependent origination, only six sense sources are mentioned—they are the inner sense sources (similar to the six faculties) of eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
One way of describing experience and the world in terms of the twelve sense sources (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and physical objects, mind and mental objects).
One way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources (eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, mind and mental objects).
One way of describing experience and the world in terms of twelve sense sources: eye and form, ear and sound, nose and odor, tongue and taste, body and touch, and mind and mental objects.
A virtuous nāga king.
A great bodhisattva.
A grove in Supreme Strength.
One of the twenty-seven realms in the Heaven Free from Strife.
A forest of the asuras.
One of the auxiliary charnel grounds.
A buddha.

en: Bearer of the Armor of Male Forms
comment_en: A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.

en: Twenty-eight marks of a great being
comment_en: A variation on the more usual set of 32 such marks; this set is mentioned only in this sūtra and in three others: the Gaṇḍa­vyūha (ch. 45 of Toh 44), the Tathā­gatācintya­guhya­nirdeśa (Toh 47), and the longest Sāgara­mati­paripṛcchā (Toh 153). None of these texts give a list.

comment_en: The main identifying physical characteristics of both buddhas and universal monarchs, to which are added the so-called “eighty minor marks.”
Thirty-two of the 112 identifying physical characteristics of both buddhas and universal monarchs, in addition to the so-called “eighty minor marks.” For a detailed list see Berzin (2012).
Another name of the Rāṣṭrapāla­paripṛcchā­sūtra.
An epithet for the Buddha. Also the ideal man, a good or wise man.
An ocean between Godānīya and Videha.
A buddha.

en: Realm of the gods of the protector class

comment_en: One of the subtle channels in the body.
A forest in Moving Mind.
A buddha.
Also translated here as “faultless.”
A bodhisattva.
A realm of the triple-lute-bearer gods.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the vidyās attending upon Mañjuśrī.
One of the four retinue goddesses of Siddhaikavīra; also of Arapacana.
A rākṣasī known only from this sūtra.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the ancient kings; also, another name for the king Vallabha.
One of the vidyārājas dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Howling Hell.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
Young woman appointed by King Śākya Suprabuddha to look after the hair of his daughters Mahā­māyā and Māyā (the Buddha’s mother and aunt, respectively).

term: སྐྲ་ཤད་ འཛིངས་པ་ དང་ བྱ་ ཁྭ་ ཡོད་པ
comment_en: A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
Name of a yakṣa.
Another name for the king Vallabha.
A piśāca.

Gampopa Sonam Rinchen (sgam po pa bsod nams rin chen, 1079–1153). A disciple of Milarepa, and the founder of the monastic Kagyu tradition; also known as Dakpopa (dwags po pa) or Dakpo Lharjé (dwags po lha rje).

A certain king during the time of Buddha Prabhāvan who ordered the torture and slaughter of five hundred arhats, precipitating his rebirth in the Hell of Ceaseless Agony. Also his name in a previous birth as a certain king.

en: Small Person with a Curving Spine
comment_en: A certain monk of the Buddha’s order whose vile deeds committed against his mother in a previous life ripened into a series of hell births. Finally attaining a human birth, he had a curved spine and went hungry, then drank ash-gruel and passed into parinirvāṇa.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Skill of the Completely Victorious in Battle resides.

term: སྒོ་ཀུན་ ནས་ ཡེ་ཤེས་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: A buddha in a southwestern realm.
A city in South India.
A city in South India.
A buddha field in the future where the bodhisattva Supreme Wisdom attains buddhahood as the tathāgata Supreme Sun of Bliss.
Heliotropium indicum.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Acquainting the mind with a virtuous object or mentally contemplating the Buddha’s teachings (Rigzin 75). Also translated here as “meditation.”
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
The realization that all phenomena are illusory and empty, which occurs when a bodhisattva understands the unborn nature of phenomena.
A buddha realm to the east.

Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother. She and her sister Māyā both married King Śuddhodana of Kapilavastu. Here she is said to be the daughter of Śākya Suprabuddha. In other stories, Mahā­māyā is alternatively said to be the daughter of King Āñjāna of Devaḍaha. Also called “Mahā­māyādevī” and “Māyādevī.”

The female central deity of the Mahā­māyā Tantra who appears in the form of the male Heruka. She was also a popular form of the Brahmanical great goddess (Mahādevī), to whom the Buddhist figure is intimately related. Also rendered here as “Mahāmāyā.”

Buddha Śākyamuni’s aunt, and the daughter of Śākya Suprabuddha. She and her sister Mahā­māyā (Buddha Śākyamuni’s mother) both married King Śuddhodana of Kapilavastu. Somewhat confusingly, in other stories she is identified as Mahā­prajāpatī Gautamī, q.v., while Māyā is often used as a short form of the name of the Buddha’s mother Mahā­māyā.
An upāsaka in Dhanyākara.
Śrāvaka arhat, one of the sixteen sthavira arhats (see “elder”).
The Buddha’s son who became the first novice monk and a prominent member of his monastic saṅgha.
The Buddha’s son and disciple.
The Buddha’s son who became a monk (bhikṣu) and his disciple.

Rāhula is the name of Śākyamuni Buddha’s physical son. Edgerton reports from different sources that he miraculously descended from Tuṣita heaven into his mother’s womb, and insisted on becoming a monk when he found out that the Buddha was his father. He was ordained by Śāriputra.
Son of Siddhartha Gautama, who, when the latter attained awakening as Buddha Śākyamuni, became a monk and eventually one of his foremost disciples.
An asura king. He is said to cause eclipses by seizing or blocking the sun and moon.
Śākyamuni Buddha’s own son, who became a distinguished disciple. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-060-005.html#UT22084-060-005-945.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight great śrāvakas or arhats.

Śākyamuni Buddha’s son who became the first novice monk and a prominent member of his monastic saṅgha.

The asura who is said to cause eclipses by seizing the sun and moon.
One of the kings of the asuras; the demon who causes an eclipse.

Eminent among the long-life gods, he is said to have on different occasions seized the sun and moon, only releasing them on the Buddha’s order.

One of the kings of asuras; the demon who is thought to cause an eclipse.
The demon who ‟swallows” the moon or the sun during an eclipse.
A demon who is supposed to seize the sun and moon and thus cause eclipses.

The continent to the north of Mount Meru according to Buddhist cosmology. In the Abhidharmakośa, it is described as square in shape and its human inhabitants enjoy a fixed lifespan, namely a thousand years, and do not hold personal property or marry.

Along with the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, and Atharvaveda, one of the four Vedas, the most ancient Sanskrit religious literature of India. It primarily contains melodic notations for the chanting of Vedic hymns.

The exact place where every buddha in this world will manifest the attainment of buddhahood. In our world, it is the spot beneath the Bodhi tree in the village presently known as Bodhgaya. Literally, “the essence of enlightenment.” Also translated elsewhere as byang chub kyi snying po.

This name refers to two people in this text: (1) A captain; a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva. (2) A prince; a former incarnation of the buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.

See note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-031-002.html#UT22084-031-002-255.

This refers to one of the two central qualities of buddhas or high bodhisattvas: their feeling born of the wish for all living beings to be free of suffering and to attain the supreme happiness. It is important to note that this great compassion has nothing to do with any sentimental emotion such as that stimulated by such a reflection as “Oh, the poor creatures! How they are suffering!” On the contrary, great compassion is accompanied by the clear awareness that ultimately there are no such things as living beings, suffering, etc., in reality. Thus it is a sensitivity that does not entertain any dualistic notion of subject and object; indeed, such an unlimited sensitivity might best be termed “empathy.”
A specific state of mind resulting from the four abodes of Brahma and defined as the wish to liberate all beings from suffering.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A great bodhisattva.

Son of the Vaiśālī army chief Siṃha at the time of the Buddha’s stay there, he was sentenced to death for the murder of a prostitute. The Buddha secured his release, ordained him, and he attained arhatship.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level,” whereas it may very well be like “samādhi,” sam-āpatti, with the same meaning.
A bodhisattva.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state, in tems of both the state itself and the various meditative states that serve as attainments along the path. The Tibetan translation interprets it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level;” however, it can also be parsed as sam-āpatti, in which case it would have the sense of “concentration,” or “absorption,” much like “samādhi,” but with the added sense of “completion.”

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level,” whereas it may very well be like “samādhi,” sam-āpatti, with the similar meaning of concentration. Unlike samādhi, however, it also occurs with the meaning of “completion,” “attainment,” and “diligent practice.”
A state of mental equilibrium derived from deep concentration.
A kind of meditative concentration.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of being “equal” or “level,” whereas it may very well be, like “samādhi,” sam-āpatti, with the similar meaning of concentration, but also of completion.

One of the synonyms for the meditative state. The Tibetan translation interpreted it as sama-āpatti, which brings in the idea of “equal,” or “level,” whereas it may be intended as sam-āpatti, with a meaning similar to “samādhi” or “concentration,” but also to “completion.”
A state of mental equilibrium derived from deep concentration.

term: སྟོང་གསུམ་ གྱི་ སྟོང་ ཆེན་པོ་ -འི་ འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས

term: སྟོང་གསུམ་ གྱི་ སྟོང་ ཆེན་པོ་ -འི་ འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས
comment_en: The largest universe described in Buddhist cosmology. This term, in Abhidharma cosmology, refers to 1,000³ world systems, i.e., 1,000 “dichiliocosms” or “two thousand great thousand world realms” (dvisāhasra­mahā­sāhasra­loka­dhātu), which are in turn made up of 1,000 first-order world systems.

term: སྟོང་གསུམ་ གྱི་ སྟོང་ ཆེན་པོ་ -འི་ འཇིག་རྟེན་ གྱི་ ཁམས
comment_en: The largest universe described in Buddhist cosmology. This term, in Abhidharma cosmology, refers to 1,000³ world systems, i.e., 1,000 “dichiliocosms” or “two thousand great thousand world realms” (dvi­sāhasra­mahā­sāhasra­loka­dhātu), which are in turn made up of 1,000 first-order world systems, each with its own Mount Meru, continents, sun, and moon, as well as desire, form and formless realms, heavens of gods, etc.

Sometimes translated as a billionfold universe. A “great, third order thousandfold” universe (i.e. 1,000³ fold), consisting of a thousand “middle order thousandfold” (1,000² fold) universes, each of which consists of a thousand “first order thousandfold” (1,000 fold) universes, each containing a thousand world systems each with their own Mount Meru, sun and moon, four continents, eight subcontinents, peripheral ring of mountains, etc.
A universe containing one billion worlds.
A universe containing one billion worlds.
See “great trichiliocosm.”
A universe containing one billion worlds.
Name of a nāga king.
“Thousand Splendors.” The name of a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Sahasraśiri.
The buddha realm of the buddha King Maheśvara.
“The great thousand, three thousand-fold universe,” a cosmological term that signifies the entire universe.
A lotus pond on Draped in Light Rays.
A bodhisattva.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.

term: སྟོང་ སུམ་ གྱི་ སྟོང་ ཆེན་པོ་ -འི་ འཇིག་རྟེན
comment_en: This term in Abhidharma cosmology refers to 1,000³ world systems, i.e., 1,000 “dichiliocosms,” or “two thousand great thousand world realms” (dvi­sāhasra­mahā­sāhasra­loka­dhātu), which are in turn made up of 1,000 first-order world systems each with its own Mt. Meru, continents, sun, moon, as well as desire, form and formless realms, heavens of gods, etc.
A previous ruler of the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.

Maternal uncle of Śāriputra and son of Māṭhara. He went south to study Lokāyata philosophy with Tiṣya. He later returned to study Lokāyata philosophy with an order of wandering ascetics, pledged not to cut his nails so long as he upheld Lokāyata philosophy and became known as Dīrghanakha, “He Who Has Long Fingernails.”
See “Guardian of the Flame Govinda.”
Śāriputra and Maudgalyāyana joined his order after rejecting the six tīrthika teachers.
Epithet of Buddha Śākyamuni.
An epithet for the Buddha.
One of the standard epithets of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The lunar month in autum which falls in October-November, which in general Indian tradition was considered the most powerful time to perform good actions.
The month of Kārttika.
A balacakravartin king is a lesser kind of cakravartin (universal monarch) who has attained his dominion through his great might and his powerful army. See also “universal monarch.”
A kind of inferior wheel-turning king.
A buddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Always Fragrant.
A buddha.

In the Jātakas, Bālāha is a previous life of the Buddha Śākyamuni in which he saves merchants from the island of the rākṣasīs. In the Kāraṇḍa­vyūha Sūtra ( The Basket’s Display , Toh 116), it is Avalokiteśvara as a horse, saving a previous life of Śākyamuni from that island.
A ruler of the demigods.
A lord of the asuras; a member of the Buddha’s retinue.
A king in the time of Buddha Ghoṣadatta.

term: སྟོབས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ ཤུགས་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: A southern realm.
