comment_en: A bodhisattva in a realm in the upward direction.
Name of the Buddha Śākyamuni in a past life, when he was a king practicing bodhisattva conduct.
One of the mantra deities.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
Listed as the great yakṣa general of Rājagṛha in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.

The ten powers of a buddha (daśa­tathāgata­bala, de bzhin gshegs pa’i stobs bcu): (1) the power of knowing right from wrong (gnas dang gnas min mkhyen pa’i stobs), (2) the power of knowing the fruition of actions (las kyi rnam par smin pa mkhyen pa’i stobs), (3) the power of knowing various mental inclinations (mos pa sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs), (4) the power of knowing various mental faculties (khams sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs), (5) the power of knowing various degrees of intelligence (dbang po sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs), (6) the power of knowing the paths to all rebirths (sarva­tragāmin­pratipāda­jñāna­bala, thams cad du ’gro ba’i lam mkhyen pa’i stobs), (7) the power of knowing the ever-afflicted and purified phenomena (kun nas nyon mongs pa dang rnam par byang ba mkhyen pa’i stobs), (8) the power of knowing past lives (sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa mkhyen pa’i stobs), (9) the power of knowing deaths and births (’chi ’pho ba dang skye ba mkhyen pa’i stobs), and (10) the power of knowing the exhaustion of the contaminations (zag pa zad pa mkhyen pa’i stobs). See also “five powers.”

The ten powers (daśabala, stobs bcu) of the Tathāgata are (1) the power of knowledge of what is possible and what is not possible (sthānāsthāna­jñāna­bala, gnas dang gnas ma yin pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); (2) the power of knowledge of the individual results of actions (karmasvaka­jñāna­bala, las kyi rnam smin mkhyen pa’i stobs); (3) the power of knowledge of different practices leading to various destinies (sarvatra­gāminī­prati­pajjñāna­bala, thams cad du ’gro ba’i lam mkhyen pa’i stobs); (4) the power of knowledge of the different dispositions and tendencies of different beings (aneka­dhātu­nānā­dhātu­jñāna­bala, khams sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs); (5) the power of knowledge of the different aspirations of beings (nānādhi­mukti­jñāna­bala, mos pa sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs); (6) the power of knowledge of the different degrees of development of the faculties and inclinations of beings (indriya­parāparya­jñānabala, dbang po mchog dang mchog ma yin pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); (7) the power of knowledge of the absorptions, deliverances, concentrations, and attainments (dhyāna­vimokṣa­samādhi­samāpatti­jñāna­bala, bsam gtan dang rnam thar dang ting nge ’dzin dang snyoms par ’jug pa thams cad mkhyen pa’i stobs); (8) the power of knowledge of previous lives (pūrva­nivāsa­jñāna­bala, sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); (9) the power of knowledge of the deaths and births of beings according to their actions (cyutyu­papāda­jñāna­bala, ’chi ’pho bo dang skye ba mkhyen pa’i stobs); and (10) the power of knowledge of the destruction of the impurities (āsravakṣaya­jñāna­bala, zag pa zad pa mkhyen pa’i stobs). (Rahula 2001: 229–230, n118).

One set among the different qualities of a tathāgata. The ten powers are (1) the knowledge of what is possible and not possible; (2) the knowledge of the ripening of karma; (3) the knowledge of the variety of aspirations; (4) the knowledge of the variety of natures; (5) the knowledge of the different levels of capabilities; (6) the knowledge of the destinations of all paths; (7) the knowledge of various states of meditation (dhyāna, liberation, samādhi, samāpatti, and so on); (8) the knowledge of remembering previous lives; (9) the knowledge of deaths and rebirths; and (10) the knowledge of the cessation of defilements.

The classical list of the Buddha’s ten powers, which appears frequently throughout both Pali and Sanskrit sources, refers to the following powers of knowing (jñānabala): (1) Knowing what is possible and what is impossible (sthānāsthāna), (2) Knowing the ripening of karma (karmavipāka), (3) Knowing the various inclinations (nānādhimukti), (4) Knowing the various elements (nānādhātu), (5) Knowing the supreme and lesser faculties (indriya­parāpara), (6) Knowing the paths that lead to all destinations (sarvatra­gāminī­pratipad), (7) Knowing the concentrations, liberations, absorptions, and attainments (dhyāna­vimokṣa­samādhi­samāpatti), (8) Knowing the recollection of past existences (pūrva­nivāsānusmṛti), (9) Knowing death and rebirth (cyutyupapatti), and (10) Knowing the exhaustion of the defilements (āsravakṣaya).
Ten kinds of a buddha’s cognitive power.
Ten areas of a buddha’s knowledge, through which he is omniscient.

One set among the different qualities of a tathāgata. The ten powers are (1) the knowledge of what is possible and not possible; (2) the knowledge of the ripening of karma; (3) the knowledge of the variety of aspirations; (4) the knowledge of the variety of natures; (5) the knowledge of the different levels of capabilities; (6) the knowledge of the destinations of all paths; (7) the knowledge of various states of meditation (dhyāna, liberation, samādhi, samāpatti, and so on); (8) the knowledge of remembering previous lives; (9) the knowledge of deaths and rebirths; and (10) the knowledge of the cessation of defilements.

There are two different sets of ten powers, those of the Buddha and those of bodhisattvas. Those of the Buddha consist of power from knowing right from wrong (sthānāsthāna­jñāna­bala); power from knowing the consequences of actions (karma­vipāka­jñāna-); power from knowing the various inclinations (of living beings) (nānādhimukti­jñāna-); power from knowing the various types (of living beings) (nānādhātujñāna-); power from knowing the degree of the capacities (of living beings) (indriya­varāvara­jñāna-); power from knowing the path that leads everywhere (sarva­tragāmīmpratipat­jñāna-); power from knowing the obscuration, affliction, and purification of all contemplations, meditations, liberations, concentrations, and absorptions (sarva­dhyāna­vimokṣa­samādhi­samāpatti­saṃkleśa­vyavadāna­vyutthāna­jñāna-); power from knowing his own former lives (pūrva­nivāsānu­smṛti­jñāna-); power from knowing deaths and future lives (cyutyutpatti­jñāna-); and power from knowing the exhaustion of defilements (āsravakṣaya­jñāna-). The latter set consists of the bodhisattva’s power of positive thought (āśayabala); power of high resolve (adhyāśaya-); power of application (prayoga-); power of wisdom (prajña-); power of prayer (praṇidhāna-); power of vehicle (yāna-); power of activities (caryā-); power of emanations (vikurvaṇa-); power of enlightenment (bodhi-); and power of turning the wheel of the Dharma (dharma­cakra­pravartaṇa-).

One set among the different qualities of a thus-gone one. The ten powers can be listed as: (1) the knowledge of what is possible and not possible, (2) the knowledge of the ripening of karma, (3) the knowledge of the variety of aspirations, (4) the knowledge of the variety of natures, (5) the knowledge of the supreme and lesser faculties of sentient beings, (6) the knowledge of the destinations of all paths, (7) the knowledge of various states of meditation, (8) the knowledge of remembering previous lives, (9) the knowledge of deaths and rebirths, and (10) the knowledge of the cessation of defilements.

Ten wisdom powers unique to a thus-gone one: (1) the knowledge of what is possible and not possible, (2) the knowledge of the ripening of karma, (3) the knowledge of the variety of aspirations, (4) the knowledge of the variety of elements, (5) the knowledge of the different capabilities, (6) the knowledge of the destinations of all paths, (7) the knowledge of various states of meditation, (8) the knowledge of remembering previous lives, (9) the knowledge of deaths and rebirths, and (10) the knowledge of the cessation of defilements.

The ten knowledges of a buddha or bodhisattva: (1) the knowledge of what is possible and not possible, (2) the knowledge of the ripening of karma, (3) the knowledge of the variety of aspirations, (4) the knowledge of the variety of natures, (5) the knowledge of the different levels of capabilities, (6) the knowledge of the destinations of all paths, (7) the knowledge of various states of meditation, (8) the knowledge of remembering previous lives, (9) the knowledge of deaths and rebirths, and (10) the knowledge of the cessation of defilements.

A category of the distinctive qualities of a tathāgata. They are: knowing what is possible and what is impossible; knowing the results of actions or the ripening of karma; knowing the various inclinations of sentient beings; knowing the various elements; knowing the supreme and lesser faculties of sentient beings; knowing the paths that lead to all destinations of rebirth; knowing the concentrations, liberations, absorptions, equilibriums, afflictions, purifications, and abidings; knowing previous lives; knowing the death and rebirth of sentient beings; and knowing the cessation of the defilements.

Although the various sources have some variation of these ten powers, one classical list of the Buddha’s ten powers, which appears frequently throughout both Pāli and Sanskrit sources, refers to the following powers of knowing (jñānabala): (1) knowing what is possible and what is impossible (sthānāsthāna), (2) knowing the ripening of karma (karmavipāka), (3) knowing the various inclinations (nānādhimukti), (4) knowing the various elements (nānādhātu), (5) knowing the supreme and lesser faculties (indriya­parāpara), (6) knowing the paths that lead to all destinations (sarvatragāminīpratipad), (7) knowing the concentrations, liberations, absorptions, and attainments (dhyāna­vimokṣa­samādhi­samāpatti), (8) knowing the recollection of past existences (pūrva­nivāsānusmṛti), (9) knowing death and rebirth (cyutyupapatti), and (10) knowing the exhaustion of the defilements (āsravakṣaya).

Ten wisdom powers unique to a tathāgata: (1) the knowledge of what is possible and not possible, (2) the knowledge of the ripening of karma, (3) the knowledge of the variety of aspirations, (4) the knowledge of the variety of natures, (5) the knowledge of the different levels of capabilities, (6) the knowledge of the destinations of all paths, (7) the knowledge of various states of meditation, (8) the knowledge of remembering previous lives, (9) the knowledge of deaths and rebirths, and (10) the knowledge of the cessation of defilements.

May refer to either i.) the ten powers of a buddha (daśatathāgatabala, de bzhin gshegs pa’i stobs bcu): (1) the power of knowing right from wrong (gnas dang gnas min mkhyen pa’i stobs), (2) the power of knowing the fruition of actions (las kyi rnam par smin pa mkhyen pa’i stobs), (3) the power of knowing various mental inclinations (mos pa sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs), (4) the power of knowing various mental faculties (khams sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs), (5) the power of knowing various degrees of intelligence (dbang po sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs), (6) the power of knowing the paths to all rebirths (sarvatragāminpratipādajñānabala, thams cad du ’gro ba’i lam mkhyen pa’i stobs), (7) the power of knowing the ever-afflicted and purified phenomena (kun nas nyon mongs pa dang rnam par byang ba mkhyen pa’i stobs), (8) the power of knowing past lives (sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa mkhyen pa’i stobs), (9) the power of knowing deaths and births (’chi ’pho ba dang skye va mkhyen pa’i stobs), and (10) the power of knowing the exhaustion of the contaminations (zag pa zad pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); or ii.) the ten powers of a bodhisattva (daśabodhisattvabala, byang chub sems pa’i stobs bcu): (1) the power of intention (āśayabala, bsam pa’i stobs), (2) the power of resolute intention (adhyāsabala, lhag pa’i bsa pa’i stobs), (3) the power of application (pratipattibala, sbyor ba’i stobs), (4) the power of wisdom (prajñābala, shes rab kyi stobs), (5) the power of prayers (praṇidhānabala, smon lam gyi stobs), (6) the power of vehicle (yānabala, thig pa’i stobs), (7) the power of conduct (cāryabala, spyod pa’i stobs), (8) the power of emancipation (vikurbānbala, sprul pa’i stobs), (9) the power of enlightenment (bodhisattvabala, byang chub kyi stobs), and (10) the power of turning the wheel of the doctrine (dharmacakrapravartanabala, chos kyi ’khor lo bskor ba’i stobs) (Rigzin 163, 194–5, 280).
In this text, this primarily refers to a buddha's ten powers, which are enumerated and described beginning at note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-039-002.html#UT22084-039-002-147.

The classical list of the Buddha’s ten powers, which appears frequently throughout both Pāli and Sanskrit sources, refers to the following powers of knowing (Skt. jñānabala): (1) Knowing what is possible and what is impossible (Skt. sthānāsthāna). (2) Knowing the ripening of karma (Skt. karmavipāka). (3) Knowing the various inclinations (Skt. nānādhimukti). (4) Knowing the various elements (Skt. nānādhātu). (5) Knowing the supreme and lesser faculties (Skt. indriyaparāpara). (6) Knowing the paths that lead to all destinations (Skt. sarvatragāminīpratipad). (7) Knowing the concentrations, liberations, absorptions, and attainments (Skt. dhyānavimokṣasamādhisamāpatti). (8) Knowing the recollection of past existences (Skt. pūrvanivāsānusmṛti). (9) Knowing death and rebirth (Skt. cyutyupapatti). (10) Knowing the exhaustion of the defilements (Skt. āsravakṣaya).
The ten powers of a buddha or bodhisattva; these concern mostly their clairvoyant knowledge.

The powers (sometimes also called strengths), unique to tathāgatas, of: (1) knowing what is possible and what is impossible (sthānāsthāna­jñāna­bala, gnas dang gnas ma yin pa mkhyen pa); (2) knowing the ripening of karma (karmavipāka­jñāna­bala, las kyi rnam smin mkhyen pa); (3) knowing the various inclinations (nānādhimukti­jñāna­bala, mos pa sna tshogs mkhyen pa); (4) knowing the various elements (nānādhātu­jñāna­bala, khams sna tshogs mkhyen pa); (5) knowing the supreme and lesser faculties (indriya­parāpara­jñāna­bala, dbang po mchog dang mchog ma yin pa mkhyen pa); (6) knowing the paths that lead to all destinations (sarvatra­gāminī­pratipaj­jñāna­bala, thams cad du ’gro ba’i lam mkhyen pa); (7) knowing the concentrations, liberations, absorptions, equilibriums, afflictions, purifications, and abidings (dhyāna­vimokṣa­samādhi­samāpatti­saṃkleśa­vyavadāna­vyutthāna­jñāna­bala, bsam gtan dang rnam thar dang ting ’dzin dang snyoms ’jug dang kun nas nyon mongs pa dang rnam par byang ba dang ldan ba thams cad mkhyen pa); (8) knowing the recollection of past existences (pūrva­nivāsānusmṛti­jñāna­bala, sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa mkhyen pa); (9) knowing death and rebirth (cyutyupapatti­jñāna­bala, ’chi ’pho ba dang skye ba mkhyen pa); and (10) knowing the exhaustion of the defilements (āsravakṣaya­jñāna­bala, zag pa zad pa mkhyen pa).
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A king in the time of Buddha Ghoṣadatta. Also the father of the rebirth of King Śirībala in the time of Buddha Narendraghoṣa.

term: སྟོབས་ མཐའ་ ཡས་ གྲགས་པ་ -ར་ བརྗོད་པ་ -འི་ དཔལ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ འབྱུང་བ་ -འི་ བློ་གྲོས
comment_en: A buddha in the distant past.
A leader of the Licchavis.
Name of a past king in a story the Buddha tells.
A buddha.
One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A buddha in the distant past.
The five strengths are a stronger form of the five powers: faith, mindfulness, diligence, samādhi, and wisdom.
Faith, vigor, mindfulness, absorption, and insight. Although the same as the five spiritual faculties, they are stronger in terms of not being shaken by adverse conditions.

Similar to the five faculties but at a further stage of development and thus cannot be shaken by adverse conditions, these are: faith (śraddhā), diligence (vīrya), mindfulness (smṛti), absorption (samādhi), and insight (prajña).
Faith, diligence, mindfulness, absorption, and insight. These are the same as the five powers, at a further stage of development.
The strengths of faith, heroism, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom. They are the same as the five faculties, only at a greater stage of development.
Possibly the island of Bali in the Indonesian archipelago, but this identification is rather problematic.
One of the dhāraṇī goddesses present at the delivery of the MMK.
A leader of the asuras.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Leader of Loyal Heroes Who Uses Weapons to Eliminate Afflictions.
One of the grahas.
One of the kings of the asuras.
The seventy-second buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
One of the ten perfections.

The ten powers (daśabala, stobs bcu) of the Tathāgata are 1) the power of knowledge of what is possible and what is not possible (sthānāsthāna­jñāna­bala, gnas dang gnas ma yin pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); 2) the power of knowledge of the individual results of actions (karmasvaka­jñāna­bala, las kyi rnam smin mkhyen pa’i stobs); 3) the power of knowledge of different practices leading to various destinies (sarvatra­gāminī­prati­pajjñāna­bala, thams cad du ’gro ba’i lam mkhyen pa’i stobs); 4) the power of knowledge of the different dispositions and tendencies of different beings (aneka­dhātu­nānā­dhātu­jñāna­bala, khams sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs); 5) the power of knowledge of the different aspirations of beings (nānādhi­mukti­jñāna­bala, mos pa sna tshogs mkhyen pa’i stobs); 6) the power of knowledge of the different degrees of development of the faculties and inclinations of beings (indriya­parāparya­jñānabala, dbang po mchog dang mchog ma yin pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); 7) the power of knowledge of the absorptions, deliverances, concentrations, and attainments (dhyāna­vimokṣa­samādhi­samāpatti­jñāna­bala, bsam gtan dang rnam thar dang ting nge ’dzin dang snyoms par ’jug pa thams cad mkhyen pa’i stobs); 8) the power of knowledge of previous lives (pūrva­nivāsa­jñāna­bala, sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa mkhyen pa’i stobs); 9) the power of knowledge of the deaths and births of beings according to their actions (cyutyu­papāda­jñāna­bala, ’chi ’pho bo dang skye ba mkhyen pa’i stobs); and 10) the power of knowledge of the destruction of the impurities (āsravakṣaya­jñāna­bala, zag pa zad pa mkhyen pa’i stobs). (Rahula 2001: 229–230, n118).
A set of ten powers attributed to buddhas.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi; a south Indian king contemporary with Mahendra.
The name of a demon said to reside in Para­nirmitavaśavartin.
A city.
A demonic being who resides in the Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations. An epithet of Māra.
Demonic being (his name means “the wicked one”) who resides in the Heaven of Making Use of Others’ Emanations.
A city near Rājagṛha.
The name of a world system in the northwestern direction.
See “Vṛścika.”
Scorpio (zodiac sign and constellation).
Name of a demon who lived in the past.
A householder bodhisattva.
One of the sixteen great bodhisattvas. The content of the list varies from text to text.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi; one of the great piśācīs.
One of the subtle channels in the body.
‟Divinely Beautiful,” one of the eight goddesses of offerings in the Bhūtaḍāmara maṇḍala; also the name of one of the eight great yakṣiṇīs.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Glorious Supremely Renowned Intense Subduer resides.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment. This hell is the same as Wrapped in Every Possible Pain.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
Second of the six aspects of perception.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Ultimate Torment.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
First of the four noble truths.
Third of the four misconceptions.
Fifth of the eleven aspects of knowledge.

The term “suffering” includes all essentially unsatisfactory experiences of life in cyclic existence, whether physical or mental. These comprise (1) the suffering of suffering, i.e., the physical sensations and mental experiences which are self-evident as suffering and toward which spontaneous feelings of aversion arise; (2) the suffering of change, i.e., all experiences which are normally recognised as pleasant and desirable, but which are nonetheless suffering in that persistent indulgence in these always results in changing attitudes of dissatisfaction and boredom; and (3) the suffering of the pervasive conditioning underlying the round of birth, aging, and death.
One of the rāśis.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great piśācīs.
Third of the eight hot hells of Buddhist cosmology. The guardians of the Crushing Hell repeatedly crush its inhabitants between mountains.
A minister, brother of Susena.
King of the city of Ayodhyā before the time of Buddha Śākyamuni. Not to be confused with Mahendra or Mahendrasena.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A minister, brother of Sena.
A buddha realm.
A king.
A king.

The village where the village headman’s daughters, Nandā and Nandabalā (elsewhere known as Sujata and her sister) nursed Siddhārtha Gautama after his six years of austerities and where he later convinced them of the Truths.
A scholar steeped in study of the Tripiṭaka.

The “three (scriptural) baskets” of Dharma teachings: (1) the basket of teachings on moral discipline (Vinaya) (vinayapiṭaka, ’dul ba’i sde snod), (2) the basket of teachings in discourses (Sūtra) (sūtrapiṭaka, mdo sde’i sde snod), and (3) the basket of teachings on knowledge (Abhidharma) (abhidharmapiṭaka, mngon pa’i sde snod).
The three collections of the Buddhist teachings: Sūtra, Vinaya, and Abhidharma.
A great bodhisattva.
Alternative name of Suṣeṇa.
A female slave of King Ikṣuvāku.
Very hot hell. Probably a variation of Pratāpana (Tib. rab tu tsha ba), as the name occurs in no other sūtra.
A royal capital in another world in the distant past.
A royal capital in another world in the distant past.
King of the kinnaras. See the introduction note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-058-006.html#UT22084-058-006-816. His name has been translated into Tibetan both as “sdong po” and “ljon pa.”
One of the four kings of the kinnaras. Translated in other sūtras as ljon pa and shing rlon.

The Gaṇḍavyūha­sūtra (Toh 44-45) is an important Sanskrit ­sūtra that traces the journey of the young pilgrim Sudhana toward awakening. It was later incorporated into the large scriptural omnibus Buddhāvataṃsaka­sūtra as its forty-fifth chapter.
Refers to unconventional practices of a tantric yogin.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
Chief editor of the Tibetan translation of The White Lotus of the Good Dharma and the translation program from the late eighth to early ninth century in Tibet. From the Nanam (sna nam) clan.
Jasminum grandiflorum. Also known as Spanish or Catalonian jasmine, even though it originates from South India. Particularly used as offerings in both Buddhist and Hindu temples.
(1) A disciple of the Buddha. (2) A buddha in the past.

Child of householders in Śrāvastī, eventually ordained. At the time of his entrance into the womb and again upon his birth a rain of jasmine flowers fell. He went on to attain arhatship and various spiritual qualities from the cause of having scattered loose jasmine petals over, and having made offerings and prayers to reliquary stūpas in a previous life.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
A certain householder of the country of Mithilā.
A king of vidyādharas.
The twenty-third buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Citrārtha-indra.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha.
One of the seven kings mentioned in the story of Govinda.
A buddha realm.
Two crossed vajras.
Two crossed vajras.
One of the groves of the Trāyastriṃśa (Heaven of the Thirty-Three) gods.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
(1) A grove in Lateral (sna tshogs). (2) A forest at Sudharma (bkra ba).
(1) A realm of the ever-infatuated gods. (2) A river in Dwelling on Summits.
A buddha realm.
A world system.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Image of Mount Sumeru.
The world of the past buddha King Rhythm of a Lion’s Roar.
A great bodhisattva.
“Attainment of Light,” the world in which Kāśyapa will become a buddha.
Name of the forty-eighth meditative stability.
A buddhafield in the western direction of the Tathāgata Illuminator.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one King of the Drum’s Melody.
One of the mahoraga kings.
A bodhisattva in, and principle protagonist of, The Teaching by the Child Inconceivable Radiance. This is also the name he will have as a buddha in the future, as prophesied by the Buddha.
Name of the forty-ninth meditative stability.
Name of the thirty-sixth meditative stability.
A buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
Name of the thirty-fifth meditative stability.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
More commonly known as Amitāyus in the sūtras, he is the buddha of the western realm of Sukhāvatī. Rebirth in that realm has been an important goal since early Mahāyāna.
A buddha who lives in a western buddha realm called Excellence.
The Buddha of boundless light; one of the five Tathāgatas in Tantrism; a visitor in Vimalakīrti’s house, according to the goddess’s report.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The name of an eon in the past.
Refers to night goddess Pramudita­nayana­jagad­virocanā.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Endowed with Immaculate Light.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Obhāsa­sāgara­viyūha.
A buddha realm.

The last buddha of the Bhadra kalpa, which according to The White Lotus of Compassion Sūtra (Toh 111, Mahā­karuṇā­puṇḍarīka­sūtra, where it was translated as gsal mdzad) is the thousand-and-fifth buddha. The Buddha Ratnagarbha prophesied that the youngest of the thousand Vedapāṭhaka pupils of Brahmin Samudrarenu would be the Buddha Roca. In present times it is most commonly translated as mos pa.
One of the mahoraga kings.
A buddha in the distant past.
The sixty-fourth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha who lives in a buddha realm below called Vast Expanse.
One of the bodhisattvas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The guardian deity of the Buddha’s monastery in Veṇuvana.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha in the distant past. BHS verse: Obhāsayanta­prabha­rājā.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva.
The name of the eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. Also the name of the twenty-seventh buddha in a different kalpa in the distant past. BHS: Obhāsarāja.
A buddha in the distant past.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
“Display of Radiance,” the name of a certain kalpa in the distant past.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A bodhisattva in attendance as the Buddha delivers this teaching.
Mentioned by the Buddha as the last of the thousand buddhas of this eon.
A future buddha.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A deity in the retinue of Śakra.
A nāga king. This might be another name for the attested nāga king Upakambala. See Edgerton (1985).
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Aldebaran in the occidental tradition.
The wife of the Moon.
The name of a nakṣatra.
In this context, a ritual object used in rituals of enthrallment.
A type of worm (srin bu) that lives in and feeds on the body.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Reviving Hell.
The name of Prince Kuśa disguised as a cook.
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Lambda Scorpii in the occidental tradition.
The name of a nakṣatra.
An island in the vicinity of Jambudvīpa.
A hunter.
Nardostachys jatamansi, Nardostachys grandiflora.
A great bodhisattva.
A vulture king.
“Razor Blade,” one of the hells.
The Maitraka dynasty that started from Dharasena I.

term: སྤུ་ ཟིང་ ཞེས་ བྱེད་པ་ -འི་ འཇིགས་ བྲལ
en: He Whose Body Hairs Never Rise in Fear
comment_en: A buddha.

White coral is fossilized coral. It appears in one version of the list of seven precious materials. The Tibetan tradition describes it as being formed from ice over a long period of time. It is coral that has undergone transformation under millions of years of underwater pressure. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musalagalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber.

White coral is fossilized coral. It appears in one version of the list of seven jewels or treasures. Tibetan tradition describes it as being formed from ice over a long period of time. It is coral that has undergone millions of years of underwater pressure. It can also refer to tridacna (Tridacnidae) shell, which is also presently referred to by the name musaragalva. Attempts to identify musalagalva have included sapphire, cat’s eye, red coral, conch, and amber.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Moon Light.
A city or village.
A rishi of ancient India, the son of Rishi Bhṛgu, known for having become a youth again after he had reached an old age.
The planet Saturn.
See “Śanaiścara.”
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Beta Leonis in the occidental tradition.

Four types of right effort consisting in (1) abandoning existing negative mind states, (2) abandoning the production of such states, (3) giving rise to virtuous mind states that are not yet produced, and (4) letting those states continue.

The Nibandhana explains that this refers to a standard list of eight assembled factors: zest (chanda), effort (vyāyāma), faith (śraddhā), mindfulness (smṛti), discerning awareness (saṁprajanya), intention (cetanā), and equanimity (upekṣā) (Samtani 1971, p. 221).
A country.
A name assumed by Prince Kuśa, the Buddha in a former life.

One of the sixteen principal mahājanapadas (great countries) of ancient India, and a confederacy of eight or nine clans. It extended from the north bank of the Ganges opposite Pāṭaliputra up to the Madhesh regions of present southern Nepal.

One of the sixteen principal mahājanapadas (great countries) of ancient India, and a confederacy of eight or nine clans. It extended from the north bank of the Ganges opposite Pāṭaliputra up to the Madhesh regions of present southern Nepal.
The name of the country in which Māyā and Mahā­māya are said to have been born in “The Story of Keśinī” from The Hundred Deeds.
A temple on Mount Gośṛṅga.
A great bodhisattva.

A bodhisattva who appears mainly in chapters 11 and 12 of this sūtra. In the Chinese version, like other bodhisattvas who appear in the second half of the sūtra, considered to be of a later date than the first half, he is not in the initial list of bodhisattvas given in the first chapter.
Name of Vīrasena when he becomes a buddha.

term: སྤོབས་པ་ དཔག་མེད་ བཀོད་པ་ ཡང་དག་པ་ -ར་ སྤྱོད་པ་ -འི་ བློ
comment_en: The name of a buddha in the northern direction.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.
The name of an eon in which the Buddha He Who Attained Awakening after Countless Millions of Eons resides.
Name of a buddha realm in the east where the buddha Forcefully Proceeding from the Precious Lotus resides.
Lit. “Heap of Eloquence.”
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.

term: སྤོབས་པ་ མཐའ་ཡས་པ་ -འི་ ཏོག་ གི་ རྒྱལ་མཚན་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ སྤྲུལ་པ་ -འི་ དབྱངས
comment_en: A bodhisattva mahāsattva present in the Buddha’s assembly. His name means, “Magical Voice like a Victory Banner of Infinite Eloquence.”
Name of the seventy-sixth meditative stability.
A bodhisattva present during the delivery of the King of the Array of all Dharma Qualities.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
A great bodhisattva.
A bodhisattva.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
A great bodhisattva.
Fourth of the four unhindered discernments. Inspiration here is the means by which the teachings are enunciated.
A bodhisattva mahāsattva.
A merchant of the city of Śrāvastī who is the primary interlocutor in this sūtra.
A bodhisattva in the buddhafield at the nadir called Appearing as Illumination.
The name of a tathāgata presiding over a buddhafield to the south of the buddhafield Full of Pearls.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha in a southern realm.
A queen of Rāhu, king of asuras.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A principal bodhisattva in the Mahāyāna sūtras. He is described in this sūtra as coming from Akṣobhya’s realm.
Name of a bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A mountain or mountain range closely associated with solitary buddhas.
One of the pratyeka­buddhas attending the delivery of the MMK; one of the eight chief pratyeka­buddhas.
A mountain east of Mount Sumeru.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the world’s great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in western Tibet. In other sūtras translated as spos ngad can, spos ngad ldang, and spos nad ldan.
Name of a mountain.
A mountain known for its incense trees.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
The name of a bodhisattva. “Fragrant Sovereign King.”
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Lord of Movement.
A buddha realm.

term: སྤོས་ ཀྱི་ བལ་ གླང་ གླང་པོ་ཆེ་ ཆེན་པོ
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A buddha in a southeastern buddha realm.
A buddha.
A park in another world in the distant past.
Alternative name for Forest of Music.
A southeastern buddha realm.

term: སྤོས་ ཀྱི་ འོད་འཕྲོ་བ་ རབ་ཏུ་ སྣང་བ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: One of countless buddhas in a past kalpa.
A buddha realm.
The thirty-sixth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past.
A world realm in the northwest.
A buddha.
A royal city in the distant past.
A buddha.

term: སྤོས་ ཀྱི་ སྤྲིན་ གྱིས་ བརྒྱན་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་མཚན
comment_en: A buddha realm in the southeastern direction.

term: སྤོས་ ཀྱིས་ ཡོངས་སུ་ གང་བ་ རིན་ཆེན་ བརྩེགས་པ
en: Heaped with Jewels and Full of Perfume
comment_en: The buddhafield of the Thus-Gone One Suvarṇa­bhadra­vimala­ratna­prabhā­savrata­siddhi.
A buddha.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the worlds great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in west Tibet.

A legendary mountain north of the Himalayas, with Lake Anavatapta, the source of the world’s great rivers, at its base. It is said to be south of Mount Kailash, though both have been identified with Mount Tise in west Tibet.
Name of a mountain range, better known as Gandhamādana.
A buddha realm.
A river in the realm of the Four Great Kings.

Universe of the Buddha Gandhottama­kūṭa; a universe wherein the Dharma is taught through the medium of scent. According to Lamotte, p. 319, n. 2, this universe is mentioned in the Śikṣāsamuccaya, the Laṇkāvatāra, and the Prasannapadā. However, In the Prasannapadā, this universe is said to be ruled by Samantabhadra, not Gandhottama­kūṭa (see Lamotte, p. 320, n. 3).

term: སྤོས་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ འོད་ དང་ ལྡན་པ
comment_en: A western buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Jewel Light.
Name of the thus-gone one of the world system Fragrant with an Ocean of Incense.

Name of a bodhisattva.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvati Sūtra. The name has been variously interpreted. In “The lord of Avalokita,” Avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahāsāṃghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras, he was one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in southern India became important in southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not yet feature in the Kāraṇḍa­vyūha Sūtra, which emphasized the premeninence of Avalokiteśvara above all buddhas and bodhisattvas and introduced the mantra oṁ maṇi­padme hūṁ.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvativyūha. The name has been variously interpreted. “The lord of Avalokita,” Avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahāsamghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras, he was one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in South India became important in Southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not feature in the Kāraṇḍavyūha.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvatī Sūtra. The name has been variously interpreted. In “The lord of Avalokita,” Avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahāsamghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras, he is one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in southern India became important in Southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not yet feature in the Kāraṇḍavyūha Sūtra (Toh 116), which emphasized the preeminence of Avalokiteśvara above all buddhas and bodhisattvas and introduced the mantra oṃ maṇipadme hūṃ.
One of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of compassion.

A bodhisattva who first appears in the Sukhāvatī­vyūha sūtra (Toh 115) and then in a number of other Mahāyāna sūtras such as the Sad­dharma­puṇḍarīka (Toh 113). Avalokiteśvara develops into a great bodhisattva who embodies compassion with multiple forms in Indian, Chinese, and Tibetan Buddhism.
Name of a bodhisattva.
One of the eight main bodhisattvas, the heart sons of the Buddha.
The name of a bodhisattva.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvatī­vyūha Sūtra ( The Display of the Pure Land of Sukhāvatī , Toh 115). The name has been variously interpreted. In its meaning as “the lord of avalokita,” avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahāsāṃghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras, he was one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the Buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in South India became important in Southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not feature in the Kāraṇḍa­vyūha Sūtra ( The Basket’s Display , Toh 116), which is the most important sūtra dedicated to Avalokiteśvara.
One of the most popular bodhisattvas in the Mahāyāna Buddhist pantheon and one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, the embodiment of compassion.

One of the eight main bodhisattvas, the heart sons of the Buddha.
The bodhisattva who embodies compassion, also mentioned in this text as Āryāva­loki­teśvara, the noble Avaloki­teśvara.
The bodhisattva who is the epitome of compassion.

First appeared as a bodhisattva beside Amitābha in the Sukhāvati­vyūha. The name has been variously interpreted. “The lord of Avalokita,” Avalokita has been interpreted as “seeing,” although, as a past passive participle, it is literally “lord of what has been seen.” One of the principal sūtras in the Mahā­sāṃghika tradition was the Avalokita Sūtra, which has not been translated into Tibetan, in which the word is a synonym for enlightenment, as it is “that which has been seen” by the buddhas. In the early tantras he was one of the lords of the three families, as the embodiment of the compassion of the buddhas. The Potalaka Mountain in South India became important in Southern Indian Buddhism as his residence in this world, but Potalaka does not feature in the Kāraṇḍa­vyūha.

en: Pinnacle of their crown cannot be seen
comment_en: Seventy-first of the eighty minor marks in this text, although it does not figure in other lists of the minor marks. It is considered as a feature of the crown extension (uṣṇīṣa) in some texts and an additional, separate mark of a tathāgata in others. See also Unseen Pinnacle.
Name of the seventh meditative stability. See also Pinnacle of their crown cannot be seen.

One of the features of a tathāgata, sometimes included as an additional characteristic of the uṣṇīṣa (q.v.) and sometimes as a separate sign, either within the major and minor marks or in addition to them. Although sometimes explained with the sense almost of a prohibition against looking down on a tathāgata from above, it is more usually linked to the idea that the uṣṇīṣa extends upwards so far that its top is literally out of sight. Its mention in this text relates to the overall stature of a tathāgata, presumably in more than one sense.
A feature of the uṣṇīṣa whereby its top, or its upward extent, cannot be seen.
Another name for Māndhātṛ, a wheel-turning king who was the Buddha in a former life. See also note https://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-001-006.html#UT22084-001-006-3140.

An optional set of thirteen practices that monastics can adopt in order to cultivate greater detachment. They consist of (1) wearing patched robes made from discarded cloth rather than from cloth donated by laypeople; (2) wearing only three robes; (3) going for alms; (4) not omitting any house while on the alms round, rather than begging only at those houses known to provide good food; (5) eating only what can be eaten in one sitting; (6) eating only food received in the alms bowl, rather than more elaborate meals presented to the Saṅgha; (7) refusing more food after indicating one has eaten enough; (8) dwelling in the forest; (9) dwelling at the root of a tree; (10) dwelling in the open air, using only a tent made from one’s robes as shelter; (11) dwelling in a charnel ground; (12) being satisfied with whatever dwelling one has; and (13) sleeping in a sitting position without ever lying down.

Usually this term refers to a set of thirteen ascetic practices that can be taken up optionally by monks to further their moral discipline. Here, it refers to the practice of ascetic purification in general.

comment_en: The Medicine Buddha, the thus-gone one residing in the buddhafield Vaiḍūryanirbhāsa.

term: སྨན་ གྱི་ ལྷ་ བཻ་ ཌཱུརྱའི་ འོད
comment_en: The Medicine Buddha, the thus-gone one residing in the buddhafield Vaiḍūrya­nirbhāsa. Also called Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja.
A short form of the name of Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha, the Medicine Buddha.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A pore on Avalokiteśvara’s body.
A minister who was the Buddha in a former life.

term: སྨན་ དང་ རྩི་ཏོག་ དང་ ཤིང་ དང་ ནོར་ དང་ འབྲུ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ དཔལ

comment_en: One of the future buddhas of this kalpa.
A great bodhisattva.
The last of five hundred buddhas in a kalpa in the distant future.
Inula racemosa.

en: Famous and Melodious King of Medicine
comment_en: A bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.
A bodhisattva.
One of the bodhisattva great beings.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its twenty-seventh week.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
Universe of the Buddha Duṣprasāhā.
A world system that existed thirty eons ago.

Gyurme Dorje (’gyur med rdo rje), the first throneholder of Mindroling (smin grol gling), also known as Terdak Lingpa (gter bdag gling pa), a great scholar, author, and discoverer of spiritual treasures (1646–1714).

Gyurme Dorje (’gyur med rdo rje), the first throneholder of Mindroling (smin grol gling), also known as Terdak Lingpa (gter bdag gling pa), a great scholar, author, and discoverer of spiritual treasures (1646–1714).
The name of a lunar asterism. Its chief star is known as Pleiades in the occidental tradition.
The name of a nakṣatra.
Divine son of Śiva and Pārvatī.
Son of Śiva and a Hindu god of war.
A town in Videha.
One of the great yakṣiṇīs.
One of the vidyārājñīs attending the delivery of the MMK.
A bodhisattva.
The absence of any conceptual goal that one is focused upon achieving, knowing that all composite phenomena create suffering. One of the three doorways to liberation.
The absence of any conceptual goal that one is focused upon achieving, knowing that all composite phenomena create suffering. One of the three doorways to liberation.
A bodhisattva from King Jewel Mound’s buddha realm.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Glory of the Protection by Knowledge.
A buddha.
The ninety-eighth buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS in verse: Mahā­praṇidhi­vega­śiri.
A great bodhisattva.
The term for aspirations such as helping all beings, generating a buddhafield, and bringing all beings to perfect awakening, etc., that a bodhisattva makes while practicing bodhisattva conduct.
The term for aspirations such as helping all beings, generating a buddhafield, bringing all beings to perfect awakening, and so forth that a bodhisattva makes while practicing bodhisattva conduct.

term: སྨོན་ལམ་ ཇི་ལྟ་བ་ བཞིན་ དུ་ ཡོངས་སུ་ རྫོགས་ ཤིང་ དག་ ལ་ རྡུལ་མེད་པ་ བསགས་པ
en: Immaculate Accumulation of Perfection and Purity in Accordance with Aspiration
comment_en: Mañjuśrī's future buddha realm when he awakens as Samantadarśin.

term: སྨོན་ལམ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ལས་ འབྱུང་བ་ -འི་ རིན་པོ་ཆེ་ -འི་ གཟི་བརྗིད་ ཤིན་ཏུ་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
en: King Who Is Extremely Exalted by the Precious Majesty Arising from All Aspirations
comment_en: A buddha.
A hypothetical buddha.

term: སྨོན་ལམ་ བསམ་ གྱིས་ མི་ ཁྱབ་པ་ ཁྱད་པར་ དུ་ འཕགས་པ་ -འི་ རྒྱལ་པོ
comment_en: A buddha countless eons in the past.
A bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha.
A great bodhisattva.

term: སྨོན་ལམ་ རྒྱ་མཚོ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཀྱི་ དབྱངས་ ནོར་བུ་ རིན་ཆེན་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ -འི་ གཙུག་ པུད
en: Crown Ornament of the King of Jewels That Sings an Ocean of Aspirations
comment_en: A bodhisattva.

term: སྨོན་ལམ་ རྒྱ་མཚོ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ རབ་ཏུ་ སྒྲོག་པ་ -འི་ རིན་ཆེན་ རྒྱལ་པོ་ -འི་ གཙུག་ཕུད
comment_en: A bodhisattva present in Śrāvastī.
The name of the eighty-first buddha in a kalpa in the distant past. BHS verse: Praṇidhāna­sāgara­prabhāsa­śirī.
A great bodhisattva.

term: སྨོན་ལམ་ ལ་ རབ་ཏུ་ གནས་པ་ -ས་ མངོན་པར་ འཕགས་པ
comment_en: The buddha realm of Fully Illuminated Oceanic King of Many Hundreds of Virtues.
A future buddha.
One of the ten perfections.
A declaration of one’s aspirations and vows, and/or an invocation and request of the buddhas, bodhisattvas, etc.
A forest in the territory ruled by King Bimbisāra.
A wheel-turning king in the past.
One of the śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.

term: སྨྲ་ འདོད་ ཀྱི་ བུ་མོ་ -འི་ བུ་ ཡང་དག་ རྒྱལ་བ་ ཅན
comment_en: One of the six teachers at the time of the Buddha.

term: སྨྲ་ འདོད་ ཀྱི་ བུ་མོ་ -འི་ བུ་ ཡང་དག་ རྒྱལ་བ་ ཅན
comment_en: One of the six outsider teachers.

term: སྨྲ་ འདོད་ ཀྱི་ བུ་མོ་ -འི་ བུ་ ཡང་དག་ རྒྱལ

comment_en: One of the six philosophical extremists who lived during the time of Buddha Śākyamuni.
A brahmin.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabharājasūtra.
One of the twelve great yakṣa generals who protect and serve those who bear, read, recite, copy, or commission a copy of the Bhaiṣajya­guru­vaiḍūrya­prabha­rāja­sūtra.
A bodhisattva in the retinue of the Buddha.
The name of a karmic wind involved in the formation of an embryo in its tenth week.
See “Tula.”
Libra (zodiac sign and constellation).

en: Minced up by Raining Loops of Wire
comment_en: A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.
A hunter.
A yakṣiṇī; a rākṣasī in the Mahā­māyūrī­vidyārājñī (Toh 559).
“Sister”; a class of female spirits.
One of the vidyārājñīs dwelling with Śākyamuni in the realm of the Pure Abode.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A great bodhisattva.
An ancient king of Kāmarūpa.
A sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A sage.
A king and sage; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha realm.

term: སྲིད་པ་ -འི་ འདམ་བུ་ ཐམས་ཅད་ ཕུང་པོ་ མེད་པ་ -ར་ རྣམ་པ་ -ར་ འཐོར་བ
en: Dispersal of All Bases of Rebirth [through Realization]
comment_en: Name of the eighty-sixth meditative stability.
The king of Nandivardhana.

Along with the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, and Sāmaveda, one of the four Vedas, the most ancient Sanskrit religious literature of India. Primarily concerned with practical applications, including protection, healing, and magic.
Along with the Ṛg Veda, Yajur Veda, and Sāma Veda, one of the four Vedas, the most ancient Sanskrit religious literature of India.
Along with the Ṛg Veda, Yajur Veda, and Sāma Veda, one of the four Vedas, the most ancient Sanskrit religious literature of India.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
A race of ugly, evil-natured, supernatural beings with a yearning for human flesh.
A class of semi-divine beings that are often, but certainly not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition.
A race of physical beings who are ugly, evil-natured, and have a yearning for human flesh, but who also have miraculous powers, such as being able to change their appearance, as in the Kāraṇḍavyūha.
A race of ugly, evil-natured supernatural beings with a yearning for human flesh.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
A demon; a class of demons.
A class of flesh-eating demons that haunts frightening places.
A class of flesh-eating demons.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
A class of semi-divine beings that are often, but certainly not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition. Some are flesh-eating demons who haunt frightening places.
A general term in Indian culture for a type of spirit that (inter alia) haunts cemeteries and eats human flesh.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
A class of terrestrial demons perhaps similar to ogres.
A class of nonhuman beings that are often, but certainly not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition. Some are flesh-eating demons who haunt frightening places.
A class of demons.
A class of semidivine beings who are often, but certainly not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition. Some are flesh-eating demons who haunt frightening places.
A class of nonhuman beings who are often, but not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition.
A class of demonic spirit being.
A class of demonic spirit beings.
A class of demons.
One of the rāśis.
A class of nonhuman beings that are often, but not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition.
A race of ugly, evil-natured supernatural beings with a yearning for human flesh.
A race of ugly, evil-natured supernatural beings with a yearning for human flesh.
A class of flesh-eating demons that haunt frightening places.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
A class of nonhuman beings that are often, but not always, considered demonic in the Buddhist tradition.
A flesh-eating demon that haunts frightening places.
The name of a demon king.

term: སྲིན་བུ་ ན་ཀྲ་ དང་ འཁོར་ལོ་ དང་ མེ་ འཇིགས་ འཇིགས་ ལྟར་ སྐྱེས་པ
en: Terrifying Inferno with Swarms of Crocodiles
comment_en: One of the sixteen realms that surround the Hell of Heat.
A forest.
One of the tathāgatas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A country.
A country visited by Venerable Upasena; home of Lotus Color.
One of the female śrāvakas attending the delivery of the MMK.
A female pūtana.
One of the great mātṛs.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
One of the great dūtīs attending upon Lord Vajrapāṇi.
A powerful deity of the desire realm, more commonly known as Viṣṇu.
A great bodhisattva, a buddha, and one of the ten incarnations of the Hindu deity Viṣṇu, embodying superhuman strength.
One of the ten incarnations of the Hindu deity Viṣṇu, embodying superhuman strength.

An alternate name for Viṣṇu (khyab ’jug), which is also used for Brahmā and Kṛṣṇa. The Sanskrit is variously interpreted as “the path of human beings,” and “the son of man.” The Tibetan here is “the son of Nāra,” with Nāra translated as “one without craving.”
Another name for the Hindu god Viṣṇu.

In the ancient Indian tradition, the son of the first man; later seen as a powerful avatar of Viṣṇu, but also as the progenitor of Brahmā. In Buddhist texts, he figures in various ways including (as he does in most of this text) as a bodhisattva, while still one of the most powerful gods of the Realm of Form (as in 1.21).
One of the epithets of Viṣṇu.

In the ancient Indian tradition, the son of the first man; later seen as a powerful avatar of Viṣṇu, but also as the progenitor of Brahmā. In Buddhist texts, he figures in various ways including as a bodhisattva, while still one of the most powerful gods of the form realm.
Major deity in the pantheon of the classical Indian religious traditions, he is famous for this strength.
One of the epithets of Viṣṇu.
In Indian lore, incarnation of Viṣṇu, whose strength was legendary (see Abhi­dharma­kośa VII, pp. 72-74).
An alternate name for Viṣṇu. The Sanskrit is variously interpreted, including as “dwelling in water,” but is most obviously “the path of human beings.”
One of the ten incarnations of the god Viṣṇu, embodying superhuman strength.
Literally, “Child of No Craving.” Name of Viṣṇu.
Another name for the god Viṣṇu.
In the Hindu tradition understood as the god Viṣṇu in the form of the “Supreme Lord.” He is associated with the peacock feather. Not to be confused with the householder Viṣṇu.
Literally, “Child of No Craving”; a name of the god Viṣṇu.

term: སྲེད་ མེད་ ཀྱི་ བུ་ -འི་ བརྟུལ་ཞུགས་ ཀྱི་ གོ་ཆ་ རི་རབ་ ཀྱི་ དཔལ
སྲེད་ མེད་ ཀྱི་ བུ་ -འི་ ལྟར་ སྐུ་གྲིམས་པ
en: Body is firm, like that of Nārāyaṇa
comment_en: Second of the eighty minor marks. See “Nārāyaṇa.”
Epithet of Viṣṇu.
A name of Viṣṇu.
An epithet of Viṣṇu.
A future buddha.
One of the māras; also one of the five yakṣa generals.
One of the nonmental motivations, defined as the force of life-duration, being a concept of the Abhidharma. See T. Stcherbatski, Central Conception of Buddhism (London, 1923), p. 105.
Name of a bodhisattva.
The manipulation of breath by means of yogic exercise. The Tibetan translation of the Sanskrit compound prāṇāyāma is more usually the compound srog rtsol.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Great Howling Hell. Alternatively referred to as Instant Revival Upon Death (shi ma thag tu ’tsho ba) in the Tibetan text.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A vidyārāja from the personal retinue of Vajrapāṇi.
A famous Tibetan king of the seventh century.
617–650; a famous king from Tibet’s Imperial Period.
617–650; a famous king from Tibet’s Imperial Period.
A captain; a former incarnation of the Buddha.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Thus-Gone King, Guru of Immeasurably Many.
Instructor or spiritual teacher. Usually refers either to an accomplished master of meditation practice or to a learned scholar. The title of an official position in a monastery.
A spiritual teacher.
Teacher or master, especially a spiritual master. The term is rendered elsewhere in this translation as “ācārya.”
A spiritual teacher (sometimes more specifically the deputy or substitute of the upādhyāya).
Those who belong to any of the first to seventh of the eight stages of spiritual achievement, the eighth being that of an arhat, who needs no further training.
Son of the brahmin Agnidatta in the country of Pāṭaliputra, a monk and Tripiṭaka master whose murder at the hands of Sūrata’s disciples hastens the Dharma’s disappearance from this world.
The state of a person who has not yet attained arhatship.
Name of a nāga king; a monkey god; Rāma’s companion and devotee in the Rāmāyaṇa.
A country in the east of India, roughly corresponding to modern Bengal.
One of the two pīlavas.
A krodha accomplished by the brahmin Pāṇini.
Indian plant; a deadly poison.
Heliotropium indicum (?)
Unidentified river, possibly the Kali Gandaki.
A nāga.
A certain nāga king converted by Mādhyandina during his missionary work in Kashmir.
An unvirtuous nāga king.
The name of one of the wrathful forms of Vajrapāṇi; in the Sampuṭodbhava he is also referred to as Krodhavijaya or simply Krodha.

The wrathful buddha personifying the true nature of all forms and all the sensory fields and elements; a wrathful deity of the vīra type; also an epithet applied to some wrathful deities, especially Hevajra and Saṃvara.
The wrathful form of Akṣobhya, buddha of the vajra family, who appears in the center of many tantric maṇḍalas. He is typicaly depicted wearing mortuary implements and wreathed in flame.
One of the goddesses in the retinue of Heruka.
A central Asian region, at times referring to Mongolia.
A kind of sugar.
The fragrant aloeswood tree Aquilaria agallocha. Alternately a Tibetan translation of śiṃśapā, which the Atharvaveda identifies as the tree Dalbergia sissoo or Indian redwood.
Name of the world system of the thus-gone one Moon’s Light/Light of the Sublime Precious Moon.
Name of one of the eight cold hells. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
One of the eight cold hells.
Fifth of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. It is named for the sounds its inhabitants make while enduring unthinkable cold.
One of the cold hells.
Abutilon indicum.

term: ཨ་ ཏི་ མུག་ ཏ་ ཀ་ -འི་ ཕྲེང་བ་ ཅན

comment_en: Atiśa Dīpaṃkara­śrī­jñāna (982–1054 ce), often referred to in Tibetan as jo bo, “(The) Lord,” was a renowned figure in the history of Tibetan Buddhism famous for coming to Tibet and revitalizing Buddhism there during the early eleventh century.
The Indian master Atiśa Dīpaṅkaraśrījñāna (982–1054) is renowned in the history of Tibetan Buddhism for coming to Tibet and revitalizing Buddhism there during the early eleventh century.
Indian paṇḍita referred to in the sūtra’s colophon
A river on Saṅkāśa.
The name of the town where Kaineya lived; traditionally spelled Udumā, the rendering in The Hundred Deeds may be derived from the Pāli/Prakṛt form Ātumā.
“One with the Face of Ananta.” One of the eight nāga queens.
A city in Godānīya.
A mountain in the east of Jambudvīpa.
A region on the Deccan Plateau.
Achyranthes aspera.
An Indian paṇḍita involved in translating this sūtra.
A city in Godānīya.
One of the sages (ṛṣi).

term: ཨ་མྱེ་ -ས་ ཞབས་ ང་ དབང་ ཀུན་དགའ་ བསོད་ནམས
comment_en: A seventeenth century scholar (1597–1659), the twenty-seventh Sakya Trizin.

term: ཨ་མྱེ་ -ས་ ཞབས་ ང་ དབང་ ཀུན་དགའ་ བསོད་ནམས
comment_en: A seventeenth century scholar (1597–1659), the twenty-seventh Sakya Trizin.
The 27th Sakya throneholder (1597–1659), an accomplished scholar, author, and diplomat.
The 27th Sakya throneholder (1597–1659), an accomplished scholar, author, and diplomat.
A courtesan.
A courtesan of Vaiśālī who gave her garden to the Buddha and his retinue, where they stay during the events of the sūtra.
A courtesan of Vaiśālī.

en: Grove of the caretaker of mango trees
comment_en: A phrase usually translated as Āmrapālī’s grove, referring to the grove in Vaiśālī donated to the Buddha by the courtesan Āmrapālī (“Protected by a Mango Tree”), but here possibly to be interpreted as a generic term, as the narrative locates it in Vārāṇasī.
A certain brahmin village during the Buddha’s time.
A famous and beautiful patron of the Buddha’s, courtesan in the city of Vaiśālī.
The grove donated to the Buddha by the courtesan Āmrapālī.
The site in Vaiśālī where Buddha Śākyamuni taught and performed miracles.
One of sixteen realms that surround the Crushing Hell.
The alphabet of the Kharoṣṭhī script, forming an important mnemonic incantation.
The alphabet of the Kharoṣṭhī script, forming an important mnemonic incantation.
This seems to be the Buddhist (Vajrayāna) name of the male deity, Aralli, in the centre of the dharmodaya.
King Śrīsena’s royal estate.
The name of a star.
A realm that neighbors the Hell of Intense Heat.

en: Union of the two series of vowels and consonants

comment_en: The vowels (āli) and consonants (kāli) of the Sanskrit alphabet.
Ficus religiosa, the species of fig tree under which the Buddha attained awakening.
A demigod who inhabits one of the six types of worlds (Skt. loka) that make up saṃsāra. The asuras are the enemies of the devas, fighting with them for supremacy. See also “animal.”
A town in the region of Magadha.
A kingdom on the southern bank of the Ganges (in modern day Bihar and Bengal) whose influence waned during the life of Śākyamūni Buddha at the hands of the kings of Magadha. Its capital was at Campā.
A country.
A land in the east of Jambudvīpa.
At the time of the Buddha, the countries of Aṅga and Magadha were referred to as a single entity.

The King of Aṅga was the pre-eminent ruler in the eastern Gangetic region at the time of the Buddha’s birth. His defeat at the hands of Prince Bimbisāra of Magadha is narrated at the start of the Pravrajyāvastu.
The name of a nakṣatra.
The rishi who is said to have composed most of the fourth Veda, the Atharvaveda.
An ancient country whose territory spanned parts of what is today eastern Bihar and West Bengal.
One of the power places.
Unidentified region of India.
Unidentified; occurs in a mantra of enthrallment.
A mountain in the sea west of Jambudvīpa.
One of the twenty-four (the number may vary according to source) pīṭhas, or places of pilgrimage mentioned in the tantras.

A huge flat rock, Indra’s throne in the Realm of the Thirty-Three Gods; it is called Pāṇḍukambala, “like a blanket,” because it is made of a pale stone reminiscent of thick wollen cloth. Sakaki 7127 in the Mahāvyutpatti.
One of the four pīṭhas.
Terminalia arjuna.
A lake on Equal Peaks.
Third-century disciple of Nāgārjuna. His name is usually translated into Tibetan as ’phags pa lha.
Synonymous with Kubera, who, in this sūtra, is distinct from Vaiśravaṇa. The name Ailavila is derived from his mother, and means “the son of Ilavilā.”
Ficus glomerata; cluster fig.

The mythological flower of the fig tree said to appear on rare occasions, such as the birth of a buddha. The actual fig tree flower is contained within the fruit. The flower also came to be portrayed as a kind of lotus.
Ficus glomerata.
An ancient city in Magadha.

A simile for rarity, as fig trees do not have discernible blossoms. In Tibet the udumbara (Ficus glomerata), being unknown, became portrayed as a gigantic lotuslike flower. The Chinese adds the adjective “rare” and, like the Tibetan, simply transliterates udumbara.
Śiva.
The name that Avalokiteśvara prophecies the goddess Umādevī will have on attainment of Buddhahood.
A mountain in the northern region.
Incarvillea compacta maxim, an herb with pink trumpet-shaped flowers used in Tibetan medicine.

en: King Whose Fragrance Is That of a Blossoming Utpala
comment_en: A buddha.
Nymphaea caerulea. The “blue lotus” is actually a lily, so it is also known as the blue water lily.
The name of a kalpa in the distant past.

en: Splitting Open Like a Blue Lotus Hell
comment_en: Name of one of the eight cold hells. The extreme cold of this hell turns the skin of its inhabitants blue until they crack apart.
One of the cold hells.
A river in Dwelling on Summits.
A merchant in Jambudvīpa, later to be reborn as Auspicious Time.
A great bodhisattva.
One of the eight great nāga kings.
Blue lotus, waterlily.
“With a Face Like a Water Lily,” the name of a legendary king.
A great bodhisattva.
A buddha.

A realm of the ever-infatuated gods.
Name of a former incarnation of the Buddha while he was a practicing bodhisattva.
A buddha.
A buddha realm.
One of the Buddha’s former rebirths.
See “Splitting Open Like a Blue Lotus Hell.”

en: Splitting Open Like a Blue Lotus Hell
comment_en: Sixth of the eight cold hells of Buddhist cosmology. The extreme cold of this hell turns the skin of its inhabitants blue until they crack apart in five or six pieces. Also rendered here as “Blue Lotus Hell.”
A buddha realm.
Nymphaea caerulea. The “blue lotus” is actually a lily, so it is also known as the blue water lily.
A sage; former incarnation of the Buddha.
One of the mahoraga kings.
One of the great piśācīs.

A nāga king who in the lifetime of the previous buddha had cut down a tree and had therefore been reborn as a nāga. Residing in Taxila, he is said to have miraculously extended himself to where the Buddha was present. This tale is found represented in ancient sculpture.
A nāga king.
A nāga king
A nāga king.
A village.
A region of ancient India, not far from Mathurā.
A forest near Otalā.
A brahmin.
A country in the eastern part of India, modern-day Orissa.
One of the four pīṭhas.
One of the two kṣetras.
